column2: As far as anyone can remember in the baseball commissioner's office or at the National Broadcasting Company, there has never been a political message during a World Series broadcast. This year will be no exception.

DALLAS, Sept. 16 -- George C. Wallace said today that he wanted a running mate on his American Independent party ticket who would be like J. Edgar Hoover, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -The Johnson Administration is moving ahead with plans that could temporarily increase United States combat capability in West Germany while cutting back on administrative and support forces in Europe.

The United States Supreme Court was asked yesterday by the nation's stevedoring industry to decide whether a longshoreman injured in an accident on a pier is covered by the Federal Longshoremen and Harbor Workers Compensation Act.
More than 15,000 striking teachers and their supporters surrounded City Hall yesterday to demonstrate their support of the walkout by the United Federation of Teachers.

The presidents of parent asboard had discharged the district superintendent under pressure and threats from "extremists" after a meeting last sociations of a group of schools on the Lower Side called yesterday for the suspension of the local school board. They charged that the Tuesday.
The Board of Education and the teachers' union narrowed their differences yesterday, but there were no indications when normal school operations would be resumed.
Forces within the Democratic party that have opposed the Johnson Administration and its policies for the last year are organizing themselves as a permanent power in party politics.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 16 -- Jim Ryun arrived on schedule in the 1,500-meter run today, but Dave Patrick ran his big race one day too soon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- With the opening games out of the way, it is now clear that there are only three real contenders for the coveted title in the tough N.P.L. It is seven weeks until the super poll, but even at this early date in a lackluster season the squads with a shot at the big money can be counted on your fingers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -The White House denied today that President Johnson had decided not to sell supersonic Phantom jet fighter-bombers to Israel in the near future.
MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 16 -- To cope with the rapidly swelling ranks of graduate students and to meet research challenges from elsewhere, West German science is fleeing the cities.
AS in most current Off Broadway theater, the action in Ohrbach's fall import show yesterday took place in the aisles.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -The diplomatic social season, which is usually in full swing by now, is getting a slow, halting start this year because of nature and international affairs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- There was a "dramatic shift" in the flow of private capital between the United States and foreign countries in the first half of this year, an assistant secretary of commerce reported today.
A lawyer,, a graduate physicist and a former creative director of a large advertising agency testified yesterday that they had been duped by executive counseling companies.
Longshoremen in the Port of New York were informed by their leaders last night that because employers had not made a satisfactory contract offer, they should prepare for a strike.

MUNICH, West Germany, Sept. 16 -- A technique has been developed that enables men, through observations made from the ground by the unaided eye, to see portions of the earth's magnetic field outlined hundreds of miles overhead in glowing colored filaments.

PARIS, Sept. 16 -- Dr. Kenneth D. Kaunda, President of Zambia, broke down in tears today during an hourlong speech at a United Nations conference in which he said that human rights were being violated on an unprecedented scale.

HONG KONG, Sept. 16 -Peasant-soldier teams engaged in taking over the schools of rural Communits China have beei given a model that provides for nine years of schooling, from the first grade through high school, a reduction of three years.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 16 (AP) -- John H. Crooker Jr., chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, said today that airline route proceedings now before the board might lead to lower fares for travelers.
BONN, Sept. 16 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization began two major maneuvers today on land and sea.

A SHIPMENT of frozen dinners recently left a Brooklyn plant bound for the Hong Kong Hilton Hotel. Each dinner label was stamped with an inconspicuous circled U. The stamp was a symbol that the dinners were completely kosher.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 -- A new constitution advocating black nationalism was adopted by the Congress of Racial Equality at a reconvening of its annual convention here this weekend. Roy Innis of New York was elected national director, succeeding Floyd B. McKissick.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 15 -- The political book that has caused the greatest impact in Latin America this year is not Ernesto Che Guevara's guerrilla diary but Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber's "The American Challenge."
THE best music in New York last night could be heard in Town Hall, where Abram Loft and Armand Basile were giving the second of three concerts devoted to all the violin sonatas of Mozart.
Stock prices resumed their advance yesterday, aided by reports that indicated the expected slowdown in the economy was not developing as predicted.
Your columns have carried many letters from people, often academics, who write that they cannot take part in this election because they feel that the candidates offer no choice on Vietnam.

IT obviously will be the St. Louis Cardinals and the Detroit Tigers in the forthcoming World Series, a news item that falls somewhat short of being a stunning surprise. Yet it took 34 years for them to get round to having a rematch of their wingding of 1934, a seven-game spectacular that the rowdy Gas House Gang of St. Louis won with the flourish of an insolent 11-0 victory in the finale.

LONDON, Sept. 16 (AP) -Helicopters, troops and policemen rescued scores of Britons marooned today by the worst floods in 15 years. Two persons perished and a third was believed dead in the flood area, in southeastern England.
Cocoa futures advanced yesterday in another round of prices that rose by the daily limit, Just as they did last week.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 16 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, whose off-the-cuff denunciations of civil disorders have sometimes encouraged the impression that he was hand-picked by the South as Richard M. Nixon's running mate, has put down in writing his "definitive" views on law and order.
There are times when Bud Harrelson paws the ground at shortstop and imagines what the fans are saying in the stands at Shea Stadium.

SCHENECTADY, Sept. 16 -James L. Buckley, Conservative candidate for the United States Senate, was welcomed warmly today by workers at the General Electric Company's "Grand Canyon of industry," said to be the largest machine shop in the world.
The volume of trading on the American Stock Exchange crossed the 1-billion-share level yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -President Johnson's Cabinet Committee on Price Stability called the automobile price increase announced by the Chrysler Corporation today "manifestly excessive" and "a severe setback to the cause of price stability."
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 16 -- The former tax receiver of Yorktown was charged today with appropriating about $4,000 in town taxes in an 11-count indictment handed up in county court here.

Gulf Western Industries, Inc., confirmed yesterday that it had acquired about 1.6 million shares of Pan American World Airways, Inc., which had a market value of $38.2-million based on yesterday's final quotation of 23 7/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Wilson Burch is 23 years old and black. Seven years ago, he was a senior in high school, living in Harlem and using heroin. Yesterday, he registered as a freshman at Harvard.

The Caxton Ovid, a 15th-century manuscript of which a segment was sold two years ago for $252,000, the highest price ever paid at auction for a book, will be published here and in London today in a facsimile edition that experts consider to be a faithful reproduction.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 16 -- It must be obvious to the tycoons of professional football that their business is in trouble. The season's first games occurred on television Sunday and suddenly, after all those years during which it seemed the most exciting entertainment on television, football seemed dull, stale and old hat.
The International Paper Company informed its customers yesterday that it was planning an increase of $5 a ton in the price of newsprint, to take effect Jan. 1.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 16 (AP) -Ron Smith returned the secondhalf kickoff 94 yards for a touchdown and the Los Angeles Rams went on to beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 24-13 tonight in a National Football League game.

George Meany conceded yesterday that George C. Wallace had gained support among union members in his bid for the Presidency, but the labor leader said the A.F.L.-C.I.O. was going to fight against any swing to the third-party candidate.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 16 (AP) -- Al Salerno and William Valentine, American League umpires, were dismissed today by Joe Cronin, the league president.
The London stock market closed mixed yesterday, after an initial advance failed to persist.
MOSCOW, Sept. 16 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union withdrew from European Cup Soccer competition today in protest against a realignment of matches following Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia.

LISBON, Tuesday, Sept. 17 -- The condition of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar was described as "desperate" early this morning after he had a relapse yesterday in the hospital where he underwent brain surgery Sept. 7.

THE sixth annual New York Film Festival -- and with developments along the festival circuit this year, the New York screenings at Philharmonic Hall have suddenly become the only film festival of even minimal importance -- opened at Lincoln Center last night, fittingly enough, with a Czechoslovak movie, "Capricious Summer," by Jiri Menzel (of "Closely Watched Trains").

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A Senate subcommittee produced evidence today that a regional sales manager for a drug concern had called elderly patients "crocks and cruds" and had exhorted his men in a fashion seeming more fitted to selling groceries than powerful drugs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- A key staff member of the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated today that he would oppose, for the present at least, any plan to permit brokers who are not members of the New York Stock Exchange to do business on that exchange at fees that are less than those charged the general public.

FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Army authorities said today a soldier found hanged from a tree on this sprawling military reservation had been identified as a young officer who had been listed as absent without leave since May.
CINCINNATI, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Carol Mann drew closer this week to the money-winning championship on this year's tour of the Ladies Professional Golf Association.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -"Inefficient umpires who were never first-class at any one time," was the way Cronin described Valentine and Salerno today.

Frank D. O'Connor has turned down as "a political disgrace" a request from Vice President Humphrey's campaign workers that he resign as President of the City Council to enable the Democrats to nominate a Negro or Puerto Rican for his office and so strengthen the ticket in the city.

American Airlines' new corporate advertising campaign (featuring all the little people that help make them big) breaks Sunday on C.B.S.-TV. Half of the carrier's $20-million annual budget is going into the effort.

NEW YORK balletgoers no longer measure out their years with coffee spoons but with the ritual performances of Gerald Arpinos "Viva Vivaldi!" with which each fall the City Center Joffrey Ballet announces that it is back in town and that a new dance season has started.
The American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations took two steps yesterday aimed at assisting minorities and helping to solve urban problems.
ROME, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -Italian bishops, confronted by a flood of sex and violence in the movies, issued new guidelines yesterday on what films to see and not to see.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Bill Sudakis and Paul Popovich knocked in two runs apiece and Claude Osteen delivered three key singles as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Cincinnati Reds, 7-5, tonight.

Nytronics, Inc., a producer of electronic components, reached agreement in principle yesterday to acquire Radio Engineering Products, Ltd., of Montreal, for cash and stock valued at about $45-million.
Governor Rockefeller agreed yesterday to lend the "Guernica" tapestry to Mexico for the Olympic Games. The tapestry, a copy of "Guernica" by Picasso, depicts the tragedy of the Spanish Civil War.
LISBON, Sept. 17 -- The Council of State, Portugal's highest consultative body, met here today to consider the problem of choosing a successor to Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- John Jarboe defeated Pat Malloy today in a Democratic runoff and will oppose Representative Page Belcher, a Republican, in November in the First Congressional District.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 17 -- The painting, "Abe Lincoln's First Book," by the self-taught Negro artist. Horace Pippin, has been presented to the Museum of Art, Carnegie Institute, by Mr. and Mrs. James L. Winokur of this city.
GLADSTONE, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Headed by Mike Plumb, the team captain, five riders today were named to the United States Olympic team's threeday equestrian squad.
State financial aid to the city's public school system probably will not be affected by the teachers' strike here, a spokesman for the Board of Education said yesterday.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 17 -- Vice President Humphrey played a wide range of campaign roles before good audiences in upstate New York today, giving some of his most taut and vigorous presentations yet on the big election issues.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 17 -Richard M. Nixon said today that "a complete reappraisal" of the Federal budget was being conducted for him, with special attention to "America's commitment abroad."
Growing fears of a dock strike Oct. 1 have prompted a number of importers and exporters to ship by air.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) -Danny Cater batted in three runs with three singles to lead the Oakland Athletics to an 8-1 victory tonight after the Chicago White Sox had won the first game, 2-1, on Joe Horlen's fivehitter and Bill Melton's two-run homer.

Pan American World Airways, which first began operations at Newark Airport last February, is planning increased use of the facility long before the new airport complex is completed, the carrier reported yesterday.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 17 -- A portrait identified as a likeness of Alexander Turney Stewart, the founder of this Nassau County community, has proved something of a mystery to a committee preparing for the village's centennial celebration next year.
The snarl of paperwork crippling the back-office operations of Wall Street's brokerage houses has forced a number of major firms to curtail their business drastically.
Brandon Films, Inc., importer and distributor of movies, has been acquired by Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc., the publisher. The terms of the cash transaction were not disclosed.

A bunch of the boys were whooping it up in the bar of the Speedway Motel in Indianapolis, bad-mouthing -to use their phrase -- Andy Granatelli's turbine racer. It was the eve of last year's Indianapolis 500, and the Indy crowd resented the prospect of this new-fangled contrap tion making their piston-engine cars obsolete.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 17 -Tensions are rising sharply between angry landlords and the Government's militant young agrarian reformers in the drought-stricken Central Valley, the country's agricultural heartland.
About 40 religious institutions have made facilities available to hundreds of public school children who have been unable to attend classes because of the teachers' strike.

TULSA, Okla., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Mr. Wallace announced tonight that he had met ballot qualifications in all 50 states. He made the announcement from his hotel suite here on a long-distance telephone hookup to his Washington state convention in Seattle, where about 700 delegates signed a petition to complete the ballot requirements.

Lincoln Center's fourth series of "Great Performers at Philharmonic Hall" will open Oct. 13 with a recital by Andre Watts. Other performers in the series are Montserrat Caballe, Bruno-Leonardo Gelber, Arthur Grumiaux, Anna Moffo, Christa Ludwig and Walter Berry, Lorin Hollander, Geza Anda, Rudolf Serkin, Peter Serkin, Leontyne Price and Judy Collins.
WASHINGTON Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Charles P. Taft says that campaign "code words" with racial implications are probably the biggest concern of the Fair Campaign Practices Committee this year.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Food costs in Saigon rose more than 2 per cent in August over July, while costs were nearly 23 per cent higher than in August, 1967, the official South Vietnamese news agency reported today.

James R. Cain has been elected controller of the Fedders Corporation. He was formerly controller and assistant treasurer of the Norge division of the Borg-Warner Corporation. Norge was acquired by Fedders last July.

Wives of Asian diplomats at the United Nations attended a reception yesterday in the home of Mrs. Carl Taylor at 15 Sutton Place. The women discussed plans for "Once Upon a Wedding," a fashion show and luncheon to be held on Nov. 26 at the Pierre for the benefit of the Pan Pacific and Southeast Asia Women's Association.
Following is a summary of how the issues developed in the city's school crisis:
Nine top executives of construction companies pleaded guilty yesterday to charges that they had rigged bids on contracts with major utilities here.

A psychologist told a communications forum yesterday that the traditional American news format "is 30 to 40 years behind the times." He said it had a pervasive effect on people's feelings about themselves and the world.

YUCCA FLAT, Nev., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- A nuclear explosion of low-intermediate yield was set off underground today at the Nevada test site by the Atomic Energy Commission as part of the Plowshare program to develop peaceful uses for nuclear explosions.

The nation's 11 Circuit Courts of Appeals have approved plans for carrying out a new law designed to open jury service in Federal Courts to thousands who have never had that opportunity and to require service of many who have successfully avoided it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- President Johnson today called the automobile price increase announced yesterday by Chrysler Corporation "excessive" and a "sharp blow" to the nation's effort to fight inflation.
A ballroom full of magazine people yesterday heard Lynn Townsend, Chrsyler's top man, call for less Government regulation.

The 75th anniversary of the General Organization of the United Daughters of the Confederacy will be celebrated on Sept. 24 with a reception and a dinner at the Seventh Regiment Armory, 643 Park Avenue, at 66th Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A thief entered the home of Mayor Walter E. Washington early today and the Mayor himself chased the intruder without catching him. The amount taken was not determined immediately.

OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 17 -Six Black Panthers -- including Eldridge Cleaver -- pleaded not guilty today to attempted murder and assault charges stemming from a gun battle with policemen in West Oakland on April 6.

COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- A University of Missouri freshman basketball prospect who collapsed in a gymnasium yesterday and died apparently suffered a rare type of heart attack, an autopsy revealed today.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Karl Clement of Nassau, the defending champion, won her first-round match from Mrs. Henry Schuler of Brookville, 3 and 2; today in the Women's Cross-County Golf Association match-play championship.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Six inmates, four of them Federal prisoners in transit, attempted to break out of the Lycoming County Prison today but the escape failed when a sheriff stared down one armed with a knife and city policemen flocked into the jail.
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) -Zvonimir Petrecevic, a star on the Yugoslav national basketball team, began working out with the Chicago Bulls today.
Federal Judge Walter Mansfield denied yesterday motions for a new trial or acquittal made by three members of Lybrand, Ross Bros. Montgomery, a leading accounting firm.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today, 11 to 6, President Johnson's nomination of Justice Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States.
The election of Louis L. Rosenberg as a trustee of the Lincoln Savings Bank, was announced yesterday by Michael J. Burke, president.

You don't have to be Mexican to love Tony Aguilar and his national Mexican Festival and Rodeo, but it helps to have seen one or two of his 100 or so Mexican films (like "La Cucaracha" with Dolores del Rio), to understand a bit of Spanish, and to take some youngsters who like cowboys and horses with you.

TRENTON, Sept. 17 -- State Attorney General Arthur J. Sills, visibly trembling with rage, told a legislative hearing here this evening that he would ask Gov. Richard J. Hughes to authorize a special grand jury investigation of organized crime and official corruption in New Jersey.

Higher costs were blamed yesterday by Alexander H. Cohen, producer of "Dear World," starring Angela Lansbury, for the second increase in posted ticket prices before the musical opens Dec. 26 at the Mark Hellinger Theater.

PRAGUE, Sept. 17 -- The Presidium of the Czechoslovak Communist party announced tonight that it was preparing for "further two-way political negotiations in the near future." This came amid reports that the party's First Secretary, Alexander Dubcek, might fly to Moscow late in the week.

Traffic accidents in the United States brought economic losses of $7.67-billion in the first seven months of 1968, the Insurance Information Institute has calculated, up $759-million from the corresponding period last year.

YONKERS, Sept. 17 -- Going into today's action at Delaware, Ohio, and tonight's events at Yonkers Raceway, trotters and pacers driven by Stanley Dancer and Bill Haughton this season had earned totals of $1,040,003 and $972,088, respectively.

GENEVA, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The International Committee of the Red Cross announced today that it resumed its mercy flights into Biafra last night, carrying 65 tons of relief supplies after a two-day halt due to the "general situation."
BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 17 -- A significant and vocal opposition to the Government has grown up here in the three months since the promulgation of the country's new Constitution.

BONN, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany said today in an interview that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization must be strengthened militarily and politically because of the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
THE American Contract Bridge League recently promulgated a long-overdue relaxation of its restrictions on weak two-bids.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- If there was anybody around who doubted the effects of 7,377 feet of altitude on a distance runner, all he had to do was look at Jim Ryun at 3:34 P.M. yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- The Detroit Tigers won their first American League pennant in 23 years tonight by defeating the New York Yankees, 2-1.
HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -Gov. Ronald Reagan of California will speak at a Nixon for President dinner Oct. 9 in Houston.
The American Enka Corporation realized an 83 per cent increase in earnings for the 36 weeks ended Sept. 8 on a sales gain of 30 per cent, the textile producer reported yesterday.

All five floors of the Wildenstein Gallery, 19 East 64th Street, will be open for the first time on the evening of Oct. 9 to show supporters of the Arthritis Foundation the gallery's permanent collection of paintings, sculpture, drawings and fine furniture.

HARTFORD, Sept. 17 -- Don Miller, Trinity College's dedicated young football coach, worked a small miracle last season, his first as head man. He directed the Bantams to a 6-1-1 won-lost-tied record, missing a perfect season by 3 points.

TORONTO, Sept. 17 -- Nino Benvenuti, the heavy in a comedy of errors that led to a triple-header boxing show tonight at Maple Leaf Gardens, worked his way back into the hearts of Toronto's Italian population with a unanimous decision over Art Hernandez of Omaha in a 10-round nontitle bout.

A small group of educators have worked quietly during the first tumultuous year of self-government in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville experimental school district to develop a curriculum emphasizing Afro-American and Puerto Rican history and culture.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, a unit of McDonnell Douglas Corporation, announced yesterday in Long Beach, Calif., that the LTV Aerospace Corporation's Vought Aeronautics division had been chosen to make the horizontal stabilizers and elevators for the McDonnell Douglas DC-10 tri-jet transports.

FORT WORTH, Sept. 17 -Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland told Texas Republicans today that the Vietnam conflict was "the most politically mismanaged war" in the nation's history and promised that the first priority of a Nixon-Agnew Administration would be to end the war "quickly and honorably."
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Justice Department said today it had filed a civil antitrust suit to block the merger of two banks in Pennsylvania's Schuylkill County.

Plume Atwood Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that Henry L. Shepherd, chairman, had resigned for reasons of health. Concurrently, the company said that Edward Suisman and his son, John, had resigned as directors.

HOUSTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -Mike Cuellar checked Atlanta on six hits tonight and singles by Jim Wynn and Rusty Staub touched off a four-run fourthinning rally that helped Houston gain a 5-1 victory over the Braves.

A group of about 75 welfare recipients rampaged through three Brooklyn welfare centers yesterday, overturning furniture and barring about 600 caseworkers from the centers. The protesters, mostly women, ripped telephones from walls, scattered papers and three desks onto piles in the middle of the intake rooms of the three centers, which are in the same building in downtown Brooklyn.

UPPER MARLBORO, Md., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Kathy Kusner, 27-year-old Olympic rider who wants to be the nation's first woman major-track jockey, has asked the courts to overrule her rejection by the Maryland State Racing Commission.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Frank Howard snapped a tie with a two-run double to the opposite field in the eighth inning tonight to give the Washington Senators a 4-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said here yesterday that Richard M. Nixon was trying "to tiptoe through the tulips" to avoid a stand on major campaign issues.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept 17 (UPI) -- A field of 17 entries, the largest since 1961, was named today to compete for a record $104,226 purse in the 23d annual Little Brown Jug for 3-year-old pacers Thursday.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 17 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells shot a 36, 40 -- 76 today to take the opening-round lead in the eighth Garden State Women's Golf Association strokeplay championship at the Springdale Golf Club.

Ten of the nation's major college athletic conferences will send representatives to the 19th annual basketball officiating clinic for rules interpretation Sunday and Monday at the New York Athletic Club.
STOCKHOLM, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Social Democratic Government announced plans today to exert control over more of Sweden's private enterprise.
The Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, announced plans late yesterday to reorganize as a one-bank holding company whose first investment would be in shares of the bank itself.

State Education Commissioner James E. Allen's formula for a settlement of the intolerable school shutdown is in danger of being wrecked by a cross fire of mutual distrust and misunderstandings. Against a background of grievous errors committed by all parties involved in the controversy that has led to the current crisis, the positions have hardened to an extent that makes a peaceful and rational resolution steadily more elusive.

CLINTON, N. Y., Sept. 17 -- "For a girl to have picked Kirkland is like choosing a husband from a written description," Dr. Millicent C. McIntosh told the 175 girls who had enrolled in the first class at Kirkland when it was still only a dream.
BOSTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -Four seasoned Democratic Congressmen, including two with close Kennedy family ties, were renominated in the Massachusetts primary tonight.

CHICAGO, Sept. 17 -- Adlai E. Stevenson 3d, the state Treasurer, issued a strongly worded challenge today to the old order in Illinois Democratic politics, which is represented by Mayor Richard J. Daley.

TOKYO, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Japan's vehicle output in August fell 55 per cent to 326,979 units, the Japan Automobile Industry Association announced today. Of these, 156,814 were passenger cars, 167,589 trucks and 2,576 buses.
MILO BAUGHMAN calls his new furniture collection "Environment 70." He could have called it "Instant Decorating."

SEVERAL hours before the show began, the women who had paid $25 a person for their tickets knew that the weather wasn't going to cooperate. The sun was bright, the thermometer was climbing and it was almost too much to bear.
"What we have done thus far is to test a series of pilot projects before making them bigger, and we have found that they do work."
CHICAGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) -Abbie Hoffman, a leader of the protesters who demonstrated here during the Democratic National Convention, was arrested twice today.

IN the 1964 Olympic Games at Tokyo the United States scored smashing successes in track and field, winning 12 of 24 events. There is no reason to suppose that the victory total at Mexico City next month will show much slackening, if any.

The United States Smelting, Refining and Mining Company purchase 30,700 common shares of the Clevite Corporation in August, increasing its holdings to 358,322 shares, according to papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Gaylord Perry of the San Francisco Giants pitched a nohitter tonight, yielding only walks in the second and eighth innings as he beat Bob Gibson and the St. Louis Cardinals, 1-0.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- District Attorney Arlen Specter reported today a "giant increase" in deaths caused by overdoses of narcotics. He said a report by Dr. Joseph Spelman, city Medical Examiner, showed that 40 deaths in this year's first six months were due to overdoses, compared with 29 in all of 1967.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 17 -When Robert L. Sprinkel 3d and Richard E. Boesel Jr. were weighing the question of whether a mutual fund could be run as a competition among money managers, they had to dispose of a bit of stock market folklore.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 17 -- The largest gathering of Communist parties since the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia almost a month ago is scheduled for Budapest early next week.

The Sun Oil Company announced yesterday that it had deferred its usual stock dividend due to current merger negotiations with the Sunray DX Oil Company. The proposed merger will be taken up at the company's board meeting in October.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

The last-ditch effort to persuade the Board of Estimate to grant immediate priority to extension of the projected Second Avenue subway from Thirty-fourth Street south to the tip of Manhattan Island ought not delay approval of the $1.27-billion plan now before the Board.
ALGIERS, Sept. 17 -- The fifth leaders' meeting of the organization of American Unity ended here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Housing starts in August remained at an annual rate of more than 1.5 million units for the second straight month, the Census Bureau reported today.

MATT SNELL made two decisions yesterday. The fullback of the New York Jets chose the option route with regard to his contractual arrangements and he also chose to keep on playing. Snell and Weeb Ewbank, the coachgeneral manager who likes to keep the salaries "in line," as he puts it, failed yesterday to reach an agreement regarding a new pact.
NHATRANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 17 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu warned today against individual "peace solutions" that may go against Government policy.

SEATTLE, Sept. 17 (AP) -Gov. Dan Evans, a Republican, easily won nomination today for a second term, and City Councilman Art Fletcher was leading for the Republican nomination for Lieutenant Governor in Washington's primary.
Shareholders of Gulf Oil Corporation at a special meeting in Pittsburgh yesterday approved the previously announced two-for-one stock split, which becomes effective today.

DALLAS, Sept. 17 -- George C. Wallace roused himself from a new attack of illness today to accept the Presidential nomination of the American party of Texas. The party convention and nomi nating procedure was a technicality necessary to place Mr. Wallace's name on the election ballot in Texas.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board's proposed new lending policies were described by disagreeing expert witnesses today both as "a step in the right direction" and as "a major step backward."

BERLIN, Sept. 17 -- Foreign Minister Willy Brandt of West Germany said today that the West must undertake "a reevaluation in the field of military security in Europe" since Soviet action against Czechoslovakia had "caused a breakdown in international confidence."

Jack Palance will portray Fidel Castro in "Che," the forthcoming movie based on the life of the late Ernest Guevara. The 20th Century-Fox production will go before the cameras next week. Omar Sharif has been cast in the title role of the late Cuban Minister of Finance who was killed in Bolivia last October.

HARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 17 -Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Allison Choate, Rye, N. Y., carded 37, 36 -- 73 on the 5,655-yard, par 36, 36 -- 72 South course at Westchester Country Club today and won the best-ball event of the 45th annual United States Senior Women's Golf Association tournament.

ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 17 (AP) -- President Johnson attended funeral services in the colonial red-brick chapel of Arlington National Cemetery today for Maj. Gen. Keith L. Ware, who was killed Friday in a helicopter crash while directing his First Infantry Division troops in battle against the North Vietnamese.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. William C. Chip, of the United States Marine Corps, suffered a spine fracture today in the crash of a helicopter on a combat mission.
ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- Former Gov. George C. Wallace's Courage party petitions have been upheld by Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo.
The Bay Ridge Savings Bank, Brooklyn, has received from the New York State Banking Department authorization to change its name to the Anchor Savings Bank on Oct. 1.

The Czechoslovak film industry is continuing to operate as it has since last April, without censorship, Jiri Menzel, whose "Capricious Summer" opened the New York Film Festival last night, reported here yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Ryan Aeronautical Corporation said today that more than one financial group had discussed making a tender offer for Ryan shares at prices above the current market. The company, which declined to identify the groups, said it had no assurance that any of the present discussions would lead to an actual tender offer.

SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 17 -- "American athletes are really quite remarkable," Payton Jordan, coach of the United States mens track team, said. "Just when they seem hopelessly beaten, they find that extra something that carries them over the hump."

The World Bank's $250million bond issue was priced yesterday to give investors a yield of 6.435 per cent, somewhat higher than other triple-A bonds sold earlier this month but below the rate the institution had to pay in March, when it made the costliest long-term borrowing in the United States in its 22-year history.

If shipping raw logs out of the country reduces the domestic lumber supply and raises prices, shouldn't the Government protect the consumers by restricting such exports? That proposition, advanced in a letter on this page by Senators Morse and Hatfield of Oregon, has a simplistic appeal. But carried to its logical conclusion, it would result in the cessation of all trade between nations.
Newsprint producers showed a marked reluctance yesterday to go along with a $5a-ton price increase planned for Jan. 1 by the International Paper Company.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 -- Israeli long-range artillery shelled Irbid, Jordan's second largest city, this morning in response to what military sources described as a new and dangerous intensification of warfare by Arab terrorists.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -Paul O'Dwyer got to the Senate today -- or at least as far as the Senate dining room -- and won some financial support from the national party group seeking to elect Democratic Senators this fall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The United States warned the Soviet Union and its Warsaw Pact allies today that unilateral intervention by force in West Germany would lead to an "immediate allied response" under the North Atlantic Treaty.

ALTAMONTE SPRINGS, Fla., Sept. 17 (AP) -- A young Negro was taken for a terror ride and "beaten to an unrecognizable pulp" by a group of whites who mistakenly believed he had had sexual relations with a white teen-age girl, authorities said today.

Louis Armstrong was taken to a hospital yesterday for tests after his legs swelled, forcing him to cancel an engagement. His agent, Joe Glaser, said that Mr. Armstrong's doctor believes the trouble may be phlebitis. Mr. Glaser said the 68-year-old trumpeter and his band were to have appeared at the Eastern States Exposition in West Springfield, Mass.

The National Cash Register Company announced yesterday that it had received about 95.2 per cent of the outstanding stock of Electronic Communications, Inc., through its recent tender offer. The office-equipment concern had offered to exchange one share of its common stock for each two shares of Electronic Communications common stock. N.C.R. said it would continue to accept tenders for a limited period but did not specify a deadline.
The problems facing Bob Hicks, entering his seventh season as head football coach at Wagner College, are types with which more harried coaches would not mind dealing.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- Ambassadors of members of the North Atlantic alliance today discussed the political and military consequences of the invasion of Czechoslovakia at a special session here.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 17 -Gene Alley hit his third home run of the season tonight to pace the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies and snap an eightgame winning streak by Chris Short.

LONDON, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -Hundreds of rescuers using rowboats and landing craft today aided thousands of Britons stranded by the worst floods in 15 years as a day of torrential rain wrecked hopes of receding waters.

Two Negro leaders from opposite ends of the state told the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime yesterday that the Black Panthers and other extremists represented only a small fraction of the black community.

Most cocoa futures contracts rose the daily limit of 100 points, or one cent a pound, again yesterday, and all deliveries made new life-of-contract highs. At the end of trading, orders for about 750 contracts remained unsatisfied.

Leaders of the security industry will meet tomorrow to assess the back-office situation and to discuss whether a fourday trading week should be retained in October. One Wall Street official said yesterday it remained "a toss-up" on any decision to return to regular trading hours.
A three-building complex for offices, research, personnel training and computer use will be built by Uniroyal, Inc., on a rolling 1,500-acre site in Middlebury, Conn.

Nina Foch, the actress, once wrote that a performer feels far more sharply than an author or playwright the pain of adverse criticism. For an author or playwright, she said, his work is rejected. For a performer, it is himself.

NEWARK, Sept. 17 (AP) -- A Penn Central employe was shot and killed today during an apparent holdup. The police said Michael Tomasulo, 60 years old, employed by the railroad for 42 years, was found face down on the Haynes Avenue bridge with bullet wounds in the arm, abdomen and left side. The police said he had just cashed his paycheck and one belonging to a friend.
TROY, N.Y. Sept. 17 -- James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate, is a man who laughs easily and whose appearance is relaxed and unworried.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 17 (AP)A team led by Ed Kroll of Cooperstown, a proposted a best-ball score of 53 today to win the professional and amateur section of the $30,000 New York State Professional Golfers' Association championship at the Saratoga Spa Golf Course.

Albert Christ-Janer, dean of the Pratt Institute's School of Art and Design and professor of art for the last 10 years, has been appointed director of the school's Center for Contemporary Printmaking, 831 Broadway, and the newly-acquired Pratt Institute Manhattan Center, 46 Park Avenue.

BOSTON, Sept. 17 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy will make his first campaign appearance with Vice President Humphrey Thursday in Boston. He will introduce the Democratic Presidential nominee at a noon rally in the downtown shopping district.

Even enthusiastic supporters of school decentralization are saying privately that the battle between the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district and the United Federation of Teachers will create a backlash that is certain to slow decentralization.

LONDON, Sept. 17 -- On weekday mornings at 10 A.M. -- and often Saturdays as well -- a lanky 65-year-old man in an over-sized tweed suit strolls down the platform at Dulwich Station to commute to his office on London's seedy Soho Square.
PRAGUE, Sept. 17 -- The Council of Mutual Economic Assistance, for two decades an apparatus of Soviet economic power, has been shaken by the growing spirit of independence in Eastern Europe.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The second wrongful death suit in 10 days was filed in Mahoning County Common Pleas Court today against Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard and the Youngstown Osteopathic Hospital.
BUFFALO, Sept. 17 -- Vice President Humphrey did his thing on Vietnam today.
Landlords here pressed their attack against rent controls yesterday with a demand at a legislative hearing that the state force New York City to take controlled apartment buildings off their hands.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Gov. Ronald Reagan and Assembly Speaker Jesse M. Unruh both denounced today the University of California's invitation to Eldridge Cleaver to lecture on racism at the Berkeley campus.
A bersek college student fired about 100 shots from three rifles and a shotgun at policemen in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn early yesterday, but no one was injured, according to the police.

JODRELL BANK, England, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Observers at Jodrell Bank reported today that the Soviet Union's Zond 5 spacecraft had passed the moon within about 1,000 miles and was believed to be on its way back to earth.

JERSEY CITY, Sept. 17 -Mayor Thomas J. Whelan announced today that he planned to run for re-election next May. He acted after former Mayor John V. Kenny, the Hudson County Democratic party leader, said Mr. Whelan would have the support of the party organization.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- The Senate, with liberals joining conservatives, voted today to require imprisonment up to life for any person using a firearm in a violent Federal crime, from Presidential assassination to theft.

ALBANY, Sept. 17 -- The State Teachers Association said today it would propose amending the Taylor Law, which bars strikes by public employes, to add a new step for resolving impasses in negotiations.
News of an improvement in the British trade balance in August sent leading industrial shares to new highs on the London stock market yesterday.
The election of Joseph E. Lonning as president of the Kellogg Company, Battle Creek, Mich., was announced yesterday. He will be chief operating officer of the cereal company.

Obsessed with the idea of catching base runners between first and second, the Chicago Cubs let two others score in the process last night and gave the New York Mets a 3-2 victory before 9,117, the smallest night-game crowd of the season at Shea Stadium.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 17 -- At the end of four days of highlevel foreign-policy discussions here, India and the Soviet Union "reaffirmed the similarity and closeness" of their view on international questions today.

Members of the committee planning the Convocation Dinner for the 83d birthday of Harry Hershfield, the toastmaster and raconteur, attended a reception last night in the home of Mrs. Ronald Tree at 123 East 79th Street.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- Umpires Al Salerno and Bill Valentine, dismissed by Joe Cronin, the American League president, said today they would petition Commissioner William Eckert for reinstatement and permission to organize an umpires' union without fear of repercussion.

THE long-awaited debut of Diahann Carroll in "Julia," the first regularly scheduled series about a Negro woman -- a supremely attractive one -- took place last night on the National Broadcasting Company.
Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, the acting president of Columbia University, has made it clear to radical students that he is prepared to listen to proposals for change at the university but not to demands.

Somebody poured soap suds into the Lincoln Center Plaza fountain, turning it into a beautiful still-life that seemed to be made of Styrofoam, A shaggy, anonymous man railed against Lincoln Center's "false reality," while a young woman distributed "Prison Poems" by Ho Chi Minh.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rescued the nuclear nonproliferation treaty from possible oblivion today.
WASHINGTON, Sept 17 (AP) -- The Senate approved by voice vote and sent to President Johnson today a bill authorizing $23-million for preschool and early education services for handicapped children.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The Turkish high court today banned translations of Ernesto Che Guevara's diaries. The court said that dissemination of Communist propaganda was illegal.
Time erases all, it seems, except the Judy Bond labor dispute.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -President Johnson said with emphasis today that he is for Hubert Humphrey.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 17 -A 23-year-old American volunteer mission teacher, Roxane McCauley, has been ordered out of Zambia. She said the reason was that she had defended her country against criticism by a Zambian minister.

WARSAW, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- A new Polish movie, criticized because it stars the wife of an "anti-Polish" American journalist, has been shown in Moscow to a select audience of Soviet filmmakers, actors, critics and ministry officials.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie underscored for labor leaders, senior citizens and police chiefs here yesterday that the 1968 election held far greater import for them than an "emotional outlet."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Government's high-speed passenger train project between Washington and New York is in serious trouble because of equipment problems, Senator Gordon Allott, Republican of Colorado, said today.

The administrator of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district defied an order yesterday from the city's Superintendent of Schools and refused to take back 100 union teachers who have come under fire from community forces.

The Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York announced yesterday that it wrote a record $95,352,000 of new business in the eight months ended Aug. 31. This compared with $86,232,000 in new business written in the period last year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- House Republicans rallied under the Nixon banner tonight to pave the way for a one-year extension of major farm programs and block a proposed $20,000 ceiling on annual Federal payments to individual farms.

The Carpenter Steel Company said yesterday that its previously announced merger plan with the Electronic Specialty Company may not be feasible" in view of an announcement by the International Controls Corporation that it had received tenders for more than 50 per cent of the shares of Electronic Specialty.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The San Diego Toros clinched the Western Conference title of North American Soccer League with a 1-0 victory over the Kansas City Spurs in a defensive contest last night. The goal came at the midpoint of the second overtime period.

CAIRO, Sept. 17 -- A student delegate created an uproar in the national congress of the Arab Socialist Union today by saying that he had been approached to organize student demonstrations and disorders as a prelude to a coup d'etat.

WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 17 -- Mrs. Mary Coe Bartol of Stanwich and Mrs. Harry M. Day of Woodway, tied for the firstround lead in the 39th annual women's open golf championship of Fairfield and Westchester Counties by scoring 83's at Metropolis Country Club today.
The stock market continued to push upward in active trading yesterday.

Long regarded as among the world's most beautiful rivers, the Connecticut meanders 400 miles from the Canadian border to Long Island Sound through the mountains and plains, fields, forests and marshes of four New England states. But this scenic setting -- like that of many other once-beautiful New England rivers, such as the Housatonic -- is increasingly threatened by encroaching industrial and residential growth.
PARIS, Sept. 17 (Reuters) -- The police tonight evicted rebel students from the occupied Paris School of Fine Arts as incidents flared in two other university buildings.
Capt. Ivar Gronbukt, senior master of the Norwegian America Line and in command of its 24,000-ton flagship Sagafjord, sailed into retirement yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 17 -- At least two allied units suffered heavy losses in the last 24 hours as sharp fighting broke out near the demilitarized zone and in a rural area just south of Danang.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- A hushed crowd of more than 2,000 film buffs and movie critics crowded into Royal Festival Hall last night for a performance unique in British cinema.

Ralph Ginzburg, the publisher, has moved to set aside the $75,000 libel judgment obtained against him and Fact Magazine in May by Barry Goldwater. The publisher is using remarks attributed to General Eisenhower in a new book as the basis of his action.
Prices were mixed and slightly higher in heavy trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
LONDON, Sept. 17 -- Britain's precarious world trade position gained a surprise shot in the arm today with a report from the Board of Trade that exports soared to a new high during August.

NORMALLY, Puccini's "Turandot" at the Metropolitan Opera has Birgit Nilsson and Franco Corelli as the two leading singers. But Mr. Corelli was otherwise occupied at the opening on Monday night, and therefore last night saw Sandor Konya in the role of Calaf. Miss Nilsson, of course, sang the title role.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 17 (AP) -- The Legislature sent to Gov. Ronald Reagan today a bill designed to prevent the commercialization of photographs taken during the autopsy on Senator Robert F. Kennedy.

The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, has reacted coolly to a proposal by the presiding judge of the archdiocesan marriage tribunal that Catholics in "intolerable" marriages be permitted to decide for themselves whether they are morally free to remarry.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 17 -- Richard M. Nixon said today he had received reports of collusion between the forces of Vice President Humphrey and George C. Wallace, the third-party candidate, to block a Nixon victory in the South.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday it had received an order from the Budd Company for the propulsion and automatic speed regulation systems for 350 electric commuter cars for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority of New York.

"It seems pretty tranquil right now," said Robert Casillo as he glanced at a bulletin board in front of Hamilton Hall, Columbia University's main undergraduate building. "I thought there'd be more agitation on campus."

Dick Tiger, the old warrior, who left the war in Biafra three weeks ago to return to the United States to start a comeback, was signed yesterday to meet Frank DePaula in a 10-round light-heavyweight bout Oct. 25 at Madison Square Garden.
BONN, Sept. 17 -- East Germany has disclosed plans to extend compulsory military training to cover virtually the entire population.

DETROIT, Sept. 17 -- For the last week, the Detroit Tigers have prowled about the only clubhouse in the land with green carpeting, an air of expectancy, a 30game winner and a 12-foot banner that reads: "Sock it to 'em Tigers."
An increase of 50 per cent in Social Security benefits, with minimum payments of $100 a month, was urged here yesterday by Wilbur J. Cohen, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

VERSAILLES, Ky., Sept. 16 -- A. B. (Happy) Chandler, who almost ran for Vice President with George C. Wallace, does not know for sure why he was vetoed at the last minute. He believes the decision was not made by Mr. Wallace but by hidden financial backers, probably Southwest oil interests who thought the Chandler integration record would hurt.
OSAKA, Japan, Sept. 17 (AP) -- The International Swimming Federation announced today approval of 44 world records and one record-tying performance, a majority of them by Americans.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 17 (AP) -- Gov. Roberto Sanchez Vilella announced today that his wife had given birth to a boy at San Jorge Hospital in Santurce. The Governor said the boy will be named Roberto Jose.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 17 -- Third-quarter gains in sales and earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., should not "differ substantially" from the gains recorded in the second quarter of 1968, the company said here today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Another meeting with North Korean officials at Panmunjom has brought no breakthrough on the release of the crew of the Pueblo, the State Department said today.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 17 -- The Israeli authorities today released the first five Arab prisoners of the 16 they promised to set free as a "humanitarian gesture" in response to Algeria's return of a hijacked El Al airliner.

ATLANTA, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Georgia supporters of Vice President Humphrey announced today the opening of their state headquarters and promised a vigorous campaign on behalf of the Democratic Presidential nominee.

HONG KONG, (AP) -- Explosions and fire fed by 1,300 drums of diesel fuel blew out the sides of the 5,000-ton freighter Cerberus, being broken up for scrap today, killing at least five workmen and injuring about 20.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 17 (UPI) -The St. Louis Cardinals, having won the National League penant, issued ways and means of ordering World Series tickets today. But following the routine they won't gurantee seats in Busch Stadium.

ROCKLAND, Me., Sept. 17 -John H. Reed, a member of the National Transportation Safety Board, warned here today that train accidents in recent years had shown "a progressively worsening trend in rates, occurrences, deaths and damage."
MOSCOW, Sept. 17 (UPI) -The Soviet Union today announced a new trade agreement with Bulgaria that will help ease the Bulgarian labor surplus and solidify Moscow's East European economic bloc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 (AP) -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark and J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, will be among the first witnesses when the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence begins its hearings tomorrow.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 17 (UPI) -- George Cusimano booted home four winners at Atlantic City today but Chuck Baltazar got the big one aboard Back in Paris in the featured $6,000 allowance race.

Prices on the London Stock market eased somewhat yesterday from the high levels reached the previous day.

DURBAN, South Africa, Sept. 18 -- Many observers here had believed that Basil D'Oliviera, who is now a British citizen, would have been allowed to play with the English team on its South African tour because of the relaxation of apartheid in sport announced last year by Prime Minister Vorster.

JACOBY transfer bids, introduced by Oswald Jacoby more than a decade ago, are popular nowadays with many experts, particularly those of the younger school. Using this idea, a response of two diamonds to one notrump implies a five-card heart suit, and two hearts implies a five-card spade suit.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -The commission appointed by President Johnson to explore the causes of violence held its first hearings today and got sharply divergent views from the President's two top law enforcement officers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle disciplined at least eight priests today for persisting in their dissent from Pope Paul VI's encyclical on birth control.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -- House Republican leaders, who have more than $2-million in campaign funds at their disposal, are putting special emphasis on winning seats in 10 to 15 marginal states to assure victory for Richard M. Nixon in the event the Presidential election goes to the House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -The Soviet Union has asked that nuclear disarmament talks be held in Geneva at the end of this month, but the United States is delaying a reply.
LONDON, Sept. 18 -- The Defense Ministry raised salaries in the British armed forces by an average of 7 per cent today as part of a campaign to spur recruitment.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 (AP) -- Senate and House conferees agreed today on legislation to establish a national system of wild and scenic rivers.

Two banks and two investment companies have acquired the 100,000 shares of Downe Communications, Inc., that the Curtis Publishing Company received last month in exchange for the Ladies' Home Journal and American Home magazine.

Columbia University alumni here and throughout the country have been invited to listen to a report by Columbia trustees and administrators on the university's plans for the coming year at a closed-circuit telecast next Wednesday.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 18 -- George C. Wallace taunted Richard M. Nixon tonight to debate him and Vice President Humphrey.
SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 18 -- William McChesney Martin Jr. said here today that unless the economy slowed further the Federal Reserve might be forced to reimpose tightmoney measures.

The president of Brooklyn College said yesterday that he could take no action to drop criminal trespass charges l against 35 students arrested last May after they had occupied the college registrar's office.

The city's Board of Education was accused in Brooklyn Federal Court yesterday of discriminating against white students in violation of the 14th Amendment by forcing children to be bused "on basis of race or color" to schools of a different neighborhood.

Three judges of Rhodesia's highest court have acted to remove Britain's last legal curbs on Prime Minister Ian Smith's white rebel regime -- and to clear the way for the execution of its African opponents. Chief Justice Sir Hugh Beadle and two colleagues have ruled that the regime is the only legal Government and its 1965 Constitution the only valid Constitution.

LAST night's major television premiere, "The Outsider," was an example of getting maximum mileage from a minimum of fuel. Stephen Smith, the leader of the Kennedy forces in the state, has spurned a request to play a major role in the Presidential campaign of Vice President Humphrey.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18 -The Government's top economist said today that he still expects a slowdown in the economy this year even though there are few signs yet that the tax increase is actually working to produce such a slowdown.

The beginnings of slow -very slow -- improvement in United States business abroad seem probable in coming months, but prospects for a return to the free-striding gains of recent years are remote.

The tax-exempt bond market burst into life yesterday as investors, led by commercial banks, snapped up the heavy volume of new issues offered for sale. MADRID, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Juan Rodriguez Grille, Spain's first heart transplant patient, died today of kidney complications. WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Armed robbery and assaults with firearms in the first half of this year led a 21 per cent rise in all crime categories over the corresponding months of 1967, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today.
