Sol G. Atlas, New York realty developer, said yesterday that he would take immediate legal action to stop the impending sale of three United States investment properties of Dollar Land Holdings, Ltd., of London, to a New York investment group.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to the White House today a compromise bill establishing a nationwide system of recreational and scenic trails.

ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Peace Corps director, Jack Hood Vaughn, presented a $10,600 check from contributions made by Peace Corps members throughout the world to the Martin Luther King Memorial Scholarship Fund here today.
RENO, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Big Jay Silvester smashed his own pending world mark yesterday when he threw the discus 224 feet 5 inches during a meet at the University of Nevada.
Prices on the London stock market rose to new highs yesterday under the double spur of good company reports and the half-point cut in the British bank rate to 7 per cent.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 -- World wheat exporting nations tonight announced steps they would take to try to prevent the International Grains Arrangement from collapsing after only three months' operation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Alan Barnes, an Australian cricket official, said today the Australians would consider a suggested round-robin series among Australia, the West Indies and England this season, but he said there were "real practical reasons" against the plan.
Following is a summary of how the issues developed in the city's school crisis:

WARSAW, Sept. 19 -- The state-controlled Polish press informed its readers today for the first time that Western nations had canceled cultural and other exchanges in retaliation for Poland's participation in the occupation of Czechoslovakia.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York called tonight for prompt United Nations action on the threat of invasion made by the Soviet Union against West Germany. He said the Soviet Union was posing one of the greatest dangers to global peace since World War II.

A DECLARER who is faced with a decision in the endgame can sometimes solve the problem by mentally reconstructing a possible hand for one defender and then looking for a credibility gap. Does that player's bidding and play fit the reconstructed hand all along the line?

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Sept. 19 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers' Association rejected a new proposal offered by its feuding touring pros today. The proposal called for a 14-man executive committee to oversee the United States tour.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum previewed its "Mastercraftsmen of Peru" exhibition last night after a formal dinner in a tangle of palm trees, grape vines, oleanders and ferns. By the time the 100 guests arrived, the laughing thrushes were back in their cages and a blue parakeet was on the loose.
MOSCOW, Sept. 19 -- The Soviet Union today reasserted its right to act against West Germany if it deemed such intervention necessary.

Lee Sherman has been appointed president of Aquatogs, Ltd., a subsidiary of Originala, Inc. Mr. Sherman was most recently president of Sherman Brothers, Inc., and has been in the rainwear business for 21 years.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Bill Collins of Purchase, N. Y., shot his second straight sub-par round today, when he posted a 69, to retain a three-stroke lead after the second round of the $30,000 New York State Professional Golfer's Association championship.
Four workmen hitched their scaffolds to the sky this week and painted it white.
Prices advanced in strong and active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- Mickey Mantle and Denny McLain shook some baseball records out of the cool gray sky here this afternoon as the Detroit Tigers defeated the New York Yankees, 6-2.

Theodore Karagheuzoff, deputy commissioner and chief engineer of the city's Traffic Department under Commissioner Henry A. Barnes since 1963, was named yesterday as Acting Commissioner. Mr. Barnes died Monday.

TOKYO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- The first use of a nuclear reactor by Japanese doctors to treat a woman suffering from a cancerous brain tumor was described as a "complete success" today by the neurosurgery department of Tokyo University.

OLD WESTBURY, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Tom Seaver of the Mets outpitched his teammate, Nolan Ryan, in the fifth annual New York Press Photographers Association golf tournament at Old Westbury Golf and Country Club today. Seaver carded an 81 to Ryan's 113.
WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 19 -- Life on the horse show circuit has not been easy for Sans Marque since he won the championship at the Boulder Brook show in Scarsdale, N, Y., on April 21.
The Federal National Mortgage Association sold $250-million of debentures yesterday to finance its transformation from a partially owned Government institution to a privately owned corporation.
Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, has told members of the Board of Estimate that he would accept their proposals for additional subway routes.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Fred Stolle of Australia defeated Andres Gimeno of Spain, 6-3, 16-18, 6-1, today in the quarter-finals of the $30,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament.
The Judicial Conference of the United States adopted yesterday recommendations designed to ameliorate the abrasive clash of two constitutional rights -- free press and fair trial.
BONN, Sept. 19 -- The West German Government has been calmed by Western allied warnings against any Soviet military intervention.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 -- Three top officials elected recently to head the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots were sworn in here today at a meeting of the union's international executive committee at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.

Although President Johnson signed the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1968 into law before Congress recessed for the nominating conventions, calling it "the most far-sighted, most comprehensive, most massive housing program in all of American history," it is still but a half-built law that needs additional Executive and Congressional action in the days before final adjournment.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 19 (AP) -- "I'm not getting my hopes up," Dave Patrick said today of his coach's efforts to have him named to the United States Olympic track team.
The General Electric Company announced yesterday the election of Philip D. Moore as a vice president and head of a new employe relations component, effective Oct. 1.

NUREMBERG, West Germany, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The annual West German jurists conference called today for a whole series of moral offenses to be deleted from the penal code -- including indecent exposure in public and "offensive" advertising of birth control methods.
Following are excerpts from a nationwide radio speech yesterday by former Vice President Richard M. Nixon on his conception of the office of President:

JERUSALEM, Sept. 19 -- Six Israeli soldiers of a patrol -one a lieutenant colonel -- were killed and four were wounded today in a brief but violent skirmish with five Al Fatah guerrillas. The guerilla band was later wiped out by the Israeli patrol.

More than 900 theatergoers rushed choking, coughing and crying from a Broadway theater last night when three acrid smoke bombs went off during the opening minutes of a preview performance of Jack Gelber's play, "The Cuban Thing."

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19 -- Two advanced research and development facilities for testing future vertical or short takeoff-and-landing (V/STOL) aircraft were dedicated today in ceremonies at the Boeing Company's Vertol Division.
The National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame will present an annual trophy to the leading club football, team in the nation, C. J. (Chet) LaRoche, the Foundation president, said yesterday.
Wilt Chamberlain, Walt Bellamy and Oscar Robertson, the National Basketball Association standouts, usually besieged with long contractual problems, began workouts yesterday.

TOKYO, Friday, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Japanese National Railway workers went on a 12-hour strike today at strategic points throughout the country after refusing to accept a management plan to have one motorman aboard each train instead of two.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Four North Korean infiltrators and a South Korean soldier were killed in a clash today along the demilitarized zone. The incident occurred while the United Nations command and North Korea were trading charges of armistice violations at a meeting here.

Childhood Productions, Inc., has agreed in principle to acquire the Franklin Typographers, New York, for cash and stock, it was announced yesterday. Franklin had sales last year of more than $1.3-million. Under the proposed terms, Franklin would become a division of Childhood Productions, distributors of films.

MARSEILLE, France, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Three masked bandits jumped and beat an armored-car driver making a bank delivery this morning and took a valise containing $120,000 worth of francs. The gang escaped in heavy traffic.
Somewhere in Taiwan today a healthy peasant boy will jump on a new bicycle and ride to school in a nearby town while his father plows a newly productive plot with a gasoline-powered garden tractor.

Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, the acting president of Columbia University, displayed his own brand of confrontation politics yesterday by walking unexpectedly into the midst of a crowd of about 700 students gathered on a campus lawn for a rally.
The Perkins Will Partnership, an architectural concern, has named George E. Shear a senior associate.
SOMERSET Colo., Sept. 19 (AP) -- Four ment were killed today, when a rock ceiling collapsed inside the United States Steel Corporation's coal mine in this western Colorado town, a doctor reported.

SUN VALLEY, Idaho, Sept. 19 -- Otwar Emminger, a director of the Deutsche Bundesbank, the West German central bank, said today there was "no economic case whatsoever" for a revaluation of the German mark.

HARRISON, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- Mrs. Allison Choate of Rye, N. Y., carded 43, 36 -- 79 on the south course at Westchester Country Club today and won the 45th annual United States Senior Women's Golf Association championship by one stroke with 80, 79 -- 159.
GERALD ARPINO'S "Incubus,'' that nightmare of childhood madness, found a new heroine at the New York City Center last night where Erika Goodman danced the role for the first time.

The city administration's unexpected readiness to find an additional $200 to $300 million for new subways will almost certainly lead to a speedy and welcome agreement on a more comprehensive plan for improving New York's rapid transit system than had previously seemed possible.

A 25,000-word account of the Cuban missile crisis written last year by Robert F. Kennedy was sold yesterday by the Senator's estate to the McCall Corporation for an advance of $1-million. It will appear in the November issue of McCall's, which will be on news-stands Oct. 22.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- A key Congressional subcommittee recommended today that the International Monetary Fund begin immediate consideration of three further reforms of the world monetary system.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- The Chevrolet division of the General Motors Corporation showed its 1969 cars to the press today, adding new gimmicks for the car owner who thought he had everything.
BOSTON, Sept. 19 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy intends to make more than a mere gesture but less than a maximum effort in behalf of Vice President Humphrey's Presidential campaign this fall.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 19 -A Palestinian commando organization controlled by the ruling Syrian Baathist party says it has made its first raid inside the Israeli-occupied Golan heights.
ATLANTA, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Atlanta will host to the soccer match between the United States and Canada in the first round of the World Cup competition on Oct. 27.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The official spokesman of the Australian entry in the America's Cup, the Royal Sydney Yacht Squadron, decided last night to endorse the Gretel Syn-for the cup.

MIAMI, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A predawn bomb today shattered windows in four scores of a building from which an anti-Castro revolutionary organization, Second Front-Alpha 66, had recently been evicted in Miami's Little Havana section.
DALLAS, Sept. 19 -- It says something about Hubert H. Humphrey's prospects of carrying Texas that, little more than six weeks before the election, he does not have a campaign manager in the state.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 19 -- Abdul Razak, Deputy Prime Minister of Malaysia, said today that the Philippines must bear full responsibility for the consequences of the suspension of diplomatic relations.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 19 -- Secretary General Thant today foresaw a resurgence of the cold war as a result of the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia.

LISBON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- An American neurosurgeon, Dr. Houston Merritt, said today that the chances of recovery of Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar from a severe stroke were "still not entirely hopeless."
JERUSALEM, Sept. 19 -- The Armenian Patriarchate in Jerusalem has decided after centuries of secrecy to display its treasures.

STONY BROOK, L. I., Sept. 19 -- Mrs. Thorne Dempsey, of the St. George's Golf and Country Club won her semi-final match from Mrs. Cutting Cushing of Meadow Brook today in the Women's Cross County Association championship.

ST. PAUL, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Mayor Lindsay of New York has made it official he is not a candidate for Vice President on a ticket headed by Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, Democrat of Minnesota. Minnesota's Secretary of State Joseph L. Donovan said yesterday he had received Mr. Lindsay's formal notification to remove his name from the general election ballots in Minnesota.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Defense Department is concerned about a sharp increase in desertions from the South Vietnamese armed forces.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $590-million, up 7 per cent from the year-earlier $551-million.
BONN, Sept. 19 -- Dr. Karl Schiller, Minister of Economics, said today on his return from Yugoslavia that West Germany would seek closer economic ties with Yugoslavia.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 19 -- The Hungarians are telling a joke these days about the invasion.
PICTURE thousands of overweights flocking, some furtively to nearby towns, to attend meetings on creaking chairs and swear off goodies.

SALERNO, Italy, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- United States and British officials joined the people of Salerno today in ceremonies marking the 25th anniversary of the World War II Allied landing in this south Italian port. The destroyer Waldron of the American Sixth Fleet made a goodwill call.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 -- Wilbur J. Cohen, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today a 10 per cent increase in the amount patients will pay for hospitalization under Medicare.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has achieved "really a miraculous turn-about" since his latest heart attack but "still is not out of danger," one of his doctors said today.
PRAGUE, Sept. 19 -- Plans for the establishment of autonomous regions for the Czech and Slovak components of Czechoslovakia moved rapidly ahead today.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- A 24-hour general strike today by Uruguay's leftist-led unions closed Montevideo's transport system, schools, newspapers and hundreds of manufacturing plants.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organization allies see varying reasons for the current Soviet propaganda campaign against West Germany, but they are in general agreement that any Soviet or Warsaw Pact incursion by force across the West German border is highly unlikely.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman said today that the United States recognized Sabah as a part of the Federation of Malaysia.
ATLANTA, Sept. 19 -- Republican leaders have offered to help preserve Congressional seniority rights for rebellious Southern Democrats who wish to join the Republican party.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The House passed a $1.6-billion foreign aid appropriation bill today only a few hours after approving an authorization ceiling about $356-million higher.

The Axe Securities Corporation, national distributor of the four Axe-Houghton mutual funds, announced yesterday the election of George H. Dolan as president. Mr. Dolan, who joined E. W. Axe Co., Inc., in 1948, will retain the post of senior vice president of that concern.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, warned organized labor today that its campaign for Hubert H. Humphrey might violate Federal prohibitions against the use of union dues for political purposes.

JAN NEMEC'S "A Report on the Party and the Guests," which was shown yesterday at the New York Film Festival and which will open next week at the 34th Street East, was delayed for two years before it was released some months ago in Czechoslovakia.
PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Nigerian federal forces have thrust seven miles north of Owerri in a move to split Biafra into two segments, army officers said today.
HOUSTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- Felipe Alou's two-run triple in the second inning, his 200th hit of the season, powered the Atlanta Braves to a 4-1 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

WHEN Joe Cronin was a ballplayer, he was hailed as the best hitting shortstop since the legendary Honus Wagner. So sharply developed was his sense of timing that he even was able to set a record near the end of his career by crashing out five home runs as a pinch-hitter. But now that he is the president of the American League, Joe has lost his touch.

SIOUX FALLS, S. D., Sept. 19 -- Vice President Humphrey dashed halfway across the country today to gather in the public tribute of the Kennedy wing of his party, but he also had to listen to further private warnings of voter resistance in his path.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Francisco Martinez, a 25-year-old Puerto Rican apprentice jockey, still was in serious condition today at the Atlantic City Hospital after an accident in yesterday's first race.

Raymond L. Howard has been elected a vice president of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc. Mr. Howard has been director of management systems for American Standard, Inc., and has also been associated with the Westinghouse Electric Corporation and the General Motors Corporation.
The American Stock Exchange disclosed yesterday that it had suspended one of its members for 15 days for violating the exchange's constitution.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 19 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie revived today one of the Democrats' traditional campaign themes: That the Republicans are the party of fiscal disaster.
Struggling through heavy crosscurrents of buying and selling, the stock market scored another advance yesterday in one of the busiest trading sessions in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

A Federal Reserve Board member, Andrew F. Brimmer, cautioned yesterday that the nation's monetary policy in coming months must be moderate -- just enough to assure a return to price stability without causing "unacceptable" unemployment.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

Chances of surviving a bout with most forms of cancer have increased substantially over the last several decades, but prospects for the victim of lung cancer remain grim, the National Cancer Institute reported yesterday.

Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that his administration would listen to the voice of responsible dissent and would draw officials from "the broadest possible base" in order to insure "a true ferment of ideas."
The Columbia student radical movement, lagging in the last few days, yesterday began to regain the spirit of last spring.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 19 -- The army seized control of the National University late last night in a move to end seven weeks of student agitation. President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz thus made good his threat to use force against attacks on public order and any attempt to disrupt the Olympic Games, which are scheduled to open here Oct. 12.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The University of Southern California's school of medicine will eliminate a full year from the standard five-year course for doctors by dropping its internship program. Dean Roger C. Egenberg said today that plans were being made to cut off still another year of the time required to train a doctor.
Bosley Crowther, motion picture critic emeritus of The New York Times, will retire from The Times next month after 40 years to become a full-time, executive consultant for Columbia Pictures.

BONN, Sept. 19 -- In a new challenge to the judiciary, the Deutsche National und Soldaten-Zeitung, an extreme right-wing weekly published in Munich, came out with a portrait of Hitler on its front-page today.
The Most Rev. Terence J. Cooke, Archbishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, viewed a copy of Michelangelo's "Pieta" yesterday on the sixth floor of Gimbels department store.
AREA A -- Although a low pressure area has produced strong turbulence on the ocean in recent days, the more stout-hearted fishermen are returning with good catches of albacore, bonita and dolphin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The House approved today a $14.5-billion appropriation bill, which, Housing Secretary Robert C. Weaver said, fails to provide him with money to carry out the new open housing law.

The Justice Department's antitrust division has requested information on the proposed merger of Swift Co. and Northwest Industries, Inc., it was disclosed yesterday by R. W. Reneker, president of Swift, and Ben W. Heineman, president of Northwest.
Tossing a psychological screen pass, Chuck Fairbanks of Oklahoma confessed yesterday he was "awed" by the size and brute strength of the Notre Dame eleven his Sooners meet tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 19 -- United Nations officials and diplomats emphasized today that the two articles of the organization's Charter invoked by the Soviet Union to uphold any use of force against West Germany were drafted in circumstances entirely different from present ones.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 19 -- At least six persons were killed and several hundred injured in scattered clashes today between the police and striking employes of the central Government.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Jim Hart belted a grand slam and Bobby Bonds hit two homers and scored four runs today as the San Francisco Giants defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 11-5.

LONDON, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The British discount rate -- the key to interest levels -- was cut to 7 per cent from 7.5 per cent today. The cut in Britain's crisis-level bank rate was viewed in financial circles here as a sign that the country's ailing economy might be on the mend. But at the same time, the man in the street was warned by the Government that his personal credit squeeze will remain.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 19 -- Malaysia announced today that she had suspended diplomatic relations with the Philippines and abrogated a year-old antismuggling pact between the two countries.
Stephen E. Smith, brother-in-law of Robert F. Kennedy and leader of the late Senator's supporters in Democratic state politics, has agreed to accept a key role in the Senate campaign of Paul O'Dwyer.

BERLIN, Sept. 19 -- Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, conferred today with Pyotr A. Abrasimov, the Soviet Ambassador to East Germany, on "intensification of militarism and revanchism" in West Germany, the East German Communist regime announced.

Edith Eisler, violinist, and Betty Rosenblum, pianist, both serious and intelligent artists, played a Brahms program last night at Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- The first continent-wide sample taken by Alcoholics Anonymous shows that 41 per cent of those who join the group stop drinking immediately and that nearly 23 per cent more do so within a year.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A white man has been sentenced to die in the South Carolina electric chair for the fatal shooting of James Owens, a Negro policeman. State officials say it may be the first time in South Carolina that a white man has received the death penalty for killing a Negro.

PRAGUE, Sept. 19 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union has apologized for Moscow press allegations that Dr. Jiri Hajek, who resigned today as Foreign Minister, was a former Nazi collaborator, informed sources here said.

LIVERPOOL, England, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Coventry City purchased Tony Hateley from Liverpool today for $192,000, making the center forward the most expensive soccer player in England in the last 24 months.

The Diana Stores Corporation, one of the country's largest chains of women's apparel stores, which also operates discount department stores, would be acquired by Daylin, Inc., of Beverly Hills, Calif., under an agreement in principle announced yesterday.
The Dutch freighter Johannes Frans was reported by the Coast Guard yesterday to be taking on water and in danger of sinking in high seas 650 miles east of here.

IN their opening contest last Sunday against Pittsburgh, the New York Giants ran 68 plays, which was high for the National Football League's opening weekend and well above the N.F.L. game average last season of 59.

DELAWARE, Ohio, Sept. 19 -- Rum Customer, 1-2 and 1-5 in the betting, easily captured today's $104,226.38 Little Brown Jug, the first link in the series for the triple crown of pacing, before a record Delaware County Fairgrounds crowd of 47,404.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee changed its mind today and voted to invite George C. Wallace to participate in any special television debates between Hubert H. Humphrey and Richard M. Nixon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (AP) -- Congress sent to President Johnson today a bill to preserve for the nation a Northern California coastal forest containing some of the tallest trees on earth -- redwoods Standing 367 feet.

Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, says there is a need to decentralize the public schools, because "it's the desire of many parents and the community to have a greater voice in their operation."

The election of Frank Massi as executive vice president of the Hearst Corporation, was announced yesterday. He succeeds the late G. O. Markuson. Mr. Massi has been treasurer since 1961 and will continue in that post.

Negotiations between radio broadcasters and Broadcast Music Inc., a music licensing organization, have been broken off after the broadcasters rejected B.M.I.'s latest position. No date has been set for new talks.

The election of Raymond C. Johnson as chairman of the New York chapter of the American Red Cross, succeeding the late Sylvan Gotshal, was announced yesterday. He is executive vice president and a director of New York Life Insurance Company.
PASSAIC, N. J., Sept. 19 (AP) -- A general - alarm fire destroyed four stores downtown tonight, injuring at least four firemen and setting off sporadic looting.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Sept. 17 -- Tanned, smiling and somewhat awed by his reception, Willem de Kooning is visiting his homeland for the first time in 42 years.

OTTAWA, Sept. 19 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau fended off charges today in the House of Commons that he had "wobbled" on Canada's commitment as an ally in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept 19 -- The world's largest annual meeting of publishers and authors, the Frankfurt Book Fair, opened today, a mixture of politics, literary controversy and almost 200,000 books, displayed by 58 countries.
DETROIT, Sept. 19 -- Top level executives of the General Motors Corporation met with Government officials in Washington today on prices of 1969 automobiles.
A cut in the British bank rate yesterday -- to 7 per cent from 7.5 -- had little apparent effect on commodity prices in London and New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 -- President Johnson took advantage of a Medal of Honor awards ceremony at the White House today to rebut once again the critics of his Vietnam policy and to call for steadfast support of the war.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Sept. 19 -- Montclair State had one of the best defenses among small-college football teams last season. Eight of those defensive stars are back. The Indians also have one of the best place-kickers in college football.

International Industries, Inc., sweetened its merger bid yesterday to the Champlain National Corporation, which had previously rejected an International Industries proposal in favor of talks with Foremost-McKesson, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 (UPI) -- President Johnson today nominated Albert B. Brooke Jr., administrative assistant to Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, as a member of the Federal Power Commission. Mr. Brooke, 47 years old, a native of Paducah, Ky., would serve out the remainder of the term of former Commissioner Charles R. Ross, which expires June 22, 1969.

Loans to business at large New York City banks rose by $407-million in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a rise of $290-million in the comparable week a year ago.
A common virus that is transmitted through sexual contact has been linked with cancer of the cervix, and researchers believe the finding indicates that cervical cancer is a venereal disease.

CHICAGO Sept. 20 -- The growth of trading-stamp sales, after a lull in the last half of 1967, has resumed this year, with prospects for spectacular gains in the future, according to industry spokesman.

WICHITA, Kan., Sept. 20 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie is well aware that the Democrats are on the defensive this year. This is especially true in a state such as Kansas, where some straw polls show the party running third in the Presidential race.

BINGHAMTON, Sept. 20 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said here today that there was a question in his mind that such pressing urban problems as education, health and housing would be "given the priority they deserve" in a Nixon Administration.
ROME, Sept. 20 (Reuters) -David L. Wolper, the film producer, is trying to retrieve tanks and armored cars that were left in Czechoslovakia last month when Warsaw Pact troops invaded the country.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 20 -- When Gil Hodges took over as manager of the Mets this spring, he said he hoped to win 70 games in his first year. He reached that mark tonight with seven games left in the season.

With thousands of lunch-hour spectators peering up from the sidewalks and looking down from office buildings and hotels, the four featured heavyweights on next Thursday's boxing card at Madison Square Garden trained yesterday atop the Seventh Avenue marquee.

HAVANA, Sept. 20 (AP) -- Members of Cuba's track, rowing and boxing teams, numbering 60 in all, departed by air today for the Olympic Games in Mexico City. The rest of the 146-member Cuban team will leave within the next 10 days.

PARIS, Sept. 20 -- A bill designed to make the French Education system more democratic, more flexible and less rigidly centralized has been adopted by the Cabinet with the backing of President de Gaulle.

Operations of the Data Processing Financial and General Corp. in the three months ended Aug. 31 resulted in net income of $1,869,047, equal to $1.11 a share, it was reported yesterday.

Metromedia News has invited spokesmen for five groups to discuss a program that would reply to Mayor Richard J. Daley's film on the demonstrations at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago. NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 20 (AP) -- The Sugar Bowl is starting early this fall to scout prospects for the New Year's Day postseason collegiate football classic. Sugar Bowl representatives will scout five games tomorrow. Usually, the Sugar Bowl doesn't watch possible bowl teams until midseason.

All 20 American League umpires, including the two who were discharged but contended they were not technically dismissed, have signed applicacations for membership in the association that already exists for National League umpires. SHADES of Philip Nolan, the man without a country. There we were on the dock in Skagway, Alaska, begging the purser of a practically empty Alaskan ferry, the Wickersham, to carry us 10 miles across the Lynn Canal to Haines, Alaska. He would not do it because of the Jones Act.

The Jewish New Year of 5729 began at sundown yesterday, and in Rosh ha-Shanah sermons, rabbis called for military aid to Israel, a greater understanding of the problems of youth and a stronger adherence to the doctrines of Judaism.
WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 22 -- Aldie Belle squeezed through to win the regular working hunter championship today at the closing session of the Eastern States horse show.

ATHENS, Sept. 22 -- The top military leadership of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gathered here today for an inspection tour of the alliance's southern defenses. The tour is taking place amid evidence that the focus of attention in the Soviet-bloc crisis is shifting, at least partly, to the Balkans.
The first issue of Cerberus, a new student newspaper that aims to be "independent" and "creative," was published last week for distribution on New York University's Washington Square campus.

Toward the end of an Administration, Presidential thoughts tend to turn toward immortality, or at least toward a preoccupation with the permanent record. It is then that plans take shape for those Presidential libraries, archives and memoirs that are meant to document the years when one man briefly assisted destiny.
Shirley Verrett made her Metropolitan Opera debut Saturday night in what must surely be one of the most difficult ways to do it -- that of taking the title role in Bizet's "Carmen."
Mayor Lindsay devoted his entire day yesterday to an effort to break up the impasse in the city's contract negotiations with its 50,000 unionized policemen, firemen and sanitation workers.
OUTSIZE, brilliantly colored diamond, balloon and swirling abstract patterns have become Emilio Pucci's signature -- first in clothes and more recently in linens. Last year his bath linens arrived.

A STEADILY increasing number of bridge players choose a floating vacation that can satisfy their yen for their favorite game. The "Travel-with-Goren" organization is responsible for 35 bridge cruises annually, five of which are fully franchised seagoing tournaments. Destinations include the Far East, the South Seas, the Mediterranean and the Caribbean, and will soon include Russia.
OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 22 -- Bobby Nichols did a jig as he holed an 18-foot birdie deuce with two holes to go in the Professional Golfers' Association team championship today.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Jim McAndrew walked around the Met clubhouse this afternoon wearing a light green double-breasted suit and an embarrassed smile.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 -- The Interior Department has told President Johnson that the problems facing the Hudson River Valley are too complex to be solved by governmental agencies "following independent and often conflicting courses of action."

ANYONE seriously worried about the future of the American theater would be well advised to take a close look at the past theater season in London. Theatrical problems, it seems, are common the world over.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 22 -- The two-week stillness along the Suez Canal will be shattered tomorrow morning, but this time with shofars instead of -- or conceivably in addition to -- 160-mm. mortars.

" FACES," which was shown yesterday at the New York Film Festival, is incomparably better than John Cassavetes's first film, "Shadows," and a really important movie about the American class, generation and marriage abyss.

ROSH HA - SHANAH, the Jewish New Year which began at sundown yesterday, traditionally includes such things as two loaves of challah (Sabbath bread) that are decorated with ladders and birds to symbolize prayers ascending, apple slices to dip into a bowl of honey, and sweet wine.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- The turmoil that has been boiling in the Democratic party this year is due largely to a deep and growing rift between two types of liberals, according to a study released today.

STONEWALL, Tex., Sept. 22 -- With President Johnson standing behind him, the Most Rev. Robert Emmet Lucey, Archbishop of San Antonio, equated the President's Vietnam war policy with the papal peace program.

MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, Sept: 22 -- Denis Hulme of New Zealand, driving a bright orange McLaren - Ford that never missed a tick, won his second consecutive Grand Prix race today. Hulme, the 1967 winner of the World Championship of Drivers in this competition, moved into a first-place tie with Graham Hill of Britain for the 1968 title.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas has granted a stay to two more groups of reservists who asked him to block the Army's plans to send them to Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 22 -- Fran Tarkenton walked off Franklin Field today with a $24 league football under his arm. The football belonged to Tarkenton, the team leader, by virtue of a triumph for the New York Giants, and later Fran gave it to a teammate, Spider Lockhart, for his accomplishments.

WASHINGTON, D. C., Sept. 22 -- Muriel Humphrey plunged into three hostile Southern states as a solo campaigner this weekend. She was clasping a straw handbag emblazoned with "Count Your Blessings" and gamely wearing the albatross of the Johnson Administration as though it were a necklace of gold.

" THERE isn't just one Central Park," a young man said Saturday. "Everybody has his own. I can move into any world I want here -- all sorts of little hidden worlds." Over the weekend, the last of the summer, unc ounted thousands of New Yorkers were finding the park they wanted some where between 59th and 110th Streets.
Top Federal maritime officials have not decided what to do about a formal request from a seagoing labor union for an investigation of the aims of so-called conglomerates in the shipping industry.

LONDON, Sept. 22 -- Susan Garth, an Englishwoman who returned from Biafra last week, delivered a letter to Queen Elizabeth II today that described the plight of the starving children there.
OTTAWA -- The first phase of a joint Government-industry search for oil in the high Arctic has ended on an optimistic note.

Rather than cancel even one matinee performance, the City Center Jeffrey Ballet regularly performs overnight miracles. Three seasons ago Michael Colgrass composed in 24 hours a score for "Sea Shadow" and delivered it before the matinee.

AUSTIN, Tex., Sept. 22 -- Chancellor Harry H. Ransom of the University of Texas system has announced the gift by the Michener Foundation of Allentown, Pa., of a major collection of 20th-century American painting.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 22 -- Problems of war and aggression in Vietnam, Czechoslovakia and the Middle East are challenging the United Nations in its peace-keeping mission as the General Assembly prepares to meet Tuesday for its 23d annual session.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 22 -- Twenty prisoners of war were shot to death early today by a Vietcong force seeking to rescue them from a South Vietnamese prisoner-of-war camp, according to a spokesman for the South Vietnamese military command.
A battle between subsidized and nonsubsidized steamship lines for the dominant share of the Defense Department's peacetime ocean-borne traffic entered a new stage on two Washington fronts last week.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Two hundred Roman Catholics walked out of St. Matthew's Cathedral here today as their Archbishop, Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, began delivering a sermon urging obedience to Pope Paul VI's restrictions on birth control.
Riker Video Industries, Inc., announced yesterday that it proposed to acquire all the common shares of Standard Kollsman Industries, Inc., through an exchange of stock.
THE youngsters appear to have a winner in the American Broadcasting Company's new adventure series called "Land of the Giants," which is seen here on Channel 7 Sundays at 7 P.M.

THIS is the second time that the program director has selected Max Ophuls's last film, "Lola Montes," for showing at the New York Film Festival. At the first festival in 1963, while the main event was being held at Philharmonic Hall, the 1955 movie was screened at the Museum of Modern Art as part of a series devoted to films that had been overlooked in American commercial release.
CHICAGO, Sept. 22 -- Many parents refused to enroll their children this month as a school desegregation plan ordered by a Federal court became effective in a suburban Chicago area.

PRAGUE, Sept. 22 -- A considerable number of Soviet military and civilian advisers were reported today to be moving into Prague notwithstanding the Czechoslovak announcement yesterday that the occupation troops were to begin withdrawing in a few days.
TRENTON, Sept. 22 -- Mario Andretti, the pint-sized driver with the heavy foot, piloted a rear-engine turbo-charged Offenhauser with determination today and won the Trenton 200 with surprising ease.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Interest rates on conventional mortgages continued to rise in August but at a slower pace than in other recent months, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 22 -- Representatives of the New party from 29 states met here today to form a national committee for the party, which was organized this summer by anti-war activists and other opponents of the Johnson Administration.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 22 -- The increasing tension between Bulgaria and Yugoslavia, rooted in an old quarrel over Macedonia, has become evident again following the rejection by a leading Yugoslav party official of what he termed greater-Bulgarian chauvinism.
John Kenneth Galbraith, president of Americans for Democratic Action, indicated Saturday night that he would endorse Vice President Humphrey.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 22 -- Joe Namath returned to the scene of some of his college glory today, but Paul Crane, the other Alabama University product on the New York Jets, provided the turning point of a 47-31 victory over the Boston Patriots.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 17 -- Prof. Paul A. Freund is barely visible amid a lifetime's accumulation of books and legal reports piled high in his Harvard Law School office. They fill most of the space under his crowded desk.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 22 -- A policeman was shot to death, scores of persons were injured and hundreds were arrested late last night and early this morning in the worst fighting since the army seized the National University Wednesday night.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 22 -- The Government closed down universities and secondary schools here and called out the army today after days of bloody street fighting.

FRANKFURT, Sept. 22 -- Screams of "Student-murderer!'' formed a counterpoint to the haunting beauty of the slow movement of a Mozart quartet that greeted President Leopold S. Senghor of Senegal today as he received a peace prize from the Frankfurt Book Fair.

GOSHEN, Conn., Sept. 22 -- A 4-year-old brindle greyhound, Ch. Shalfleet Starlight of Foxden, owned by Mr. and Mrs. James A. Farrell Jr. of Darien, Conn., won her ninth best-in-show award today at the 23d annual Northwestern Connecticut Dog Show at the Agricultural Fair Grounds.

COLLEGEVILLE, Pa., Sept. 22 -- A 4-year-old Great Dane, Ch. Reggen's Madas-L of Marydane, owned by Mary K. Johnston of Wilton, Conn., scored over 846 other dogs today in gaining the best-in-show award at the 21st annual Valley Forge Kennel Club event.

LAST night's presentation of "Vladimir Horowitz: A Television Concert at Carnegie Hall" on the Columbia Broadcasting System's television net work was a model of its kind. A 5-1 loss to the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium gave the Yankees a six-game losing streak, which began immediately after their 10-game winning streak.

The credit markets have just polished off a week of record tax-exempt bond volume plus large World Bank and Federal National Mortgage Association issues. Because of these successes, this week's smaller schedule of fixed-inome securities sales may be handled very easily, too.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 -The bustling Bruins of the University of California. Los Angeles, lost a quarterback and found a quarterback last night as they routed the University of Pittsburgh, 63-7.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 22 (AP) -- Rod Laver lost the first set to Ken Rosewall tonight, then won 12 games in succession and captured the singles competition in the $30,000 Pacific Southwest open tennis tournament. The scores were 4-6, 6-0, 6-0.

HANOVER, N. H., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Dr. John Sloan Dickey, president of Dartmouth College since 1945, announced today that he would retire during the 1969-70 school year, which marks the college's 200th anniversary.
New York sports fans will be men for all seasons this weekend when baseball bumps into football, hockey and basketball, not to mention horse racing.

An outdoor art show benefit for the United Cerebral Palsy Association will be held next Saturday and Sunday at Jackson Avenue and Ira Road in Syosset, L. I. The works on display will include oils, watercolors, graphics and sculpture by some 100 artists from the New York area.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The sale of The Keokuk Daily Gate City, one of the oldest daily newspapers in Iowa, was announced today by Dale E. Carrell Jr., editor and publisher. Mr. Carrell said that major stock in The Gate City and the Gate City Company was acquired by Richard N. Hoerner Jr., a paper box manufacturer.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Wives of New Orleans policemen don't like the idea of their husbands patrolling the streets in squad cars with policewomen. Some of the men don't like it either.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The volume of offers to sell mortgages to the Federal National Mortgage Association rose at this week's auction after an extended period of declining volume, the agency reported today. Price changes were small and mixed, with prices of 90-day purchase commitments unchanged from last week.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Dissatisfaction with Democratic stands on law and order, welfare and other programs has driven away many Democratic voters in the upper end of the Central Valley, including those tracing their registration to the Dust Bowl states of the 1930's.

Standard Kollsman Industries, Inc., said yesterday that the take-over bid made Sunday by Riker Video Industries, Inc., was "mystifying and ridiculous." Spokesmen for the electronics concern added they had never heard of Riker Video until they read of the offer in newspapers.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23 -- Brazil announced tonight a slight devaluation of the cruzeiro to 3.7 to the dollar from the former 3.65 to the dollar, set Aug. 21. The August devaluation, amounting to 13 per cent, was the third in 18 months.
TITOGRAD, Yugoslavia, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Six persons were killed and 21 injured when a suspension bridge connecting the new and the old parts of this Montenegrin capital collapsed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A gunman took an estimated total of $20,000 from a Brink's Armored Car Service messenger today in full view of crowds at the Senor Pico restaurant in Ghirardelli Square. A motorist tried to box in the gunman's car with his own auto, which was hit by a truck, injuring the motorist and his wife, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Presho.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 -- Supporters of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy apparently failed today to get the Minnesotan's name on the California ballot as an independent candidate for President.
TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Koji Watanabe prevented India from scoring a sweep of the Eastern Zone Davis Cup tennis final when he defeated Premjit Lall, 8-6, 6-1, 6-2, today.
Representative John M. Murphy said yesterday that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Mayor in the 1969 election.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Astronaut training is under way for a possible American manned moon-orbiting mission later this year that would surpass the feat of the Soviet unmanned Zond 5, space agency officials said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- A South Vietnamese general said today that Government troops had fired artillery shells into Cambodian territory at North Vietnamese fleeing to sanctuary there.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, only team to hold an edge on Dennis McLain this season, defeated Detroit's 31-game winner, 2-1, tonight. Pete Richert, in relief, halted a Tiger rally in the eighth inning.

MIDLAND, Mich., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- About 30 cars crashed into each other in a heavy fog over U. S. 10 Freeway during the morning rush hour today. One woman was killed and 11 persons were hospitalized. Killed was Marie Gustafson, 24 years old, of Bay City, Mich.

The American Stock Exchange has recommended to its members that they approve a reduction in commissions for large securities transactions by the same amount proposed by the New York Stock Exchange on Aug. 8.

MANILA, June 23 -- A loan of $7.2-million was granted by the Asian Development Bank today to Malaysia for the construction of a water-supply project in the state of Penang. The bank announced that the loan would finance the first stage of a long - range expansion plan for the Penang waterworks system.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The Soviet Union's circumlunar spacecraft Zond 5 was reported today to have returned the first recordings of scientific measurements on conditions in space as far out as the moon.

LONG BEACH, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King was operated on today at Pacific Hospital to repair damaged cartilage in her left knee and her physician, Dr. Nicholas Papageorge, said the surgery was successful.

PARIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The United States Ambassador, Sargent Shriver, had a 60-minute talk with President de Gaulle today. The meeting, at the President's suggestion, was the envoy's first since his arrival in May.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The head of the National Education Association endorsed the principle of school decentralization today and said that the dispute in the New York City schools was "a major national issue with implications for all major urban school systems."
