The teachers' strike is almost certain to have an adverse effect on the gate receipts of Public Schools Athletic League football.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept 23 -- Robert W. Komer, the chief pacification adviser in South Vietnam, said today that he saw "growing hope for an end to this war, perhaps sooner than many yet dare to think."

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Union teachers ratified today a one-year contract with the East St. Louis board of Education, paving the way for the opening of classes tomorrow four weeks behind the schedule.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I. Sept. 23 -- Mrs. Cutting Cushing of Meadow Brook today shot a 37, 38 -- 75, four over par, to win the medal in the Women's Long Island Golf Association qualifying for the match-play championship.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) -Officials of the Detroit Cougars of the North American Soccer League, announced today their decision to disband because of financial losses.
James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate, denied yesterday a charge by Senator Jacob A. Javits that "the Conservative party is out to destroy the Republican party."
The New York subway system is going to become a bit less dreary because a group of private citizens have donated $450,000 to beautify one of the stations.
"The Empire Builders," which was to have opened on Sunday at the Astor Place Theater, will now have its opening Tuesday, Oct. 1, at 7:30 P.M. at the same theater.
At 4 P.M. yesterday, the Weather Bureau reported that the high temperature for the first day of autumn, 83 degrees, had just been recorded in its Central Park station.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- The Soviet Union was reliably reported today to be seeking a postponement of the meeting of Communist parties scheduled to open here Nov. 25.

Cohu Electronics, Inc., has elected Lieut. Gen. K. B. Wolfe (Air Force, retired) as chairman. William S. Ivans, president, has been named chief executive officer. They fill vacancies created by the death of La Motte I. Cohu Sept. 10.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has agreed to sell Parkchester in the Bronx, the nation's largest apartment development, for what is believed to be the highest price ever paid for a single piece of property -- $90-million.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., categorically denied today charges by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had improperly used inside information in 1966 to help some, but not all, of its customers make a profit in trading the stock of the Douglas Aircraft Company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Complain all you like, friend, about being stacked up for an hour in your jet over New York or Paris waiting for a crack at the runway. You will get no sympathy here. For real air-travel agony nothing beats being stacked down for three hours in the airline terminal at Rochester, Atlanta or Albany waiting to take off.
Paced by strength in the blue-chip sector, the stock market posted its sixth consecutive advance yesterday in less active trading.
DUBLIN, Sept. 23 -- The Bank of America opened its first branch in Ireland today on Grafton Street, Dublin's most important shopping avenue.

BONN, Sept. 23 -- Former Gov. William W. Scranton, in Europe on a fact-finding mission for Richard M. Nixon, described as "extremely cordial" today his 90-minute meeting with Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany.

"The Presidency," a 90-minute examination of the office from the early days of Franklin D. Roosevelt to the latter days of Lyndon B. Johnson, will be produced by WNDT (Channel 13), for presentation Oct. 15 on the 24-station Eastern Educational Network.

Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the Port of New York Authority, yesterday challenged a longshore leader's contention that increased containership operations would almost cut dockworkers' job opportunities in half.

ALMOST everyone agrees that guests and ambiance are the essential ingredients of any successful party. Robert Perkins can't do anything about the former, but he's just started a rental business that packages "party atmosphere." Mr. Perkins, who owns The Greenery, an exclusive little flower shop at 306 East 53d Street, has been involved in floral decorations for parties for some years. He's also kept an eye open on what was lacking.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 22 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey with tears in his eyes told a group of housewives today that his mentally retarded granddaughter, Vicky, had pneumonia. He said it was "very serious" for a retarded child to have a bronchial problem.

ANAHEIM, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The California Angels named the former North American Soccer League commissioner, Dick Walsh, as their general manager today while retaining Bill Rigney as their field manager for the next two years.
BERLIN, Sept. 23 (UPI) -Leonard Bernstein lectured the press today on accuracy and the state of his health.

ALAMOSA, Colo., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The last two berths on the United States Olympic wrestling team were filled today when Rick Sanders of Portland (Ore.) State won the 114 1/2-pound free-style division and Larry Lyden of Hopkins, Minn., won the 171 1/2-pound Greco-Roman class.

NEWARK, Sept. 23 -- A device that produced shifting patterns and colors of light on a 32-by-24-inch screen was reported missing yesterday from the Newark College of Engineering's "Light as Art" exhibit.
MANILA, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The United States assured the Philippines today that it was "totally impartial" in the Philippine-Malaysian dispute over Sabah.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson returned to the White House today after a weekend at the LBJ Ranch in Texas to keep appointments on her social calendar. President Johnson remained at the ranch and was expected to fly back to Washington tomorrow or Wednesday.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Second-seeded Stan Smith and fourth - ranked Charles Pasarell swept to easy victories today in the opening round of the Pacific Coast international tennis tournament.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 23 -- Rumania, which walked out of a similar meeting here in February, may participate in sessions this week to discuss a later world conference of Communist parties.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Although Billy Casper widened his lead in the Professional Golfers Association money standings to $22,000, George Archer made the most significant gain during the week by winning a share of the team title.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Newcar sales continued to run above a year ago in the middle third of September, it was reported today.

HONOLULU, Sept. 23 -Gov. Spiro T. Agnew went island hopping around Hawaii today, telling his audience in this 50th state that the nation's runaway inflation made United States savings bonds a poor investment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- More than 6,000 military personnel including nearly 3,000 paratroopers will participate in a joint demonstration beginning Oct. 2 at the Army base at Fort Bragg and nearby Pope Air Force Base in North Carolina, the Pentagon announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Howard Hughes apparently will have to weather a proxy fight in order to get control of Air West, the newly formed regional airline. The financier's offer will be submitted to shareholders Nov. 26, but the directors' vote to recommend the offer was 13 to 11, with one of the 13 reserving the right to change his vote.

TODAY would have been Tommy Armour's 73d birthday. He didn't quite make it, death cutting him short by almost a fortnight. He was one of golf's more unforgettable characters. History will remember him as one of the great shotmakers of his era and thousands upon thousands of his pupils will remember him as a matchless instructor who not only had all the knowledge but the rare gift of being able to impart it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate Democratic leader, expressed concern today over the support George C. Wallace has received in the Presidential election campaign.

A group of young filmmakers, aged 16 to 21, affiliated with the Mobilization for Youth on the Lower East Side, will make a 25-minute movie on the health problems of their neighbors, thanks to a $10,000 grant by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
CAIRO, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -President Nasser and King Hussein met tonight for talks on the latest developments in the Middle East situation.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Eldridge Cleaver of the Black Panthers will deliver 10 lectures on racism at the University of California whether or not the Board of Regents likes it, student leaders said today.
SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., Sept. 23 (AP) -- A dozen women, ranging in age from 19 to 34, were named yesterday to represent the United States in women's volleyball competition at the Olympic Games.
CHICAGO, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Chicago Bulls traded Keith Erickson to the Los Angeles Lakers today for Erwin Mueller, who was traded by the Bulls to the Lakers last season for Jim Barnes.

The cost of corporate borrowing at the nation's major banks is poised to drop. Indeed, to many bankers, the only questions are when and how much. Since midyear, there has been a basic change in the tone of the money markets.

MLADA BOLESLAV, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 23 -- This town of about 50,000 people has strongly protested to the Czechoslovak Government against the imminent permanent stationing of Soviet trops in barracks that Czechoslovak troops are being forced to leave.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- The 22d session of the United Nations General Assembly ended its business today in a 28-minute session that cleared the way for the opening of the 23d session tomorrow.
DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- The General Motors Corporation raised its 1969 car prices about 2 per cent today, about half the price increase posted by the Chrysler Corporation a week ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York areas as having been killed in Vietnam:

JAMESBURG, N. J., Sept. 23 -- Howell Fraser of Mountain Ridge, recent winner of the New Jersey assistant pro championship, led the field by 10 strokes today in the New Jersey qualifying round for the new national Professional Golfers' Association club championship at the Forsgate Country Club.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 23 -- Four firebombings were reported here tonight by the police as the racial turbulence that has sporadically flared here this month erupted with a new intensity.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Senator William Proxmire asked the Federal Reserve Board today not to put into effect its proposed major changes in the discount mechanism until Congress had a chance to explore the issue at its next session.

OLDSMAR, Fla., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Fire swept through the recently remodeled Florida Downs race track this morning, destroying the grandstand, the main office building and causing extensive damage to the Clubhouse.

Hills Bros. coffee, which crashed into the New York market last year with the line "Flavor so unbeatable it's reheatable," has just changed its tune. Now it's "Just slightly richer," followed by "More than 10 per cent richer than other leading coffees!"
A high air pollution advisory for the metropolitan area was canceled at noon yesterday by the Weather Bureau, which predicted "increased ventilation" for the Northeast.

The Uniformed Fire Officers Association charged yesterday that a Fire Department plan to transfer overworked men to lighter duty assignments in other areas of the city violated an agreement between the union and the city.
Seven youths were injured, one critically, when a small metal box stuffed with powder from cherry bombs, exploded against a light pole in Flushing, Queens, at 2:20 P.M. yesterday.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 23 -- Accused of curbing freedom of expression, the management of the Frankfurt Book Fair agreed today to relax the ban on political demonstrations.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Progressive magazine said today that it would not support Vice President Humphrey for President unless he divorced himself from the Administration's Vietnam position.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The Federal tax laws frequently provide a cash incentive to slum landlords to let their property run down, according to a study published today.

PARIS -- "It's the most perfect, delicious hotel in the world," said a tall, blue-eyed Texas oil man named L. Kenton McGee, who back home in Dallas drinks from Baccarat, sleeps on Porthault sheets and eats Roquefort cheese with slices of banana.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- President Johnson today signed a bill authorizing hostile fire pay to the 81 military crew members of the captured spy ship Pueblo.
The only man in a baseball suit who has hit 51 home runs and climbed a coconut tree this year is a 21-year-old rookie for the New York Yankees named Tony Solaita.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Professional Golfers' Association ended today attempts to heal the split between the P.G.A., said the tourning pros' through "concessions," and said it would go to court if necessary to retain control of the multi-million-dollar tournament tour.
The Duro-Test Corporation has purchased a one-story plant on a seven-acre site in Clifton, N. J., for about $1.5 -million.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Senate passed today and sent to the White House a bill to reduce from two to one the number of fish protein concentrate experimental plants. Under a previous law, the Secretary of the Interior was authorized to build one such plant and to lease another.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 23 -- A Government spokesman reported that South Vietnamese troops killed more than 200 enemy soldiers in several fierce engagements yesterday and this morning.

The appointment of Frank P. Preissle as vice president for production of the consumer products division of the Union Carbide Corporation was announced yesterday. He succeeds Harold F. Doolittle, who will continue to function as a vice president and who will l. eave! shortly for a special assignment ]as a consultant to Union Carlbide India, Ltd.

KINGTON, Jamaica, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The Jamaican Bank rate has been cut to 5 per cent, effective immediately, in a move to restore normal financial trading here, it was announced today. This ends crisis measures taken by Jamaica last November to protect its pound following sterling devaluation.

PRAGUE, Sept. 23 -- An American newsman was detained briefly last night on a Prague street by Soviet marines, who confiscated Czechoslovak press agency material that he was carrying and forced copies of Soviet publications on him.

YORK, Pa., Sept. 23 (UPI) -Mayor John Snyder imposed a 10 P.M.-to-dawn curfew tonight after classes at the Hannah Penn Junior High School were suspended as an aftermath of a student protest demonstration involving about 150 young persons, most of them Negro.

Thousands of white, middleclass parents have been trying to get their children into private and religious schools since the public school strike began, and hundreds of others have been talking about moving to the suburbs.
The first phase of the fall fund-raising campaign of the Association for the Help of Retarded Children's New York Chapter has just started. That's the door-to-door solicitation phase.
Martyn Green has been signed to play Brennan o' the Moor in "Red Roses for Me," the drama by Sean O'Casey that will open the new season of the Rhode Island School of Design Theater Oct. 17.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Gunmen shot up three schools early today and some students were reported to have been wounded or kidnapped.

The election of Leland E. Dake as a senior vice president and director of Schlumberger, Ltd., an international oil-field services and electronic instrumentation concern, was announced yesterday. He will be at Schlumberger headquarters in New York.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Atlanta Braves announced today that they have purchased Andy Findlay, an outfielder from their Shreveport fram club in the Texas League. Findlay, who was the Braves' No. 1 draft choice in 1967, hit .261 this year with six homers and 35 runs batted in.
The appointment of Robert L. Cushing and of John P. LaWare as senior vice presidents of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, was announced yesterday.

LONDON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The war of nerves developing over the soccer club match final between Manchester United of England and Estudiantes of Argentina became more tense today judging from the reaction of British newspapers.
Recently the Security Council once again adopted a resolution opposing Israel's administrative unification of Jerusalem.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- John McHugh Stuart Jr. was named chief spokesman for the United States mission at the United Nations today. He was designated senior adviser for public affairs.

The United States Golf Association announced yesterday dates and sites of the 1970 Curtis Cup matches and women's amateur championship. The Curtis Cup competition is slated for Aug. 7 and 8 at the Brae Burn Country Club in West Newton, Mass., and the amateur is to be held Aug. 17 through 22 at the Wee Burn Country Club in Darien, Conn.
TOKYO, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Kazuyoshi Kanazawa of Japan won a unanimous decision over Eli Aquinto of the Philippines tonight in a 10-round bout. Kanazawa weighed 117 1/2 pounds, Aquinto 117.
Bond prices, raised last week by the hope that major banks will soon drop the prime rate, held steady yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle, the Archbishop of Washington, called today all 130 pastors of the archdiocese to a meeting Wednesday at St. Patrick's Church.
OWERRI, Biafra (Nigeria), Sept. 23 (AP) -- Biafran troops prepared today for a stand in Umuahia -- the only major town left in their hands -- as federal troops closed in.

LOS ALAMOS, N. M., Sept. 23 (AP) -- Jarvis Scott of Los Angeles has given up her place in the 800-meter run on the United States women's Olympic track and field team to Francie Kraker of Ann Arbor, Mich.

TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Alexander Aldrich, executive director of the Hudson River Valley Commission, today welcomed the Department of the Interior's recommendation for the early formation of a three-party commission to oversee the development of the Hudson Valley.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 23 -The purchase, as a park, of a tract described as the "last and finest piece of undeveloped oceanfront land" in the Hamptons, was ordered today by the Suffolk County Board of Supervisors.
The American Express Campany has elected Peter Hovell a senior vice president and general manager of the money order division, it was announced yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 23 (AP) -- A Federal court affirmed today the on-year sentence of a Bogalusa (La.) man who attacked a photographer at a civil rights march only to discover that his victim was an F.B.I. agent.
The steel industry, undergoing its slowest period in a decade, managed to raise production ever so slightly last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

General Mills yesterday named James P. McFarland, president, as chief executive officer. Gen. Edwin W. Rawlings, 64-year-old chairman, who plans to retire next year, said he had asked that Mr. McFarland, 56, succeed him in the chief executive post. Mr. McFarland was named president and chief operating officer last December.

KAHULUI, Hawaii, Sept. 23 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew said today he meant no offense when he used the word "Polack" in referring to PolishAmericans and when he referred to an American newsman of Japanese descent who was traveling with him as "the fat Jap."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Manny Mota singled home Maury Wills in the 10th inning to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory tonight after the Cincinnati Reds had taken the first game of a twilight-night double-header, 9-6.
AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Firestone Country Club, the scene of some of the world's major golf tournaments, named Bobby Nichols of Louisville, Ky., today to serve as head pro, effective Nov. 1.
Most people who go to Florida go for a change of pace, a vacation. Tommie Agee is going to Florida for more work, for a chance to do his job better.

Hope for a Federal interstate compact effective enough to protect the majestic Hudson River Valley has been revived after a long period of stagnation. Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall now indicates some optimism that the mandate given him by Congress two years ago to negotiate such a compact can be fulfilled.

SOME writers are positive wizards at perceiving trends -- they can spend four and a half hours in Rome and spend the next four and a half months writing about Roman tendencies, from the length of Roman skirts to the length of Roman holidays.

OTTAWA, Sept. 23 -- The Province of Quebec has proposed a republican form of government for Canada, but Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that the monarchy would stay until "the people of Canada" demanded a change.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Sept. 23 -- President Johnson praised today's automobile price in-increase by General Motors, roughly half that announced a week ago by the Chrysler Corporation, as an example of "moderation" the entire automotive industry should emulate to resist inflation.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Down, the AllIreland Gaelic football champion, announced today it would play two games in New York at Gaelic Park on Oct. 13 and 20.

The New York Jets made a 1968 contract agreement with Matt Snell yesterday. Weeb Ewbank, the coach-general manager, said the agreement for "a multiple-year contract" had been reached with Probus Management, Inc., the company representing Snell, the Jets' fullback.

The General Assembly of the United Nations, once widely hailed as "the world's last best hope for peace," opens its twenty-third annual session today in an atmosphere of diminishing hope for the world organization and for the cause of international peace and justice it was designed to promote.
Except for some giveaway lettering on the side, the big squat plane looks conventional enough to pass for just another propeller airliner on a congested airport tarmac.
LONDON, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Plymouth and Barnsley played to a scoreless draw in their English Third Division soccer game in Plymouth. It was the only league game played in Britain today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
The American Stock Exchange marched to new high ground yesterday. Its index rose to $30.16, up 20 cents from the close on Friday, setting a record.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- A group of 134 House Republicans urged today swift action on Congressional and election reform bills to counter "broad currents of unrest running across the land."

William A. Andres, chairman of the board of Dayton's Department Stores, a division of the Dayton Corporation, has been named senior vice president of the Dayton Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON. Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Ken McMullen singled with one out in the 14th inning tonight to give the Washington Senators a 6-5 victory and end the Boston Red Sox's five-game streak.

Show Off, running in the silks of Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, and Dihela, owned by Alfred Giordano, won a division each of the Astarita at Belmont Park yesterday. Show Off registered the more decisive success, scoring by three lengths, but Dihela contributed the more thrilling performance in beating the favored Imbibe by a length.
THE Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League began its 1968-69 season last week, with an entry of 15 teams, split into three divisions instead of two as in former years.

Danish cuisine, gifts and hosts will be in evidence Monday at the Plaza during a Denmark Luncheon that will benefit the New York Philharmonic. Consul General G. F. K. Harhoff of the Royal Danish Consulate and Mrs. Harhoff are the hosts and Victor Borge, the pianist and comedian, will preside.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 -- Vice President Humphrey has received the endorsement of 87.8 per cent of the leadership of the United Automobile Workers, with George C. Wallace receiving 10.2 per cent and Richard M. Nixon 1 per cent.

MANILA, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Philippines announced today that British and Australian ships would not be permitted to pass through Philippine waters without obtaining permission. The decision, apparently was in retaliation against Britain's announcement last week that she was supporting Malaysia in the dispute over Sabah.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (AP) -The Soviet Union launched the 243d satellite in its Cosmos series today. Tass, the Soviet press agency, said the satellite carried equipment for space study and that all instruments were working normally.

ONE of the liveliest programs of the sixth congress of the International Music Council, which took place recently in New York and Washington, dealt with the difficult and challenging problem of "communication of music through television and film."
LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Britain is prepared to cooperate in an attempt to airlift food and relief supplies to the Biafrans, a Commonwealth officer said here today.
The city's Council Against Poverty yesterday called a rally for 7:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Manhattan Center to demand an "action program" to end the teachers strike.
LISBON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar remained in a coma today, breathing with the aid of a machine on the seventh day after a massive stroke.

The election of James N. Land Jr. and Nicholas H. Witte as senior vice presidents and members of the executive committee of the First Boston Corporation was announced yesterday. They also are directors of the company.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The State Department said today that Secretary of State Dean Rusk would meet with foreign ministers of the NATO countries in New York Oct. 7 for informal talks on the Czechoslovak occupation.
PARIS, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -Thirty persons, some of them students, were evicted today for the second time in 24 hours after occupying part of Paris University's arts college in suburban Nanterre.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The new Czechoslovak representative, Zdenex Cernik, presented his credentials to Secretary General Thant today. He replaces Milan Klusak, who was recalled before the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
DELHI, N. Y., Sept. 23 -- Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic Senatorial candidate, urged tonight that the United States develop a volunteer army rather than continue the draft.

MANILA, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The title fight between the world flyweight champion, Chartchai Chionoi of Thailand, and Bernabe Villacampo of the Philippines today was set for Oct. 31 in Bangkok. Chionoi's title is recognized by the World Boxing Association.

Charles Roeslin, a 45-yearold Queens postal clerk, was killed early yesterday morning when the small foreign car he was driving was in collision with a bus owned by Jamaica Buses, Inc., a block from his home at 189th Street, Jamaica avenue, Hollis.
Following is a summary of how the issues developed in the city's school crisis:

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Sept. 22 (UPI) -- An explosion shattered a bar here today and set off a fire that caused $250,000 damage. The blast ripped apart the Veranda lounge at 5 A.M. The ensuing fire damaged a restaurant, a liquor store and a gift shop and destroyed an abandoned hotel.

Autumn was a dream of things to come in New York yesterday, a fur-collared coat in a Fifth Avenue shop window, a gold and red branch decorating the Waldorf-Astoria doorway -- but at 4 P.M. the mercury stood at 83 degrees, probably.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The United States Chamber of Commerce reported today that nearly 27 per cent of company payrolls were being paid out in employe benefits, an average of $33 a worker a week.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (AP) -Increases in the price of The Atlanta Journal. The Atlanta Constitution and the combined Sunday edition of the newspapers have been announced by Atlanta Newspapers, Inc. The seven - day price will be 75 cents, plus 3 cents tax, up from 65 cents.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Representative F. Edward Hebert, Democrat of Louisiana, says Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court had caused "irreparable mischief" by ordering a stay of Vietnam orders for a group of reservists.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Sept. 23 (AP) -- The chancellor of the State University of New York tonight envisioned "days of intellectual repression on our campuses as the mood of the American people grows more conservative and fearful."

BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Hearst-owned Baltimore News American missed two editions today because of picketing by striking employes of a radio-television station that also is part of the Hearst organization.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23 -Richard M. Nixon told several hundred campaign workers on his arrival here tonight that "the United States cannot afford Hubert Humphrey as President of the United States."

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 (AP) -- An inmate waved to a handful of people outside the prison walls today, then climbed down from the boilerhouse roof at Western State Penitentiary, ending a two-day demonstration against prison conditions.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The Air Force announced today plans to train 450 more pilots a year by establishing a new pilot school at Columbus Air Force Base, Miss., next summer. It will be the 10th undergraduate pilot training school for the Air Force.
The Eastman Kodak Company, in an unusual move yesterday, sold the assets of 36 stores serving the professional trade to a group of former managers.
Paper is being turned out at an astronomical rate in the United States and Canada by bigger and faster machines, larger than a rootball field, are on the way.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Colombian authorities today identified as Castro sympathizers the two men who diverted two Avianca airliners to Cuba yesterday.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Television of the Minnesota Vikings-Green Bay Packers game yesterday cut sharply into the attendance for the Canadian Football League game between Winnipeg and Edmonton, the Winnipeg general manager charged today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 23 (UP) -- The San Francisco Giants drew less than a million at home this season for the first time since they moved West after the 1957 campaign.

Bruno Sammartino defeated Rocky Fitzpatrick last night before 8,047 fans in the feature heavyweight wrestling event at Madison Square Garden. Fitzpatrick of Carson City, Nev., was billed as the Rocky Mountain champion.

El Morocco was fined $1,000 by the State Liquor Authority yesterday for subletting one of its rooms last spring to serve as "Eugene's," a discotheque operated on behalf of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's campaign for the Democratic presidential nomination.
New York City guaranteed disaster by taking a piecemeal approach to school decentralization, according to the director of the Center for Urban Education.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 23 (AP) The Baltimore Clippers announced today that four Detroit Red Wing players had been assigned to the American Hockey League club.

ATLANTA, Sept. 23 (UPI) -Alan Howard of Davenport, Iowa, took the lead today with a par 72 in qualifying for the 14th annual United States Golf Association seniors' championship at the Atlanta Country Club.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 23 -- At least 40 people were wounded in an exchange of gunfire late tonight between the police and students.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 23 -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived here this morning to begin a three-week tour of South America and the Caribbean.
A woman tried yesterday to lower the Czechoslovak flag, one of the 125 national banners on display at Rockefeller Center, but a security man stopped her before she could pull the rope.

TORONTO, Sept. 23 -- The Ontario Securities Commission cut deeply today into the maximum profits underwriters may take when they sell mining stocks to the public outside a stock exchange. In so doing, the commission adopted one of several recommendations in a report on mining financing issued today by David S. Beatty, one of the part-time members of the six-seat commission.

HOUSTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -Bo Hagan, the Rice football coach, still simmering over the disputed University of Washington -Rice 35-35 deadlock Saturday in Seattle, said game films confirmed his charges of unfair officiating and clock manipulation.

The American Ballet Theater announced plans yesterday for a four-week, 16-ballet Christmas season, including its new productions of "Giselle" and "Swan Lake," at the revamped Opera House of the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
Wheat futures turned in a dramatic performance yesterday. At the opening, all contracts registered new life-ofcontract lows, continuing last week's trend.
The Bronx, Flatbush and Queens chapters of the Kidney Foundation of New York will have their night at the races Friday at Yonkers Raceway.

General Motors has re-enacted the steel price scenario by posting price increases for its new models well below those proposed by Chrysler. Since G.M. accounts for about half the nation's auto production, it calls the pricing tune -- just as U.S. Steel did in steel. Chrysler will have to curb its appetite for higher prices, and the other auto makers, who had been delaying their price decisions, will undoubtedly follow G.M.'s lead.

AN agreement intended to prevent further contamination of Lake Michigan by DDT and other long-lived pesticides has been signed by representatives of the conservation and resources agencies of Michigan, Indiana, Illinois and Wisconsin.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 21 -- On Aug. 30, the feast day of St. Rose, the Most Rev. Luis Barbaren Gastelumendi, auxiliary bishop of this archdiocese, celebrated in the gilded cathedral the high mass that precedes the processional emergence each year of the statue of Lima's patron.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 23 -- George C. Wallace said today that he would announce his choice as a Vice-Presidential running mate by next Monday and that "it's going to come as a real surprise."
A Columbia Broadcasting System state-by-state survey released last night found that if the election were held now, Richard M. Nixon would win in a landslide, and George C. Wallace would be second.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 23 -- The Food Minister, Jagjivan Ram, said today that uneven monsoon rains had resulted in serious drought conditions in 6 of India's 17 states.
GLASGOW, Ky., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Luska J. Twyman, 54 years old, became last night the first Negro Mayor of a Kentucky city.

CAPE KENNEDY, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Air Force today postponed for at least two days the launching of four satellites that had been set for early tomorrow. The delay was caused by a suspected problem with one of the spacecraft mounted on the top stage of the triplebarreled Titan 3C rocket.
Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo yesterday certified the names of candidates who will be on the ballot in New York State in the Nov. 5 election.
Some members of the Long Island University's board of trustees will attempt next Monday to remove Dr. R. Gordon Hoxie as chancellor at a special meeting called to consider his future.

ALSDORF, West Germany, Sept. 23 -- A West German embryologist said today that it was "absolutely sure," from the embryological point of view, that the drug thalidomide had not been the cause of deformities in babies.

LONDON, Sept. 23 -- Britons can expect less-expensive cigarettes as the result of an announcement today that major tobacco manufacturers were dropping plans to fight a Government ban on fair-trade prices, or what the British call resale price maintenance.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 -- Israeli military officials said today that an Egyptian force, probably a small commando unit, crossed the Suez Canal last night and attacked an Israeli vehicle, wounding one soldier.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 23 -Some Wall Street analysts, Cassandra-like, have been prophesying middleaged spread for Xerox, whose stock is still in its infancy as a hot issue on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company has fired the first salvo in what is expected to become a barrage of litigation involving the interpretation of the disclosure sections of the Federal securities laws.

CHICAGO, Sept. 23 -- William G. Clark, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, accused President Johnson today of using "wheel and deal" methods in an effort to "ram through" his nomination of Justice Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Hal Greer, seasoned guard of the Philadelphia 76ers of the National Basketball Association, was assured today that his right knee is perfectly sound.

The Grambling-Morgan State football game at Yankee Stadium Saturday, created because of the Football Coaches Foundation's concern over "the American dilemma of dropouts" is bound to be a big success in raising money for scholarship aid.
JACQUES KAPLAN'S plan to make leopard and cheetah unfashionable has brought him warm commendations from naturalists but somewhat mixed reactions from furriers.

Today presents a fateful opportunity for the warring forces in the city school system to take realistic stock of their positions and recognize their obligation to accord priority to the educational needs of a million children, now locked out of their classrooms. Rationality, not muscle, must provide the key for reopening the schools tomorrow.
Prices of industrial issues declined in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Many of the Democrats in Congress who have been critics of the Vietnam war have sought the assistance of Senators Edward M. Kennedy and Eugene J. McCarthy in their campaigns for re-election.
WHITE PLAINS, Sept. 23 -Dissident Democrats in Westchester County, running on their own peace plank, have challenged the regular party organization to an electionyear showdown.
VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 23 -- Dr. Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System, defended today the television industry's coverage of the Democratic National Convention last month.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 23 (AP) -- Ad Majora carried the Briardale Farm silks to a convincing six-length victory today in the 17th running of the Home Bred Handicap here before a crowd of 13,764.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 23 -- Air Marshal Nur Khan, commander in chief of Pakistan's Air Force, will leave here Thursday for goodwill visits to the United States and Great Britain, it was announced today.
RICHMOND, Sept. 23 (AP) -Forty-three more Army reservists at Fort Lee, Va., sought today Federal court intervention barring the Army from transferring them to Vietnam.

DETROIT, Sept. 23 (AP) -Several thousand Detroit Tiger baseball fans created a traffic jam round the city's main downtown post office just before midnight yesterday. They gathered eagerly, but in vain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- The Republican women's "voteswagon," a big specially equipped bus, was christened today by the Senate Republican leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, and sent off with 17 persons and two dogs on a 17-state votegetting tour.

President Johnson had persuaded the Soviet leaders to agree to a specific agenda for a summit conference that was to have been announced the same day five Warsaw Pact armies invaded Czechoslovakia, according to Dr. John P. Roche, until recently a special consultant to the President.

Dr. Nicholaas Diederichs, the Finance Minister of South Africa, called once more last night for an increase in the price of gold as a means to strengthen its role in safeguarding international liquidity.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Emil E. Narick, candidate for the presidency of the 1.2-millionmember United Steelworkers of America, said today that he had been transferred from the post of assistant general counsel of the union to staff representative in the union's research department.

A special Board of Education committee and the governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville Demonstration School District met for three hours last night but made little headway toward ending the teachers strike.

VIENNA, Sept. 23 -- The Roman Catholic bishops of Austria said in a joint statement today that married Catholics who were limiting the number of their children "for ethical reasons" dictated by their own conscience would be admitted to Holy Communion without having to confess their practice of birth control as a sin.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 23 -- Jerry Rubin and Thomas Hayden were served subpoenas today requiring their appearance before the House Committee on Un-American Activities in Washington on Oct. 1. Each of them burned his subpoena.

EXCEPT for the novelty of seeing racial hostility made explicit in a television program, the American Broadcasting Company's new Western series, "The Outcasts," is little more than a routine oatburner out of the old Republic studio stables.
NEWARK, Sept. 23 -- Sixty employes of the Essex County Welfare Board were sent home from work today when a sit-in of welfare recipients blocked access to the board's offices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -- The Senate Preparedness Subcommittee recommended strongly today a continuing expansion and improvement of the nation's nuclear submarine fleet to meet the "serious challenge" posed by the growing number of Soviet nuclear submarines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Dean Krister Stendall of the Harvard Divinity School met today with the full faculty and then with top-level faculty members and advisers about a young marine veteran of the Vietnam war who is seeking sanctuary in a university chapel.
A suspect was arrested yesterday in a Bellevue Hospital bed as one of two men who held up S. Klein's department store on Union Square Aug. 20 and escaped with $11,600.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 (AP) -- The House was forced to adjourn for lack of a quorum today.
The election of Ira D. Daly, a partner in Lehman Brothers, to the board of the United States Life Insurance Company was announced yesterday.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- The Soviet Union charged today that local Czechoslovak officials were aggravating relations between the population and the soldiers of the five occupying armies.
VIENNA, Sept. 23 -- The occupation of Czechoslovakia and other Soviet-bloc military activities appear to have jolted Albania out of her long isolation.

Stockholders of Pickwick International, Inc., a leading economy-priced record merchandiser, voted at their annual meeting here yesterday to approve the previously announced merger of Heilicher Brothers, Inc., Minneapolis, a record merchandising concern, into Pickwick. Seymour Leslie, chairman and president, told the meeting, that the combined earnings and sales of both companies brought earnings for Pickwick in the quarter to July 31 to 23 cents a share from 14 cents, in the 1967 period.
The Ocean Hill-Brownsville governing board has adopted a plan for community school control that it hopes will serve as a model for the city.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 23 (AP) -The St. Louis Cardinals dipped into a pile of mailbags filled with World Series ticket requests today and the first letter to come up was from Edward Escobedo of Belleville, Ill.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y., Sept. 23 (UPI) -- Dan Gurney, Jack Brabham and John Surtees today joined the field for the $105,900 Grand Prix of the United States at the Watkins Glen circuit Oct. 6. All three will compete for world title road racing points, Gurney in a McLaren-Ford V-8, Surtees in a V-12 Honda, and Brabham in a Renco V-8.

WARSAW, Sept. 23 -- Poland's orthodox Communist regime expressed increasing impatience today with what it termed Czechoslovak half measures and foot dragging and warned of an impending impasse unless Prague undertook concrete political steps to implement the recent Moscow accords.

ALBANY, Sept. 23 (UPI) -Total August employment of 7,940,000 in New York State was the highest for any month on record, Industrial Commissioner M. P. Catherwood announced today. The August unemployment for the state was 270,000, or 3.3 per cent, equaling the lowest unemployment rate on record.
The Navy has selected a design by the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation for its first Deep Submergence Search Vehicle, a member of a family of deep-diving craft planned by the Navy.

Steve Mizerak Jr. of Perth Amboy, N. J., suffered his first defeat in the $15,000 Empire Billiard Association pocket billiards tournament yesterday when he lost to Dan Gartner of New York, 150-93, at the Hotel Commodore.

PRAGUE, Sept. 23 -- Official sources said today that the Soviet Union would withdraw 20 army divisions from Czechoslovakia by Oct. 28, the 50th anniversary of this republic, and ultimately leave behind six to eight divisions.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 23 -- An adviser to King Hussein says that the Jordanian Government is urgently seeking a political settlement of the Palestine issue out of fear that otherwise there will be a military showdown with Israel.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -The Senate rejected today a move aimed at easing President Johnson's budget-cutting problem by about $1-billion.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 23 (AP) -- An entire Australian soccer team from Macedonia and two club officials were barred from the sport for life today after a referee claimed he was attacked on the field in a game played last week.

The city's organized relief recipients are planning a rent revolt in which they would hold back from landlords the rent money provided them in welfare checks and use it instead for clothing, food and household furnishings.
MOSCOW, Sept. 23 -- The Soviet Union charged today that local Czechoslovak officials were aggravating relations between the population and the soldiers of the five occupying armies.
VIENNA, Sept. 23 -- The occupation of Czechoslovakia and other Soviet-bloc military activities appear to have jolted Albania out of her long isolation.

Stockholders of Pickwick International, Inc., a leading economy-priced record merchandiser, voted at their annual meeting here yesterday to approve the previously announced merger of Heilicher Brothers, Inc., Minneapolis, a record merchandising concern, into Pickwick. Seymour Leslie, chairman and president, told the meeting, that the combined earnings and sales of both companies brought earnings for Pickwick in the quarter to July 31 to 23 cents a share from 14 cents, in the 1967 period.

ABU SIMBEL, United Arab Republic, Sept. 23 -- The 3,200-year-old twin temples of Pharoah Ramses II and his wife, Queen Neferati, were dedicated yesterday in a colorful ceremony, marking the completion of a four-year, $36-million salvage task.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 -Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for immediate United Nations action to send food and other supplies to starving thousands in Biafra.

A 550-gallon steel tank filled with lacquer exploded at 11:15 A.M. yesterday as it was being transported by truck on the elevated Gowanus Expressway at 24th Street, in the Bush Terminal section of Brooklyn. The driver of the 40-foot aluminum truck-trailer, Donald E. Davidson of Millington, N, ,1., was:not !njured.

The commander of the United States Navy vessel Pueblo has been quoted as saying that she "was an intelligence-gathering" ship "operating under the cover of an oceanographic researching ship" when captured by the North Koreans last Jan. 23.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The National Safety Council named Toledo, Ohio, and Lansing, Mich., today as cities with the best accident-prevention efforts in 1967. Toledo will receive an award for cities of more than 350,000 population and Lansing for smaller cities.

PRAGUE, Sept. 24 -- Czechoslovak-Soviet relations have hit another major snag and the leadership of the Czechoslovak Communist party is to meet tomorrow to consider whether and how to conduct new talks with Moscow.

The American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in net income for the 12 and eight months ended Aug. 31 and for the month of August. Donald C. Cook, president, placed net income for the 12 months at $93,378,000, or 7.4 per cent higher than the $91,567,000 reported a year earlier.
The United States Steel Corporation said yesterday it was considering the possibility of establishing a plant in the European Economic Community to manufacture products for the building industry.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The head of the Independent Bankers Association told a Congressional committee today that the Federal Reserve Board should have asked for new legislation, rather than merely making a ruling that the banks it regulates may open "loan-production offices" anywhere in the country.

Bache Co., Inc., announced yesterday that Michael V. Caggiano, Ronald S. Platt and Max Schonholz have been named voting stockholders of the investment firm. As such, they have been admitted as allied members of the New York Stock Exchange.
IF your're counting explosions -- cultural, population or other -- include the museum explosion.

LAUREL, Sept. 24 Md., (AP) -- Mrs. Edith W. Bancroft's Damascus, Horse of the Year in 1967 with 12 victories in 16 starts, was named today to run in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International Nov. 11.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 95.1 on Monday from 94.8 on Friday.

Richard Nixon is beginning to think and talk cautiously about his approach to the problems of the Presidency, and his approach, particularly in the field of foreign affairs, is both interesting and highly personal.
Intensive negotiations between the city and the major uniformed services began yesterday in an effort to reach a contract settlement before next Monday's deadline.
The New York Stock Exchange reported that customers' margin debt to its member firms declined by $120-million in August to $6.39-billion, the lowest level since March, when it was $6.19-billion.
OFFUTT AIR FORCE BASE, Neb., Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The Strategic Air Command tonight listed airmen from Queens and Connecticut as among those killed in the crash.
The following dispatch was written for The New York Times by Marvine Howe.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- The new President of the General Assembly appealed today to the members of the United Nations to banish doubt and skepticism about the organization. Emilio Arenales Catalan, the Foreign Minister of Guatemala, was elected President by the Assembly today and presided over the first meeting of its 23d session.

The National Jewish Hospital and Research Center at Denver will benefit from a "Night at the Races" tomorrow at Yonkers Raceway. Miss Joan Wolf is chairman for the party sponsored by women volunteers of the New York junior division of the hospital.

The Judicial Conference of the United States, chief arbiter of conduct in all Federal courts, has made a notable contribution to establishing a more secure balance between the constitutional guarantees of fair trial and free press.
You are traveling down a superhighway behind the wheel of a heavily laden vehicle. A sign, "Hill," flashes by, but there is no indication whether it is an upgrade or downgrade.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The acting head of the space agency said today that a preoccupation with being first in space could cause the United States to lose its lead in conventional air travel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, in an unexpected maneuver, moved tonight that the Senate take up President Johnson's nomination of Associate Justice Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States.
LONDON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The authoritative Jane's Fighting Ships suggests that the Soviet Navy may have switched to a defensive rather than an aggressive role.

YONKERS, Sept. 24 -- About 59 owners, trainers and drivers will fly to Rochester, N. Y., tomorrow morning. There, upon the landing of the American Airlines Flight 413, which is scheduled to depart from La Guardia Field at 8:45 A.M., the contingent will be transported by bus to four breeding farms in the rich grazing land that is the Geneseo Valley.
The election of M. F. Wirges, 43 years old, as vice president for research and corporate planning of the Cities Service Company was announced yesterday.
If racing's "Presidential" election were held today, Dr. Fager probably would defeat Damascus in the voting for Horse of the Year.
SEATTLE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A 16-year-old high school youth, Al Sabado, died today of head injuries reportedly suffered in football practice at Cleveland High School.

MONTEVIDEO, Sept. 24 -- The Government of Uruguay, which has been trying for the last three months to suppress a nearly continuous wave of strikes and street violence, today ordered the expulsion of three officials of the Soviet Embassy here.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- President Johnson announced here today that he had directed Under Secretary of Labor James J. Reynolds to enter the stalled New York longshore industry contract talks.

In calling for the reinstatement of a teacher at Far Rockaway High School who declined to lead his class in the pledge of allegiance to the flag, the trial examiner, Bethuel M. Webster, has helped to clarify the nature of patriotism itself for students.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Chief Justice Earl Warren denied today a request by 43 Army reservists from New York to delay their impending departure from Vietnam until the Supreme Court decides the legality of their call to active duty.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- A bank robber was chased by a Nassau County police car and helicopter today and seized in Queens after a 15-mile chase along congested highways at up to 90 miles an hour.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 24, (Reuters) -- Israeli security forces have discovered three arms caches in the Hebron region and arrested several persons, it was announced today.
"How can we hope to develop effective traffic safety programs when the experts cannot even agree on the causes of accidents?"

Leonard C. Hobert, who was recently appointed president of the Milwaukee division of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., has been elected a vice president and director of Gimbel Brothers, it was announced yesterday.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 24 -- It was near dawn when a strange male voice called over the police dispatcher's radio: "Hello, City Hall. Hello, City Hall."

James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the Senate, charged yesterday that "the Johnson Administration's disastrous cutbacks in weapon development and space research are already coming to haunt us."

DENVER, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A Denver County judge, George Manerbino, dismissed charges today against 23 suspended students who took part in a sit-in demonstration last spring at the University of Denver.

Philip W. Scott, president of the Budd Company, announced yesterday that 1968 was expected to be a "darn good year for the company" even though the company expects a net loss of $750,000 for the quarter ended Sept. 30.
The Monsanto Company said yesterday it expected third-quarter earnings to improve by about 35 per cent, and sales by about 10 per cent from last year's corresponding quarter.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Sept. 24 -- Mrs. Cutting Cushing, Meadow Brook, the medalist in the Women's Long Island Golf Association match play championship, won her first-round match today by defeating Mrs. Karl Clement, Nassau, 3 and 2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle re jected today an appeal by leaders of the National Federation of Priests' Councils for arbitrations of his dispute with 44 priests in the Washington Archdiocese over the birth control issue.

Fred Halstead, Presidential candidate of the Trotskyite Socialist Workers party, said yesterday that the moral climate among American troops in South Vietnam, Japan and at home was ripening for a major antiwar movement in the armed forces.
HELSINKI, Finland, Sept. 24 -- The Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia has made the Finns more determined than ever to stick to their policies of neutrality and friendly relations with Moscow.
Persistent selling, most of it stemming from profit taking, pushed prices down over a broad range on the London stock market yesterday.
The election of Talbot Shelton as a director of the United Nuclear Corporation was announced yesterday. He is a vice president of Smith Barney Co., Inc.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The Navy announced today that it would reduce civilian employment at its 15 research facilities by 2,390 -- or 10 per cent -- as a part of the Pentagon's economy drive.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 23 -- A wonderful thing happened to the campaign of Richard M. Nixon last Saturday when his motorcade stopped for lunch at the George Washington Hotel in Valley Forge, Pa. There, where Washington's ragged army starved in the winter of 177778, there was not enough food for the press and campaign staff.

SANTA FE, N. M., Sept. 23 -- The Republican candidate for Governor this fall in New Mexico is an "Anglo" with a Spanish-American wife and has considerable support among the poor in the Spanish community.

The Pan American Petroleum Corporation and the Consumers Gas Company of Ontario said yesterday that exploratory wells drilled in Lake Erie had encountered oil and gas producing formations. Pan American, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), said much testing would be required before reserves could be evaluated.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Sept. 25 -- American B-52 jets flew five heavy bombing missions yesterday in Tayninh Province, northwest of Saigon, amid growing rumors that the capital would come under attack again.
The New York Yankees and Cleveland Indians split a double-header at Yankee Stadium last night, which was all right with the Indians but not so good for the Yankees.

When Grambling College, which produced Tank Younger, Willie Davis, Ernie Ladd, Willie Young and Buck Buchanan, takes the field Saturday at Yankee Stadium to play football against Morgan State College, which produced Roosevelt Brown, Leroy Kelley, Daryl Johnson and Willie Lanier, it will be a "dream" game in more ways than one.
The Chase Manhattan Bank, the nation's largest lender to business, yesterday reduced its prime rate -- its minimum charge on business loans -- to 6 per cent from 6 1/2 per cent, effective today.

KINGSTON, Jamaica, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Prime Minister Hugh Shearer has announced that extensive repairs and improvements will be made to Montego Bay's international airport Oct. 14 to Nov. 10, but that normal traffic will be affected for only one of the four weeks.

More than half the voters polled recently by the Louis Harris organization said they would rather see someone other than Richard M. Nixon, Hubert H. Humphrey or George C. Wallace become President next year.
The board of directors of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway Company designated John S. Reed yesterday as chief executive officer, effective Oct. 1. Mr. Reed is president of the carrier.

"Give a Damn" is the provocative slogan adopted by the Urban Coalition to try to jolt affluent Americans into active concern for the impoverished minority of their countrymen who are trapped in city slums.
DENVER, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Denver Broncos of the American Football League today put Bob Humphreys, a place kicker, on waivers. Dave Washington, an end, was placed on the injured waiver list.
The head of the teachers' union said last night that the city had offered to provide "massive police protection" if striking teachers would return to schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district.
LONDON, Sept. 24 -- The Roman Catholic bishops of England and Wales took a mild line today in a letter of advice to their flock on the papal encyclical forbidding contraception.

WAKE ISLAND, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- An Air Force jet tanker, attempting to land with at least one of its engines out, crashed today as it reached the runway. Eleven persons were killed, 23 injured and 22 others aboard were unhurt.

YORK, Pa., Sept. 24 (AP) -Mayor John L. Snyder imposed a 10 P.M.-to-6 A.M. curfew on the city tonight to control the congregating of street gangs that have terrorized the citizenry. The curfew was put in effect for the second straight night, but businesses were allowed to remain open as they were last night.
THE VERY THING, a small antiques and objects shop that opens today at 149 East 72d Street, is the enterprise of two antiques buffs who decided to go professional.

EVERYTHING is coming out in the right places in the newest collections on Seventh Avenue. Hemlines have ceased their migration and are hovering above the knees. Waistlines are definitely out in the open and bright, cheerful colors are replacing the gloom of fall.
Bob Gibson, St. Louis Cardinal pitching ace, was named winner yesterday of the August poll of the competition for the S. Rae Hickok Professional Athlete of the Year award.
Yesterday's high temperature in Central Park was 81 degrees at 2:05 P.M. -- and that's for sure. The low was 69 degrees at 7:30 A.M. -- but that's not so sure.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Arthur Ashe, the United States Open champion, was forced to withdraw from the Pacific Coast international tennis championship today because of a pinched nerve in his neck.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A dozen Negro prisoners still control one section of the Longbinh stockade, where one man was killed in racial rioting last month.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 24 -- Assembly Speaker Jesse M. Unruh, who headed Senator Robert F. Kennedy's California Presidential primary last spring, said today that he would support the Humphrey-Muskie ticket "with no reluctance."

A brief but wild battle broke out last night opposite Henry Miller's Theater off Times Square between anti-Castro Cuban pickets and policemen after the closing curtain of Jack Gelber's play "The Cuban Thing."

The opening last night of "Plaza 9 and All That Jazz," the new room at the Plaza Hotel, attracted patrons from the society and entertainment worlds.

Notre Dame and Purdue shared top billing in the college football polls yesterday. But the deadlock may not last beyond Saturday, when they meet at South Bend, Ind., in a game that will cast a long shadow toward the national championship.
The Air Force ordered a temporary halt to all F-111 flights yesterday after a crash Monday at a base in Las Vegas.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- A young Marine, absent without leave, who was arrested today after claiming sanctuary in a chapel in protest to the Vietnam war, labeled his action a "mistake" and urged other servicemen to go through "channels" if they must protest.

CHICAGO, Sept. 24 (AP) -President Avery Brundage of the International Olympic Committee said today that Mexican Olympic officials had assured him that the situation in Mexico City was being controlled and that the 19th Olympiad would be held as scheduled.
The Police Department is investigating a delay of one to two years in the distribution of more than $11,000 owed to nearly 2,000 new members of the force.
ATLANTA, Sept. 24 -- Jerry Koosman will have to settle for the distinction as the Mets' biggest winner, not their first 20-game winner. At least not this year.

LISBON, Sept. 24 -- The Portuguese opposition, which has been silent since Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar was stricken eight days ago with a massive cerebral hemorrhage, issued a call today for elections and the restoration of civil liberties.
KOSICE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 24 -- Soviet troops have taken over a number of Czechoslovak army barracks and public buildings in this East Slovak city.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- White House, Pentagon and Congressional sources said today that they had heard nothing of any plans for reducing United States forces in Vietnam in the near future.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -Two House members from Queens proposed today the creation of a Federal-New York aviation authority to replace the Port of New York Author ity in the aviation field.

The police crackdown on games of chance in a Roman Catholic churchyard at the Feast of San Gennaro in New York's Little Italy was denounced yesterday by a nationwide American-Italian organization.

ROZVADOV, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 24 -- In this heavily forested land, where the pines of Bohemia merge into the pines of Bavaria, there is an immense presence of Soviet power that is felt, but rarely seen.

MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- An American girl and a British youth were arrested and detained for several hours this evening as they scattered leaflets condemning the invasion of Czechoslovakia among crowds of Russians.
Jack I. Straus, for 30 years the chief executive officer of R. H. Macy Co. and one of the nation's leading retailers, relinquished yesterday his position as chairman of the department store chain.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 24 -- Richard M. Nixon leads his two Presidential rivals, Hubert H. Humphrey and George C. Wallace, in charisma, according to the Gallup Poll.

DESPITE weak denials to the contrary, everyone assumes that Denny McLain, a hero-worshipper at heart, fed a nice, fat pitch to his boyhood idol, Mickey Mantle, late in a game at Detroit last Thursday. The Mick gratefully hit it into the seats for the home run that lifted him past Jimmy Foxx to third place behind Babe Ruth and Willie Mays in the career list.

CASH-HEAVY United Fruit Company watched in dismay yesterday as a leading Wall Street brokerage house stacked up several big blocks of United Fruit's stock for one of the biggest trades in stock exchange history.
The teachers' union charged yesterday that a rally being staged by the city's Council Against Poverty tonight represented "strikebreaking activity" with the use of public funds.

The election of Dr. Willard M. Bright, 54 years old, as president of the professional products group of the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Company, was announced yesterday. He formerly was vice president and a member of the board of the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 24 -- Five persons were injured tonight as bands of Negro youths hurled rocks and bottles at automobiles passing through the predominantly low-income South Side. It was the third consecutive night of disorders in the area.
Two of the country's leading boarding schools -- one for boys, the other for girls -- have agreed to merge.

SEATTLE, Sept. 24 -- Richard M. Nixon began to toughen his charges and sharpen his language against Vice President Humphrey today as he took his campaign from the Middle West into the Mountain States and on to the Pacific.

DENVER, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Joseph S. Minnis, leader of Colorado's 45,000 Episcopalians, was stripped of his ecclesiastical authority and banished from the state today by a church court that heard charges that he had breached his ordination vows.
IVY League football coaches like to say that the only games that count are the ones within the hallowed halls of Ivy. It is only half true.

FRANKFURT. West Germany, Sept. 24 -- A number of liberal Czechoslovak writers who have been outside their homeland since the Soviet invasion in August are quietly debating whether to return and carry on the struggle for intellectual freedom they won under the regime of Alexander Dubcek.
The appointment of Dr. D. Barry Davis as vice president for commercial development of E. R. Squibb Sons, Inc., was announced yesterday. Martin Schmidt was named vice president for administration.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 24 -More than 2,000 students voted unanimously tonight to demand that Eldridge Cleaver be allowed to give his full series of 10 racism lectures this fall at the University of California.
The University Computing Company reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire the Gulf Insurance Company through an exchange of stock worth more than $190million.

THE Supreme Court of Canada recently upheld, by a four-to-one majority, a conviction against the proprietors of a Toronto bridge club for keeping a common gaming house. In contradiction to several United States rulings, the jurists decided that bridge is a game of mixed chance and skill, and therefore contrary to the Canadian criminal code relating to gaming and betting houses.

MISTER JACK, as everybody at Macy's calls Jack Isidor Straus, has stepped down as chief executive. But although he will no longer be the chief, Mr. Straus intends to set a pace designed to keep him active in the 13th-floor Herald Square executive suite he has occupied for 30 years.
THERE was more excitement outside Henry Miller's Theater last night than inside when Jack Gelber's play "The Cuban Thing" opened to the vociferous displeasure of anti-Castro demonstrators.

Earnings in excess of $50-million, or between $2.85 and $2.90 a share, for the fiscal year ended July 31, are expected by Distillers Corporation-Seagrams, Ltd., Edgar M. Bronfman, vice president and treasurer, said yesterday.

A 20 per cent income tax surcharge and a 50 per cent increase in the sales tax to 3 per cent are among the possibilities being studied to cover a projected $700-million deficit in the state budget for next fiscal year.

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Professional Golfers' Association obtained a temporary restraining order in United States District Court here today in a move to balk the independence plans of the rebel American Professional Golfers.

An air traffic controllers' union said last night that the head of the Federal Aviation Administration would come to New York tomorrow to meet with controllers at Kennedy International Airport who have urged that the present radar system be abandoned.

A group of about 300 Hasidic Jews who had just come from synagogues in Brooklyn's Williamsburg section engaged in a bottle-throwing melee with about 100 Puerto Ricans last night. The cause of the incident could not be established.
DENVER, Sept. 24 -- While United States swimmers prepare for a record gold medal assault in Mexico City, another group of American aquatic athletes may provide the surprise of the 1968 Olympic games.

RED HOOK, N. Y. -- A tangled orchard ends behind a row of split-level ranch houses here, the weary branches of old apple trees -- bent these September days with plump red fruit -- hanging over manicured lawns.

Seven of the city's largest auto and truck rental companies filed suit yesterday in State Supreme Court to void a recent ordinance that would make them liable for parking violations committed by their customers.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Sept. 24 (AP) -- The New York State Publishers Association today elected as its president Peter Corson, publisher of The Lockport Union-Sun Journal. He was elected at the final session of the group's 47th annual meeting, to succeed A. Gordon Bennett of The Buffalo Courier-Express.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A group of protesters against the Vietnam war broke into a Selective Service office shortly after it closed today, seized bags full of records and set them afire in a tiny park across the street, the police said.

James Bonn, a pianist who teaches at the University of Kentucky, gave a recital at Town Hall last night that shows he is happiest with music that is busy, quick-moving and complex.
Gould Properties, Inc., has announced the appointment of Joseph A. Amato as a vice president in charge of administration and management of properties.
JERSEY CITY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- A 23-year-old Black Panther leader, Isiah Rowley, and two followers were arrested here today in an altercation that sent five policemen to a hospital for treatment.

SEATTLE, Sept. 24 (UPI) -Al Sabado Jr., a 16-year-old football player at Cleveland High School, died today of injuries suffered during a practice session. School officials said Sabado, a back, collapsed on the practice field two weeks ago after suffering a head injury in a light contact drill.

LONDON, Sept. 24 -- Simultaneous demonstrations were mounted in Warsaw, Budapest and Sofia by the War Resisters' International. The organization's headquarters here reported that all the demonstrators had been arrested.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- England canceled today a scheduled cricket tour of South Africa after the South African Premier, John Vorster, refused to permit a colored player on the team to enter the country.

BOSTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Boston Patriots today placed Art Graham, an end, on the American Football League's injured waiver list.
A reorganization of Waltham Precision Instruments, Inc., Waltham, Mass., was announced yesterday by Frederick C. Rieck, president and chief executive officer.

BISMARCK, N. D., Sept. 24 -- Richard M. Nixon and his political team are pleased with the initial evidence that Governor Rockefeller's party organization is determined to carry New York State for the national ticket.

The Coburn Corporation of America announced yesterday it had acquired three Georgia-based insurance companies and a California computer software company. The First of Georgia Insurance Group was acquired by an exchange of Coburn common stock valued at $7.4-million.
Campaign workers for Senator Robert F. Kennedy are still trying to retire a $3.5-million debt remaining from the Senator's six primary races before his assassination in June.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation won a patent yesterday covering the invention in the late nineteenfifties of a mechanism basic to the functioning of many types of lasers.

SAIGON, Sept. 24 (AP) -South Vietnamese forces have fired 105-mm. howitzers into Cambodia in an effort to silence Vietcong guns shooting across the border, the commander of South Vietnam's III Corps said today.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Sept. 24 (AP) -- Edward F. Flanagan, a national hammer throw champion at Holy Cross, is the new assistant varsity track coach at Brown University. Flanagan, who was named yesterday, coached at Boston University for 14 years.
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and Empress Farah arrived today on a state visit and received an elaborate greeting by Soviet leaders.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24(AP) -- A treaty providing for the rescue and recovery of astronauts downed in foreign lands was approved today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

McKEESPORT, Pa., Sept. 24 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie stood in a steaming church school hall on a deteriorating side street here tonight and quietly pleaded with his listeners to recall the painful struggles of their immigrant past and reject the "apostles of division."
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24 -- An all-night battle between the police and students that ended late this morning brought death to at least three persons and possibly to 15.
The stock market found a friend at the Chase Manhattan Bank yesterday.
The auxiliary of the Graham Home for Children will hold a cocktail party for its members tomorrow at the Lunt-Fontanne Theater.
TORONTO, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- The National Hockey League president, Clarence Campbell, said today this year's Stanley Cup playoffs would end no later than May 13.
DETROIT, Sept. 24 -- The Ford Motor Company said today that its dealers sold 47,876 cars in the Sept. 11-20 period, up 80 per cent from 26,645 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Antennas on the Explorer 38 were extended to 600 feet each today to double the radio astronomy satellite's capacity to map radio signals in space.
Maxine Marx, the casting director of Cunningham Walsh, is a dynamic, fast-talking, opinionated brunette with a deep love for show business and the people in it.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Senate voted today to exempt almost $1-billion in farm price support payments from the ceiling on Federal spending, and then cut an estimated total of $500-million from a program to pay medical bills for the ailing poor.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Beer-loving athletes were saddened today to learn that the press bar at the Olympic Village had been put out of bounds for them.

IF last night's installment of the Columbia Broadcasting System's new Western, "Lancer," is typical of the series, it should be a dandy. There are reasons to suspect it might not be, but more of that later.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 -- The press accreditation of Bert W. Okuley, a news editor in the Saigon bureau of United Press International, was suspended today for 30 days by the United States command.
A marked decrease in the number of flights seriously delayed at major airports here this month was reported yesterday by the Federal Aviation Administration and airline officials.

AT the third measure of Anton Bruckner's Seventh Symphony, the cellos come in with a great upward phrase. Eugene Ormandy conducted the Philadelphia Orchestra last night in the Bruckner, and when those cellos came in, organlike, filling the hall with deep, rich sound, everybody knew that the Philadelphia Orchestra was still the Philadelphia Orchestra and Carnegie Hall still Carnegie Hall.
A wealthy oil company executive was ordered yesterday to provide his estranged wife with $5,000 so she could investigate any extramarital activity on his part.
