BERLIN, Sept. 24 -- Two Berliners met after the Soviet intervention in Czechoslovakia. "What will happen if the Soviet Union decides to invade West Berlin?" one asked. "That is easy," the other replied. "The allies will send a strong protest to Moscow."
MOSCOW, Sept. 24 -- The president of the Soviet Academy of Art today attacked artists whose mode of creation is not socialist realism.

FOR moviegoers in general, it is a good thing that "Kaya," the early evening feature yesterday at the film festival, had an Englishlanguage preface before the subtitled showing. It says simply that the picture is based on a series of strange, unaccountable murders in early World War II in a Dalmatian Coast town.
The Consolidated Leasing Corporation of America, based in Chicago, reported yesterday record revenues and earnings for the fiscal year ended July 31.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 24 -Vice President Humphrey asserted today that his Presidential campaign was "gaining ground" after a slow start.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced the underground detonation today of a low-yield nuclear device at its Nevada test site. The test, involving the equivalent of less than 20,000 tons of TNT, was the 21st announced this year.

HARTFORD, Sept. 24 -- The Right Rev. John H. Esquirol, a New York University graduate who was practicing law in Brooklyn 40 years ago, was designated today as the next Episcopal Bishop of Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -The United States and the Soviet Union have exchanged protests over propaganda activities.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 24 (UPI) -- Sterling Hayden's son, Christian, 19 years old, was acquitted today by a Federal judge of a charge that he had failed to report for induction into the armed forces. District Judge Warren J. Ferguson's ruling followed a one-day trial in which Hugh Mannes, the lawyer for the actor's son, had contended the order for induction was invalid.

ATLANTA, Sept. 24 -- Gil Hodges, the manager of the New York Mets, was taken to a hospital tonight after he had complained of chest pains while sitting in the dugout during the game with the Atlanta Braves.

The appointment of Arthur J. Goldberg as Distinguished Lecturer in the Columbia University School of Law and as a professor in the School of Interternational Affairs was announced yesterday by Andrew W. Cordier, acting president of the university.

The General Public Utilities Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 9.7 per cent in revenues for the first eight months. William G. Kuhns, president, noted that kilowatt-hour sales for the period ran 10.2 per cent over the year-ago level.

White-gloved waiters plowed through the milling crowds with trays of drinks and hors d'oeuvres. Friends greeted friends with little cries and social pecks on the cheek. The air-conditioning broke down, and a drunk lurched against a programed sculpture, smashing part of its protective glass.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 -- The Treasury bill rate fell at today's auction from last month's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Sept. 24 -- Paul O'Dwyer told a Vassar College audience of more than a thousand tonight that the nation's young people "are saying things that we better begin listening to."
The unbeaten New York Giants have scored 68 points in two games, which is fine for a team that managed only 49 in four preseason efforts.

Harry S. Oliver Jr. and David H. Reed hav been named vice presidents of the Bank of New York, it was announced yesterday. The bank also promoted John F. MacDonald and Oscar A. Wilkerson 3d to assistant vice presidents and Owen A. Brady and John B. Odgers to assistant treasurer.

After an arduous passage through a House-Senate conference, the Food Stamp bill has again reached the House floor. Several weeks ago the House in response to the spirited leadership of Representative Sullivan, Democrat of Missouri, voted to authorize the Food Stamp Program for four years in contrast to the oneyear extension approved by the Senate. The conferees compromised on two and one-half years and authorized a substantial increase in the level of spending.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 24 (AP) -- Several buildings including the City Hall were destroyed yesterday when a huge chunk of coastland sank several feet in the southern Brazilian city of Guaratuba. There were no injuries.
With the teachers' strike now in its third week, the United Federation of Teachers is preparing to make interest-free loans to its members who are running out or money.

THE Columbia Broadcasting System's new alternate-week news magazine, "60 Minutes," is something television has long needed. Last night's edition explored only a few of the many possibilities open to an imaginative editor, but it was a worthwhile introduction.

The nation's major electric utilities spent more than $127-million on air-pollution-control equipment and services in 1967, according to a survey released yesterday by the Edison Electric Institute, trade association of the investor-owned utilities.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 24 -- Gen. William C. Westmoreland said tonight that he was encouraged by the trend of the fighting in South Vietnam.
A prime-rate reduction by the Chase Manhattan Bank gave the credit markets a psychological lift yesterday, but prices of most fixed-income securities advanced only slightly if at all.

In light of the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia, which few experts had predicted, the NATO countries must now consider the Kremlin hierarchy unstable and its behavior unpredictable.

LONDON, Sept. 24 (Reuters) -- British smokers, who pay from 36 to 68 cents for a pack of cigarettes, went on a spending spree today when supermarkets and chain stores began a price war. The battle produced cuts of up to 6 cents on a pack of 20 cigarettes.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange turned upward yesterday in an active day's trading.

"Cadillac Dreams," a two-act comedy by a young Negro Cleveland playright, Norman Jordan, will open at Judson Hall Oct. 11, for a seven-night run. The play is about two black servants in a white household who try to marry cff their niece to a rich black athlete
THE LETTERS OF CARL SANDBURG. Edited by Herbert Mitgang. 576 pages. Harcourt, Brace World. $12.50.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Sept. 24 -- The Illinois Supreme Court ruled today that the state might revoke the license of a real estate broker or salesman who discriminated in the sale or rental of housing.

The International Business Machines Corporation took title yesterday to 170 acres of vacant, rolling land in Franklin Lakes, N.J. It plans to build an office building on the site for its office proudcts division, which, at present, is in New York City.

BOISE, Idaho, Sept. 24 -- Representative Melvin R. Laird, a leading House Republican, said today that current plans of the Johnson Administration called for reducing United States forces in South Vietnam by roughly 90,000 men by June 30.

Senator Charles E. Goodell was called to account yesterday for his criticism of the Republican standard bearers, Richard M. Nixon and Spiro T. Agnew at a campaign luncheon of Republican women, mostly turbaned matrons wearing jeweled elephant pins.

Arnold Bernhard Co., Inc., manager and investment adviser of the Value Line Development Capital Corporation, has announced the election of Dr. Louis E. Conhaim as president and a director, Jack W. Clark as a director and Arnold Bernhard as chairman of the board of the closed-end investment company.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 24 -- A grenade that was dropped accidentally from a United States military truck exploded in Saigon this morning and wounded seven South Vietnamese, including a policeman, the police reported.
LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Two young Westerners expelled from the Soviet Union for distributing leaflets attacking the occupation of Czechoslovakia arrived here by air tonight.
BERLIN, Sept. 23 -- "We Bombed in New Haven" had its European premiere Sunday night in West Berlin's state-supported Schiller Theater with the playwright, Joseph Heller, in the audience.

QUANGTRI, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 -- For the last two weeks, some 3,000 American and South Vietnamese troops have been sweeping through an enemy stronghold in the dense jungle a few miles south of here.
John Nerud said yesterday he would not enter his 4-year- old colt, Dr. Fager, in the Washington D.C. International at Laurel race track on Nov. 11.

DENVER, Sept. 25 -- Richard M. Nixon, who has steadily maintained that he cannot discuss Vietnam for fear of jeopardizing the Paris talks, has apparently hit upon a way during the last two days to put Vice President Humphrey under a cross-fire on Vietnam.

Recognizing that tens of millions of cigarette addicts are unable or unwilling to quit despite convincing evidence of the harmful effects of cigarette smoking, the United States Public Health Service has issued a useful pamphlet called "If You Must Smoke."

SPRINGFIELD, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The defending champion, Thornwald Larson of Baltusrol, and Frank McBride of Arcola shared the lead at 158 today in the 47th annual New Jersey State Seniors Golf Asociation championship at the Baltusrol Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Federal Reserve Board proposed a new rule today that would restrict the right of banks to use "repurchase agreements" in ways that escape reserve requirements and the limitations on payment of interest on time deposits.

BONN, Sept. 25 -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger said today that West Germany's foreign policy in the wake of the invasion of Czechoslovakia should be to speak softly and carry a somewhat bigger stick to defend itself.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Leroy Stynchcombe, the white incumbent, won nomination today over a Negro bail bonds-man for sheriff of Fulton County in a runoff election to name a Democratic nominee. Mr. Stynchcombe, a former deputy seeking his first elective term after being appointed to the post, received 34,470 votes to 23,101 for J. A. (Alley Pat) Patrick, with 179 Of 198 precincts reported.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Reva MacArthur Weaver widow of the Rev. Dr. Galen R. Weaver, secretary for racial and cultural affairs in the United Church of Christ at his death in 1965, died today at Lawrence Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived at 94 White Road, Scarsdale.

The city offered its 10,000 sanitation workers a $625 salary increase over the next two years during negotiations yesterday. But the union's 250-member wage negotiating committee, meeting last night, quickly and unanimously rejected the city's proposal as inadequate.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 25 (AP) -- United States District Judge J. Smith Henley declared unconstitutional today an 1838 Arkansas law that prohibits interracial marriage.

Stockholders of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., and Bath Industries, Inc., at separate meetings yesterday, approved a proposal to merge Congoleum-Nairn into Bath Industries. They also approved the transfer of Congoleum-Nairn's assets into a new subsidiary, Congoleum Industries, Inc.
TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- A controversy between Federal and state law enforcement officials that has simmered quietly for years flared here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson walked a few blocks from the White House today to United Democrats for Humphrey headquarters for campaign material that she said she would send to those on her "big Christmas card list.

Bobby Douglas of Bridgeport, Ohio, and Wayne Baughman, an Air Force captain at Colorado Springs, have been selected captains of the United States Olympic wrestling teams in free-style and Greco-Roman, respectively.

Cocoa prices moved widely yesterday, rising the 100-point, or one-cent, limit in the case of some contracts, and then dropping from these levels by more than 100 points. At the day's end, prices generally were down about 50 points, or half a cent, below Tuesday's level.

Luis Tiant, a principal contributor to the Year of the Pitcher all season long, wound up his 1968 activities by pitching a one-hitter against the New York Yankees and clinching fourth place for the Cleveland Indians at Yankee Stadium yesterday.
MALIBU, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Burt Lancaster was arrested late last night and spent the night in jail after he refused to sign a speeding ticket, sheriff's deputies said.

On the eve of the opening of classes at Columbia University, Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, its acting president, told thousands of alumni last night that the number of students intent on disrupting the university this fall "happily is decreasing by the day."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Sept. 25 -- The dean of Rutgers College proposed today the establishment of an assembly of students, faculty members, alumni, parents and trustees to serve as the major deliberative and representative body of the college.
The election of Richard A. Donovan to the new post of vice president for employe relations of the National Lead Company was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a new rule that would require any company whose stock is publicly traded to take steps to assure prompt issuance of its certificates to new owners and prompt registration of changes in ownership.
MEXICO CITY Sept. 25 -- The police reported tonight that one person had died by gunfire and two had been wounded in a battle with secondary-school students in the southeastern part of Mexico City.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 25 -- "Shall we toast with slivovitsa?," said the bearded capitalist publisher to the portly Yugoslav editor who was visiting the American stand in the closing hours of the Frankfurt Book Fair.

HOUSTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -Bo Belinsky, who has pitched with the California Angels, Philadelphia Phillies and Houston Astros, was purchased by the Astros last night from the Hawaii Islanders of the Pacific Coast League.

MACHIPONGO, Va., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Two New York sailors were killed and another survived yesterday when their automobile swerved off Route 13 near here and struck a culvert. The dead were Robert Charles Young, 19 years old, of 1685 Oceana Avenue, Brooklyn, and John J. McDermott, 20, of Lynbrook, L. I.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Senators opposing the nomination of Abe Fortas as Chief Justice began a historic filibuster today by concentrating on what was termed his questionable "sense of propriety" as a Justice.
Up above Times Square a new sign burned brightly last night.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 -- Terrorist bombings have destroyed a downtown Israeli trade fair here and damaged a Zionist meeting house in Rosario Province.

NEWARK, Sept. 25 (AP) -Federal Bureau of Investigation agents arrested three men -- including a Jersey City policeman -- today and charged them with possessing about $25,000 worth of stolen medical supplies. WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford said today that the Administration had "no intention" of lowering the level of American troops committed to South Vietnam "either by next June or at any time in the foreseeable future."

CONSIDERING the stakes involved -- the right to challenge the world champion -- Boris Spassky turned in an astounding performance in the fourth game of his match with Viktor Korchnoi.
HONG KONG, Sept. 25 -- Peking today brought to a climax two months of progressively increased stress on economic activity with sweeping claims of an "all-round leap forward" in industrial production.

Gil Hodges, the 44-year-old manager of the New York Mets and onetime hero of the Brooklyn Dodgers, suffered a mild heart attack in Atlanta Stadium Tuesday night and will be hospitalized for perhaps several weeks.

The U.S.M. Corporation, formerly known as the United Shoe Machinery Corporation, reported from its Boston headquarters yesterday that it had increased earnings on record revenues for the three and six months ended Aug. 31.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- James L. Robertson, the vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, disclosed today that the board had overruled its own legal staff in granting to the banks it regulates the authority to establish loan offices anywhere in the country.
DENVER, Sept. 25 -- Only about six crises attended Richard M. Nixon's rally in Denver today and Hubert H. Humphrey would give his eye teeth for such crises.
GENEVA, Sept. 25 -- An American relief agency plans to send a Norwegian ship to aid war victims in Nigeria and Biafra and at the same time "arouse Americans to their usual humanitarian concern.."

The acting head of the Federal Aviation Administration visited a controversial air-traffic-control room at Kennedy International Airport yesterday and conceded later that "the controllers have some legitimate complaints."
ROCHESTER, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The recovery of 28 of 40 small pieces of bronze sculpture, valued at more than $16,000 was reported by the police today. The sculpture was stolen from the Schuman Gallery.

PARIS, Sept. 25 -- North Vietnam reacted unfavorably today to the idea of having the United Nations General Assembly vote on a resolution calling for a halt in the American bombing of the North.

WASHINGTON, Pa., Sept. 25 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie startled a rally in front of the soot-blackened old courthouse here today, including 30 or 40 noisy antiwar protesters, by inviting a young heckler to share the platform with him.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Queen of the Stage finished before male rivals in the Beach Haven Purse today, but her number was taken down and she was placed second.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Ten members of the House of Representatives called today for the establishment of a federally administered fund for payment of damage claims resulting from sonic booms.

MORRIS NEWBURGER was born in Philadelphia and was graduated from Harvard in 1926. He joined his father's investment company and later founded his own -- Newburger, Loeb Co. He was an Army Air Force officer in World War II, he belonged to several clubs, he lived on Fifth Avenue. His wife's picture appeared on the society page. Morris Newburger left two sons when he died, earlier this month, at the age of 62.

"The Cuban Thing," which had spurred political demonstrations since its arrival at Henry Miller's Theater, closed after 13 previews and its opening night performance on Tuesday. It was Broadway's second entry of the new season and the first casualty.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Sept. 25 (Canadian Press) -- Crown Zellerbach Canada, Ltd., announced today that a $5-a-ton increase in the basic price of standard newsprint would become effective Jan. 1 in British Columbia and Alberta.
The London Stock Exchange experienced widespread losses yesterday, both during the official part of the session and after hours, as a wave of selling hit prices.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- When a doctor prescribes a drug, he probably has learned what he knows about it from the manufacturer's sales pitch rather than from any objective source, the head of a Government study group testified today.
FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- The leader of a military junta that ruled Sierra Leone for 13 months was charged today with high treason.

Union Bancorp, the one-bank holding company that owns the Union Bank of Los Angeles, which has deposits of $1.2-billion, announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Swett and Crawford, Inc., a major Los Angeles insurance agency, plus the Harbor Insurance Company, which the agency controls.
THE SPRINGS, L. I. -- The Green River Cemetery, a tiny patch of graveyard that once served only natives of this bucolic community, is slowly becoming an Upper Bohemian answer to Forest Lawn.
FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 25 -- James Harper Cruikshank, a real estate operator with offices at 45 Nassau Street, Manhattan, died yesterday at his home, 170 New York Avenue. He was 90 years old.
WHEN the New York Jets departed from Buffalo a year ago after losing their season opener, 20-17, Jim Turner was concerned.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The House passed by voice vote today a compromise bill to establish a National Wild and Scenic Rivers system, designating all or parts of eight rivers as the initial units.
EDP Technology, Inc., announced yesterday that it would purchase the Cornell Aeronautical Laboratory from Cornell University for $25-million.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union warned Israel today of the serious responsibility she bore for the consequences of her "dangerous provocations" against the United Arab Republic, Jordan and Syria.
OTTAWA, Sept. 25 -- The Cabinet of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau continues to debate its promised reassessment of Canada's place in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

THE rites of autumn, as celebrated by New York department stores, are well under way. Bloomingdale's joined in today, but, rather than filling its eight floors with an array of merchandise and a lengthy program of events, the store has chosen to concentrate on a few things instead. Its theme, loosely applied, is New York.

MOSCOW, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, who arrived for a 10-day state visit yesterday, held talks today with the Soviet Communist party leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev; President Nikolai V. Podgorny, and Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- New York State's Medicaid program, which was cut back sharply earlier this year, is facing another assault from Congress that possibly could cost the state upwards of $90-million in Federal aid.

"A LIGHT FANTASTIC" is Gerald Arpino's Renaissance ballet. After having ventured so successfully into the Baroque with his two plotless Vivaldi ballets, "Viva Vivaldi" and "Cello Concerto," the City Center Joffrey Ballet's resident choreographer has imbued his newest plotless work, which received its premiere last night at the City Center, with a sparkling Elizabethan flavor.

The Mid-Continent Telephone Corporation said yesterday it had agreed to acquire the North Florida Telephone Company in an exchange of stock valued at "in excess of $8-million." This marks the Ohio-based holding company's entry into its 12th state.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Sept. 25 -- About 200 high school and university students went on a 10-minute rampage in the main street here today.

THERE are enough things going for "Here Come the Brides," the new one-hour comedy series on the American Broadcasting Company, to predict a happy future for all concerned. This one is not aiming for the big laughs. It is content, rather, to settle for a lot of little smiles and the pleasures of being among a lot of lusty people who appear to be having a good time.

Uday Shankar will make his first American appearance since 1962 on Tuesday evening, Oct. 8, in the Hunter College Assembly Hall. He is a brother of Ravi Shankar, the sitarist. He will present eight evening performances, as well as Saturday and Sunday matinees, between Oct. 8 and Oct. 13 and then take his company on a tour of 40 cities.

ROME, Sept. 25 -- Reliable sources in close touch with Roman Catholic affairs reported today that the Rev. E. C. Schillebeekx, a noted Dutch theologian and university professor, was under investigation by a commission of the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith.

United States Aviation Underwriters, Inc., a major aircraft insurance group, announced yesterday the election of Frank J. Lynch as vice president and John V. Brennan as assistant vice president. Both are lawyers specializing in aircraft insurance with the group.

ATHENS, Sept. 25 -- The Greek people were told today that a vote in favor of the new Constitution on Sunday would also imply approval of the military coup that ended parliamentary rule in Greece 17 months ago.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- A provision to exempt all Federal school aid funds from the spending cut ordered by Congress was approved today by House-Senate negotiators as part of a compromise $3-billion vocational education bill.

Brass rod prices will be raised as of today by the Bridgeport Brass Company, a division of National Distillers and Chemical Corporation. The action follows a similar move by the Chase Brass Corporation last Friday.
KATMANDU, Nepal, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- King Mahendra today appointed a new Council of Ministers under Premier Surya Bahadur Thapa.

HEIDELBERG, West Germany, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- A 24-year-old Californian is the 50,000th European-based United States soldier to be accepted as a volunteer for service in Vietnam. Specialist 4 Wayne H. Persall of Redlands, Calif., received a scroll of appreciation today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- "Sit down, Son. I'd like to talk to you."

LONDON, Sept. 25 -- Commonwealth Finance Ministers, most of them representing sterling area countries, found the position of the pound improved, but hardly robust, as they began a two-day closed meeting in London today, the first such gathering since devaluation last November.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Johnson appointed Tyler Abell today to be United States Chief of Protocol, with the personal rank of ambassador.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The California Supreme Court rejected today a move by backers of Senator McCarthy to put his name on the November ballot as an independent candidate for President.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court has granted the request of 43 Army reservists from New York to stay temporarily their impending departure for Vietnam. The 43 are members of the 74th Field Hospital, based at Fort Lee.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Shorn of their more controversial provisions, bills to extend basic farm programs for a year and continue and expand food aid for the poor passed the House today, as farm and city interests collaborated.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 25 -- Israeli and Egyptian spokesmen, speaking with rare unanimity, today denounced a report that King Hussein of Jordan was seeking a political settlement with Israel.

ASMARA, Ethiopia, Sept. 24 -- Training to be an Arab terrorist commander is a little like American infantry training, but as done in Syria it includes jogging in time to shouts of "Death to Israel!" a man identified as a Moslem defector reported today.
BOSTON, Sept. 25 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York took to the Massachusetts campaign trail today to give his help to Republican candidates.

LONDON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- England's cricket team which canceled a tour of South Africa because of a racial dispute, will tour India and Pakistan instead this winter, it was announced today by the Marylebone Cricket Club, the ruling body of English cricket.

Two assistants to Mayor Lindsay received more impressive job titles yesterday although their pay remained at $25,000 a year. Robert M. Blum, 39 years old, was appointed counsel to the Mayor, and Werner H. Kramarsky was named special assistant to the Mayor.

LISBON, Sept. 25 -- Highly placed sources said today that President Americo Thomaz had named Marcelo Caetano, a 62-year-old law professor and businessman, to succeed the critically ill Antonio de Oliveira Salazar as Premier.

PRAGUE, Sept. 25 -- With official blessings and for the first time since the resumption of censorship after the invasion, the Czechoslovak press renewed polemics today with East Germany in response to attacks on Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak party leader.

SAN FERNANDO, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- A 40-ton earth-mover crashed into the Foothill Nursing Home and Sanitarium yesterday, injuring four elderly women critically. The driver, Edward Carter of Los Angeles, 47 years old, was found dead in the wreckage.

Avco Embassy Pictures Corporation will join the Motion Picture Association of America on Nov. 1, it was announced yesterday by Jack Valenti, association president. Avco Embassy, whose president is Joseph E. Levine, will become the ninth member of the association.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday, that resolution of the New York City, teachers' strike was entirely up to the Mayor, the city Board of Education and the State Education Commissioner; it could not be his responsibility "I don't have the authority."

WARSAW, Sept. 25 -- A prominent lawyer who has defended Poles accused of political crimes went on trial behind closed door today on charges of possessing documents deemed harmful to the interests of the state.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 -- Manager Gil Hodges, recuperating from a mild heart attack, was not permitted to listen to the radio account of the New York Mets' game with the Atlanta Braves tonight. Perhaps it would have hastened his recovery had he tuned in because the Mets played one of their best and fastest games, gaining a 3-0 victory.
THE last two all-breed shows of the Long Island outdoor season take place this weekend -- the Suffolk on Saturday and the Westbury on Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Senate unexpectedly returned to its Foreign Relations Committee today the names of 10 nominees for posts as representatives to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
The Pan American Petroleum Corporation, subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), announced yesterday the successful testing of a wildcat well in the Cook Inlet of Alaska.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Justice Department's antitrust division is "actively exploring'' the possibility of an antitrust suit attacking connections between certain banks and insurance companies, Edwin M. Zimmerman, the chief of the division, disclosed today.

BERLIN, Sept. 25 -- Dr. Klaus Fuchs, the atomic physicist jailed by Britain for spying the the Soviet Union, said in East Berlin today that West Germany had the capacity to produce 50 atomic bombs a year from 1970.

Most of the nation's major banks, led by the First National City Bank of New York, reduced yesterday their minimum charge for business loans -- the "prime rate" -- to 6 1/4 per cent from 6 1/2 per cent.
The futures of four heavyweight contenders will be determined tonight at Madison Square Garden.
DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- The Ford Motor Company announced today a rise of about 2 per cent on its 1969 car prices, matching the increases set Monday by the General Motors Corporation.

THE HAGUE, Sept. 25 -- Crown Princess Beatrix was delivered of a son by Cesarean section today. He is third in line of succession to the Dutch throne. On April 27, 1967, Beatrix gave birth to Prince Willem Alexander.

Airline and aviation officials plan to discuss the possible use of satellites to control air traffic across the ocean, airline safety in the coming era of jumbo jets and progress in detecting the hidden menace of clear air turbulence at the Flight Safety Foundation's 21st Annual International Air Safety Seminar, to be held Oct. 7 to 11 at the Disneyland Hotel, Anaheim, Calif.

More than 3,500 opponents of the teachers' strike jammed Manhattan Center last night and heard the Rev. Milton A. Galamison, a member of the Board of Education, declare that if the teacher strike continued, they should "organize forces and open schools -- if necessary, one by one."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -Nicholas deB. Katzenbach and a woman member of the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence disagreed today on the role of civil disobedience. The woman had a chance for the last word but smiled a victory smile instead.
ALBANY, Sept. 25 -- The Senate majority leader, Earl W. Brydges, accused New York City officials of inaction in New York City's school crisis.

The largest ship to be built in Germany began taking shape last week at the Bremen yard of Weser. The combining of prefabricated sections was regarded as the modern symbolic equivalent of laying the keel of an Esso tanker that Will have a capacity of 225,000 dead-weight tons, first of a series of three.
A Brooklyn grand jury began an investigation yesterday into an assault made against three Black Panthers in Brooklyn Criminal Court by a group of whites who included some off-duty policemen.
JERICHO, L. I., Sept. 25 -For the second day in a row Nassau County policemen seized a burglary suspect today after a high-speed chase along the Long Island Expressway.

The Holland-America Line announced yesterday that it was planning two additional 28 1/2-day Caribbean cruises from Los Angeles. The liner Statendam will leave the California city on Jan. 9 and March 11.

CHICAGO, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Al Hattab wore down Flagstaff after a stretch duel today and won the $36,500 Hawthorne Juvenile Stakes by a head before a crowd of 12,909 at Hawthorne. Traffic Mark, a slight favorite over the winner, was four lengths back in third in the 1 1/16-mile race.

SHARON, Pa., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The Sharon Steel Corporation told its shareholders today it was not in a position now to recommend acceptance of the NVF Corporation's proposal to acquire the steel company.

The city's top labor leaders strongly applauded last night a statement that "Mayor Lindsay quit knuckling under to the vigilantes of Ocean Hill-Browns-ville" and support the United Federation of Teachers.

The appointment of Nicholas E. Crane as vice president of Dean Witter Co., Inc., was announced yesterday. He was manager of the company's New York research department for 20 years and is now manager of the option department.

Vice Adm. John T. Hayward, president of the Naval War College from 1966 until his retirement from the Navy last month, has been named a vice president of General Dynamics Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

ATLANTA, Sept. 25 (UPI) -Hosea Williams, an aide of the late Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., failed today to get on the ballot as a candidate for the Georgia legislature. Secretary of State Ben Fortson, the man in charge of certifying petition candidates, said validation checks showed that Mr. Williams needed 413 signatures but had only 300.

Three roles in three operas were sung and acted by Muriel Greenspon last night in the New York City Opera's presentation of Puccini's "Il Trittico" at the New York State Theater. She was Frugola in "Il Taborro," the Princepessa in "Suor Angelica" and Zita in "Gianni Schicchi."
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Czechoslovakia defeated Denmark, 3-0, in a World Cup qualification soccer match tonight.

When Melvin Ritter and Jane Allen -- violinist and pianist, husband and wife -- play, the effect is chamber music, not a violin recital. The Middle Western duo has been giving concerts in New York with some regularity for the last decade, and this has invariably been the reaction.

John C. Emery, founder of Emery Air Freight, will be presented with the Air Freight Forwarders Association's "Air Cargo Man of the Year" tomorrow. The award will be made at the association's 11th annual dinner to be held at the Pierre Hotel here.
Except for 700 seats at $25 each (which may be purchased only in multiples of two's), every seat has been sold for the Grambling-Morgan State football game at Yankee Stadium on Saturday.

The city Board of Education, in a move to end the crippling school strike, yesterday ordered the administrator of the embattled Ocean Hill-Brownsville district to "facilitate" the "normal return" tomorrow of 110 disputed teachers to their schools.
WAYCROSS, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The home of Sheriff Robert E. Lee was blown up today minutes after he won re-election. No one was in the house which burned to the ground.

George C. Wallace advocates aggressive use of force by the police sufficient to suppress protests and militancy among Negroes and on the left. "Proper use of the police power is the only thing left now to try to curtail anarchy in the country," Mr. Wallace asserts. He would "let the police stop it like they know how to stop it."
DON C. LILJENQUIST, author of "Woman Is My Idea," the play at the Belasco Theater last night, seemed to have some difficulty in getting his play ended. This was not altogether surprising.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy paid a brief call on Secretary General Thant today. He declined to discuss the purpose of his visit with newsmen and there was no word from United Nations quarters except to confirm the appointment.
Federal authorities were preparing last night to put pressure on the waterfront industry for a settlement in the waterfront labor crisis or for a postponement of the deadline set for midnight Monday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Charles Will Wright, an internationally known mineral engineer, died of a heart attack in his home here. His age was 89.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Some Pentagon officials, combing through the defense budget in an effort to cut $3-billion in spending, are looking into the possibility of withdrawing three squadrons of fighter-bombers from South Korea.
The appointment of William S. Little as senior vice president with responsibility for all operating divisions of Becton, Dickinson Co., was announced yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 25 -- The other night an American walked into one of the restaurants here where there seemed to be more violins than waiters. He was dejected and the lead violinist interrupted "Play, Gypsy" and turned to "Alexander's Ragtime Band," a tune not particularly suited to the violin.

The life insurance industry's special program to invest a billion dollars in blighted urban areas has reached the $700-million mark in the one year since its inception, according to the Institute of Life Insurance.

The moment of glory appears over for Czechoslovakia's free press. With Soviet heavyhandedness and Kafkaesque improbability, a new Committee for Press and Information has imposed censorship again with the approval of the Czechoslovak National Assembly. It will make sure that newspapers, magazines and broadcasting stations "do not divulge information in disagreement with the vital interests of Czechoslovakia's domestic and foreign policy."

SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 25 -- Dr. Joseph A. Walsh, a well-known proctologist and a past president of the Pennsylvania Medical Society, died last night in Mercy Hospital here of a heart ailment. His home was at nearby Blakely. He was 54 years old.

Radio station WMCA celebrated 25 years as part of the Straus Broadcasting Group, at a dinner party at Voisin last night, with a brief look back and an ambitious look forward to a new kind of public-service programing.

TRENTON, Sept. 25 -- About 250 angry white students at Trenton High School, many of them wearing "Wallace for President" buttons and some carrying "White Power" signs, boycotted classes today, pledging not to return until Negro students stop "taking potshots" at them.
George C. Wallace is planning a mass rally at Shea Stadium in his quest for votes for President in this area.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The leading House Republican on international monetary matters said today there was "broad bipartisan support" for the United States gold policy outlined yesterday by Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler.

The Police Department gave its official backing yesterday to Mayor Lindsay's denial that the police who shut down gambling in a Roman Catholic churchyard during the Feast of San Gennaro had acted on orders from City Hall.
TORONTO, Sept. 25 -- Canada's new national administration has begun a campaign of fiscal restraint to eliminate lingering inflationary forces.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Lord Beswick, chief Labor whip in the House of Lords, who has led a British Parliamentary delegation to South Vietnam, said today his visit had changed his opinion about the bombing of North Vietnam.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 25 -- The Bridgeport Hospital auxiliary will give a ball on Saturday at the Stratfield Hotel. Proceeds will go to the new intensive-care and cardiac unit at the hospital. Mrs. David B. Smith of Fairfield is chairman of the event.
CLIFTON, N. J., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Mrs. Maud McCormick Murphy, wife of Jack Murphy, New York Yankees television director, died today in Passaic General Hospital. She was 52 years old.

Since crime and social unrest have both increased over the past decade, Richard M. Nixon and his running mate, Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, have made the restoration of "law and order" the chief theme of their campaign. Despite this emphasis, it cannot be said that they have clarified these difficult problems or offered specific, convincing programs to cope with them.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- President Johnson signed today a measure guaranteeing the Defense Department a complete audit of financial records of contractors and subcontractors to determine whether the Government was overcharged.
ATLANTA, Sept. 25 (UPI) -Mack Brothers Jr. of Nashville defeated the national seniors golf medalist, Johnny Tullio of Aurora, Ohio, 4 and 2, at the Atlanta Country Club links today.
The American Broadcasting Company will televise a color documentary of Mrs. Lyndon Baines Johnson in December.
Following are the disputants' positions on specific issues in the school strike:

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A Soviet trawler has unofficially joined a North Atlantic Treaty Organization convoy heading for New London, Conn., the Maritime Command of the Canadian armed forces said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Senator Henry M. Jackson reported today that the possibility of communications, radar and missile systems being blacked out by electric pulses from nuclear explosions remained a "serious problem" despite five years of intensive research.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges and over-the-counter markets were closed yesterday, continuing a pattern set last June when the mounting paperwork led the stock markets to suspend trading on Wednesdays.
GLENEAGLES, Scotland, Sept. 25 (AP) -- A golf quartet from the North Shore Club, Glenview, Ill., led the field today after two rounds of the British amateur-professional four-ball tournament.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The South Vietnamese customs agency said today that about $120-million worth of goods from American military post exchanges wound up on the black market last year.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -District Attorney Phil Canale denied today a defense charge that guards had eavesdropped over microphones on conversations between James Earl Ray and his attorney, Arthur B. Hanes. Mr. Canale, in a written reply to defense motions, said the microphones in Ray's cell were turned off during his talks with Mr. Hanes, former Mayor of Birmingham.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 25 -- Sons and daughters of Adios Boy, Egyptian Candor, Duke Rodney, Duane Hanover, Great Lullwater and Jimmy Norman, to mention only a few, looked good today to most of the touring horsemen on their annual inspection of trotting and pacing yearlings bred in this state.
Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn has announced that James J. Jordan Jr., who has been creative director of the New York office, has been named world-wide creative director.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Premier Tran Van Huong today appointed Dr. Le Minh Tri as Minister of Education, replacing Dr. Nguyen Van Tho.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

Emory Lewis has resigned as editor of Cue magazine to write books. The first, "Stages," a story of the American theater since 1915, has been scheduled for publication in February by Prentice-Hall, Inc.

DETROIT, Sept. 25 -- The American Motors Corporation said today it had arranged private placement of a $35-million issue of convertible subordinated long-term notes through Lehman Brothers and Goodbody Co.

ALBANY, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Dr. Ernest L. Boyer was appointed vice chancellor of the State University of New York today. He will succeed Dr. Harold C. Syrett, who has become president of Brooklyn College, in the $32,000-a-year post.
THE TRUMPET OF CONSCIENCE. By Martin Luther King Jr. 78 pages. Harper Row. $3.95.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Government officials disclosed today that the Soviet Union approached the United States two weeks ago with a compromise peace plan for the Middle East.

A GALLERY of spectators usually surrounds the big-name players in a major tournament, and this tends to improve the score of the famous player: Inexperienced players arriving at the table are often unnerved by the prospect of having to play in front of a large and critical audience.

Directors of the Latrobe Steel Company of Latrobe, Pa., a specialty steel concern, yesterday elected Joseph E. Workman as chairman of the board. Mr. Workman, formerly vice chairman, replaces Marcus W. Saxman Jr., who died on Sept. 13.
INDIANAPOLIS, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The United States Auto Club suspended driver-owner Parnelli Jones of Torrance, Calif., yesterday for "conduct detrimental to auto racing and U.S.A.C."

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Sept. 25 (AP) -- An experimental re-entry vehicle atop an Atlas-F booster was successfully launched down the Western Test Range today, an Air Force spokesman said. The launch was a part of the advanced ballistic re-entry system.
John A. Gronouski, executive vice chairman of the United Democrats for Humphrey, conceded yesterday that financing had been slow to come into the Vice President's campaign for the Presidency.

OTTAWA, Sept. 25 -- Premier Daniel Johnson of Quebec today portrayed his government as an earnest member of the Canadian confederation, a partner eager to conciliate all outstanding differences between French-speaking and English-speaking Canadians.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Vice President Humphrey said tonight that Mr. Nixon had demonstrated ignorance about provisions of the National Labor Relations Act in connection with the strike of California grape workers.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 (AP) -- An explosion and fire destroyed a $1.5-million Israeli commercial exhibition in the heart of Buenos Aires early today. An Israeli Embassy spokesman said the explosion had been caused by a bomb, but the police said they could not confirm this yet.
MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- The Soviet Union tonight criticized unidentified Czechoslovak leaders for having praised the recent role of the Czechoslovak press, radio and television.

SEAL BEACH, Calif., Sept. 25 -- In the first radical departure of his Presidential campaign, Vice President Humphrey proposed today that Social Security payments be increased by 50 per cent, or about $12-billion, over the next four years.

ROME, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Pope Paul VI deplored extremism among youths today and called their riotous demonstrations "explosions of folly." At the same time, he charged that contemporary society was responsible for triggering students' riots.
CAIRO, Sept. 25 -- An Egyptian Government spokesman charged today that alarmist reports in the European press had unduly exaggerated the tension along the Suez Canal ceasefire line.

INWOOD, L. I., Sept. 25 -Jerry Pittman, the 1965 titleholder, chipped in at the home green of the Inwood Country Club today for a 67. The fiveunder-par round gave the 31year-old instructor from The Creek, Locust Valley, a twostroke edge in the Metropolitan open golf championship.

The leaders of the State Legislature have privately acknowledged that some form of a state tax increase will be necessary next year, but they have refused to concede that they will have to resort to the politically distasteful sales and income taxes.
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange yesterday reported changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

NEWARK, Sept. 25 -- The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced today that the Atomic Energy Commission had approved construction of the utility's 2,160,000kilowatt nuclear generating station in Salem County on the lower Delaware River.
LIMA, Peru, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Tear-gas barrages and water cannon dispersed angry bands of youthful demonstrators on busy streets here early today.
An auction of 44 works of art by British painters and sculptors at the Parke-Bernet Gallery last night brought at total of $375,000.

WARSAW, Sept. 25 -- Four young Danes arrested yesterday for distributing leaflets in Warsaw condemning the invasion of Czechoslovakia are to be released and expelled from Poland, a Danish embassy spokesman said today.

A former police lieutenant who was dismissed by the commissioner for departmental infractions after 21 years on the force filed suit yesterday in Federal Court for reinstatement of the pension he was denied.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets announced today that Bob Quick, their second choice in the National Basketball Association college draft, has been ordered to report Monday for Army induction.

The Kiwi Club of Manhattan will hold a luncheon and fashion show in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Saturday. Mrs. John V. Lindsay, Mrs. Jacob K. Javits and Mrs. George Spater, whose husband is president of American Airlines, are honorary chairmen for the event.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 25 -- Mrs. Cutting Cushing, Meadow Brook, who defeated Mrs. Gordon McGrath, Piping Rock, 3 and 2, will meet Mrs. Thorne Dempsey, Piping Rock, in a semi-final of the Women's Long Island Golf Association's match-play championship tomorrow.
CLEVELAND, Sept. 25 -- The Negro Ensemble Company of New York began a week's engagement at Karamu House tonight before a standing-room-only crowd.
After a year of sending only sports cars, Jaguar of England is once again offering a family-sized sedan in its 1969 line of automobiles.

William Francis Ferris, who was president until he retired in 1965 of the brokerage firm of W. F. Ferris Company, died Tuesday at New York Hospital of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 5 Tudor City Place.
ATLANTA, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Eugene C. Patterson has resigned as editor of The Atlanta Constitution effective at the end of the month, it was announced today.
Buying losses for gains has become an important pursuit of the sophisticated investor -- the person searching for turnaround situations in hope of a long-term appreciation on his stock-purchase.
"You have to run a darned good business but you can't become an old lady, either," declared Ernest L. Molloy, the new chief executive officer of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Navy has agreed to let general aviation (business and private planes) use Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn on a limited scale to relieve congestion at Kennedy International and La Guardia Airports, a New York Congressman disclosed today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Sept. 25 -- Zdenek Cernik, the new chief of the Czechoslovak delegation at the United Nations, said today that any discussions, of the issues involving the Soviet Union and his country on an international level at this time would be more harmful than helpful.
Four children were missing last night after a 12-foot wooden boat with 12 persons aboard capsized in Jamaica Bay.

A key supporter of Chancellor R. Gordon Hoxie said yesterday that he would seek to delay consideration of a move to oust Dr. Hoxie at a special meeting of the board of trustees of Long Island University next Monday because he felt most of the trustees had been "pressured" into opposing the chancellor.
OSLO, Norway, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Early snow covered Norway's mountains today.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Almost 400 square miles of the Kruger National Park have been destroyed by fire, the National Parks Board announced tonight. The fire, which raged along a front of 12 to 20 miles in the southwestern corner of the game reserve, was brought under control this afternoon.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Former Gov. George C. Wallace, keeping to himself any development on the impending selection of a Vice-Presidential running mate, spent today at his national campaign headquarters attending to administrative details and working on his platform.

The American Civil Liberties Union, disturbed by the violence in Chicago during the Democratic National Convention and the tensions of the election campaign, has drafted a set of guidelines for dissent and the role of free speech to be observed by candidates, demonstrators, the police and other officials and the mass media.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The World Bank gave a cautiously optimistic report today on the improved prospects of agriculture in the poor countries but said progress in population control had been "extremely modest."
JERUSALEM, Sept. 23 (Reuters) -- Israel accused the Soviet Union tonight of pursuing a Middle East policy that was "one of the main obstacles on the road to a lasting peace."

Mayor Lindsay said through a spokesman yesterday that he "will take any steps necessary" to have his name removed as a Vice-Presidential candidate on the Vermont and New Hampshire ballots. The Mayor learned yesterday that groups in both states had filed petitions for a national ticket pairing him with Senator Eugene J. McCarthy as a Presidential candidate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 25 -- A United States Army Special Forces camp near the Cambodian border withstood a savage enemy shelling and ground attack this morning with the aid of heavy artillery barrages and air strikes.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art previewed "The Great Age of Fresco" exhibition with a black-tie dinner and a reception last night, and nobody seemed to be having more fun than Thomas P. F. Hoving, the museum's new director.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Campaign workers for Richard M. Nixon were ordered today to stop heckling their candidate's opponent for the Presidency, Vice President Humphrey.

SELKIRK, N. Y., Sept. 25 -- The Penn Central Railroad dedicated today the industry's most modern electronic freight classification yard. The $29-million facility, hub of the railroad's eastern operations, was named the Alfred E. Perlman Yard in honor of the company's president.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- The Senate confirmed Angier Biddle Duke, former State Department chief of protocol, today as Ambassador to Denmark.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Senate passed and sent to President Johnson today a catch - all $14.5 - billion money bill containing funds for city housing programs.

Paul O'Dwyer proposed yesterday that the Federal Government and the medical profession join in establishing a domestic Medicorps, operating on a voluntary basis to improve health in city slums and depressed regions.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 25 -- The head of the Syracuse Police Benevolent Association charged today that civil rights organizations were more responsible for the current racial disorders here than the perpetrators themselves.
THE Adams family of Hewlett, L. I., helped put the football hex on Gettysburg last Saturday. It will attempt to do the same to Adelphi this Saturday at Kings Point.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- Estudiantes de La Plata of Argentina beat Manchester United of England, 1-0, in the first-leg game of the World Club Soccer Cup final tonight.

BUDAPEST, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The Hungarian police announced today that five Westerners were under arrest after they had distributed leaflets on the Czechoslovak situation in Budapest. They included Robert Eaton, of Philadelphia.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 (Reuters) -- The Soviet press agency Tass will get a new headquarters building in Moscow equipped with the latest transmission equipment. Tass, one of the world's largest press agencies, has news services in Russian, English, Spanish, French and German.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- The House Republican leader, Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, denied today that he had suggested that Republican Congressional candidates support George C. Wallace to avoid hurting their own campaigns.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the promotions of Warren I. Beckwith to vice president and of Philip Briggs and Donald A. Odell to second vice presidents. Mr. Beckwith is in group insurance administration and customer relations.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- The American Conservatory Theater exceeded its expectations with total box-office receipts of $1,225,968 for its second season here, its managing director, William Bushnell, announced today.

The departmental trial of Patrolman Leonard Grossman, who was suspended more than five years ago for alleged involvement in a Mafia plot to murder informers, became snagged yesterday on a hazy legal question.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. -- Only a few decades after Communists in China and Socialists in Israel showed the way, this citadel of respectability now has its own commune of faculty and families from Harvard University, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Wellesley College, and Brandeis University.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee approved today by voice vote a bill to allow the television networks to provide time for three-way debates among the major Presidential candidates.
ALGIERS, Sept. 25 -- Algeria put a ban today on certain shipments of Algerian crude oil that are exported by French producing companies below world posted prices.

Howard Butcher 3d, the Philadelphia investment banker whose firm was accused by a stockholder of having traded in the stock of the Penn Central Company on the basis of inside information, has resigned as a director of the giant carrier.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Senator McCarthy formally requested today that his name be removed from the New Hampshire election ballot as the Presidential candidate of the New party, a spokesman said.
PARIS, Sept. 25 -- If there were 50 million Frenchmen a year ago and if France's population grew by 600,000, how many Frenchmen are there today?

BINGHAMTON, N. Y., Sept. 25 (AP) -- Demonstrators interrupted addresses by both daughters of Richard M. Nixon today at a rally in behalf of the Republican Presidential candidate in the city's downtown section.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, back from a nine-day campaign trip through Hawaii and the Western states, said tonight that he and the Republican Presidential candidate, Richard M. Nixon, were not interested in debating Vice President Humphrey.

RICHMOND, Sept. 25 (AP) -- Part of a Mississippi Army Reserve company, praised by its Senator yesterday as representative of the great majority of reservists, filed suit today to avoid shipment to Vietnam.
MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 25 -"Hollywood has been funny for so long that it's stopped being," a character in a nineteen-fifties novel by John P. Marquand observed; but he was wrong.

THE leopards and the cheetahs have vanished from the Georges Kaplan fur salon, but they're not likely to be missed. Furs have been painted in abstract designs, inlaid with initials, encrusted with jewels or dyed an unlikely purple to take women's minds off the spotted cats.
Kid Gavilan set his horn-rimmed glasses on the table and clapped his hands to indicate the kind of reception an admiring Cuba used to give him.
BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 25 (UPI) -- Defending champion Charles Pasarell and thirdseeded Bob Lutz scored easy victories today in the Pacific Coast international men's singles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -William S. Gaud, head of the Agency for International Development, told a Senate committee today that House cuts of $365-million in funds already authorized for the aid program would cripple the Alliance for Progress in Latin America and curtail Asia's "green revolution."

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 25 -- Vice President Humphrey arrived in California yesterday to find some of his most acute organizational problems eased. But most Democratic leaders here are no different from those elsewhere on one crucial point.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Following are excerpts from statements on the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice made today on the Senate floor by the Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield, and Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan:

SEOUL, Sept. 25 -- South Korean troops trapped seven North Korean infiltrators on the western front just below the demilitarized zone and killed them in a fierce clash yesterday, the Government said today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- The Federal Government today invited proposals from the American steamship industry for the deyelopment of competitive nuclear reactor propulsion systems for merchant ships.
Short-term interest rates declined yesterday in the wake of bank reductions in the prime rate.

"Excelsior," said Richard F. Casey of Benton Bowles raising a glass of champagne, and all the other board members and staff of the American Research Foundation deserted the fruit cup and did likewise.
The City Planning Commission, in a 4-to-3 decision, approved yesterday the construction of a heliport on top of the new Police Headquarters Building adjacent to City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Communist China, which in recent years has paid little attention to Eastern Europe, has started broadcasting in Czech, Slovak, Polish and Rumanian to strengthen its anti-Soviet propaganda efforts on Moscow's doorstep.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept. 25 -- For the fourth time within the last five months this city was shaken early today by a bomb explosion that the authorities believe to be the work of emigre Croatian Ustashi terrorists.
CHICAGO, Sept. 25 -- Inland Steel Company today announced two accounting changes which have the effect of increasing stated net income.

Surveys of a long-dormant Costa Rican volcano that erupted explosively two months ago, killing more than 100 persons led the chief Federal geologist to state yesterday that a similar disaster could occur in the United States.
A cryptic announcement from United Fruit Company yesterday filled in a single blank in the mystery purchase on Tuesday of 733,000 shares of United Fruit.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 -- Emil J. Pattberg, Jr., chairman of the board of the First Boston Corporation, questioned the wisdom today of fixed sales commissions on stock transactions.

Kernel Marty of Stephen Wolfson's Happy Valley Farm won the $14,150 Elkridge Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Moving in the middle of the pack in the early stages of the 1 7/8-mile event, Kernel Marty gained the lead well before the finish and extended it to a six-length advantage over the Chance Hill Farm's Sailor Town at the wire.

Elimination of automobile commuter discounts on the Port of New York Authority's bridges and tunnels was urged yesterday by City Councilman Edward I. Koch. He called it one way of attacking the related problems of automobile congestion and air pollution here.
DENVER, Sept. 26 -- "The ball club is not ready to play yet," Henry Iba said between bites of shrimp creole in the hotel coffee shop. "We've got to have a lot more fight on the boards."

MAXIMILIANO ZOMOSA is still walking down the aisle and onstage at the City Center to strip off his mustardcolored corduroy suit, blue shirt and knee socks, and Trinette Singleton beckons again as a lovely paisleyprint sex goddess.
LANSING, Mich., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Gov. George Romney of Michigan described George C. Wallace today as a "racist" and "builder of hate," whose election to the Presidency would destroy the nation.

ASMARA, Ethiopia, Sept. 25 -- Ethiopian authorities said this week that they had broken the back of an Arab-supported guerrilla movement struggling to pry the coastal province of Eritrea out of Emperor Haile Selassie's realm.
At least 25,000 youngsters will ring doorbells for Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic Senate candidate's campaign manager said yesterday.

THE International Team Trials, which begin in Atlantic City in four weeks' time, will be dominated by New York experts quantitatively and perhaps qualitatively as well. Exactly half the contestants -- 16 out of 32 -are from the metropolitan area, if one counts one young star who recently departed to Dallas.
BOSTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Northeast Airlines announced today that it would resume service to Newark on Nov. 1 after an absence of 22 years. Newark will be the carrier's 35th airport.
Prices of goods and services bought by families in the New York metropolitan area rose sharply in August, producing an increase during this year's first eight months that was the highest in 20 years.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- H. Roemer McPhee, Washington lawyer, wsa named general counsel today to the Republican National Finance Committee headed by Maurice H. Stans. Mr. McPhee was a member of the White House staff from 1954 to the end of the Eisenhower Administration, starting as an economic adviser and later becoming associate special counsel to the President.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced yesterday the appointment of Richard K. LeBlond 2d, senior vice president, as head of the bank's national division, effective Dec. 1. He will succeed Walter M. Ross, executive vice president, who will retire on that date.
Mayor Lindsay and the head of the teachers' union said early this morning it was possible that the city's striking teachers would go back to work Monday.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, the heart surgeon, has bequeathed his eyes to the Sao Paulo eye bank. During a visit to the Clinicas Hospital yesterday, the South African heart transplant expert was approached by a volunteer worker for the eye bank.
LISBON, Sept. 26 -- The appointment of Marcelo Caetano as the successor to Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar was announced today by President Americo Thomaz.
Deputy Chief Inspector James H. Cotter, head of the Chief Inspector's Confidential Investigating Unit of the Police Department, retired yesterday after more than 30 years of service.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Commerce Department today estimated last week's total retail store sales at $6,413,000,000, up 8 per cent from the year-earlier $5,955,000,000.
HAVANA, Sept. 26 (UPI) -The Soviet steamer Michel Kalinin landed 223 North Vietnamese children today in Havana, where they will continue their studies under Cuban scholarship grants.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

SAN DIEGO, Sept. 26 -- Five major tournaments with purses totaling $700,000 annually are about to drop from the control of the Professional Golfers Association in favor of the new group organized by the touring players.

There is no better evidence of the difference between President Johnson and Vice President Humphrey on Vietnam policy than the decision of George Ball to resign as Mr. Johnson's Ambassador at the United Nations to be Mr. Humphrey's principal adviser in the election campaign.

BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 26 -- Estudiantes of Argentina, holder of the South American Cup, defeated Manchester United of England, holder of the European Cup, by 1-0 last night in the first leg of the world club-title soccer series.

KOSICE, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 25 -- The Soviet occupation forces in eastern Slovakia brought along a psychological-warfare detachment in an apparent attempt to exploit the differences between Slovaks, Hungarians and Ukrainians in this area and the Czechs of Bohemia and Moravia.

CARTERET, N. J., Sept. 26 (AP) -- One driver was killed and another was injured today in a chain-reaction collision of three trucks on the New Jersey Turnpike. The state police identified the dead man as Edwin L. Lynch, 52 years old of Oxford, Mass.

CAPETOWN, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The world's longest surviving heart transplant patient, Dr. Philip Blaiberg, a retired dentist, was discharged today from Groote Shuur Hospital, where he underwent treatment for three months first for liver inflammation and then for a lung complaint.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -American physicians are the best-informed doctors in the world about drugs and their effects, C. Joseph Stetler, president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association, said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk welcomed today Vice President Humphrey's proposal that a United Nations peacekeeping force be created but he said he doubted that it could function in Vietnam "while the war is in progress."
ALBANY, Sept. 26 -- The State Court of Appeals today unanimously upheld the Democratic primary victory of United States Representative Jacob H. Gilbert in the 22d Congressional District in the Bronx.
BONN, Sept. 26 -- Thirtyone men and women issued a manifesto in Frankfurt today declaring they had founded a new German Communist party in conformity with the West German Government's Constitution.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Reports of a romance between George C. Wallace and a blonde campaign worker were described today by his headquarters as "false, untrue" and an attempt to damage his campaign for the Presidency.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Following are excerpts from the introduction of Secretary General Thant's annual report to the General Assembly:
LAGOS, Nigeria, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The 15 - month - old Nigerian civil war has cost the Nigerian Government at least $840-million, Prof. John Letiche of the University of California said today.

A three-bedroom apartment with fireplaces and a wood-paneled living room is available for rent at Park Avenue and 61st Street for $1,150 a month. The address is socially impeccable, but one must walk through one bedroom to get to another, and the owner advises that one fireplace is a fake and the other probably does not work.

Last June, 24-year-old Bob Bednarski became, more or less, the strongest man in the world. He won the national heavyweight championship in weight lifting, broke two of the four world records and was fitting himself for an Olympic medal, preferably gold.

Two partners and an accountant in the accounting concern of Lybrand, Ross Bros. Montgomery were fined a total of $17,000 in United States District Court here yesterday for misrepresenting a vending company's balance sheet.

The city of Rye, N.Y., started legal action yesterday to prevent the Metropolitan Transportation Authority and the State Department of Transportation from building a highway bridge across Long Island Sound between Rye and Oyster Bay, L.I.
The city's deputy budget director indicated last night that the city would again have to raise money to meet a budget deficit next year.

The STP Corporation, engaged in the marketing of motor oil and fuel additives, made its first public offering of common stock yesterday and investors bid the shares up to $35 from the original price of $25. Goldman, Sachs Co. managed the sale of 700,000 shares of STP, which was organized in January to acquire the STP division of the Studebaker Corporation.

The city's Health Commissioner yesterday coupled a denunciation of a proposed cut in Federal funds for Medicaid that could cost the state $90-million with a warning that municipal hospitals faced a crisis as a result of past Medicaid cuts.

WARSAW, Sept. 26 -- Marshal Ivan I. Yakubovsky's current visits to East European capitals have convinced influential Poles that the Warsaw Pact alliance, whose forces he commands, is planning a major military build-up in the Balkans.
WASHINGTON -- Not many girls get a leave of absence from their jobs with such ease, and for such an important cause.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Ralston Purina Company announced today its board of directors had acted to resolve what it termed a possible conflict of interest among certain directors, officers and employes who purchased stock of a new company.

Richard S. Salant, the president of C. B. S. News, excoriated "good citizens" and "some government officials" yesterday for their "immensely dangerous" proposals to limit broadcast news coverage after the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last month.
The two main subjects yesterday at the stormy, threehour, annual meeting of Glen Alden Corporation were dividends and Schenley Industries, Inc.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Dave McNally yielded three doubles to the first six batters he faced, then settled down and pitched his 22d victory of the season tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 7-1 decision over the Cleveland Indians.
Merger negotiations have been terminated between Famous Artists Schools, Inc., and Frederick Chusid Co., it was announced jointly yesterday. No reason was given.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The General Accounting Office said today that the Government had saved about $520,000 in fees after the office discovered overestimates of cost in a National Aeronautics and Space Administration contract with the Bendix Corporation.

VIENNA, Sept. 26 -- The chairman of the United States Atomic Energy Commission expressed the view today that the invasion of Czechoslovakia had "only delayed" the signing and ratification of the treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

MINNEAPOLIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The first Negro ever chosen to head a major board of the United Methodist Church was selected yesterday. He is Bishop Noah W. Moore Jr. of Lincoln, Neb., who was chosen as head of the board of evangelists.

GUATEMALA, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- President Julio Cesar Mendez Montenegro today extended for a further 30 days a limited state of emergency declared last month following the assassination of Ambassador John Gordon Mein of the United States.
Forty giant California condors nestle high in the cliffs along the Pacific Ocean. Living in the thick swamps of Florida are 40 Everglades kites. They are the only survivors of once common species.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Three more groups of military reservists fighting deployment to Vietnam were denied Supreme Court stays today.

CAIRO, Sept. 26 -- An Egyptian Government spokesman declared today that Cairo had accepted and had agreed to implement the Security Council resolution of Nov. 22, 1967, which "excludes the annihilation of the Israeli state."
MIAMI, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- A tropical depression in the Atlantic northwest of Bermuda developed today into tropical storm Frances, the sixth storm of the hurricane season.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- James R. Hoffa, the Teamster leader, who is serving a four-year sentence for jury tampering, asked the Supreme Court today to reverse its ruling denying him his fourth request for a new trial.

A Roman Catholic priest said yesterday that he had resigned as a member of the city's Council Against Poverty in protest over Mayor Lindsay's "deafness to the pleas of the dislocated poor" of the West Side Urban Renewal Area.

Joe Morrison, an elder statesman of the team, was the first player on the field yesterday at Yankee Stadium where the Giants established tenancy for the 1968 season. The Yankees had left Wednesday night and football replaced baseball in the famous old stadium.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle has imposed sanctions on two more priests because of their stand on birth control, it was disclosed today. This raises the total punished by him to 16.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Colombia and Rumania signed trade and payment agreements today. The two countries agreed to establish permanent commercial missions and to resume normal diplomatic relations.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- President de Gaulle paid warm tribute to Premier Johnson today as an ardent advocate of closer relations between France and French-speaking Canada.

The Rangers start an adventurous 48 hours tonight when they return to Madison Square Garden to meet the National Hockey League champions, the Montreal Canadiens, in an exhibition game more important than the usual preseason contest.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -White House and State Department sources tacitly confirmed today reports that the Soviet Government had recently proposed to the United States a peace plan for the Middle East.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The International Amateur Athletic Federation has barred the athletic shoe with 68 brush-type spikes, track and field managers learned today.

William S. Payson, who 10 years ago founded Avery, Hand Co., in Westport, Conn., came to the Princeton Club yesterday to make some important announcements. With him were Peter F. M. Stewart and Charles H. Hanson, both very much involved.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Striking nonprofessional workers at city hospitals defied a city ultimatum today and refused to show up for work. At issue are higher pay and other benefits.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- The Chrysler Corporation rolled back its new-car prices today.

Construction work will start soon on a three-story office building with a total of 150,000 square feet of floor space in Great Neck, L. I. The building site, consisting of about two acres at 98 Cutter Mill Road, near the Long Island Railroad Station, was formerly the property of Mobilite, Inc., lamp manufactuer. Mobilite's 50,000square-foot building will be razed for the office structure.
In a display of courage beyond the pall of duty, S. J. Perelman arrived in New York the other day.

The Hakodate Dock Company, Ltd., Tokyo, has announced the opening of a liaison office here in the Pan American Building, 200 Park Avenue. The shipbuilders maintain construction and repairing facilities at Kakodate and Muroran in Kokkaido, Japan.

The Wilmington Advertising Club got the inside dope yesterday on the hows and whys of Benton Bowles's Jack Benny campaign for Texaco as well as a few words on humor in advertising from Mr. Benny himself.
Steve Cooper has been named vice president of the Wamsutta Knitting Mills Division of M. Lowenstein Sons. He was previously general sales manager in charge of merchandising for Wamsutta.

Bobby Douglas of Bridgeport, Ohio, and Capt. Wayne Baughman of Colorado Springs, Colo., were named yesterday captains of the United States Olympic wrestling teams. Douglas, a featherweight, will be captain of the free-style squad, while Baughman, a middleweight, will head the Greco-Roman team.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford declared today that he was mobilizing the resources of the defense establishment in a determined attack on some of the nation's basic domestic problems.
A bid to use Shea Stadium for a political rally on behalf of George C. Wallace was turned down yesterday by August -Heckscher, the city's Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator.
LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The Fulbright program of international exchanges in higher education is heading for an end in Europe as a result of Congressional budget cuts.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- The United Nations, which has tossed many a brickbat in Washington's direction recently, now finds itself being treated by the Administration with little respect and scant attention. George W. Ball, whose appointment as chief of the United States delegation was confirmed only yesterday, resigned today, four days before a scheduled speech explaining United States policy to the 23d session of the General Assembly.
The Mercury Theater, the first resident professional theater company in Auckland, New Zealand, has ended its first four months of activity showing a profit, the New Zealand News Letter reports.

With the arrest yesterday of two welfare clients who willfully disrupted operations at a Brooklyn welfare center the city at last showed that it will not permit such violations of the law to go unpunished. The disruption was part of a continuing campaign against certain welfare policies and it was a test of the city's resolve, after a destructive rampage at three centers last week, which had resulted in no arrests.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission has dealt a heavy blow to plans for building a 55-story office tower above the waiting room of Grand Central Terminal.
