William H. Chartener, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Economic Affairs, told a blue-ribbon group of corporate economists yesterday that they should press for a break-up of what he termed an "academic monopoly" among economic policymakers.

MIYAZAKI, Japan, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Sulfredo Basco of the Philippines, won the Orient junior featherweight championship today by stopping the champion, Kiyohide Yuzudo, in the 10th round of a scheduled 12-round fight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Vice President Humphrey, campaigning in California, strongly reaffirmed today his support of American involvement in Vietnam but promised to take a fresh look at the war "with new advisers" if he won the Presidency.

"I DON'T know how we're going to stop Marty Domres -- especially since we gave up four scoring passes against Rutgers last week. We know how good Domres is. In fact, we think we'll be facing a tough team in Columbia."
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Edgar Lacy, former University of California, Los Angeles, star, has signed with the Los Angeles Stars of the American Basketball Association.
DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie encountered a new demand from students today -- that he grant them silence rather than respond to a question.
Two women were arrested yesterday at the Clinton Welfare Center in Brooklyn in what was described as a test of the city's crackdown on destructive welfare demonstrations.

The bodies of four children who drowned when their boat capsized Wednesday in Jamaica Bay with eight others aboard were recovered yesterday morning by police divers. The police found the bodies near the site of the accident off Beach 43d Street in Norton Basin, Far Rockaway.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Secretary General Thant, in a bleak estimate of international economic cooperation, deplored today the "staggering proportions" of armament expenditures that absorb funds needed to fight world poverty.

A new three-year working agreement has been reached by Pepsico and the Intenational Longshoremen's Association, Local 1476, according to the union. Pepsico is Pepsi-Cola's sugar refining plant in Long Island City, Queens, N.Y.

MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 -Eight of the leaders who for two months have been carrying on a strike and agitation by university and secondary school students sat around a classroom yesterday and explained to a reporter that they would do nothing to hinder the Olympic Games here Oct. 12-27.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:

Appointment of Brother Barnabas Paul as director of the National Office of the Christian Brothers was announced yesterday by Brother Leo Kirby, assistant to the Superior General of the order. Brother Barnabas, a native of New York, was formerly principal of St. Augustine High School and Bishop Loughlin Memorial High in Brooklyn.

Charles Evers, head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People in Mississippi, will open a four-day campaign swing for Hubert H. Humphrey at a noontime rally today at Seventh Avenue and West 38th Street.
MOSCOW, Sept. 26 -- An ideological justification for the intervention in Czechoslovakia was advanced today by Pravda, newspaper of the Soviet Communist party.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Sept 26 (AP) -- Gov. Ronald Reagan signed today a bill sought by friends of the Kennedy family to prevent mass publication of photographs taken during the Robert F. Kennedy autopsy.

ROME, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -Pontifical flags flew over Vatican buildings today to celebrate Pope Paul's 71st birthday. Messages of good wishes flooded in from world statesmen, religious leaders and organizations.

ATHENS, Sept. 24 -- A Greek military policeman chased an American woman into the lobby of the United States Embassy late today at the end of a rather hectic day for the touring Tenenbaum family of Boulder, Colo.
In an unexpected move on the eve of the New York City public high school football season, the striking United Federation of Teachers told the coaches yesterday not to go through with the games.
PRINGFIELD, N. J.,.Sept. 26 -- Martin M. Issler, head of the New Jersey Seniors Golf Association also became its champion today.
A new type of specialized department store, emphasizing imports and aimed largely at the fashion-conscious suburbanite and city dweller, is being established by Eugene Ferkauf and Allan J. Bloostein.

YONKERS, Sept. 26 -- Lucien Paul Fontaine, not yet 30 years old but away from his native Pointe aux Trembles, Quebec, so long he has almost forgotten what the town looks like, had been enjoying the harness racing beat -- but not recently.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended Sept. 21 totaled an estimated 15.1 billion ton-miles, an increase of 5.3 per cent over the comparable 1967 week.

PARIS, Sept. 26 -- The French Government today was reliably reported weighing the difficult decision whether to permit or veto close association of Citroen, France's No. 2 automobile maker, with Fiat of Italy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- President Johnson announced today the resignation of George W. Ball as chief United States representative to the United Nations and nominated James Russell Wiggins, editor and executive vice president of The Washington Post, to succeed him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 26 -- Richard M. Nixon headed South today to try to wrest the Border states from George C. Wallace without dignifying the third-party challenger or engaging him in direct debate.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 26 -- Premier Levi Eshkol warned tonight that Arab border provocations could lead to another war in the Middle East.

BLACK pants. White pants. Silk pants. Satin pants. Plain pants. Fancy pants. Baggy pants. Tight pants. Yes, women are wearing pants this fall, if the designers and other fashion-connected women who turned up for the annual Coty American Fashion Critics' Awards show last night were any indication.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 26 -- St. Louis high school students did Hubert H. Humphrey's work for him today. They threw at Richard M. Nixon many of the questions the Vice President has demanded he answer. Mr. Nixon's replies came mostly from his standard campaign speech.

STRASBOURG, Sept. 26 -- The Consultative Assembly of the 18-nation Council of Europe today branded the draft Greek constitution as undemocratic and called for free parliamentary elections in Greece within six months.

AREA A -- The best flounder fishing in 10 years is being reported by anglers in the Barnegat Light area with cut bait being attacked ravenously by the flat fish. Plenty of albacore, 5-to-7 pounds, are being taken with spoons and red feathers from Manasquan Inlet to Atlantic City, Anglers chumming Manasquan Ridge have been scoring heavily with 8-to-15-pound bluefish.
Narcotics said to have a street sale value of $8-million to $10-million were seized in an early morning raid yesterday at an East Village storefront church.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 -- The Flying Lady, a hallmark hood ornament on Rolls-Royce luxury cars for years but missing on 1968 models as a concession to safety, is back again on 1969 cars with a new-found spring to her feet.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Senate prepared today for a roll-call vote Tuesday on whether to curtail debate on the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States.
HOBOKEN, N. J., Sept. 26 -Dr. Preston R. Clement, dean of the faculty at Stevens Institute of Technology, has been named provost of the college.

Fifty teachers picketed the Ford Foundation for two hours yesterday, alleging that in "financing" the Ocean Hill-Brownsville local-control school project in Brooklyn, the foundation was supporting racism and union busting.

"BLONDIE," a half-hour comedy series based on Chic Young's famous cartoon characters, had its premiere last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System. It is seen locally Thursdays on Channel 2 at 7:30 P.M.

ANOTHER World Series approaches and it will be distinguished for the first time in more than three decades by a 30-game winner, Denny McLain of the Tigers. If history repeats itself as unerringly as the experts contend it does, the hard-throwing Detroiter should beat the formidable Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals in the opener because almost every previous 30-game winner won his opening Series joust. Don't bet on it, though.
The Detroit Edison Company sold $150-million of bonds yesterday, the largest public offering of debt securities ever made by an investor-owned, operating electric utility.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Donald Carl Dunham, a former United States foreign service officer, has been named resident representative of the United Nations development program for Australia and New Zealand.
New chief executive officers were elected yesterday by four major corporations, while a fifth moved its chief executive from president to chairman.

Zubin Mehta, conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, has accepted a post as musical adviser to the Israel Philharmonic for the next three years. The Israel Philharmonic has no permanent conductor. Mr. Mehta will spend at least two months a year with the orchestra.

THIS, if you will pardon the frankness, is going to be a difficult notice to write. On the cover of the Playbill for Robert Shaw's "The Man in the Glass Booth," which opened at the Royale Theater last night, is a diagrammatic picture of a man in a glass booth.

A special benefit concert to aid the Alan King Medical Center in Jerusalem will be held at Philharmonic Hall at 8:30 P.M. Sunday. Among the performers scheduled to appear are Harry Belafonte, Johnny Carson, Buddy Hackett, Dustin Hoffman, Alan King, Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme.

George W. Ball predicted last night that the Vietnam war "will be well on its way toward an honorable political solution" within the first few months of the next Presidential term -- if Vice President Humphrey is elected President.

Eavesdropped conversations played back on a tape yesterday at the departmental trial of a suspended patrolman, Leonard Grossman, were described by police witnesses as those of Mr. Grossman and Michael Scandifia, an ex-convict and reputed member of the Mafia, while plotting the murder of stool pigeons.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 26 -- The city School Board early today dismissed John O. Hopkins as head of the community school project after a 5 1/2-hour hearing punctuated by cheers and jeers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -The cutback in the Fulbright international exchange program is a result of action by Con gress not the Administration.

UMUAHIA, Biafra, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Biafran leader, said today that his secessionist state's war with Nigeria is "just beginning," despite a string of federal military victories.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after an early advance faded in a steady retreat.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Treasury Secretary Henry H. Fowler said today that Spiro T. Agnew had done a "disservice to the country" by what Mr. Fowler said was criticism of the United States savings bond program.
Prices barely held their own in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- The Chrysler Corporation said today it would build an auto assembly plant at New Stanton, Pa., 32 miles southeast of Pittsburgh. The plant is to be in production in the summer of 1970 and will have a capacity of 200,000 cars a year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -Orville L. Freeman accused Richard M. Nixon today of talking "garbage" to farmers. The Secretary of Agriculture challenged the Republican Presidential candidate to say specifically whether he would keep or kill programs to aid farmers.

ATLANTA, Sept. 27 (UPI) -Curtis Person of Memphis made it past the second round of the United States Golf Association's senior tournament today for the first time. The 58-year-old player defeated Jack Purdum of Sharon Center, Ohio, 1 up.

PETWORTH, England (Canadian Press) -- A 100-year-old Sussex railway station, closed several years ago, is making its contribution to Britain's export drive and keeping thousands of children happy at the same time.
The Feria de Sevilla, a Spanish costume gala for the benefit of the Helen Keller World Crusade for the Blind, drew 400 party goers to the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park last night.

All parties to the school crisis could and should have made use of yesterday as a breathing space to prepare the way for an orderly and peaceful return to the classroom today. The time ought to have been devoted to allaying fears and cooling hostilities.

BOSTON, Sept. 26 -- A simmering school dispute spilled violently into the streets of Boston tonight, and Mayor Kevin H. White announced the formation of a biracial committee under his leadership to study school decentralization.

The United States submarine Hardhead, which sank nine Japanese ships during World War II, will be open for public inspection from 1 P.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow. The Hardhead will be berthed at Pier 86, at the foot of West 46th Street.

MADRID, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Real Madrid of Spain eliminated Atlantic of Limassol, Cyprus, from the European Soccer Cup of League Champions with a 6-0 victory in the second leg of their first round match tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Two world boxing championships will be at stake in Memorial Coliseum tomorrow night in a program expected to draw 20,000 fans and $200,000 at the box office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee will meet next Thursday to decide what course to follow on the so-called equal-time suspension bill to make possible televised debates between Presidential candidates.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- President Johnson is going to carry on his official duties actively right up to the end of his term Jan. 20, his press secretary, George Christian, said today.
On major Continental stock markets, the trend continued mixed with prices of domestic shares in Paris showing firmness. Prices in Frankfurt were easier.

BERKELEY, Calif., Sept. 26 (AP) -- Tom Gorman of Seattle upset Bob Lutz, the United States Davis Cup player, 6-4, 2-6, 6-0, today to gain the quarter-finals in the Pacific Coast tennis tournament. Lutz was the third-seeded player in the tournament, and Gorman was 13th.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Attorney General Ramsey Clark will meet with the chiefs of the nation's major police departments next month in their continuing study of the prevention and control of civil disorder.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 26 -- Yale University announced today that tuition fees and room and board expenses at its undergraduate college would rise a total of $300 to $3,600 for the 1969-70 school year to meet rising costs.

One of the largest and oldest privately owned enterprises in the United States is about to go public. It is the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company of Brooklyn, founded in 1842 and run by the Schaefer family ever since.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 -- United States armor took a large toll of enemy lives yesterday in continued fighting on the flatlands to the southwest of Tamky, near the coast of the South China Sea.
Following are the disputants' positions on specific issues in the school strike:

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -The nation's railroads appealed to the Interstate Commerce Commission today to use emergency procedures to permit the rails to put into effect immediaely the freight rate increases they asked for last March.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 26 -- Vice President Humphrey sent a telegram today to Mr. Nixon saying that he had asked his campaign manager, Lawrence F. O'Brien, to confer with a representative from the Nixon camp to work out arrangements for "what I hope will be a series of debates."

The appointment of Dr. Daniel S. Martin as chairman of surgery for the Catholic Medical Center of Brooklyn and Queens was announced yesterday. The center embraces six hospital divisions. Dr. Martin will make his headquarters at Mary Immaculate Hospital in Jamaica, Queens.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Mexican authorities announced today that at least 15 persons were killed and more than 500 injured yesterday in an earthquake in the southern state of Chiapas.

DETROIT, Sept. 26 -- The Ford Motor Company said yesterday that it was recalling 41,850 Econoline vehicles for a possible safety defect. The Econoline series includes van-shaped trucks, buses and recreation vehicles.
Zubin Mehta, conductor of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, has accepted a post as musical adviser to the Israel Philharmonic for the next three years.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 26 -- Mrs. Cutting Cushing of Meadow Brook and Mrs. Maurice Moore of Rockville Links gained the 36-hole final today of the Women's Long Island Golf Association championship over the 6,155-yard, par 35, 36-71 Piping Rock course.

The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum announced yesterday that because of the school strike city school children would be admitted free today from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. The decision -the first such by the museum -was reached by the trustees, who felt that Mastercraftsmen of Peru, the exhibition now on view, was one of the museum's major accomplishments in its continuing program of educational exhibitions.
DONGHA, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 -- United States marines, operating in the extreme north of South Vietnam, have changed their style of fighting in the last six months.

When Charles A. Wellman completes the job of rehabilitating Lytton Financial, there are likely to be few signs remaining of the flamboyant Bart Lytton, who lost control of his savings and loan empire last April.
Savagery and sentiment hypnotized 9,128 boxing aficionados last night at Madison Square Garden.

INWOOD, L. I. Sept. 26 -The moat guarding the 18th green at the Inwood Country Club proved a dangerous hazard for both Jerry Pittman and Mike Fetchick in the Metropolitan open golf championship today. Each knocked his second shot there into the water.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 26 (AP) -- Police Chief Mario F. Floriani was given a raise today that will increase his $10,000-a-year salary by $2,500. Last week he turned down an offer of a $20,000-a-year appointment as Trenton's Public Safety director.

The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York started its 51st annual campaign last night with a record goal of $29.5-million for the maintenance and support of its 130 affiliated social service and medical institutions.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, who is opposed to capital punishment, reserved decision today on an order for the execution of the convicted slayer of a policeman.

Investors purchased $530,986,000 of new mutual fund shares in August, up from $346,519,000 a year earlier, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. They redeemed $308,703,000, up from the year-ago level of $249,055,000.

When the Original Dixieland Jazz Band introduced jazz to midtown Manhattan in 1917, the Plaza Hotel was only three blocks away from Reisenweber's, the restaurant on Columbus Circle where those first jazz sounds were heard.

HIGHLANDS, N. J. Sept. 26 -- For its 1968 benefit, the Monmouth County Organization for Social Service has scheduled for Saturday an Electric Circus dance in the Pin-Up Lounge here. Proceeds from the event, which will include two rock bands, a light show, go-go girls and a buffet supper, will go to the organization's community nursing program.

There is no question that the United States Senate has the obligation to put Associate Justice Fortas' judicial and ethical standards under the closest examination in fulfillment of its constitutional duty to pass upon Mr. Fortas' nomination for the post of Chief Justice. But this involves debate, not filibuster.

The International Business Machines Corporation has elected Frank T. Cary, senior vice president and general manager of its data processing group, to its board of directors, it was announced yesterday.
Gil Hodges was reported making good progress in Atlanta yesterday following the mild heart attack he suffered during the Mets-Braves baseball game Tuesday night.

OMAHA, Sept. 26 (AP) -- The Confederate and the rebel flag will no longer be the symbol of Archbishop Rummel High School, a five-year-old parochial school. In a prepared statement, the school said, "The symbols of the rebel and the Confederate flag represent in the minds of many people a society that has attempted to destroy our system of government and maintain the enslavement of millions of black people."
ATLANTA, Sept. 26 -- The Atlanta Constitution, long respected for the caliber of its editors, will begin publishing without one next week.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 26 -- The Executive Council of the Episcopal Church today banned all official gatherings in Chicago for a period of one year because of what it called the city's efforts to "justify po lice violence" during the Democratic National Convention.
BAKERSFIELD, Calif., Sept. 26 -- H. L. Hunt, the Texas oil billionaire, has spent two days here organizing the League for Liberty and promoting his HLH products at the Kern County fair.
PRAGUE, Sept. 26 -- The Czechoslovak leadership met all day and well into the evening today to consider its next move in efforts to speed the gradual withdrawal of Soviet-led occupation forces.

Construction began yesterday on Ohrbach's 100,000-squarefoot store in the Willowbrook Mall, Wayne, N. J. The twolevel store, to be Ohrbach's second in New Jersey, is due to open in the fall of 1969. Ohrbach's and Sears, Roebuck will operate the main stores in the new mall.

TRENTON, Sept. 26 -- Racial strife closed Trenton High School today for the fourth time in nine months and spilled over into a nearby park, where an angry crowd of boycotting white students threatened to chase out a smaller group of Negro students who had come to make peace.
The General Tire and Rubber Company showed sharp increases in earnings for the three months and nine months ended Aug. 31, it was reported yesterday.
PARIS, Sept. 26 -- Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel today rejected a Soviet plan for a Middle East peace settlement.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Air Force's Titan 3C orbited four satellites in a 6 1/2-hour display of precision rocketry today and all four, including an experimental tactical radio satellite, began sending signals back to earth.

MOSCOW, Sept. 25 -- Following is the text' of an article titled "Sovereignty and International Duties of Socialist Countries," published today in Pravda, Soviet Communist party newspaper, and translated by Novosti, Soviet press agency:

It is almost unthinkable that any pianist would pone a New York debut recital with Charles Ives's First Sonata, but that is what Nina Deutsch did in Carnegie Hall last night. The work is typically Ivesian, a half-hour of rummaging around within his own private musical attic, lighting here and there on a fondly remembered tune that has fallen into shreds and patches.

DEMOCRACY AND THE STUDENT LEFT. By George F. Kennan and Students and Teachers from: Barnard, Brandeis, Brooklyn, California, Columbia, Cornell, Dartmouth, Harvard, Illinois Institute of Technology, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Notre Dame, Ohio State, Princeton, Rochester, Rutgers, Syracuse, Toronto, Wesleyan, West Virginia, Williams, Yale. 239 pages. Atlantic-Little, Brown. $5.75.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Following are the texts of a statement by President Johnson announcing acceptance of the resignation of George W. Ball as permanent United States representative at the United Nations, of a statement by Mr. Ball, of Mr. Ball's letter of resignation and of a letter from the President to Mr. Ball:

CAMDEN, N. J., Sept. 26 -- Cazzie Russell's two field goals in the last nine seconds tonight, the second going through at the buzzer, gave the New York Knickerbockers a 113-112 come-from-behind victory over the Philadelphia 76'ers in the opening National Basketball Association exhibition for each club.

A member of the Columbia chapter of the Students for a Democratic Society last night cited the details of a psychology professor's classified $37,185 research contract with the Department of Defense at a hectic campus meeting as the professor sat nearby listening.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- President Johnson has asked the Senate to approve a treaty outlining jurisdiction in hijacking and other offenses aboard airplanes on international flights.

Suggestions that the sprawling, diverse and often embattled Long Island University be split into two separate institutions have been rejected in a detailed study prepared by Heald, Hobson and Associates, the educational consulting firm.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- Secretary General Thant today proposed a meeting of the Big Four leaders to halt what he described as a spreading feeling of insecurity in the world.

Art Carney and Zoe Caldwell teetered on a ladder at the northwest corner of Seventh Avenue and 44th Street yesterday afternoon, as if they were rehearsing a precarious scene in a new comedy, and hung up a sign giving directions to legitimate theaters nearby.

The money market was tight during the week ending Wednesday, banking figures released yesterday showed. Funds were generally in short supply throughout the period, despite the reduction in minimum business-loans rates by most of the nation's major commercial banks.
The Allied Chemical Corporation announced yesterday that it expected to report a loss for the third quarter.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today approved an agreement under which Pan American World Airways will take over and operate Teterboro Airport in New Jersey for general-aviation planes.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 26 -- The elite of Texas society turned out tonight for a remarkable fashion show, a dinner dance and a glimpse of Prince Rainier III and Princess Grace of Monaco.

The Board of Education's order calling for the return of 110 disputed teachers to the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district violates the district's new educational philosophy and personnel organization, the unit's administrator said yesterday.

Business lacks a favorable image and, in fact, is looked down upon as lacking morality, a day-long meeting was told here yesterday. The gathering was the 45th anniversary convocation of the American Management Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Ginastera's "Bomarzo" was given by the New York City Opera at the State Theater last night for the first time this season, and it found the company in peak form.

JOAN HARRISON, the gifted associate of Alfred Hitchcock in matters of calculated horror, is the executive producer of "Journey to the Unknown." Her program started very promisingly last night with an exceptionally artistic projection of a fantasy about a distraught boy who falls in love with a mannequin in a store window.

HOUSTON, Sept. 26 (UPI) -William J. Whaley, who was the world's only living lung transplant patient, died tonight at Methodist Hospital of acute respiratory infection. Mr. Whaley lived longer, 27 days, than any other lung transplant patient in history.

State Supreme Court Justice Francis J. Bloustein paved the way yesterday for criminal contempt proceedings against the United Federation of Teachers and the Council of Supervisory Association by issuing a preliminary injunction ordering both groups back to work.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- A compromise bill to put $7.2-billion into the nation's colleges and universities, but at the same time curbing campus demonstrators, cleared the House today in scarcely three minutes.
A rally staged by Columbia University radicals erupted into violence last night, only hours after classes had opened for the fall term in an atmosphere of unaccustomed peace and tranquility.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Sept. 26 -- James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for Senator, was greeted here today by supporters wearing Wallace buttons, and was told that a majority of his followers in this southern tier region also were supporting the former Governor of Alabama for President.
The new cars, showrooms and headquarters building of the General Motors Corporation were introduced to the public yesterday.
Federal mediators plugged away yesterday at the deadlock in the waterfront labor dispute with no sign of progress.

How close to race warfare the school strike has brought this city was made brutally plain in two rallies held Wednesday night just after the Board of Education announced, with Mayor Lindsay's support, its equitable plan for reopening all the schools.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Mordechai Shpigler scored all four goals with a brilliant sharpshooting exhibition last night as the Israeli Olympic soccer team defeated the United States World Cup squad, 4-0, before 7,500 at Temple Stadium.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- The Morning Star, newspaper of the British Communist party, criticized the Pravda article as a "red herring" designed to divert attention from the Soviet violation of the oft-stated prin ciple that no Communist state or group of states had the right to intervene in another Communist country against its wishes.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 25 -The flight of Arab refugees from Israeli-occupied territory to the Kingdom of Jordan has ended for the time being.
JERUSALEM, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- A brief exchange of shots between Israelis and Jordanians broke out today across the Jordan River.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 26 -- Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic were enthusiastically received last night in the Tivoli Concert Hall, where they gave a gala program under the auspices of the State Department.
The merger of the KayserRoth Corporation into the Penn Central Company is expected to take place about Jan. 1, 1969, the heads of both concerns announced yesterday.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- Former Gov. William M. Scranton of Pennsylvania, on a mission for the Republican Presidential candidate, Richard M. Nixon, was briefed today on the West's defense readiness.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 26 (Reuters) -- The Soviet lunar space craft Zond-5 will be brought to Bombay next week and then flown home to the Soviet Union, a Soviet Embassy spokesman said today. The spokesman said that Zond-5, which splashed down in the Indian Ocean Saturday after flying around the moon, would arrive next Tuesday or Wednesday.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 26 (AP) -Defense Minister Moshe Dayan says that resumption of war in the Middle East is more likely now than it was a few months ago.
LISBON, Sept. 25 -- "It is the most difficult succession in the country's history," Prof. Marcelo Caetano told friends who visited him after Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar suffered a stroke.

DENVER, Sept. 26 (AP) -Three international officers of the United Rubber, Cork, Linoleum and Plastic Workers of America were re-elected for two-year terms here today. They are Peter Bommarito of Akron, Ohio, president; Kenneth Oldham, vice president, and Ike Gold, secretary-treasurer.

The Anken Chemical and Film Corporation announced yesterday that John B. Blakely, chairman, and M. Richard Boyer, vice president, had resigned as directors and officers of the concern. It said the resignations were based on personal

THE Expansion Draft, by which the four new major league teams will be stocked with players in mid-October, has provided baseball with its hottest topic of conversation in many years. Everyone interested, from owners and general managers down through the players themselves and the fans, have been making up "protected" lists, trying to guess who will be retained, who will be gobbled up by the new teams, and who will be available but unchosen.
HARTFORD, Sept. 26 -- Fifteen Connecticut taxpayers filed suit today to halt Federal construction grants to church-related colleges and universities.
Hong Kong flu is here in the United States.

The city offered its 22,000 patrolmen a $700 salary increase over two years during contract negotiations yesterday. But negotiators for the patrolmen, like those for the sanitationmen a day earlier, rejected the city's proposal as inadequate.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 (AP) -- A special House subcommittee said today the price the Army is to pay for M-I6 rifles in its most recent contracts is unreasonable and should be lowered.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 26 -- A trickle of labor union funds has started lubricating the lagging Senate campaign of John J. Gilligan, and he is expected to be endorsed formally tomorrow by the political arm of the Ohio A.F.L.-C.I.O.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 26 (AP) -- United States economic officials today labeled as exaggerated a statement by the South Vietnamese Director of Customs that $120-million in post-exchange goods ended up on the black market in 1967.
Senator Javits drew cheers from a roomful of real-estate men yesterday by lecturing them on their moral responsibility to build and rehabilitate housing in Negro slums.
A playhouse 30 feet below a 42-story office building may become the rent-free home of the American Place Theater.

OTTAWA, Sept. 26 -- Premier Daniel Johnson of Quebec, regarded throughout Canada as one of the most moderate voices in Quebec politics, died in his sleep last night at Manicouagan, in northern Quebec.

"DOWN through the years, people have called the Sears catalogue the Wish Book." That's what it says in the latest Sears, Roebuck and Company catalogue -- its 606-page Christmas edition -- and the company wastes no time making it possible for a shopper to do some quite expensive wishing. Right on the inside front cover of the 30-ounce book is a white mink robe for $4,500.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The nation's modest trade surplus of July shrank in August as imports rose faster than exports, the Commerce Department reported today.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Sept. 26 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy removed himself today as a possible choice for the largely honorary title of Rector of Glasgow University. The Minnesota Senator said in a letter that he understood that his candidacy would hurt another candidate, Lord MacLub, whose sponsors had written that his views on the war in Vietnam were similar to the Senator's and that Lord MacLub was willing to be an active rector.

The appointment of Albert H. Price, controller of the Ronson Corporation, as vice president of Ronson servicedomestic consumer products, was announced yesterday. His appointment to this new post is effective Oct. 1.

Wheat prices moved up about a penny a bushel yesterday, following their recent small show of strength. Yesterday traders were talking of somewhat expanded buying by foreign nations of wheat for shipment abroad under Government aid programs.
Two tellers from two different savings and loan institutions were accused in Federal Court yesterday of embezzling a total of $130,000.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that prohibitions against the broadcasting of loterry advertising and information apply to state-sponsored lotteries, such as New York's.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 26 -- Mutual funds, pension funds and other institutions contributed more than their share to the huge gain in the volume of stock trading in the AprilJune quarter, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

SEATTLE, Sept. 26 (UPI) -- The Seattle Pilots plan to sponsor a Pioneer League baseball team in Billings, Mont., which has not had professional baseball since 1963, Marvin Milkes, general manager of the American League expansion team, announced today.
The 32d annual dinner dance sponsored by the Italian Charities of America, Inc., will be held Saturday in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton. Thomas Manno is general chairman of the event.

LONDON, Sept. 26 -- Recent price declines on the London Stock Exchange worsened in early trading today and gave the market its sharpest setback in months. But a heavy buying rally near the close slowed the trend and cut earlier losses.

The Malaysian state of Sabah on the northern tip of Borneo is a Maine-sized tropical paradise, rich in rubber, timber and fisheries and with more than enough fertile land to support its half-million people.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy returned from a European vacation yesterday and told newsmen at Kennedy Airport, "I look a little better to you now after those other candidates, don't I?"

Swift Co., the world's largest meat packer, is going into the oil business through the proposed purchase of two privately held companies engaged in exploration, refining, marketing and transportation of petroleum products, for stock worth $36.5-million.
SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 25 -- "Democracy does not bloom in a day, and Korea is no exception," said the editorial page of a Seoul newspaper this week.

PRAGUE, Sept. 27 -- Marshal Ivan I. Yakubovsky, Soviet commander in chief of the Warsaw Pact forces, arrived in Prague today as the Russians sought to consolidate their military and political influence here.

Lincoln Hospital, which stands like a grim, brick fortress in the slums of the Southeast Bronx, decked its halls with balloons and streamers, opened its doors and invited the community to an unusual kind of fair this week.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The United States court of appeals for the Fifth Circuit was asked by the Federal Government today for a landmark decision giving poor people the right to court-appointed defense attorneys in misdemeanor cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -The Senate Appropriations Committee today restored $313million, or most of the funds slashed by the House, to the foreign aid spending bill. The committee approved a money bill of $1.93-billion, compared with the House figure of $1.6billion.

CHERRY POINT, N. C., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- A DC-7 Universal Airlines cargo plane crashed and burned today in a wooded area near the Cherry Point Marine Air Station. The three civilian crewmen escaped serious injury.

The election of Raymond J. Armstrong as a member of the board of directors of Amtel, Inc., a diversified manufacturer, was announced yesterday. Mr. Armstrong is president of American Dual Vest Fund, Inc., a vice president of the Starwood Corporation, and a director of a number of companies, including the Teaching Systems and Resources Corporation, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company.
The Commissioner of Markets, Gerard M. Weisberg, was named by Mayor Lindsay yesterday to be the first commissioner of the new Department of Consumer Affairs.

Steve Harris, a junior quarterback, passed for all four touchdowns and kicked the extra point yesterday in pacing Trinity School to a 25-0 victory over Locust Valley Friends at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

A 17-year-old student at Benjamin Franklin High School collapsed and died in the school gymnasium yesterday afternoon after climbing a rope in the gym under the supervision of a teacher. A Metropolitan Hospital spokesman said pulmonary collapse had caused the death of the student, Pedro Santiago, 17 years old, of 211 East 105th Street.

DETROIT, Sept. 27 -- The American Motors Corporation, smallest of the four United States auto manufacturers, said today it had raised 1969 car prices 2.1 per cent, or an average of $56. Optional equipment prices also went up about 1 per cent, the company said.

Tadeusz Kerner, a native of Poland, former citizen of Israel and present resident of New York, had a full house last night for his Carnegie Recital Hall appearance. The program was sponsored by the PolishAmerican Medical Society, Medicus, so after a brief obeisance to Mozart and Debussy, the pianist devoted the evening to works by three Polish composers: Karol Szymanowski, Tadeusz Szeligowski and Chopin.
LISBON, Sept. 27 -- Mornings, shiny yellow trolley cars float through the green mist hanging over the harbor and up into the sunlight splashing the city's seven hills.
Teachers in Public School 6, on the Upper East Side, will be helping to enroll students in classes instead of picketing if the strike is still in force Monday.
The Great American Holding Corporation filed suit yesterday in United States District Court here seeking to enjoin the National General Corporation from attempting to take it over.
THE BACK COUNTRY. By Gary Snyder. 128 pages. New Directions. $4. "THE WILD WICKED OLD MAN." And Other Poems. By Archibald MacLeish. 44 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $4.

DON RICKLES, the bald adlibber who specializes in the crushing insult, encountered difficulties last night in the premiere of his own half-hour show at 9 o'clock on the network of the American Broadcasting Company.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Mrs. Peggy Dobbins, 29 years old of Brooklyn, was bound over to a grand jury today on charges of having thrown a stench bomb during a telecast of the Sept. 7 Miss America Pageant near where Mayor Richard S. Jackson and other dignitaries were seated. Mrs. Dobbins, who took part in bra-burnings and other demonstrations against the pageant, was released in $1,000 bail.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 27 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that his Government's rural development program had "more or less" recovered from the blows of the enemy's offensive during Tet, the Lunar New Year, early this year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Subversive Activities Control Board will open its second round of hearings Tuesday on a Government request to name seven persons who are members of the Communist Party, U.S.A., it was announced today.

The North American Rockwell Corporation made a $175-million offer yesterday for the Abex Corporation, which had agreed in principle three weeks earlier to merge into Illinois Central Industries, Inc., in return for stock valued at $130-million at that time.
BONN, Sept 27 -- President de Gaulle met with Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger this afternoon for a crucial round of talks on the European Common Market and Western defense security.

THE Giants open the pro-football season in New York tomorrow against the Washington Redskins at Yankee Stadium, while the Jets are in Buffalo. Both local teams are favored to extend their winning streaks to three games.

PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Princeton's cross-country team took five of the first seven places to pass Seton Hall here today, 19 to 36. Eamon Downey, a junior star for the Tigers, set a course record of 25 minutes 28.5 seconds as he finished first, 22 seconds ahead of his teammate, Rich Stafford.
The city will open 5,278 offices next week where residents may register to vote in the November election.

CHICAGO, Sept. 27 -- United Patriots International agreed today to delay until Sunday a rally in Grant Park in support of the police handling of demonstrators during the Democratic National Convention last month.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Department of Defense awarded two contracts today totaling $475-million toward the construction of the $5-billion "Sentinel" system for defense against intercontinental missiles.

GREENBELT, Md., Sept. 27 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration unveiled here today its heaviest and most sophisticated unmanned scientific satellite, the $75-million Orbiting Astronomical Observatory.

NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Mr. Garrison has subpoenaed the diary of Seymore Gelber, Assistant Attorney General in Florida, on the ground that it allegedly refers to a man who mentioned in April, 1963, the possibility that President Kennedy would be killed with a high-powered rifle from atop a building.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Ralph Nader, the automobile safety crusader, said today that some auto makers had failed to meet the Government's safety standards for seat belts and outside mirrors on 1968 model cars.

BONN, Sept. 27 -- A Frankfurt Court gave Daniel CohnBendit, the radical student leader, an eight-month suspended prison term today after having found him guilty of incitement to riots, breach of the peace and resistance to the law.

The A minor and E major violin concertos of Bach formed the core of the Mozart Festival Orchestra's program at Town Hall last night. Arrayed around these works were Virgil Thomson's "Portrait of Nicolas de Chatelain," the Overture to Sammartini's "Memet," Suk's "Meditation on St. Wenceslas" and Rossini's Sonata in C major.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- Gaston Monnerville, who would be President de Gaulle's successor pending new elections if the presidency became vacant, will soon lose this position, which he enjoys as President of the Senate.
LISBON, Sept. 27 -- Following is the official translation of excerpts from the speech delivered today by Marcelo Caetano after his swearing-in as Premier:

RIDGEFIELD, N. J., Sept. 27 -- Leonia High swept the ends often today for a 20-0 victory over Ridgefield. Kevin Ward, a 165-pound halfback, scored on end runs of 7 and 14 yards, capping long marches in the first and third periods.

OTTAWA, Sept. 27 -- JeanJacques Bertrand, Minister of Justice of the province of Quebec, announced after a Cabinet meeting today that a successor to Premier Daniel Johnson, who died yesterday, would not be chosen until after Mr. Johnson's funeral.

The American Savings Loan Association announced yesterday it has entered into an agreement with Daniel K. Ludwig, a New York investor, giving him rights to purchase up to 800,000 shares, or 40 per cent, of the association's authorized common stock.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -Behind the unsuccessful United States-Spanish bargaining over extending for five years military base rights in Spain, there has loomed the larger question of the value of foreign bases.

A proposal by the Students for a Democratic Society urged a meeting of Columbia University students last night to shun "terrorism, sabotage and window-busting for the hell of it" in favor of a community economic action program.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission refused today to issue a formal order that the Penn Central system take over the bankrupt New Haven Railroad on Jan. 1. But it said New Year's Day was still the target for the action.

SAN BERNARDINO, Calif., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The second stage of a precedent-setting case in the operation of newspapers in the United States was reached today with announcement that the San Bernardino Sun and Telegram would be sold to the Gannett Company of Rochester, N. Y.
Negotiations aimed at ending the 11-day teachers' strike collapsed early this morning, with the president of teachers' union predicting gloomily that the strike "will be a real longie."

CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Pfc. Willy R. Michalik, 20 years old, a German immigrant who once said he considered it a privilege to fight for the United States in Vietnam, has been posthumously granted American citizenship.

Ramon Alatorre, the director of the accommodations and ticket office for the Mexican Olympic Organizing Committee, said yesterday that all hotels in Mexico City were fully booked for the period of the Olympic Games from Oct. 12 to Oct. 27.
MOSCOW, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, left here by air today for the Siberian city of Irkutsk to begin a week-long provincial tour of the Soviet Union.
DEDHAM pottery has become popular with a group of collectors, who treasure it as an antique although it was made as late as 1943.
Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic arrived at Kennedy International Airport last night after a five-week tour of Europe and Israel.

FORT WILLIAM, Ontario, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- The Great Lakes Paper Company, Ltd., announced today that it will increase its price for newsprint by $5 a ton on Jan. 1. The move followed general industry action that will make the price $145 a ton in New York.
INWOOD, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Jerry Pittman set a course record, finished 14 under par and won the Metropolitan open golf championship by eight strokes today.
OAKLAND, Calif., Sept. 27 -- Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther leader, was sentenced today to a prison term of 2 to 15 years for the voluntary manslaughter of John Frey, an Oakland patrolman.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 27 -- Striking university and secondary school students tonight denounced an effort to get them back to their classrooms and halt their two-month-old agitation.

TRENTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- New Jersey farm leaders urged the American Farm Bureau Federation today to shift its convention from Kansas City, Mo., where the City Council endorsed a "boycott" of California grapes, to Chicago, "where city officials have demonstrated support for law and order."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Assistant Treasury Secretary Stanley E. Surrey described today a specter facing the nation's bond markets and its financial system generally -- a probable threefold increase within 10 years in state and local Government borrowing to meet burgeoning needs, including the newer federally aided social programs.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -Senator Edmund S. Muskie believes that the overriding political handicap now limiting Vice President Humphrey in his bid for the Presidency is his failure thus far to convince the American electorate that he has the quality of leadership.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Sept. 27 -- Mrs. Cutting Cushing of Meadow Brook Club won the Women's Long Island Golf Association match-play championship today by defeating Mrs. Maurice Moore of Rockville Links, 2 and 1, over the 6,155-yard, par 35, 36 -- 71 Piping Rock course.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Clay L. Shaw asked the Supreme Court today to give him "sanctuary" against prosecution by District Attorney Jim Garrison of New Orleans.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- The world's major wheat exporting countries have reached what a Department of Agriculture official described today as a "firm agreement" to hold world wheat prices at minimum levels, "or, if we can arrange it, at higher levels."
PRAGUE, Sept. 27 -- Youths are flocking to join the Communist party of Czechoslovakia -- trying to insure continued change from within toward liberalization and democracy.

The Eastern U.S.A. Branch of the Institute of Marine Engineers will hold its next meeting on Thursday at Busto's Restaurant, 11 Stone Street. Theme of the meeting will be centralized and automatic controls in ships.
YONKERS, Sept. 27 -- Both divisions of the New York Sire Stakes races for 4-year-old trotters went to odds-on favorites tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

GENEVA, Sept. 27 (AP) -- Charles H. Jordan, former executive vice president of the American Joint Distribution Committee, who died under mysterious circumstances in Prague last year, was posthumously awarded the Fridtjof Nansen medal today for outstanding services on behalf of refugees.
The stock market scored a modest gain yesterday in active trading as investors focused their attention on a host of special situations.

For the first time, baseball's World Series will be televised live by communications satellite in Puerto Rico, it was announced yesterday. Starting Wednesday, through arrangements with the international division of the National Broadcasting Company, the games will be transmitted to WKAQ in San Juan.
FOR the city's major hotels, the social season blossoms in the fall. Doormen don their winter uniforms. Carpets are unrolled. New decor is unveiled.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The white-haired dean, a canon and three cathedral officials jumped off St. Paul's Cathedral today by controlled parachute.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Sept. 27 (AP) The names of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy and Mayor Lindsay of New York are being withdrawn from Vermont's Presidential ballot, Secretary of State Harry H. Cooley said today. Mr. Cooley said his action was prompted by a telegram from Mr. McCarthy and a telephone conversation with Mr. Lindsay's office in New York.

The Independent Oil and Chemical Workers local at Procter Gamble's Port Ivory plant on Staten Island voted yesterday to authorize a call for a strike. The union's four-year contract expires at midnight tonight.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Sept. 27, (UPI) -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India arrived today for a three-day visit.

President Johnson has named Robert P. Boyle as the United States representative to the International Civil Aviation Organization in Montreal. Mr. Boyle has been deputy assistant administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration's Office of International Aviation Affairs since 1963.

LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- King Hussein of Jordan today discussed the Middle Eastern crisis with Prime Minister Wilson. The King, here for a minor sinus operation, also spent 30 minutes with Foreign Secretary Michael Stewart.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 27 -- George C. Wallace of Alabama, who regularly campaigns against pseudo liberals, pseudo intellectuals and pseudo theoreticians, has uncovered another dangerous figure.

LONDON, Sept. 27 -- The British economy, particularly the important automobile industry, is being hobbled by a rash of wildcat strikes and slowdowns. Millions of pounds in vital export orders are being lost through shutdowns resulting from industrial guerrilla warfare between factory managers and local unions -- and even among the workers themselves.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Britain and the Bahamas announced today a new Constitution that will give the Bahamas greater self-government.

The difference of a hair, in offense or defense, could mean success, I feel, for the Cardinals or the Tigers, in this World Series. The teams are so nearly matched in talented personnel that individual effort under stress is going to make the difference when the first ball is thrown out this Wednesday.
"Waiting for Godard" is the way a tired Lincoln Center staff member characterized the sixth New York Film Festival, which closes tonight at Philharmonic Hall.

ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Talks between the United States and Turkey on eventual transfer of about 50 American bases to Turkish control are deadlocked over minor obstacles, informed sources said today.
The Zapata Off-Shore Company announced yesterday a $350-million take-over bid for the United Fruit Company.

WARSAW, Sept. 27 -- The first veiled public criticism of the purge of Jewish intelleituals was published today amid reliable reports that 200 Jews left Poland last week because of the resurgent "anti-Zionist" campaign.
MONTERREY, Mex., Sept. 27 (AP) -- Spain and Poland won the first two basketball games in Olympic competition last night. Spain routed Indonesia, 105-69, while Poland defeated Australia, 68-64.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 27 -- John J. Gillgan of Cincinnati, a former member of the House, won labor's formal endorsement for the Senate today after his Republican opponent charged that George Meany had intervened in the Democratic nominee's behalf.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 27 -- France in effect vetoed today for the third time British membership in the Common Market by turning down a German proposal for an interim commercial arrangement that would ultimately lead to Britain's admission.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 27 (AP) -- The Philadelphia 76ers mixed an aggressive defense with a fast break for 51 points in the third period tonight and went on to defeat the Detroit Pistons, 142,-109, in a National Basketball Association exhibition game.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 27 -- Three Israeli soldiers were killed yesterday evening when a mine blew up their ammunition carrier in the Negev.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 27 -Vice President Humphrey believes he has hit upon a visceral political issue that may prove more important to large blocs of voters than the war in Vietnam or crime in the streets.

MADRID, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Spain is determined to press her demands for a "reasonable deal" with the United States in exchange for renewing their military bases agreement, authoritative sources said here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland accused Chief Justice Earl Warren today of a lack of "political awareness" and "sensitivity as a Republican appointee" in offering to resign from the Supreme Court this year during a Democratic Administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 27 -- By a heavy majority, the Security Council called on Israel again tonight to allow a special representative of Secretary General Thant to inspect the conditions and treatment of Arabs living in areas ruled by Israel. The vote was 12 to 0 with the United States, Canada and Denmark abstaining.
WASHINGTON Sept. 27 -- The dispute between Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle and 44 of his priests has reached an apparent deadlock involving issues of episcopal authority and freedom of conscience.

Three new public schools and two additions to existing schools will be built with high-rise apartment buildings above them at no cost to the city other than the price of the land, a state-created public corporation announced yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Sept. 27 (UPI) -- A member of Richard M. Nixon's team went to Puerto Rico today with plans to form a committee to back his candidate for President -- and found the committee ready-made. Richard J. Buck, a New York financier, ended up endorsing the "United Citizens for Nixon" group.
Prices on the London stock market fell again yesterday in a continuance of the shakeout from high levels reached earlier this month.
HOUSTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Dr. Denton Cooley, who has done more heart transplants than any other surgeon, said today that he planned to build an artificial heart because of the scarcity of donors.
LONDON, Sept. 27 (Reuters) -- Czechoslovakia asked Britain today to consider declaring the 1938 Munich agreement null and void from the start.

NEWARK, Sept. 27 (AP) -- A woman who is 107 years old signed up for Social Security and Medicare benefits for the first time here today.

With Rube Walker calling the strategic shots for Gil Hodges, the New York Mets opened their final weekend of the baseball season last night by losing to the Philadelphia Phillies in 11 innings, 3-2.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -- Secretary of State Rusk will deliver the United States policy speech to the United Nations General Assembly next Wednesday. It will be his first address to the world organization.

The USLIFE Holding Corporation announced yesterday that it has reached agreement to acquire the Great National Life Insurance Company, Dallas, for an exchange of stock with a maximum of 500,000 shares valued at more than $17.2-million.

PARIS, Sept. 27 -- The French Government added another condition today to those it feels must be met for disarmament talks to be of meaning. This is the prior "rapid solution to the conflicts presently underway around the world as well as of those which threaten to erupt."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27-Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz said in a telephone conversation tonight that if he had been a delegate to the Democratic National Convention last month he would have supported the minority plank that called for an immediate halt to bombing of North Vietnam.
"Woman Is My Idea," which was written, directed and produced by Dan C. Liljenquist, will close at the Belasco tonight after giving 10 previews and 5 regular performances.
Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes, members of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that Earl Rubin would become a partner of the firm effective Tuesday.

Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System, said yesterday that he remained convinced the tax surcharge and spending cut would prove effective in moderating the pace of economic expansion.

Although it is growing late, there is still time for Congress to approve this country's contribution to the financial replenishment of the International Development Association, the World Bank affiliate that extends loans on liberal terms to poor countries. WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 (UPI) -- Legislation to create a seven-member National Water Commission was signed yesterday by President Johnson. The commission will make a nationwide study of water supply problems.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 27 -The prospects for Justice Abe Fortas's confirmation as Chief Justice of the United States suffered a critical setback today when the Senate minority leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, dropped his strong advocacy of the nomination.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 29 -Judith Johnson Sherwin, a New York composer and playwright, has won the 1968 award in the Yale Series of Younger Poets.
