BONN, Sept. 29 -- The West German economy is back on the track again with a full head of steam and the nation's economists have learned something from the derailment of the 1966-67 recession.

UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria), Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Lieut. Col. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the Biafran leader, has appealed to Communist China for help in the war with federal Nigeria and against "anglo-American imperialism and Soviet revisionism," it was disclosed today.
Two appointments of executives to top management posts in shipping companies and the election of an airline executive as president of the Foreign Commerce Club of New York were announced yesterday.

BUCHAREST, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Rumania's independentminded Communist party praised Communist China today in a article occasioned by the 19th anniversary of the proclamation of the Chinese Communist republic, which will be celebrated Tuesday.
VIENNA, Sept. 29 -- The thrust of Soviet military power into the heart of the European Continent is spurring a new neighborliness from the Danube to the Adriatic Sea.
Three additional senior vice presidents have been elected at Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles. They are D. Reynolds Moore, John R. Bassett and Marston Myers.
Paul O'Dwyer demonstrated yesterday that ethnic politics is not dead in New York City.
BROOKVILLE, L.I. Sept. 29 -Susie, a Skye Terrier known more formerly as Ch. Glamoor Good News, was named today as the best of 1,500 dogs at the 46th annual fixture of the Westbury Kennel Association.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 -- Controversy flared here today at the opening of the 93d annual convention of the American Bankers Association over the rapidly spreading trend among the nation's largest banks to form one-bank holding companies.
Two major Norwegian cargo ship operators have announced a $20-million passenger ship venture.

WHEN seen in a small theater, under conditions that make it personal, Jan Nemec's "Oratorio for Prague" is a film so moving that one is near tears from the first moment after the credits appear. The movie was begun as a documentary about the liberalization of Czechoslovakia, and then simply continued when the Russian tanks moved in.
UPPSALA, Sweden, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The Swedish Seismological Institute recorded a severe underground earth shock today, which was said to have been caused by a Soviet nuclear test.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -The staff of the International Monetary Fund has suggested that the Fund might help to finance "buffer stocks" of some commodities where such a device could help to stabilize the price, it was learned today.

HONG KONG, Monday, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Chinese Communist coastal batteries will suspend the odd-day shelling of the Nationalist-held Quemoy and Matsu groups Oct. 1 and 3 to allow inhabitants and defenders there to "celebrate" Peking's National Day, Hsinhua, Peking's press agency, said today.
REVOLUTIONARY IMMORTALITY: Mao Tsetung and the Chinese Cultural Revolution. By Robert Jay Lifton. 178 pages. Random House-Vintage. Hardcover, $4.95. Paperback, $1.95.

FREEPORT, L. I., Sept. 29 -James L. Buckley, Conservative candidate for United States Senator, declared tonight that a conservative tide was running and that he intended to try to spur it in New York, "even without Rockefeller's millions."
The United Fruit Company indicated yesterday that it had not decided yet what to do about the Zapata Off-Shore Company's $350-million takeover proposal made last Friday.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 29 -An aroused Governor Ronald Reagan has jumped angrily into the middle of California's heated contest for the Senate, in which one candidate this weekend accused another of approaching "perilously close" to endorsing "a policy of national treason" on the Vietnam war.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 29 -- Economics Minister Au Ngoc Ho said today that the nominations of Richard M. Nixon and Hubert H. Humphrey as Presidential candidates in the United States had given a significant stimulus to what had been a flagging South Vietnamese economy.
MOSCOW, Sept. 29 (AP) -The captain of a Soviet fishing boat disclosed new evidence today that William Willis, the 75year-old lone sailor from Long Island, was lost at sea in July.

JERICHO, L. I., Sept. 29 -Muffie Mauger of Huntington, L. I., dominated the junior jumper division of the Old Mill Farm horse show today when she rode Diamond Cutter to the championship and 18 Kt. to reserve honors.

HOUSTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -The Oakland Raiders, stymied by fumbles and a strong Houston defense, struck back for two second-half touchdowns today on the passing of Daryle Lamonica and the running of Hewritt Dixon for a 24-15 American Football League victory over the Oilers.

Despite a late ambush by Richie Allen, who hit three home runs in his last three turns at bat and knocked in seven runs to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 10-3 victory, the New York Mets ended their seventh season yesterday without relinquishing ninth place.

Thomas W. Morrison has been elected president and chief executive officer of SKF Industries, it was announced over the weekend. Thomas F. Morris has been elected executive vice president and chief operation officer.

TOKYO, Sept. 29 -- Japan, which took its first steps into the industrial age only 100 years ago, is now poised alongside the United States for a leap into a new stage of social and economic development.
The city's teachers voted last night to end their strike, permitting a reopening of school this morning.

The city has negotiated a reimbursement of about $8.3million from the Blue Cross hospitalization insurance plan, Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday. The payment, to be made in three equal installments over the next 90 days, reflects an upward revision of costs charged Blue Cross subscribers at municipal hospitals from July 1, 1964 through June 30, 1967.
Following are major details of the agreement signed at the Munich conference of Sept. 29-30, 1938:
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 29 -- The steel market is showing a greater firmness.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Thirty one thoroughbred horses were killed early today when fire destroyed two barns at Thistledown Race Track in suburban North Randall, causing damages estimated at $185,000. Nineteen animals were led to safety by stablehands.
Under a network of scaffolding and steel beams, the cornerstone of the new Episcopal Church of St. Matthew and St. Timothy was dedicated yesterday in an outdoor ecumenical service.

Dr. George Mueller, associate administrator for manned space flight of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said here yesterday that he estimated the United States had a "slightly better than 50-50 chance" of beating the Soviet Union to a landing on the moon.

The Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture will benefit from a champagne art preview on Thursday at the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue. The exhibition of works by Skowhegan teachers and alumni, will be open to the public from 1 P.M. to 5 P.M. from Friday through Oct. 13.

China Air Lines will begin a trans-Pacfic service from Taiwan to the United States early in 1970, according to a Government spokesman. The airline has recently concluded a contract with the Boeing Company for two 150-passenger 707 jetliners and has obtained a $20-million loan from the Import and Export Bank to finance the purchase.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, Sept. 30 -- North Vietnamese troops attacked a United States Army Special Forces camp and a province district headquarters south of Danang yesterday for the second consecutive day.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 29 -Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, relaxed in privacy today at a resort on nearby Lake Geneva after leaving behind him here a salute to the ghost of Neville Chamberlain and, indirectly an apology to Vice President Humphrey.
QUEBEC, Sept. 29 -- Premier Maurice Couve de Murville of France arrived here tonight to represent President de Gaulle at a funeral mass tomorrow morning for Premier Daniel Johnson of Quebec.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Sept. 29 -- Aboard the Humphrey plane they say "change is the thing" and on the Republican jets they say "Nixon's the one." And to a remarkable degree, each candidate agrees with the other that these are, indeed, the central issues.

Columbia University will receive more than $1-million under the will of the late David Feinson to endow a professorship in the humanities. The bequest has not yet been designated for a specific department.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Sept. 29 -- The wartime escape of nearly all the 8,000 Jews in Denmark to Sweden was commemorated today in a 25thanniversary service in the Copenhagen Synagogue.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford said today that, even if South Vietnamese forces took over more of the fighting in Vietnam in the next year. United States troops would probably not be brought home immediately.

David W. Walsh has been appointed vice president of Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. Mr. Walsh served since 1962 as vice president for administration of Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, the center's clinical unit.

Dr. H. A. Ranges' Kay R III captured the Windjammer Trophy and Henry Hock's gaffheaded schooner, Herandis, was awarded the William Atkin memorial trophy in Douglaston Yacht Squadron's fourth annual windjammers' cruising race on Long Island Sound yesterday.

ROCKDALE, Tex., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- An early morning twocar collision at a highway intersection near Rockdale, Tex., today killed seven persons and injured two others. The Texas Department of Public Safety said that five of the dead persons and one of the injured had been in a small foreign car, which collided with another vehicle on U.S. 77.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The passing of Bill Munson and the running of Mel Farr offset a near-record performance by Green Bay's end, Carroll Dale, today to give the Detroit Lions a 23-17 victory over the Packers.

Ten fraternities at C. W. Post College, Brookville, L. I., will stage the first boxing bouts to be held at the college next Friday for the benefit of the United States Olympic Fund. Each of the interfraternity bouts is scheduled for three rounds.
The agreement between the Board of Education and the United Federation of Teachers has cleared the way for the end of the illegal strike. At long last, the city's schools can reopen today.
BOSTON, Sept. 29 -- The entire season for the Yankees and the Red Sox was summarized and symbolized in their final out of the year today.
FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., Sept. 29 (AP) -- Ralph Boston set a wind-aided world record of 27 feet 5 1/2 inches in the long jump today in a pre-Olympics meet.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 26 -- The ancient Ethiopian Orthodox Church, known for its hermits and its ritual dancing, is taking small and tentative steps toward modernization.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, chairman of the National Citizens Committee for Public Broadcasting, charged yesterday that the commercial television networks and the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company were "in collusion" to dominate technical facilities for the coast-to-coast relay of video "trivia.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 26 -- The ancient Ethiopian Orthodox Church, known for its hermits and its ritual dancing, is taking small and tentative steps toward modernization.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, chairman of the National Citizens Committee for Public Broadcasting, charged yesterday that the commercial television networks and the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company were "in collusion" to dominate technical facilities for the coast-to-coast relay of video "trivia.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Sept. 29 -- The invincible New Zealanders, Denis Hulme and Bruce McLaren, turned in another of their tidy, ho-hum performances today to win first and second places in the third race of the 1968 Canadian-American Challenge Cup over the 2.5-mile road course of Speedway Park.

SAIGON, Sept. 29 (AP) -Richard Threlkeld, a correspondent, and Tran Khiem, both for the Columbia Broadcasting System were wounded slightly today at the Special Forces camp 25 miles southwest of Danang.

Commerce Bancshares, Inc., has announced plans to acquire the Delmar Bank of University City, Mo., and the Union State Bank of St. Charles, Mo., in exchange for a total of 107,250 of its shares worth $5.84-million.
MONTREAL, Sept. 29 (AP) -Canadian doctors transplanted the heart of a 16-year-old motorcycle crash victim in a 58year-old man today in the country's fifth such operation.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 29 -- One of the biggest shortages facing the Indian economy these days is that of decisions at the highest levels of government.

FOR all its length of 22 blocks Bleecker Street cuts through differences of age, race, nationality, sexuality and outlook, mixing urban sophisticates and heartland rustics, derelicts and the chauffeur-driven in a frenzied distillate of city life.

SEATTLE, Sept. 29 (UPI) -Vice President Humphrey conducted top level strategy discussions today with his key advisors on the thorny problems of Vietnam and leather-lunged hecklers who are harassing his campaign.

Dennis McLain of the Detroit Tigers and Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals, who are expected to oppose each other Wednesday in the opening game of the World Series, won the individual pitching honors in the final American and National League averages, respectively.

New Yorkers were spared yesterday from another threatened curtailment of vital services when unionized pharmacists and other drug-store employes reached a tentative contract agreement with the operators of 2,000 retail establishments.
Nothing has been very decisive in the credit markets recently, and this lack of resolution seems likely to continue this week.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 29 (UPI) -- The police broke up a milling crowd of 300 rock-hurling Negroes with tear gas barrages tonight, but members of the crowd regrouped in small bands and roamed a 15-block Negro section stoning cars and breaking windows.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 29 -- Some of "The Folks" appear in person. The guest book at George C. Wallace's campaign headquarters near the railroad station here contains the names of citizens from Connecticut to California.

VERY few novels have been written about tournament bridge, which is somewhat surprising. The setting of a national championship in a luxury hotel provides a wide range of possibilities for the novelist: the emotional and intellectual problems of players of all levels in an atmosphere of tension.
WARSAW, Sept. 29 -- Jerzy Andrzejewski, a prominent Polish novelist who has denounced Polish participation in the occupation of Czechoslovakia, was denounced today in the newspaper Zycie Warszawy.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Eighteen Senators and 35 members of the House, joined today in asking the Justice Department and Federal Trade Commission to investigate the possibility of illegal collusion in gasoline and fuel-oil price increases.

CHICAGO, Sept. 29 (AP) -Bob Moose's throwing error, Pittsburgh's sixth miscue of the game, allowed Jim Hickman to score the winning run in the ninth inning as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5-4, today.

HANOVER, West Germany, Sept. 29 -- The extreme rightwing National Democratic party won a modest vote today in the state of Lower Saxony, sending candidates to county and village legislatures for the first time.

Walter Lippmann, the political commentator, said yesterday in his biweekly column for Newsweek magazine that "unless something, which is not now probable, happens, it seems to me the better, though not the most beautiful course, that the voters should oust the party that has cost the country so much."

Sonia Vargas addressed herself to a Mozart program at her recital yesterday afternoon in Town Hall. The young Peruvian pianist set a difficult task for herself by selecting four of the composer's ripest and most searching sonatas: No. 8, in A minor (K. 310); No. 9, in D (K. 311); No. 13, in B flat (K. 333) and No. 14 in C minor (K. 457).

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -The experiment, begun last March, of insulating the world's monetary gold from newly mined supplies appears to have worked with only modest "leakage" in its full quarter of operation, new figures from the International Monetary Fund disclosed today.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Sept. 29 -- Following are excerpts from the text of an address entitled "Order and Justice Under Law" delivered tonight by Richard M. Nixon over the national radio network of the Mutual Broadcasting System:

AT SEA, Off Northeastern Australia, Monday, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Fifty warships from the navies of Britain, the United States, Australia and New Zealand began an exercise called Coral Sands in darkness early today.

RESTON, Va., Sept. 29 -Judge Keith Browne selected Elaine S. Reich's Doberman pinscher, Ch. Zorohaven's Camilla, as the best in show in an entry of 1,447 at the Old Dominion Kennel Club's 51st show today.

SEATTLE, Sept. 29 -- A reporter who recently switched from the Nixon to the Humphrey campaign got his first full exposure to the Vice President in action during a question-and-answer session at Pepperdine College in Los Angeles the other day.

In an afternoon of glory for all hands, the New York Giants scored and scored yesterday, defeating the Washington Redskins, 48-21, in the first home game of the season at Yankee Stadium before a crowd of 62,979.
NEWARK, Sept. 29 -- City policemen ringed the Essex County Jail here tonight as some of its inmates rioted, smashing equipment, breaking windows and setting a fire.
PRAGUE, Sept. 29 (AP) -Czechoslovakia has signed a contract to deliver 29 million pairs of shoes to the Soviet Union in 1969.

VALENCIA, Venezuela, Sept. 29 (UPI) -- Guerrillas took over a hacienda belonging to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, of New York, at gunpoint, painted revolutionary slogans on walls and stole an undisclosed amount of money, the National News Agency reported today.

In one of the largest shortterm leasing transactions in a Manhattan office building in recent years. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith has subleased 75,000 square feet for three years in the new skyscraper at 111 Wall Street.

SEATTLE, Sept. 29 -- The trouble started last night with a shouting match between Bill Dana, the sad-eyed comedian who introduces himself as Jose Jimenez, and about 200 militant antiwar demonstrators packed into one corner of the balcony of the Seattle Center Arena.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Sept. 29 -- More than 250 pilots of Pakistan International Airlines went on strike today. They charged that they had been forced to fly unserviceable planes.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 29 -- Five persons were killed and 40 injured early this morning in a fire started by a smokebomb while a movie about the Palestinian commandos was being made in a nightclub, the Club Purgatoire.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Sept. 29 -- The first issue of a new Sunday newspaper, The Sunday Record Call, was published here today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29 -- A Government advisory commission, adopting a suggestion by Governor Rockefeller, has urged a broader financial base for the Medicaid program by making greater use of private health insurance.

Jerry Peete gave his New York recital debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Peete possesses a light tenor of moderately pleasant quality, but at present his technical equipment is not sufficiently developed to sustain an ambitious recital program.
Town Hall was aglow with lovely music yesterday afternoon, as Natasha Lutov, a young American mezzo-soprano, made her New York recital debut.

One of those little dramas that add excitement to opera from time to time was played out on Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera. The work of the evening was Cilea's "Adriana Lecouvreur," and it was to hae had Renata Tebaldi and Franco Corelli as its stars.

BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 29 (AP) -- The young lawyer who unseated the chairman of the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities promised today to be "moderate in all things" when he takes Louisiana's Third District seat.
ON his always tidy desk in his 27th-floor corner office at 250 Broadway, Herbert Lawrence Haber, the director of the city's Office of Labor Relations, keeps a pair of symbolic gadgets.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- About 200 demonstrators shouted at the Moiseyev dance company when it arrived from the Soviet Union today. The demonstrators were Czechoslovaks and White Russians.
BUFFALO, Sept. 29 -- Interceptions, which have plagued Joe Namath's development as a quarterback, returned today to sabotage the New York Jets.

Students at Horace Mann, one of the nation's prestigious country day schools for boys, have been told for more than three-quarters of a century how they as "young gentlemen" were to dress, wear their hair and conduct much of their personal lives while at the school.

CAPRI, Italy, Sept. 29, (AP) -- More than 100 demonstrators marched today demanding an end of unregulated construction that threatens this resort island's beauty. Airplanes dropped leaflets addressed to the Italian Government and to foreigners.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 29 (AP) -- Aloysius A. Mazewski, 52 years old, a Chicago lawyer, was elected president of the Polish American Congress today at the end of the organization. The Congress represents tion..
LONDON, Sept. 29 (Reuters) -- Several hundred demonstrators marched through central London today demanding a ban on all immigration to Britain.

Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., has elected Russell Ziegler to the newly created post of vice president and director of community and public affairs, it was announced over the weekend by B. T. Leithead, chairman of the apparel manufacturer and retailer.

NASHVILLE, Sept. 29 (UPI) The executive committee of the National Governors Conference meets tomorrow with eight of the nine committee members expected to attend. A discussion on recent Federa l cutbacks in highway expenditures will take place at the meeting.
WHAT price victory? Chicago was delighted to beat Minnesota, upset conqueror of Green Bay, for the Bears' first victory of the young season. But the game cost two of their three quarterbacks.
Fixed-income securities prices fell fairly sharply yesterday, largely because dealers tired of holding inventories of bonds without much success in attracting investors.

The dispute between Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle and the dissenting priests in the Washington, D. C., archdiocese has moved rapidly beyond the merits of birth control to even more fundamental issues of individual conscience and church authority.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Former President Sukarno has been placed under house arrest again after five days of interrogation at an undisclosed location about Communist underground activities, Defense Ministry informants sai today.

A State Supreme Court Justice in Queens said yesterday had he found it odd that the city had rented Shea Stadium to the Beatles but had denied it to George C. Wallace, the third-party Presidential candidate.

FEW Broadway ventures have promised so much as Theater 1969, which has opened a repertory season at the Billy Rose Theater with a selection of a few of the most interesting plays of our time. For a Broadway audience already tired of Cubans and Mormons, and fearful of what the future might hold, the Billy Rose holds out the hope of being a rallying point for sanity.
PARIS -- The storm that tore at French society last May is shaking French scientific institutions to their foundations.
The threatened slowdowns or strikes by the police, firemen sanitationmen were temporarily postponed last night after union leaders had conferred with Arthur J. Goldberg, prospective mediator.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- J. R. Wiggins, nominated by President Johnson to be the United States representative to the United Nations, defended the Administration's policy in Vietnam today as necessary to help protect self-determination for small nations.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Israeli and Jordanian troops exchanged fire in two brief duels across the Jordan River tonight, an Israeli Army spokesman announced.

The appointment of Dr. Alexander Thomas as director of the psychiatric division of the Bellevue Hospital Center was announced yesterday. He succeeds Dr. Arthur Zitrin, professor of psychiatry at New York University, in the hospital post.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Scripps-Howard newspapers today endorsed Richard M. Nixon for President.

WASHINGTON Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Helene Lindow, a close friend of President Johnson's daughter Luci and a White House employe, was named today press, social and personal secretary, to Mrs. Johnson effective next January.

Judge Milton Pollack yesterday dismissed a suit brought by three Negro voters from East Elmhurst for intervention in the 1966 alignment of Assembly districts in their part of Queens County. They had contended that the boundaries of the 23d and 31st Districts were "racially motivated."
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- For the third time in five years, the friendly city of St. Louis prepared today to play host to the World Series as participants and observers poured in from every direction.

Time Inc. lost a Federal Court copyright infringement suit yesterday against the author, publisher and distributor of the book, "Six Seconds in Dallas," a study of the assassination of President Kennedy.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Johnson declared Carl Hayden Day at the White House today.

ELMIRA, N. Y., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Mike Riordan, a rookie who entered the game when Walt Frazier was injured, scored 20 points tonight and led the New York Knickerbockers to a 127-112 victory over the Detroit Pistons in an exhibition game.

Yom Kippur, or the Day of Atonement -- the most sacred event on the Hebrew calendar -- begins at sundown today and ends at sundown tomorrow. There will be fasting and prayers of repentance and self-evaluation.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- President Arthur da Costa e Silva of Brazil, where the economy is growing at a strong 6 per cent this year, lamented recently to a diplomatic visitor that the benefits of this growth are being diluted by a soaring population.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The St. Louis weather bureau said today there was a probability the weather would be good for the first two games of the World Series here Wednesday and Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Robert S. McNamara projected today a doubling of the lending of the World Bank to the poor countries in the next five years but warned that the "crippling effect" of population growth could thwart the effort of economic development.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie described Richard M Nixon today as "somewhat of a modulated Wallace" in his law and order appeal to the voters.

Two new members have been added to the board of Hart Schaffner Marx, Chicago-based manufacturer and retailer of men's wear, increasing the board's size to 14 members. The new directors are James K. Wilson, president of Hart Schaffner Marx Clothes, and Robert J. Witt, president of the company's retail stores which number 190 units across the country.

Senator Charles E. Goodell yesterday appointed as his press secretary a Negro who called himself a "responsible militant" and told newsmen that "there could have been some improvement" in Mr. Goodell's legislative record.

TROY, N. Y,. Sept. 30 -- The sentencing of Faith Evans, a civil-rights worker, to six months in jail for a minor offense is sending shock waves through this city's ordinarily apathetic black community.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Hank Bauer said today he had signed a two-year contract to manage Oakland.

The New York Yankees, acting in accordance with a previous agreement, yesterday requested waivers on Rocky Colavito, the 35-year-old outfielder who ranks 15th on the career home-run list, for the purpose of granting him his unconditional release.

Charles F. Noyes, 91-year-old dean of New York real estate brokers, has sold for the account of his grandchildren a half-interest in a downtown building that was owned by the Baron Von Zedlitz und Leipe, one of General Romel's Afrika Korps officers, until it was seized by the Alien Property Custodian and sold, in 1951, at public auction.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 -- South Vietnamese troops killed 75 North Vietnamese regulars yesterday in clashes on the fringes of the city of Quangngai, a South Vietnamese military spokesman said today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 -- A South Vietnamese private was strolling along Hal Ba Trung Street over the weekend when two Vietcong terrorists roared by on a motorbike and fired at him twice. Both bullets missed.
During a lunch hour in the garment district back in the 1930's the Communist party could count on turning out a crowd of thousands to listen to its candidates for the White House.

TORONTO, Sept. 30 -- The Ontario Securities Commission and the Toronto Stock Exchange declared today that investor-owned companies have an obligation to prevent "insiders" with confidential information about a company from buying or selling its stock before the information is made public.

PARIS, Sept. 30 -- North Vietnam's negotiators here are reported by usually reliable sources to have considered the advisability of breaking off the deadlocked talks with the United States but have discarded the idea for the time being.

BANGKOK, Thailand -- The prospects of a rapprochement between Thailand and Cambodia have become increasingly remote, in the opinion of diplomatic sources here, as a result of stepped-up friction along their common border during the last several months.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- President Johnson signed today the lower Colorado River Basin bill, which he hailed as a landmark water conservation measure sought by Arizona for decades.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Is it an unfair campaign practice to call Richard M. Nixon "Tricky Dick?"

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- After dueling with Right Busy for a half-mile today, Tony's India pulled away and won the Winchester Purse, a six-furlong race, by three lengths. Right Busy dropped back to fourth at the wire as Misty Jac came on for second position, four lengths ahead of Satisfying.

The National Mediation Board agreed yesterday to mediate a contract dispute between the Long Island Rail Road and the Botherhood of Railroad Trainmen, thus averting a strike threatened for today by 1,000 trainmen, railroad police and bar car attendants.

BONN, Sept. 30 -- The chief West German Government spokesman said today, on the 30th anniversary of the Munich Pact, that West Germany emphatically denied having any territorial claims on Czechoslovakia.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- Malfunctioning traffic lights that had been tampered with were blamed today for a massive, horn - blowing, temper - fraying traffic jam during the commuting hours in downtown Newark this morning.
LONDON, Sept. 30 -- The European automobile industry is in upheaval in an effort to contain the growing challenge by the Big Three of the United States -- General Motors, Ford and Chrysler.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 30 -- A three-judge Federal court heard arguments today on a plea by the National Democratic Party of Alabama for reinstatement of all its candidates on the November ballot.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Lester Josephson tore the Achilles tendon in his left ankle today and will be lost to the Los Angeles Rams for the remainder of the season.

ARLINGTON, Va., Sept. 30 (AP) -- President Johnson and his family attended a funeral service at Arlington National Cemetery today for a Navy pilot who was a close friend of the President's younger daughter, Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent. Lieut (jg) Leroy Bates, 22 years old, of Houston, who died in the crash of a training plane in Arizona, was buried with full military houors.
TOKYO -- Scientific research is managing to survive and thrive in Japan despite apathetic government support.

FOR some time now, visitors to Scandinavia have been bringing back word that Denmark is no longer just a land of fairy tales, open sandwiches and Victor Borge. It also has ravishing maidens, high fashion and Finn Birger Christensen.
The United Hospital Fund of New York opens its 89th annual campaign today on behalf of 78 member nonprofit, voluntary hospitals. This campaign is one of the most crucial in the fund's history.

MADISON, N. J., Sept. 30 -- An old friend telephoned the home of Ted Monica, the Madison football coach, yesterday morning. Ted wasn't at home, but the friend, Pete Carmichael, talked with Mrs. Monica instead.

NEW YORK STATE'S bow and arrow season for big game--deer and bear--opens in the Northern Zone Oct. 11 and closes Oct. 24, the day before the animals may be sought with arms.

The city's efforts to control air pollution were sharply attacked yesterday by Representative William F. Ryan as state and Federal officials met to discuss a proposed air-quality-control region for the metropolitan area.

The appointment of Richard F. Coons as director of international operations of the investment banking firm of Kidder, Peabody Co., Inc., members of the New York Stock Exchange, was announced yesterday.

The Committee of American Steamship Lines, the trade organization of the subsidized segment of the American merchant marine, announced yesterday that it would go out of business on Jan. 1.

A student volunteer service organization at Columbia University harshly criticized yesterday the university's expansion on Morningside Heights as an "antisocial policy" of driving out the poor to "create an institutional enclave and middle-income ghetto."
NEWARK, Sept. 30 -- The old Essex County Jail appeared calm today following last night's rioting and the transfer of 130 prisoners to other penal institutions.

ASTORIA, Ore. -- Just south of here, along the flat white beach at Newport with its silvering driftwood and its icy surf, the cold war is as tangible as the Soviet fishing vessels at work just over the twelve-mile limit -- or maybe even within it.
The American civilian space program has concluded its first decade with an impressive string of successes and with astronauts poised for their first ride in the Apollo mooncraft.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy was sworn in today as a trustee of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, succeeding his late brother Robert. Supreme Court Justice Abe Fortas, whose nomination to be Chief Justice was being debated on the Senate floor, administered the oath of office.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Following is the text of the speech by Robert S. McNamara, president of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank), to the bank's annual meeting today:
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- The Chicago White So purchased today the contract of Bob Christian, an outfielder, from the Detroit Tigers for a sum in excess of the waiver price of $10,000.

WARSAW, Sept. 30 -- A prominent lawyer who has defended Poles accused of political offenses was given a six-month suspended sentence today for possessing religious documents deemed harmful to Polish state interests.

Kinney National Service, Inc., signed a contract last night for the sale of its Rent A Car business, its assets and Kinney Rent A Car trademark to the Sandgate Corporation for about $11-million in cash and notes. Sandgate, formerly known as the All-State Auto Rental Corporation, also purchased about 10,000 passenger cars ranging in age from four to 20 months.
The election of John J. Macklin as a senior vice president of the Charter New York Corporation was announced yesterday.
HAMBURG, West Germany, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States aircraft carrier Wasp was docked in Hamburg harbor today for an 8-day visit. She took part last week in the North Atlantic.

MOSCOW, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Izvestia, the Soviet Government newspaper today assailed Mao Tse-tung as "personally anti-Soviet" and denounced China for its condemnation of the Soviet-led occupation of Czechoslovakia.

Ruth's Rullah and Flit-to shared the top honore in the feature competition at Belmont Park yesterday. The main race was the Long Island Handicap at 1 3/8 miles on the turf and the turnout for the event was so large that it had to be run in two divisions.

The Avco Corporation reported yesterday net earnings for the nine months ended Aug. 31, of $40,381,000, equal to $2.61 a share, compared with $36,793,000, or $2.25 a share, for the preceding year's period.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- George C. Wallace encountered the first visible setback of his driving Presidential campaign here today.

MEXICO CITY, Sept 30 (AP) -- Representatives of the German firm manufacturing the controversial brush-sole track shoe are going ahead with plans to give a pair to each of the 3,000 Olympic Games track competitors in the hope the ban on the shoes will be lifted.
Trans World Airlines and Northeast Airlines announced yesterday changes among some senior executives.
PARIS, Sept. 30 -- The arts went underground in Paris over the weekend.
The steel industry, which managed two weeks ago to lift its production rate by a fraction, lost last week all that it had gained in that week and the week before.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Last year's Wimbledon singles champion, John Newcombe, beat Tony Roche, a fellow Australian, 11-9, 4-6, 6-2, today to win the final of the Transvaal Province professional tennis championships.
PEKING, Sept. 30 (Agence France-Presse) -- The Soviet and five other ambassadors from five Communist countries staged a walk-out today when Premier Chou En-lai attacked "Soviet revisionism."
GROSSINGER, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Another skiable surface substitute was demonstrated at Grossinger's in the Catskills today.

NEWARK, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Plans for a campaign rally for Mr. Wallace in Military Park on Saturday were approved today by the city Department of Public Works. The candidate is scheduled to appear here at noon after a 10 A.M. rally in Jersey City.
Salomon Brothers Hutzler, an investment firm, has admitted Stanley J. Arkin, 32 years old, John Scott Crabtree, 38, and Joseph P. Lombard, 40, as general partners, the concern announced yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 -- Six Negro prisoners accused of having started a riot in the United States Army stockade at Longbinh will be charged with murder or conspiracy to commit murder, informed military sources said today.

The performance of Puccini's "Il Trittico" that was scheduled for Sept. 17 will be presented by the New York City Opera tonight at the New York State Theater. Tickets dated Sept. 17 will be honored. Other seats at all prices are available at the box office.

The opening performance of the Queen's Guards at Madison Square Garden tonight will be for the benefit of the United States Equestrian Team. The Queen's Guards, a tattoo, features 47 horses and 160 men.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., reported yesterday gains in sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Aug. 3, as well as for the final quarter and second half of the year.

The National Council of Catholic Men, the major producer of Roman Catholic network radio and television programs, has surrendered its broadcasting responsibilities to an agency of the American Roman Catholic hierarchy.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 30 -- James Earl Ray, accused of murdering the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., sat quietly in a courtroom this afternoon while his attorney tried in vain to get Memphis jail officials not to guard Ray so closely.

BALTIMORE, Sept. 30 (AP) -- If you want to see the flag flying over Fort McHenry, where "The Star-Spangled Banner" was written, it will have to be by the dawn's early light, or some other form of daylight.

BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- Pastor Martin Niemoller, the Protestant churchman who served eight years in Nazi concentration camps, joined the son of Rudolf Hess today in a new appeal to the Big Four for the release of the erstwhile deputy of Hitler from solitary confinement at Spandau prison.
Thomas P. F. Hoving served notice yesterday that broadcasting was going to get a taste of participatory democracy just like housing, schooling and many other American social institutions in 1968.
EVERETT, Wash., Sept. 30 -- The Boeing 747, twice as big as any airliner ever built before, was rolled out of the factory door today.
ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Gov. Lester G. Maddox celebrated his 53d birthday today at a brief surprise party in his office given by his staff.
The realty investment and building firm of Jack Resnick Sons, Inc., has appointed Asriel Rackow to the post of vice president.

DETROIT, Sept. 30 -- Richard M. Nixon said today he was "pleased" at the emphasis Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford placed yesterday on de-Americanizing the Vietnam war through speeding up the training and equipping of South Vietnamese forces.
"There is no truth that speaks so clearly to me as the truth of my own experience."

There probably won't be any crocks of gold in evidence at the Oct. 6 premiere party for "Finian's Rainbow." But there will be lots of Irish Georgian silver decorating the tables at the supper dance, a benefit for the Irish Georgian Society.

The Riviera villa in which the play "Scuba Duba" takes place proved to be a charming setting for an experimental concert last night. Stephen Aaron, artistic director of the New Theater who was in search of something to fill his house on free Monday nights, and Jeannette Medina, a violinist wanting to give a theatrical format to a concert, gave the venture its start.
The German mark moved down in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday.

The degree to which past Communist affiliation remains a bar to employment by Government and private industry is unknown. But the 1950's, when campus and political affiliations with the wrong organizations penalized a man's right to work, seem a long time ago as a result of an important quasi-judicial ruling just handed down that provides a refreshing contrast with the norm of the bad old days.

More than a dozen people worked quietly behind the scenes in the last month to keep the lid on the simmering contract dispute between the city and its police, firemen and sanitationmen, and thus set the stage for the intervention of Arthur Goldberg yesterday.
Prices advanced sharply in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Mrs. Leo Wagner's Timely Miss, the 3-2 favorite, rallied through the stretch today to win the $19,150 Yo Tambien Handicap by 2 1/4 lengths at Hawthorne race track.
HONG KONG, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- China and North Vietnam signed a trade agreement today.

The presiding judge of the marriage court of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has been relieved of his post and transferred to a suburban parish after he had publicly criticized the church's procedures on marriage cases.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The House ethics committee will investigate an incident in which Representative Bob Wilson, Republican of California, was recorded as voting on roll-calls although he was absent from Washington, the committee chairman said today.
"The precious metals are on the defensive," a broker commented yesterday, as gold prices in Europe fell sharply.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Sept. 30 -- Workmen perched on an unfinished office building towering over an outdoor rally of Gov. Soro T. Agnew today interrupted the Republican Vice-Presidential nominees' speech on law and order with a high-level demonstration for George C. Wallace.

LISBON, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- Former Premier Antonio Oliveira Salazar remained in grave condition tonight but Dr. Bissaia Barreto, a close friend, said it was just possible that the 79-year-old Portugese leader would come out of his coma.
David Ogilvy reported yesterday that only 60 per cent of the 1968 New York goal of the United Negro College Fund, Inc., had been raised since Jan. 1, leaving $800,000 of the $2-million goal to go.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The White House had no comment to make today on Vice President Humphrey's statement that he would be willing to halt the bombing of North Vietnam "as an acceptable risk for peace."

"THEY must be givin' away diamonds," a young woman commented as she pushed open one of the front doors to Abraham Straus yesterday morning and beheld a crowd as thick as the last shopping day before Christmas.
The General Motors Building has opened to huge crowds and what might be called mixed reviews. To the public at large, it's a smash. Some professional responses are less enthusiastic.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- A strike of American League umpires against work in the World Series was averted today on the plea of two discharged umpires not to "deprive the American baseball fan of the annual classic."

When Milton Berle last worked at the New Amsterdam Roof Theater, it was an elegant little radio studio with a glass curtain (to cut down audience noise), and he was the brash young comic on "The Rudy Vallee Hour." That was in 1929.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Sept. 30 -- A Supreme Court justice reluctantly ruled today that members of the reapportioned Suffolk Board of Supervisors could not also hold positions as town supervisors.
The return of 83 unwanted teachers to the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district was marked yesterday by a few expressions of hostility against a background of general calm.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Mel Harder, pitching coach for the Cincinnati Reds for three seasons, was dismissed today. At the same time the Reds rehired Vern Benson, Jimmy Bragan and Hal Smith as coaches.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
BERLIN, Sept. 30 -- "Ulysses," a new opera by the Italian composer Luigi Dallapiccola, had its world premiere in West Berlin's Opera House last night.

SORRENTO, Italy, Sept. 30 -- A distinct change of pace for Ingmar Bergman is evident in his new film, "The Shame," which had its world premiere simultaneously here at the International Cinema Incontri (Meeting) and in Stockholm last night.

WHEN charity is the name of the game, Manhattan's matrons of means are willing to try almost anything. They'll endure yet another fashion show, devour countless rubbery chicken lunches, and dance in such diverse places as a barn, an ocean liner -- or even the Central Park Zoo.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- A compromise began taking shape today on the vexing question of how the world will deal with newly mined South African gold, now that monetary gold and free-market gold have been separated into a "two-price system."

JABLONEC, Czechoslovakia, Sept. 30 -- Many members of the German-speaking minority here in northern Bohemia have been frightened by the Soviet occupation. A number of them already have left the country and others are planning to leave.

BLACKPOOL, England, Sept. 30 -- Roy Jenkins, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, made it plain to a rebellious Labor party conference today that he would not be moved from the tough restraints of his economic policy.

Former Gov. George C. Walace of Alabama is getting a lift in his Presidential campaign from the issues of law and order and of race, according to a survey by Louis Harris, published in yesterday's New York Post.
SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 -- Following is a transcript of a foreign policy speech by Vice President Humphrey as recorded for delivery tonight over nationwide television:

Representatives of the Writers Guild of America and the three major radio-television networks met in marathon sessions last night in an effort to agree on a new contract before the union's strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. today.

When a pianist steps forward with a recital program that consists simply of Bach's "Goldberg" Variations and Chopin's 24 Etudes, the listener is put on notice that the artist wants to be taken very seriously indeed.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- The Senate debate on Abe Fortas's nomination to be Chief Justice droned through its final day today before the climactic vote tomorrow on a motion to end a filibuster by opponents.

The chairman of the governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district stood up at the end of two-and-half-hour meeting last night and told 500 parents, teachers and members of the community that the board would order that none of the teachers it opposes be given assignments today.
TOKYO, Sept 30 -- The Tokyo Stock Exchange broke a seven-year-old record today to reach a new peak.

The election of William C. Norris and Harold H. Hammer to the board of directors of the Cemmercial Credit Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Norris is president and chairman of the board of Control Data Corporation, while Mr. Hammer is vice president, finance, of Control Data.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Sept. 30 -- Bob Campbell, Penn State's versatile halfback, underwent surgery to repair a separated shoulder today and will miss at least four weeks of action and possibly the remainder of the season.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd said today that noise abatement was going to be the biggest problem in the development of supersonic air travel.
PARIS, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Citroen, which reportedly has agreed to a merger with Fiat, confirmed today that an agreement had been signed between the two companies, but no details were given.

The "future construction" corner of the nation's economy, a closely watched indicator, continued its upward pace last month, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, a leading Democratic dove, sent Vice President Humphrey a telegram tonight praising his television speech to the nation.

The Little Orchestra Society will benefit from a Viennese Supper Dance in the Terrace Room at the Plaza on Oct. 15 following the opening of its 21st season at Philharmonic Hall with a concert version of "A Waltz Dream," an Oskar Straus operetta.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Sept. 30 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk opened a series of high-level meetings with visiting Foreign Ministers today, giving top priority to the search for a peace formula in the Middle East.
The United Fruit Company yesterday received an offer valued at more than $679-million in securities from a third suitor -- the Dillingham Corporation of Honolulu.

One hundred welfare patrolmen picketed at noon yesterday and staged a three-hour afternoon sit-in demanding increased protection on their jobs. Eighty of the men took a half day off from their duties without notice to take part in the demonstration.
The United States Merchant Marine Academy dedicated its roll of honor book at the academy's silver anniversary ceremonies yesterday in the school's Mariners Chapel on the Kings Point, L. I., campus.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit reversed today the conviction of Robert Bolivar DePugh, national coordinator of the militant right-wing Minutemen, and two others charged with violations of the Federal Firearms Act.
LISBON, Sept. 30 -- The new regime in Portugal has brought an apparent relaxation to the strict press censorship of the Salazar days.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Sept. 30 (AP) -- Members of the National Governors Conference selected Colorado Springs, Colo., as the site for next year's conference at a session here today and suggested it begin around mid-August.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that Americans are so concerned with the unlawful conduct of a small segment of youth "that we do not give sufficient attention and credit to the responsible youth of our country."

THE third-stringers, the unsung stalwarts of the football squad who serve as midweek trial horses for the varsity heroes, were given considerable credit for Rutgers' victory over Princeton last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Sweeney has a problem. He dislikes Nixon so much that he has been going around saying. "If Nixon is elected President I'll leave the country." Now that the polls indicate Nixon may win, Sweeney's problem is to find a suitable place to go after he leaves the country.

More than 3,000 supporters of the National Urban League are expected to attend "Fashion Freedom '68," a benefit for the league, which will be held Sunday at the New York Hilton. Mrs. Jacob K. Javits and Mrs. George R. Dockery are co-chairman of the event, sponsored by the league's guild in cooperation with Ebony magazine. Tickets are S6, or $I0 for reserved seats.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- George C. Wallace proposed today that rural areas be industrialized to provide training and jobs for the unskilled who are leaving the countryside to live in the nation's overcrowded cities.

Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Presidential nominee, has resigned from a number of private clubs and organizations, including a New Jersey golf club accused of excluding Negroes and Jews, a Nixon aide said yesterday.

For the last couple of weeks Colgate-Palmolive has been shipping its new Colgate Dental Cream to all points in the land. And the company will be introducing it later this month with the biggest advertising push it has ever given a product.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 -- The baseball season has finally come to a shuddering end after being in a cataleptic trance ever since the halfway mark. No tears were shed at its passing and there wasn't even a period of proper mourning. Instead, the clan already has begun to assemble here for the start of the World Series between the Cardinals and Tigers.

STOCKHOLM, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- The Swedish Conservative party announced today that it was changing its name to the United party in an attempt to rally all opposition factions for the 1970 general elections.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Senate Democratic leader, Mike Mansfield of Montana, indicated today that he still expected the 1968 Congressional session to end by Oct. 12. Senator Mansfield put through the Senate an emergency resolution to permit Federal agencies to continue in business though their regular money bills had not been passed for the current fiscal year.

ABOARD U.S.S. NEW JERSEY, off North Vietnam, Sept. 30 -- The huge 16-inch guns of the battleship New Jersey, quiet in combat since the closing days of the Korean war, broke their long silence today by shelling enemy targets in the demilitarized zone.
ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Hank Aaron, the mainstay of the Braves for 15 years, conceded today that age was starting to overtake him at 34.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- A new United States reserve unit has arrived for a tour of duty in the Danang area, the United States command announced here today. The 737th Transportation Company, from Yakima, Wash., was trained for two summers in the Mohave Desert and in the Olympic rain forest in Washington, prior to its activation.
PRAGUE, Sept. 30 -- Czechoslovak troops began withdrawing last night from the Mlada military reservation north of Prague to make room for the Seventh Soviet Army, which is to be stationed there.

American Catholics are caught up in guilt and conflict as they move toward increasingly liberal attitudes on birth control and marriage, according to a study released yesterday by the Urban Life Institute of the University of San Francisco, a Jesuit school.

Securities markets soon may return to a full trading week, but numerous brokerage concerns will be restricted -- at least temporarily -- in the amount of business they will be allowed to handle. These were the main points in a special bulletin released yesterday to the members of the New York Stock Exchange by Robert W. Haack, president of the Big Board.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi of India embarked on a round of discussions with government officials today, the second day of her official visit to Argentina.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 -- Vice President Humphrey pledged tonight to stop the bombing of North Vietnam if elected President -- but only if Hanoi gave some sign of being willing to begin serious peace talks.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- Both prices and volume showed little change at this week's mortgage commitment purchase "auction" of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the agency reported today.

Connie Francis, the singer, has filed a $350,000 suit against Eastern Air Lines, Inc., charging that she was annoyed by two intoxicated fellow passengers on a New York-to-Miami flight last Dec. 28. The action became known when Eastern filed yesterday for removal of the case from Manhattan Supreme Court to the Southern District Federal Court.
Pan American World Airways announced yesterday it would operate the largest fall and winter schedule in its history, beginning Oct. 27.

The Lytton Financial Corporation, the troubled California savings-and-loan holding company, disclosed yesterday further details of its merger program and recapitalization plan that were outlined in broad terms 10 days ago.

DALLAS, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Mickiy Mantle, the New York Yankee star, went fishing today and said he would make no decision about possible retirement until spring training next year. "I'm not going to make any decision about retirement until spring training," Mantle said.

R. Gordon Hoxie, the controversial chancellor who headed Long Island University while it went through a period of rapid expansion, submitted his resignation yesterday. It was accepted by the university's board of trustees.

MADRID, Sept. 30 (Reuters) The -- Duchess of Medina-Sidonia, Spain's crusading noblewoman, was acquitted today of insulting the Spanish judiciary in her novel about corruption and social injustice in southern Spain.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday the election of George B. Beitzel and Dr. John W. Gibson as vice presidents. Mr. Beitzel will continue as assistant general manager of the data processing group, made up of five I.B.M. divisions that develop, manufacture and market I.B.M. compters.

WHEN glamour - drenched Xerox decided to acquire C.I.T. Financial, the company that had revolutionized office paper-work procedures also decided, willy-nilly, to join the ranks of the nation's very largest industrial corporations.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 30 -- Ed Gaffney scored three goals today as the Hofstra University soccer team posted its third straight victory, 4-1, over Stony Brook. It was the opening game for the losers.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Farm prices rose 2 per cent during the month ended Sept. 15 for the third consecutive month, the Agriculture Department reported today.
A strike of 75,000 longshoremen that could halt most cargo shipments in ports from Maine to Texas began today, but President Johnson moved to cut it short.
Fordham University received $9,094,029 in gifts, grants and pledges in the 12 months ended June 30, an increase of more than one-third over the previous high mark of $6,644,027 set in 1966-67.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 30 -- A white paper, in which the South Vietnamese Government affirmed its refusal to cede any territory to North Vietnam as part of a peace settlement, was received by the official American community today with little excitement.

MONCTON, New Brunswick, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press) -- Earl Heiskala scored twice in the second period tonight, to lead the Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League to a 6-3 victory over the Quebec Aces in an exhibition game.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- One man died and 12 others were hospitalized tonight of apparent heat prostration and suffocation after they were locked in the trailer of a two-ton truck more than 13 hours.
George Ball leaped too precipitously the other day from the careful language of diplomacy to the less inhibited rhetoric of politics.

Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx, generally viewed as a possible Democratic candidate for Mayor next year, has endorsed James Farmer, Republican-Liberal, for Congress from the new Brooklyn 12th District.

When Purdue, led by Leroy Keyes, scored its impressive 37-22 victory over Notre Dame last Saturday, there was little doubt which college football team would be ranked No. 1 in the nation this week. To no one's surprise, The Associated Press and United Press International polls, which were released yesterday, showed the Boilermakers on top of the weekly ratings by runaway margins.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 30 (AP) -- The Philadelphia 76ers routed the Boston Celtics, 138-115, tonight for their second National Basketball Association exhibition victory over the world champions in two days.

James F. Reilly, a general partner in Goodbody Co., has resigned "for internal reasons," Harold P. Goodbody, managing partner, announced yesterday. Mr. Reilly, who was in charge of the firm's municipal bond department, could not be reached for comment.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Calvin Griffith, quoting Leo Durocher's phrase that "nice guys finish last," said today he would not renew Cal Ermer's contract as manager of the Minnesota Twins. The Twins finished seventh.
Standard Rate and Data Service announces the availability for direct mail use of its lists of media, advertisers and agency presidents.

CORINTH, Greece, Sept. 30 (AP) -- An express train rammed a stationary passenger train tonight about 30 miles from this city in southern Greece, killing 10 persons and injuring more than 100, the police reported.
MEXICO CITY, Sept. 30 -- Federal troops ended their occupation of the National University today as both the Government and striking students continued efforts to reduce tensions in the capital.
A mother croons over her giggling baby. "He's so adorable. I wonder what he'll be like when he grows up." Hesitantly, she continues, "There's so much violence now . . ."
QUEBEC, Sept. 30 -- Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Premier Maurice Couve de Murville agreed today that their respective governments would work for a better relationship.

The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered its air traffic controllers to discontinue using two wall-sized radar screens at Kennedy International Airport because planes are not being clearly presented on them.
General Motors is considering construction of a 25-story central headquarters in Detroit with twin towers, Edward N. Cole, president of the corporation, disclosed yesterday.
GEORGE ELIOT. A Biography. By Gordon S. Haight. 616 pages. Oxford. $12.50.
Final unofficial figures show to what extent the 1968 baseball season produced the worst all-inclusive offense since the present batting rules were adopted by both major leagues in 1903.
Local registration for voters was held yesterday at 5,278 polling places throughout the city. The polling places will be open again for registration Thursday, Friday and Saturday.
MOST bridge books have one author, but some have two and even three is not unknown.

ATHENS, Sept. 30 -- Premier George Papadopoulos indicated today that it might be some time yet before Greece gets free elections, but he held out the hope of a gradual easing of the restrictions in individual rights.
FRANKFURT, West Germany Sept. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Klaus Breuer, a 33-year-old nuclear physicist, has gone to East Berlin with his wife and 5-year-old son, a police spokesman said today.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 (UPI) -- Negro youths hurled rocks and bottles at passing cars and passing policemen tonight on Chicago's Near North Side, injuring at least one person. At least 12 arrests were made.

A Bethlehem Steel Corporation spokesman confirmed here yesterday that the company had asked San Francisco port authorities for a long-term lease on property adjoining its San Francisco shipyard for a drydock capable of handling 60,000-ton ships.
CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- James F. Hoge Jr. becomes, at 32 years of age, editor of the nation's seventh-largest morning newspaper tomorrow.
The city's teachers returned to work yesterday without major incident in the classrooms throughout the city, including the troubled Ocean Hill-Brownsville district, after a three-week strike.

ALBANY, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Dr. Evan R. Collins, the first president of the State University of New York at Albany, will resign in June, the school said today. The 56-year-old educator said that he believed 20 years was long enough to hold the kind of responsibility that had been his since he became president in 1949.
WHILE Joseph Loo was watching television on Sunday evening, the telephone rang. His mother answered.
The Clevite Corporation announced yesterday that it had withdrawn its appeal from a court order that barred the company from voting proxies obtained in favor of a merger with TRW, Inc.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30 -- Federal banking officials clashed here today at the American Bankers Association's annual convention over the spreading trend among major banks to diversify through one-bank holding companies.
ROME, Sept. 30 (Reuters) -- King Constantino had no comment on his people's endorsement of a new Constitution, a spokesman said today.

San Juan, Puerto Rico, was selected yesterday as the site for the semi-final Davis Cup tennis series between the United States and the India-West Germany winner. The series will be played on a hard court in November with the dates still being negotiated.
All partners in a leading Philadelphia investment banking house, Butcher Sherrerd, are resigning the directorships they hold in publicly owned companies.
The Little Symphony of Nashville, a bright, mostly young group of 19 players, brought a fresh and balanced program to Town Hall last night for its local debut.

SALT LAKE CITY, Sept. 30 -- Four of the most amiable men in the Republican party arrived today, identified themselves as the "truth squad" and vowed to pursue Vice President Humphrey to every campaign stop, setting straight the Nixon record and pointing out the "inconsistencies" of his Democratic opponent.

DENVER, Sept. 30 (AP) -- Coach Lou Saban of the Denver Broncos said today that Marlin Briscoe, the first Negro ever to play quarterback in the American Football League, would start Sunday against the Cincinnati Bengals.

BAD GODESBERG, West Germany -- It is called irreverently "Klein Amerika" and "the golden ghetto" and to the 1,000 Americans of the diplomatic and military community who live in the United States Government-built housing development in Plittersdorf, near Bonn, it is a little bit of home on the Rhine.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30 -- (UPI) -- Robert E. Hunter, new chairman and president of the Philco Ford Corporation, found women pickets protesting the company's manufacture of transistor radios and television sets in Taiwan when he arrived today at the company's plant here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30 -- "By the end of this Administration, I will have worked with four chiefs of protocol," Bess Abell, the White House social secretary, mused. "Three of them I liked very much, and one I am in love with."
"I'm so afraid of Nixon, Paul, you don't know," said a middle-aged man in shirtsleeves as he dashed out of a building on Jamaica Avenue and grabbed the candidate's hand.

TEHERAN, Iran, Oct. 1 -- A plan to forbid the growing of marijuana is to be discussed at the 37th General Assembly of the International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol), which opened here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Johnson signed today a bill creating a Flaming Gorge National Recreation Area, a 201,250-acre lake and scenic area straddling the Utah-Wyoming border.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The United States, with support from Japan, Canada and India, urged today that the new international money known as Special Drawing Rights be created early next year.

SEATTLE, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Boeing company's 68,000 production workers throughout the country voted today to accept a new three-year contract that the International Association of Machinists Aerospace Workers said was worth $350-million.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 AP) -- Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National Chairman, challenged Richard M. Nixon tonight to meet Hubert H. Humphrey in a nationwide television debate on Mr. Humphrey's proposals for peace in Vietnam.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Texas educator, the Rev. Dr. James M. Moudy, of Fort Worth, was elected today to become moderator of the Christian Church Disciples of Christ. It is the highest office of the new denomination of about 1.4 million members.

It looks as if the Front Street Theater in Memphis, a professional company that has been waging a valiant battle to stay alive for the last 11 years, has been reprieved -- for a while at least. Several days ago it labored under what seemed like a sentence of death, particularly anguishing because it had recently worked out a cooperative arrangement with Memphis State University that would benefit both institutions.
The Army's revised version of what happened at the Battle of the Little Bighorn 92 years ago versus Hollywood's version headed for a legal fight yesterday.

THE Redcoats came to Madison Square Garden last night, and conquered. A full house of Yanks greeted the 160 men and 47 horses of the Queen's Guard Tattoo with delight and something like awe. The British Empire may be a myth these days, but a show like this has you believing in it all over again.

LONDON, Oct. 1 -- Pierre Salinger declared today that Vice President Humphrey, with his remarks on the bombing in Vietnam, had moved "irrevocably toward those who supported the minority plank on Vietnam" at the Democratic National Convention.

HAGERSTOWN, Md., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The natural gas supply to Hagerstown was shut off today after an explosion in the pipelines that carries gas to the city of 36,000. The Columbia Gas Company of Maryland said its 9,000 customers would be without a supply until the gas was turned off at each individual home, then turned back on.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican nominee for Vice President, charged today that Vice President Humphrey's conditional proposal to stop the bombing of North Vietnam had "strengthened the hand of Hanoi" and prolonged the war.
There are slums and there are filthy streets; there are rats and there are roaches; there are heatless tenements whose residents have lost hope that they can have a healthy life.
KNOXVILLE, Oct. 1 -- Displaying the combative spirit that he had long promised his worried followers, Vice President Humphrey roared into the South today with a biting attack on George C. Wallace.

LAUREL, Miss., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The widowed mother of the 1964 Olympic long jump champion, Ralph Boston, will be with him when he competes in the Olympics in Mexico City, thanks to a group of merchants.
BONN, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesing said today that he had told President de Gaulle that, although Europe could not be built without France, Britain also belonged in it.
GENEVA, Oct. 1 -- In the midst of a series of setbacks to efforts to unify Europe's scientific efforts, a bold step in that direction has been taken here.
The New York Telephone Company again will furnish scores of all World Series games. The number is 637-1212, the company's time bureau.

With the opening next Monday of the October term of the United States Supreme Court it is deplorable that the Senate has failed to face up to its duty on the nomination of Associate Justice Fortas to be Chief Justice.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 1 -- A $6.2-million fund drive has begun here to replace the aging building of the Walker Art Center, one of the country's leading museums of contemporary art, and to expand the facilities of its connecting structure, the Tyrone Guthrie Theater.
The election of William M. Batten as a director of the Boeing Company was announced yesterday. He is chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the J. C. Penney Company.

Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, said on his arrival here last night that the Soviet Union would "cooperate within the United Nations and outside it" toward "ending the threat of a new war."

O. J. Simpson of Southern California has carried the ball 73 times and gained 425 yards in the Trojans' two games this season, but he's only in third place in the rushing department among the nation's major college football players.
ATHENS, Oct. 1 -- The Greek Government announced today that 91.87 per cent of the vote in the referendum Sunday favored the new Constitution.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Widespread floods following 24 hours of continuous torrential rain in Taiwan left 19 persons dead and set off landslides, cutting rail and road traffic, the police reported today.
John W. Burton was named yesterday as president of the Mid-Continent Manufacturing Company, Columbus, Ohio. He formerly was vice president of the H. K. Porter Company.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Vice President Humphrey's Vietnam policy speech was regarded by politicians here as a political whimper at a time when his campaign desperately needed a bang.
Salomon Brothers Hutzler, an investment firm, has admitted Stanley J. Arkin, 32 years old, John Scott Crabtree, 38, and Joseph P. Lombard, 40, as general partners, the concern announced yesterday.
It was just after 9 A.M. and on the corners behind the wooden police barricades 2welling groups of Negroes stood and shouted.

Book rights to the late Senator Robert F. Kennedy's 25,000-word account of the Cuban missile crisis have been acquired by W. W. Norton Co., a small privately owned publishing house, for a sum in excess of $250,000.

For the seventh time in the last seven contract negotiations covering dock workers in Atlantic and Gulf ports a strike by the International Longshoremen's Association has throttled international and coastal trade. And for the seventh time the White House has obtained a national emergency injunction to shield the country against the strike's deadening impact -- an effect made worse this year by the precarious state of the balance of payments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation reported today that Soviet and Communist Chinese espionage and a mushrooming New Left movement on college campuses were posing growing threats to the nation's security.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Policemen ejected today young antiwar protesters and their lawyers who staged a "stand-in" protest against a Congressional inquiry into street clashes during the Democratic National Convention.

DENVER, Oct. 1 -- "Give me two and one-half years and I'd like to be heavyweight champion," George Foreman said today, looking up from a copy of the latest "Peanuts" book and pointing to his "boy," Charlie Brown. "But first let me find out about myself."

A manufacturer of paper and plastic bags and a securities brokerage firm have signed long-term leases for office space in Greenwich Plaza, the office and commercial development on the site of the railroad station in Greenwich, Conn.
NASHVILLE, Oct. 1 -- Vice President Humphrey resolutely refused today to amplify or clarify his nationally televised speech on the war in Vietnam last night.

Donald A. Holden and Henry U. Harris Jr., have been elected directors of Tenneco, Inc. Mr. Holden is president and chairman of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company and Mr. Harris is president of Harris, Upham Co., Inc., the stock brokerage firm. Newport News Shipbuilding was acquired by Tenneco in September through an exchange of debentures and stock.
BOSTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Ed Hummer, a 6-foot-7-inch forward from Princeton, quit the Boston Celtics today, ending a second bid to earn a job with the National Basketball Association champions.
Three New York realty men -- Roger Malkin, his brother Peter L. and Lester S. Morse Jr. -- have formed a new company, Roger Malkin Associates, Inc.

The Pacific Lighting Corporation announced yesterday at Los Angeles that Paul A. Miller had been elected president and chief executive officer. Mr. Miller, who had been executive vice president, will succeed Robert A. Hornby, who will retire on Nov. 1. The company's operating subsidiaries provide natural gas to the bulk of the southern California market with the exception of the San Diego area.

Merger-minded businessmen were told yesterday by several top Washington aides that any major directional shifts in antitrust legislation would probably largely be shaped by themselves . . . not the Department of Justice or the Federal Trade Commission.

A new two-year agreement between the Harbor Carriers of New York and Lighter Captains Union, Local 996 of the International Longshoremen's Association, was announced yesterday. The local is the only "seagoing" unit of the I.L.A.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The United States command announced today the top-secret military plan for conducting the war in South Vietnam next year had been signed by all the senior allied commanders.
BROWN'S football squad will have little time to savor its opening-game victory over Rhode Island because the Bruins' next rival is Penn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Maritime Administration today announced approval of changes in basic characteristics for three large high-speed barge-carrying vessels for Lykes Bros. Steamship Company of New Orleans. A contract award for the vessels is expected shortly.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Pattrick Cardinal O'Boyle announced today that he had discharged 39 priests in the Washington archdiocese for publicly dissenting from what he called the "authentic teaching" of the Roman Catholic church.
O WAYNE ROLLINS is a courtly Georgian who is dedicated to the mathematical principle that 2 plus 2 equals 4.
MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Two young Soviet woodcutters completed a 2,700-mile journey in a rowboat through the rivers and lakes of European Russia, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- A federal army squeeze on shrunken Biafra tightened today following the capture of the important crossroads town of Okigwi.
The stock market rally continued to roll along in high gear yesterday, carrying most major market indicators to new highs for the year.

GROTON, Conn., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The apparent suicide of a Negro who was pressing discrimination charges against a volunteer fire company was ordered investigated today by State Attorney General Robert K. Killian.

White, Weld Co., investment banking and brokerage firm, yesterday announced the appointment of five new officers: Robert G. L. Harris, vice president-personnel; John P. Indelli, vice president-taxes; Martin J. McCallen, vice president-operations; James J. McDonough, vice president-accounting, and Domenick Lorelli, assistant vice president-cashiering.
