COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Some 200 rioting prisoners surrendered at South Carolina's main penitentiary today after a four-hour siege in which they attacked guards, set fires and smashed prison facilities.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said here today that in the current economic environment the Federal Reserve should not lead the way toward lower interest rates.
Red bricks, pipes, pieces of wood and dust fill the lot on East 86th Street where the German Brauhaus stood for almost 40 years.
MILAN, Italy, Oct 1 (UPI) -- Funerals in Milan became free of charge today, with the city providing everything except flowers, draperies and church rites.

The American Civil Liberties Union released recommendations yesterday to insure the academic freedom of secondary school students and teachers, saying that high-school students "should have the right to live under the principle of 'rule by law' as opposed to 'rule by personality.'"

The New York Nets of the American Basketball Association open their exhibition schedule Friday night against the Houston Mavericks at Huntington. L. I. The same teams meet Saturday night in Selden, L. I.

"Carnival," which had a run of 720 performances when it closed in 1963, will receive its first local revival on Dec. 12 at the City Center. The musical, which will continue until Jan. 5, will be performed by the City Center Light Opera Company.

GEORGE UNGER, who died Sunday night after a heart attack, was the man who knew them all. In his 21 years as assistant manager of the Cavendish Club here, and 20 before that as a leading player, he was on friendly terms with New York experts of every generation from the earliest years of the game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Robert S. McNamara's commitment of World Bank support for family planning in developing countries was praised today as a major advance in international cooperation for population control.
Colette Boky, the soprano who portrayed Gilda in last night's "Rigoletto" at the Metropolitan Opera, has the prerequisites for the part.

BROOKLYN, Mich., Oct. 1 -- As Mario Andretti, Al Unser, Art Pollard and Jim Malloy took their turns today in a series of tire tests for Firestone, electricians, carpenters and the operators of earth-moving machinery stopped work to look.
BLACKPOOL, England, Oct. 1 -- Prime Minister Wilson won cheers from the Labor party conference today with an aggresive and optimistic political speech.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The ultimate beautiful person, Gloria Vanderbilt, was in Washington tonight, and the capital's pacesetters stayed away in droves. After all, it was a public place, and someone might make comparisons.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct 1 (AP) -- The president of San Francisco State College refused today to reassign George Murray, a Black Panther, to a nonteaching post, as requested by state college trustees.

ATHENS -- The obvious choice now facing Greece's autocratic regime is whether to follow the example of Turkey's military junta earlier this decade and take the road back to parliamentary democracy or to pursue another East Mediterranean path, Nasser's, ending up neutralist and subject to Moscow's ogling.
PHOENIX -- The television commercial opens on Arizona's spectacular Monument Valley. A familiar, craggily handsome figure is standing, in Levi's and a cowboy hat, by a campfire. It's Barry Goldwater.
LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 2 -- Fifty-five Roman Catholic priests in Britain said today that they could not support Pope Paul's encyclical on birth control.
BUDAPEST, Oct. 1 -- The Soviet Union and 57 other Communist parties unanimously agreed today to postpone the world Communist summit conference scheduled for Moscow next month.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Bob Gibson said today that he wasn't awed by the aura surrounding his heralded duel with 31-game winner Denny McLain in tomorrow's first game of the World Series. McLain didn't appear to be awed, either.
The London stock market reversed its recent sharp declines with a brisk recovery yesterday.
RICHMOND, Oct. 1 -- The Richmond News Leader, Virginia's largest afternoon newspaper, endorsed today the Presidential candidacy of Richard M. Nixon.

REVILLON, which showed safe, traditional furs last June in its wholesale collection, let its young designer, Fernando Sanchez, loose among heaps of sable, fox and lynx for the furs to be sold in its Saks Fifth Avenue salon.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The North American Soccer League will meet in Chicago Nov. 1 to complete operational plans for 1969, Stu Holcomb, general manager of the Chicago Mustangs, said today.
A Federal judge signed a temporary restraining order last night directing an end to a strike by 75,000 Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshoremen that had started at 12:01 A.M. yesterday.

ROME; Oct. 1 -- The Vatican presented guidelines today for "prudent" dialogue between Christians and nonbelievers, including Communists, that could lead to mutual profit and even active collaboration for specific ends.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Using simplified tests to detect rubella infection, scientists have concluded that the disease may be even more dangerous than has been generally thought.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- This is the last time the World Series teams will be determined on the current format. With the expansion to 12 teams in each major league in 1969, there will be divisional playoffs before each league champion is crowned.
MADISON, Wis., Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Wisconsin Selective Service headquarters was firebombed last night and some draft records destroyed, officials said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Leonard H. Marks will resign soon as director of the United States Information Agency to head a United States delegation arranging for an international telecommunications satellite conference in 1969.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie said here today that Vice Presdent Humphrey's proposal for arranging a halt to the bombing of North Vietnam was not necessarily the only approach that a new Democratic Administration would take toward ending the war.
The Smothers Brothers are having problems with the censor again.
FLINT, Mich., Oct. 1 -- George C. Wallace encountered some of the most determined heckling of his fall campaign today as he faced large but often uncommitted audiences in Michigan.

LONDON, Wednesday, Oct. 2 -- A collection of royal snapshots, including some showing Queen Elizabeth II sitting up in bed, have found their way into the French picture magazine Paris Match. How they did so has mystified officials of Buckingham Palace.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Three San Francisco Giants coaches, Charley Fox, Wes Westrum and Larry Jansen, resigned today, saying they want to give the new manager of the club a free hand to choose his own coaches. Herman Franks, manager of the Giants for four years, has said he would not be back next year.

NEW DELHI, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- The Government is extending a ceasefire with the guerrilla rebels of Nagaland in northeastern India by one month until Oct. 31, officials said today. The truce came into force in September, 1964, to end a bitter 10-year jungle war between the Nagas and Indian security forces.
Gold prices declined again in London yesterday, indicating further relaxing of world tensions. In New York, silver futures contracts responded with another sharp drop.
Vassar College has decided to become fully coeducational.

The American Machine and Foundry Company announced yesterday that, after setting aside a $62.8-million special reserve, it expected to report a loss of $12.4-million for the nine months ended Sept. 30.

BRANTFORD, Ont., Oct. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Andy Bathgate, leading scorer in the National Hockey League's Western Division last season, was cut today by the Pittsburgh Penguins. Bathgate, 36 years old, was obtained in the 1967 expansion draft by Pittsburgh. He scored 20 goals and 39 assists last season.
CHICAGO, Oct. 1 -- The Federal Reserve Board has imposed a freeze on applications for new bank branches in Nassau, the Bahamas, bankers said here today.
The Detroit Tigers edged the St. Louis Cardinals in their first confrontation yesterday -- in home attendance figures for the 1968 baseball season.
MIAMI BEACH, Oct. 1 -- The 50,000-member Industrial Union of Marine and Shipbuilding Workers of America at its 24th biennial convention here today unanimously elected Andrew A. Pettis as president.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Richard M. Nixon has promised the ecurities industry that, if elected President, he will end the "heavy-handed bureaucratic regulatory schemes" of the Johnson Administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Johnson refused today to back down on his nomination of Justice Fortas.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 1 -- Yom Kippur, the most solemn day in the Hebrew calendar, began this evening with Israel virtually sealed from the Arab areas that were occupied during the war last year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- On the eve of the creation of a redwood national park, protests have been sounded in California over the road-building and log-removal activities of two lumber companies in the park area.

Franchot Tone, the actor who died here Sept. 18 at the age of 63, has left an estate estimated at between $250,000 to $500,000, according to his will, which was filed for probate yesterday in Manhattan Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Navy has quietly backed off its position that all its 2.75-inch rocket-launcher contracts must go to a St. Louis company that is under Federal indictment charging kickbacks on past contracts for the equipment.

PARIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- An agreement to build Javelins and Ramblers in West Germany was announced here today by the American Motors Corporation and Wilhelm Karmann Company. The production is to start at Karmann's Rheine plant in November and will mark the first time the company's cars have been built in Germany.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union sent Communist China a curt, frigid message of congratulations on its 19th anniversary today. The message, published in Pravda, made no reference to the Chinese Communist party.
LISBON, Oct. 1 -- "To us, Spain is almost an ideal," a liberal Portuguese journalist said the other day.
Stockholders of The New York Times Company approved, at a meeting here yesterday, a four-for-one split of the common stock. It is expected to become effective tomorrow.
The Central Aguirre Sugar Company said yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire all the shares of the Port Everglades Steel Corporation for Central Aguirre stock.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Senator Harrison A. Williams, Democrat of New Jersey, introduced legislation today to create a Federal institute on retirement income that would prepare a plan to meet the income needs of retired Americans.

Net operating earnings of the Security National Bank of Long Island increased 31.9 per cent to a record of $4,011,998, or $1.96 a share, for the nine months ended Sept. 30. This compares with $3,042,068, or $1.78 a share, for the 1967 period.

Tales of curses, threats, menacing crowds and hands raised against them in anger were told by 17 members of the United Federation of Teachers late yesterday in complaints about their treatment in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville schools.
VILLANOVA, Pa., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Jim (Jumbo) Elliott, the Villanova track coach, gave up his fight today to get Dave Patrick, his star miler, on the United States Olympic track and field team.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Double the Bet made the 9,476 fans here today wish they had when she outclassed eight other fillies to win the I.B.M. Purse by nine lengths.
STRASBOURG, France, Oct 1 (Reuters) -- The European Parliament today approved the signing of the association treaty between the European Common Market and Tanzania, Uganda and Kenya.

A cut of $1 a ton on the coming $5-a-ton increase in the price of newsprint in some Southwestern and border states was announced yesterday by the Kimberly-Clark Corporation and Bowater Paper Corporation, in line with similar adjustments made late last week by two other major producers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday its enforcement bureau had filed complaints accusing four foreign air carriers of giving illegal discounts to certain air freight customers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- House and Senate conferees agreed today on a bill to continue for two years the suspension of tariffs on copper. The bill provides, however, that if the price of copper drops from the current level of 42 cents a pound to 36 cents, a 1.5-cent-a-pound tariff will take effect, and if it drops to 24 cents, a 1.8-cent tariff will take effect.

One of the City Center Joffrey Ballet's most engaging qualities is that it is a company with no back row. Last night at the City Center, Gay Wallstrom, a newcomer, made a promising debut in her first major role as the girl in the season's first performance of "Secret Places."

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Joe Cronin, president of the American League, made the following comment today concerning the news that his umpires had joined the National League umpires in a combined association, and that they might strike next spring unless Bill Valentine and Al Salerno were reinstated: "No comment."

MEMPHIS, Oct. 1 -- The two Memphis daily newspapers said today that they would appeal the contempt of court convictions of two reporters who had written interviews with an attorney for James Earl Ray, who is accused of the murder of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at Memphis last April.
As a heavy volume of new tax-exempt bonds hit the capital market yesterday, interest rates moved up a little and investors generally showed no great interest in putting their funds to work.

BONN, Oct. 1 -- Young demonstrators shouting the Nazi slogan "Sieg heil" and throwing tear gas tonight broke up the National Democratic party's first rally in the West German capital.
BERLIN, Oct. 1 -- Mayor Klaus Schutz and his city administration moved today to request the Western allies formally to ban the right-wing National Democratic party in West Berlin.
WASHINGTON Oct. 1 (AP) -- A Department of Justice spokesman said today an investigation into the time-sharing service business of the International Business Machine Corporation is under way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Mrs. Lynda Bird Robb has hired a refugee from Communist East Germany to take care of her first baby, the White House said today. The refugee is Lottie Glasel, a middle-aged practical nurse, who speaks with a heavy German accent.
Shareholders Capital Corporation, of Los Angeles, went public yesterday with the offering of one million shares at $20 a share.
ROME, Oct. 1 -- Italy's school year began today, but lessons for the most part did not start as an administrative strike kept many of the schools closed and millions of students at home.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 94.6 on Monday from 94.5 on Friday.

LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- Not since the two top gunslingers of the old West blazed away at each other on a dusty street of some border town has there been a shoot-out to match the showdown on the morrow between Denny McLain, with 31 notches on the handle of his trusty six-shooter, and Bob Gibson, with 22.
A 10-day program saluting Brazilian filmmakers, will be presented starting on Monday at the Museum of Modern Art.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- King Hussein of Jordan underwent a sinus operation today. His condition was described as "satisfactory." He is expected to remain at the Fitzroy Nuffield Nursing Home for several days.

Two long-established home furnishings chains in the New York area, J. Michaels, Inc., and J. Kurtz Sons, announced yesterday an agreement in principle for Michaels to acquire all of the stock of Kurtz, for $2-million.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- The postponement of the world Communist conference was regarded here today as a painful blow to Soviet prestige. The project had been pressed by the Soviet Union for many years before it gained acceptance at a preparatory meeting in Budapest last February.

PARIS, Oct. 1 -- The North Vietnamese brusquely spurned today Vice President Humphrey's qualified pledge to halt the bombing of North Vietnam. They called it a campaign maneuver that offered Hanoi "nothing new."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Oct. 1 -- Premier Hilmar Baunsgaard said today that events this summer had underlined the need for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as a political instrument in the service of peace.

PARIS, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- Yves Saint Laurent opened his second ready-to-wear boutique in Paris yesterday. GEORGETOWN, Ky., Oct. 1 (AP) -- My My, the horse that won the five-gaited championship six consecutive years at the Kennedy State Fair horse show, died today at the farm of the trainer, Frank Bradshaw. The 11-year-old chestnut mare had been ill one week.
President Francois Tombalbaye of the Central African republic of Chad, arrived at Kennedy Airport yesterday. He is scheduled to meet with President Johnson today.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange achieved a modest advance in moderately active trading yesterday. Prices were up in the morning session, and lost ground during the afternoon trading, which was relatively quiet.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Oct. 1 -- Former President Marco A. Robles arrived at Miami International Airport early today. He was greeted by his wife, Petita, and his 7-year-old daughter, Roxana, who have been living here for the last several weeks.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The State Board of Regents today canceled its extraordinary meeting set for Thursday to discuss an interim school decentralization plan for New York City.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (UPI) House leaders said today that a Senate-passed bill to permit bigger trucks on interstate highways was dead.

SOUTHPORT, England, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Billy Casper was listed as a 4-1 favorite today to win his sixth tournament this year when the $139,000 Alcan Golfer-of-the-Year championship gets under way tomorrow at a soggy Royal Birkdale Golf Club course.

LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- In the pictures of Queen Elizabeth sitting up in bed, she is wearing a long-sleeved pale, opaque peignoir and has on lipstick as well as earrings and a three-strand pearl necklace.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Sale of the Scripps Miramar Ranch here was completed today when the Macco Corporation of Newport Beach, Calif., took title to the 1,180- acre property. The purchase price of the land, established by the late newspaper publisher, E. W. Scripps, in 1890 as a family home, was $4.2million.

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Soviet press agency Tass said today that there was nothing new in Vice President Humphrey's election program. His foreign policy pronouncements are only designed to catch votes, Tass said.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The Government today began issuing new identity cards to South Vietnamese 15 years or older. The cards, designed to be difficultto forge, are to assist in controlling movement into and out of areas contested by the Vietcong.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The House ethics committee ordered today a preliminary inquiry into charges of irregularities in voting in the House, with votes being cast for absent members.
Criminal Court Judge Milton Shalleck refused yesterday to grant a jury trial to a defendant in a misdemeanor case. The ruling was counter to another judge's decision of three weeks ago.

PRAGUE, Oct. 1 -- Newspapers in East Germany have stopped, at least temporarily, their campaign of polemics against Czechoslovakia, Rude Pravo, the official Czechoslovak Communist party newspaper, reported today.

The possibility of a new citywide teachers' strike developed yesterday as angry parents, children and demonstrators clashed with the police over 83 teachers they did not want returned to schools in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Jacksonville is the most extensive city in the nation, with a municipal area of 827 square miles, as a result of a consolidation effectedd last night.

The First National City Bank disclosed yesterday that it had sold its 8 per cent interest in Hill, Samuel Co. Ltd., the British bank, to Robert Fleming Co. of London. The Fleming concern placed the shares with investment clients.
United Merchants and Manufacturers, Inc., a leading diversified producer of textiles, reported yesterday substantially increased net income on higher sales for the fiscal year ended June 30.
LONDON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- A twin-jet Canberra bomber crashed into a shop in Crewkerne, in southwestern England, on a training flight today and burst into flames, killing the pilot.

BUFFALO, Oct. 1 -- More than $1-billion in highway construction contracts are being held up by the recent $200-million cutback in Federal highway expenditures, it was charged here today at the 66th annual meeting of the American Automobile Association.
The New York Generals announced yesterday that Miguel DeLima, a goalie, and Laszlo Kaszas, a halfback, had been given their unconditional releases.

Millions of dollars allocated to pay slum youths in the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps has been embezzled in the last 14 months, according to city and Federal investigators who have been checking the operation of the Human Resources Administration.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The hypnotic eyes of William Randolph Hearst, the imperious stance of James Abbott McNeill Whistler, the restless hands of President Franklin D. Roosevelt and the sour-lemon look of John D. Rockefeller Sr. are going on view next week at the nation's youngest art museum.

The first priority in Ocean Hill-Brownsville, regardless of past grievances, is assurance of continued peaceful operation of the schools. Mayor Lindsay, after yesterday's disorders, rightly warned that "if we do not retain education under law, we will have neither education nor law." This is basic: it must be understood by all parties, in their own and the children's interest.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- -- Mayor Carl B. Stokes was served with a summons today to appear in Probate Court within 10 days to answer charges of unlawful official action during snipings in July and alleged illegal use of "Cleveland, Now!" funds

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The merger of the Washington Gallery of Modern Art and the Corcoran Gallery of Art is expected to be announced this week. Details are being negotiated between officers of the Corcoran, Washington's oldest private art museum, and the city's newest gallery, which opened in the winter of 1962.

HONG KONG, Oct. 1 (AP) -- North Vietnam's top leadership sent a message today expressing "deep gratitude to the party, Government and people of Communist China for their strong and precious support and help" in the war against the United States. The message was broadcast by the Hanoi radio.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Top Administration officials, after studying Vice President Humphrey's latest statement on Vietnam, said privately today that they saw no substantive differences between Mr. Humphrey and President Johnson over United States bombing policy on North Vietnam.
WILMINGTON, N. C., Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Wilmington Star-News endorsed Mr. Nixon today, suggesting that his two opponents could "further weaken the national character."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- No quotas will be imposed on meat imports at this time, Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman indicated today.

The delegates assembly of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes, have endorsed the Democratic nominees for President and Vice President and Senator from New York.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 1 -- The 1968 Presidential race may shatter more traditional voting patterns than any other election of this century, the Gallup Poll reported today.
WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 1 -- Mrs. Robin Jordan said today that she and six friends had formed the Food for Biafra Committee of Westport.

A State Supreme Court justice in Queens yesterday over-turned as "patently unreasonable" and "improper" the city's ban on the use of Shea Stadium for a rally by third-party Presidential candidate George C. Wallace.
Arthur J. Goldberg said yesterday that he would begin an intensive mediation effort tomorrow in the police, fire and sanitation contract disputes with the city.
A transit patrolman with a keen memory last night arrested two youths, moments after they held up the change booth clerk in the Rockefeller Plaza-50th Street Independent subway station.

Gimbel Brothers, Inc., took title yesterday to 35,000 square feet of land on the Upper East Side for its new department store branch that some city planners believe represents the birth of a new major shopping district in Manhattan.
The National Maritime Union is taking the Grace Line to arbitration on the ground that it is discriminating on the basis of sex -- against men.

Vice President Humphrey's qualified pledge to take "a risk for peace" and stop the bombing of North Vietnam is somewhat different in tone but not notably different in content from the position of the Johnson Administration.
BELO HORIZONTE, Brazil, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- An interstate bus en route to Sao Paulo plunged 30 feet into a river, killing six passengers and injuring 21 others, traffic police reported today.
PARIS, Oct. 1 -- Paid television advertising made its first appearance on the Government-controlled French Television Network tonight.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 -- The Mississippi riverfront came alive today with the gathering clamor of the World Series, which will open here tomorrow with a bristling match between Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals and Denny McLain of the Detroit Tigers.

Martin H. Dubilier, president of Kearney-National, Inc., announced yesterday that Kearney-National had decided not to proceed with merger discussions with the Simplex Wire and Cable Company of Cambridge, Mass.
"Triple Play," the over-all title for Randolph Carter's three one-act plays, will open Oct. 30 at the Cherry Lane Theater. Joel M. Reed, Robert Gibson and Milo Wood are the producers.

You must be registered to vote. Permanent personal registration is in effect throughout New York State. If you have voted from your present address in a general election in the last two years you are registered. If you have not you should check to make sure your registration is still on record.

AFTER more than an irksome year of filing permits, seeking a rezoning, participating in hearings and philosophically listening to the pros and cons offered by residents to a big store being dropped into their midst, Gimbels yesterday had cleared the way to opening a store in "the richest suburb of New York -- the Upper East Side."

MOSCOW, Oct. 1 -- The Soviet economic planning chief, Deputy Premier Nikolai K. Baibakov, endorsed today a potentially controversial plan to encourage the dismissal of surplus workers by allowing managers to make use of resulting wage savings to increase the pay of remaining employes.

Laird, Inc., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, said yesterday it had formed an executive recruiting concern, Laird Executive Management, Inc., which would operate independently as an affiliate.
FORT DIX, N.J., Oct. 1 -- A 26-year-old draftee who was accused of handing out antiwar leaflets, contrary to post regulations, won acquittal at his court martial here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Following is the roll-call by which the Senate refused today to cut off debate on the motion to take up the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States (a two-thirds vote was required):

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 1 (AP) -- More than 70 Negro students from Thomas Jefferson and Battin High Schools walked out of school today to press their demands for curriculum changes and more Negro guidance counselors.

DETROIT, Oct. 1 -- Richard M. Nixon suggested today that Vice President Humphrey should clarify his conditional pledge to end the bombing of North Vietnam lest it imperil the Paris negotiations and the lives of American soldiers in Vietnam.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1 (AP) -- October's bright blue weather is expected to prevail at least through the first two games of the World Series tomorrow and Thursday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The United States announced today the names of its five delegates and five alternates to the General Assembly. The group is headed by James Russell Wiggins, former Editor of The Washington Post.

Floyd Patterson has agreed to referee the interfraternity boxing bouts Friday at C. W. Post College, Brookville, L. I., according to William Bursten, chancellor of Tau Epsilon Phi, the sponsoring fraternity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- Construction activity rose about 2 per cent, or $1.2-billion, on a seasonally adjusted basis, from July to August, the census bureau reported today. The total value of construction put in place during the month was nearly $8-billion, which equals a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $83.9-billion.
Richard M. Nixon has assured the American Jewish Conference on Soviet Jewry of his concern over what he described as the "resurgence of the Soviet anti-Jewish propaganda campaign."
Irving Crane, an automobile salesman from Rochester, N. Y., defeated Steve Mizerak of Perth Amboy, N. J., 150-112, to win the invitation pocket billiards tournament last night at the Hotel Commodore.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk discouraged Soviet attempts to open a new big-power dialogue on a Middle Eastern settlement today and urged two Arab Foreign Ministers to concentrate on urgent United Nations mediation.

Walter Cronkite, the Columbia Broadcasting System newscaster, received the Carr Van Anita award of Ohio University on Monday. The award given for outstanding contributions to the field of journalism, honors a former managing editor of The New York Times.

The Georgia-Pacific Corporation announced yesterday it had purchased the remaining 70 per cent of the privately owned Urania Lumber Company of Louisana for more than $30-million. The purchase gives Georgia-Pacific 100 per cent ownership of Urania Lumber.
Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, said yesterday that Vice President Humphrey's Vietnam speech did not contain "any indication of a meaningful change in our foreign policy."
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 1 -- A purported Rembrandt on loan to the municipally owned Bowers Memorial Museum at Santa Ana has been declared a forgery.

The Hertz Corporation is planning to buy 110,000 new 1969 cars and trucks valued at approximately $420-million, the nation's leading vehicle renting and leasing company, announced yesterday. This is believed to be the largest order auto manufacturers will receive for the 1969 model year, and compares with $375-million paid for 100,000 vehicles a year earlier.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Oct. 1 (AP) -- Lance Cpl. James A. Maushart of Vacaville, Calif., was sentenced to two years' hard labor today after he had pleaded guilty to murdering a Vietnamese civilian. He was one of seven marines charged in the May 5 and 6 slayings of five civilians. Some of the victims were identified as Vietcong.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 1 -- The Ivory Coast representative said today that his Government had decided to set up a rehabilitation center in its territory for young people who were victims of the Nigerian civil war.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Oct. 1 (AP) -- Agriculture Secretary Orville Freeman said today he had written to Richard M. Nixon last week, asking the Republican Presidential candidate how present farm programs could be improved, and had not received any reply.

PANAMA, Oct. 1 -- Dr. Arnulfo Arias took office as President of Panama today for the third time in his stormy career while his predecessor, Marco A. Robles, slipped away in the night to the United States.
VIENNA, Oct. 1 -- Radio and television networks in Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland and Rumania hooked up with Vienna tonight to relay a gala show -- and it was not waltz or operetta but pop.

Negotiations between the Writers Guild of America and the three major radio-television networks resumed briefly yesterday afternoon and then were recessed until tomorrow morning. No significant progress on a new contract was reported.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- One theme appears to underlie most conversation so far at the annual week-long meeting here of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund -- a belief that no better man than Robert S. McNamara could have been chosen as the bank's president.

Directors of the Bangor Punta Corporation authorized yesterday an exchange offer for any and all of the 713,544 outstanding shares of capital stock of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company for a market value estimated at about $32 a share in Bangor Punta securities.

A group of Columbia University employes staged a sit-in last night in the office of the university's controller to protest recognition of Local 153 of the Office and Professional Employes International Union as a bargaining agent.

TOKYO, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Tokyo celebrated today its 100th anniversary as Japan's capital. The city, which now has a population of more than 11 million, replaced Kyoto as the official residence of the Emperor and capital of Japan in 1868.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 1 (Reuters) -- The Government of Premier Osvaldo Hercelles resigned today following a dispute over a contract with an American oil company.
The Los Angeles branch of the Actors Studio is preparing several presentations with Broadway in mind, according to Jack Garfein, head of the coast group.

ATHENS, Oct. 1 -- The death toll in a railway crash last night involving Greek voters returning from their home districts to Athens, rose to 34 today. More than 120 injured were sent to hospitals. The collision occurred at Derveni, halfway between Patras and Corinth, when one passenger train telescoped into another that had halted to give first aid to a fainting woman passenger.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 1 (UPI) -- Thousands of members of the United Mine Workers, which has been negotiating a new wage contract with soft coal operators, went on strike today in several states.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 1 -- Student leaders at the National University made it clear today that they would not end their two-month-old strike despite recent concessions by the Government.
Donald N. Frey, who resigned in August as a group vice president of the Ford Motor Company because he wanted to try his hand at something new, has found that something.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The invasion of Czechoslovakia has been denounced by the principal officers of the World Federation of Trade Unions, a Communist organization that the Soviet Union has nurtured into near-global influence.

MONTPELIER, Vt. Oct. 1 (UPI) -- The Vermont Supreme Court ruled today that public financing of a religious institution did not violate the separation of church and state provisions of the constitution.

If you were going to start a new magazine, would you plan on a controlled circulation of 15,000, an advertising cost per thousand of $133.50 (Fortune's is only $15.77), make it a quarterly and sell space at no less than a full page for a full year and then limit your ad pages per issue to 25?

BETONG, Thailand, Sept. 27 -- On the wall of the border police headquarters here, there is a poster offering a reward of 250,000 Malaysian dollars ($83,000) for the capture of a cherubic looking Chinese with bushy eyebrows and an almost sweet smile.
Cardigan Bay, harness racing's first $1-million winner, will be officially retired from competition in track ceremonies the night of Oct. 12 at Yonkers Raceway.
PARIS, Oct. 1 -- New and often conflicting details on the Fiat-Citroen deal appeared today, but doubt remained whether the French Government could bring itself to approve it.

President Martha E. Peterson of Barnard College announced yesterday the appointment of Mrs. Barbara V. Hertz to the position of director of development at the college. Mrs. Hertz will be chiefly concerned with raising $7.5-million to qualify for a $2.5-million Ford Foundation challenge grant that was made to the college three years ago.

At Vice President Humphrey's direct invitation, Arthur J. Goldberg, former United States representative at the United Nations and an open advocate of a bombing halt in Vietnam, took over command yesterday of the Humphrey-Muskie campaign in New York State.

The Clevite Corporation announced yesterday it was proposing to TRW, Inc., revised terms for a merger. Last March TRW had agreed to acquire Clevite: however, the transaction was blocked by legal action of the U.S. Smelting, Refining and Mining Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 -- The Senate refused by a wide margin today to stop the filibuster by opponents of the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States. The action appeared to doom the nomination.
Fawcett Publications, Inc., has announced the appointment of Peter A. Bonanni as advertising director of Woman's Day.
Norb Hecker was dismissed yesterday as head coach of the Atlanta Falcons by the president, Rankin M. Smith, who immediately hired Norm Van Brocklin as a replacement.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 1 (AP) -- President Johnson announced today that he would nominate a Secret Service agent, Emory P. Roberts, who has been a White House receptionist since 1965, to be a member of the United States Board of Parole.

Two thieves posing as furniture delivery men held up three women in an East Side apartment yesterday afternoon and made off with $200,000 in jewels and jade statues and vases, according to the police.

AT the Giants' press luncheon yesterday in Yankee Stadium, a call was placed to Tom Fears and the coach of the New Orleans Saints was asked the $64 question: How did he propose to defense Homer Jones here on Sunday?
MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 1 (AP) -- The United States is favored to retain the Espirio Santo Trophy, emblematic of the women's world amateur team golf championship.

SCRANTON, Pa., Oct. 1 -- Richard M. Nixon swung across northern Pennsylvania today looking for signs of the heavy upstate support he will need to overcome the usual Democratic majority in Philadelphia and win the state's 29 electoral votes.
Sculpture-watching took brief precedence over bird-watching yesterday in Bryant Park as the first of five giant aluminum sculptures was set in place.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Following are excerpts from the address made before the General Assembly today by Secretary of State Dean Rusk:
Charles Lamb, the English essayist, remarked almost 150 years ago, perhaps in one of his frequent nonsensical moods, that it was long his deliberate judgment that all bankrupts ought to be hanged.
The head of the teachers' union said yesterday that there was "better than a 50-50 chance" of a new citywide teachers' strike over the disruptions in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district.

Campaign organizers for George C. Wallace, third-party Presidential candidate, yesterday canceled their plans for a rally next Wednesday in Shea Stadium in the face of the Lindsay administration's opposition and rescheduled the event at the smaller Madison Square Garden on Oct. 24.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The Democratic National Committee called today for an investigation into distribution of a "counterfeit" press release under its letterhead announcing that Vice President Humphrey and George C. Wallace would "meet on law and order."

Two publishing subsidiaries of the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles have leased three full floors in the new office building being erected at 110 East 59th Street, in a leasing transaction involving aggregate rent of $6-million.
Sixty-one youths, including nine Negroes, two American Indians and one Puerto Rican, were selected yesterday to receive training as apprentices in Locals 40 and 361 of the Iron Workers Union.

PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Shooting a five-over-par 80, Mrs. Philip J. Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S. C., took the first-round lead today in the United States Golf Association's senior women's amateur championship.
New York's giant banks began reporting on their operating results for the third quarter yesterday and once again profits rose sharply.

WASHINGTON Oct. 2 (AP) -- A leader of antiwar demonstrations during the Democratic National Convention challenged members of the House Committee on Un-American Activities today to a television debate.
The New York Public Development Corporation has elected James D. Landauer president and a director.

Some of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's supporters in the state have begun to line up behind Vice President Humphrey, without much enthusiasm, but somewhat heartened by the Vice President's pledge to stop the bombing of North Vietnam if Hanoi made a conciliatory overture.

CAIRO, Oct. 2 -- An Egyptian Air Force pilot said today that he had flown a reconnaissance aircraft over the Israeli-occupied Sinai Peninsula, had evaded six Israeli Mirage fighter-bombers and had returned safely with hundreds of important photographs of Israeli troop positions.

LONDON, Oct. 2 (UPI) -- The Royal Dorset Yacht Club of Britain may lodge a protest with the New York Yacht Club over arrangements being made for trials to choose the challenger for the 1970 America's Cup for 12-Meter yachts.

Normally, the odds against the birth of sextuplets are estimated at 3,276,800,000 to 1. But, like Mrs. Sheila Ann Thorns, who gave birth to six babies in Birmingham yesterday, more women in recent years have been upsetting the odds against multiple births by using fertility-inducing drugs.

Much has been made in the papers during the last few weeks about how everybody, including our Government, sympathizes with Czechoslovakia because it has been invaded and occupied by its Warsaw Pact allies, among whom Poland prominently figured as a driving force.

THE first regional championships ever staged on Long Island begin this afternoon at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury and continue for four days. This is believed to be the first time that a major tournament has been played at a racetrack, an expedient forced on the organizers by the shortage of substantial hotels in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

The Clevite Corporation, in announcing yesterday details of revised terms for its proposed merger into TRW, Inc., met with another rebuff from the United States Smelting Refining and Mining Company, which as the largest Clevite holder has blocked the merger since it was announced last spring.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The life insurance industry reported today that it spent or committed $700-million of its $1 - billion pledge to provide slum rehabilitation loans.
Frederick Maurice Mizrahi lost two-thirds of his $100,000 lottery prize money yesterday without a whimper after an eight-month-long legal fight.

WILKES College's football team, which is largely home-grown, played well again last Saturday while rooting hard for Grambling to beat Morgan State. But Wilkes's play was better than it's ability to root home another winner as the Colonels beat Vermont, 31-15, while Grambling lost to Morgan State, 9-7.
BONN, Oct. 2 -- The National Democratic party canceled all scheduled public meetings today after its first rally in Bonn last night broke up in pandemonium.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Two new national parks and a system of scenic rivers and trails were added to the nation's outdoor public preserve today.
LISBON, Oct. 2 -- Portugal's new Premier, Dr. Marcelo Caetano, told newspaper editors at a private meeting today that he would not end censorship but that he favored enlightened control of the press.

KOTA KINABALU, Sabah, Oct. 2 -- Prince Abdul Rahman, the Malaysian Prime Minister, canceled a scheduled trip by frigate around the northern coast of Sabah today after a Philippine naval vessel was sighted in Sabah's waters.

The three major television networks are considering appointing a Washington representative to present their joint views to Congress and to the Federal Communications Commission on such matters as CATV and communications satellites.

VIENNA, Oct. 2 -- The newspaper of the governing Austrian People's party said today that the Government was releasing 11,000 conscripts from active army service because the crisis following the occupation of Czechoslovakia had eased.
CHICAGO, Oct. 2 -- The American Bankers Association took the Federal Reserve System to task today for what it said was a "premature" easing in credit policy this summer.

MICHAEL MOTT was stymied. The 27-year-old designer for the Paraphernalia boutique chain had been assigned to do a women's collection based on the movie, "The Charge of the Light Brigade," and the film's female fashions just didn't move him.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Sam Snead, who has won more tournaments than any other player in professional golf, has notified the Professional Golfers Association he will not participate in any tournament that is not sanctioned by the P.G.A.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Pentagon announced tonight that all 16,000 Air National Guardsmen and reservists mobilized after the Pueblo incident would be returned to civilian life by June 30, 1969.
DETROIT, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Little old women went about their shopping as usual this afternoon, with little apparent awareness of Bob Gibson's fastball.

COUNTESS Ebba von Eckermann, one of Sweden's leading fashion names, is in New York with her latest collection of hand-loomed designs. The Countess, who in the past sold her designs through retail stores, has changed her mode of operation to provide an almost custom-made service.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 2 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned Moscow anew today that any military action against West Germany would bring immediate military reaction by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization powers.

The refusal of the finance subcommittee of the House Commerce Committee to take up the bill, already passed by the Senate, to tighten mutual fund regulations represents yet another instance of the domination of Congress by lobbies.

GOOD television often turns up at unexpected hours; it did from 9 to 10 A. M. yesterday on WNBC-TV (Channel 4). The first half was a major breakthrough in the educational use of the home screen -- a totally frank and completely mature discussion of birth control. The second half hour offered Joan Rivers, quite possibly the most intuitively funny woman alive.
DENVER, Oct. 2 -- Confident they can preserve America's international vanity, United States Olympic athletes will leave tomorrow for Mexico City and the 1968 Olympic Games.

GREEN VILLAGE, N. J., Oct. 2 -- More than half of New Jersey's Great Swamp, a wilderness of marsh, woodland and meandering streams only 30 miles west of Times Square, this week became a Federally protected "wilderness" that insures it against violation by the hands and machines of man.

YONKERS, Oct. 2 -- Nine colts, led by the 8-5 favored Billy Haughton entry of Rum Customer and Bye and Large, will meet Saturday night at Yonkers Raceway in the $25,000 Westchester Pace. The mile test will act as a tune-up for next week's triple-crown event, the $150,000 Cane Futurity.

Michigan State will meet St. John's University in the opening game of the Holiday Basketball Festival in Madison Square Garden and Rhode Island will face South Carolina in the first game of the Quaker City tournament in Philadelphia, the Eastern College Athletic Conference announced yesterday.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- Ambassador at Large W. Averell Harriman denied today that Vice President Humphrey's proposal for ending the bombing of North Vietnam might have adverse effects on the talks here, as Richard M. Nixon has suggested.

TWIGGY, the matchstick British model who at 17 looked like the boy next door, is blossoming. For a girl whose measurements are 31-23-32, she looked positively voluptuous at a news conference held yesterday at the St. Regis Hotel.

The Roman Catholic Church in the United States plans an expanded effort to raise funds for foreign missions this year, the national director of the church's central agency for missions said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Associate Justice Abe Fortas withdrew today as President Johnson's nominee for the office of Chief Justice, clearing the way for the President to submit a possible second nomination to the Senate.

PARIS, Oct. 2 -- France declared today that the Soviet Union had unleashed a violent campaign against West Germany as a diversionary maneuver to obscure the consequences of Soviet military intervention in Czechoslovakia.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 2 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, the former Air Force Chief of Staff, flew here today amid growing indications that he would become George C. Wallace's Vice-Presidential running mate.

WASHINGTON, Oct, 2 -- Senate-House conferees agreed today on compromise language that would apparently permit the United States to continue to participate in the new international anti-dumping code negotiated last year.

John J. Burns predicts that McCarthy people, weighing Wallace, Nixon and Agnew against Humphrey, "will come around in the end." I doubt it -- and I am working to strengthen my doubt. Many McCarthy people "came around" in 1964, won over by consider-the-alternative arguments.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- Negotiators for 80,000 coal miners were reported today to have reached a tentative agreement on a wage increase of more than $1 a day and to be discussing fringe benefits of a proposed new contract.

Columbia University officials who have been keeping count of the extraordinary expenses the university has sustained since the student unrest erupted last spring, gave estimates yesterday that totaled $300,000, and said the final figure undoubtedly would be mugh higher.

Francesco Cilea's "Adriana Lecouvreur" may indeed be, as one member of last night's Metropolitan Opera audience suggested, "an Italian zarzuela." Taken on those terms, as a comic opera, it does have its charm, as well as its longueurs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- A Government panel was told today that political assassinations have been increasing globally and apparently there is a relationship between aggressivenes on the one hand, and rapid socio-economic development and unsatisfied wants on the other.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- "The United Nations is an important organization and the United States will use it whenever it can," a high Administration official said recently in private. "But it must be reformed -- it has to be saved from itself.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- South Vietnam's Ambassador, Bui Diem, turned over two bags of IR-8 "miracle rice" harvested in his country to the United States today as a symbolic thank-you gift for the new breed of rice, which in the last year has shown promise of revolutionizing Vietnamese agriculture.

Richard M. Nixon's policy statement on regulation of the securities industry was interpreted by Wall Street yesterday as a message to the business community at large -- tantamount to a promise that a Nixon Administration would involve the Federal Government less in its affairs.
CASUALLY, but typically, Robert Gibson existed quite normally the night before he struck out 17 batters to set a World Series record.

The United States Senate would not have refused even to consider President Johnson's nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States had it not been for the Republicans' desire to have the appointment for themselves, and for the charges against Fortas of personal indiscretion and unwise political links to the President.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- The Senate, after an unusual secret session, overwhelmingly rejected today what was probably the final effort to delay deployment of a multibillion-dollar missile defense system.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 2 -- A three-judge Federal court ruled in St. Paul today that the Communist party must be listed on the Minnesota Presidential election ballot this year and cannot be banned on the basis of the Communist Control Act of 1954.

The House of Representatives is scheduled to vote today on the latest Southern effort to take away the Federal Government's power to withhold financial aid from segregated schools. The issue arises because of three amendments to the appropriations bill for the Department of Health, Education and Welfare -- all offered by Representative Whitten, Democrat of Mississippi, and approved by the House last June.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 2 (AP) -- Wally Jones hit on six straight shots in the fourth quarter tonight to lead the Philadelphia 76ers to a 129-114 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association exhibition game.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 2 -- J. B. Stoner, known as an organizer of the National States Rights party and the Ku Klux Klan and as an apostle of anti-Negro violence, visited James Earl Ray in his Memphis jail cell last Saturday.
HOUSTON, Oct. 2 -- A Federal District judge sentenced four persons to prison today for their part in the 1966 collapse of the Westec Corporation.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the formation of the five-man Environmental Control Board and the appointment of "two very distinguished scientists" to serve on it.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 2 -- Bob Gibson outpitched Denny McLain, overpowered the rest of the Detroit Tigers and struck out 17 batters today as the St. Louis Cardinals won the opening game of the World Series, 4-0.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 2 -- The sign outside the plush hotel bar on Paseo de la Reforma said "2 Trasmision Serie Mundial Beisbol," meaning that Channel 2 would be televising the World Series today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 -- Manufacturers inventories recorded by far their largest rise this year -- a total of $1-billion, after seasonal adjustment, in August. New orders were almost unchanged.

Columbia University agreed yesterday to hold a union election to determine representation of its clerical employes after about 20 workers staged an all-night sit-in at the office of the university's controller.

MONTCLAIR, N. J., Oct. 2 -- The Montclair Board of Education said today that it was "deeply concerned" about recent incidents at the high school that "appear to be racially motivated." It said it would act to end such incidents.

ALBANY, Oct. 2 (AP) -- A State Supreme Court justice ruled today that Herman B. Ferguson, who has been convicted of conspiring to murder moderate civil rights leaders, was entitled to a place on the ballot as a candidate for United States Senator.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 2 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a compromise $3.1-billion vocational education bill.
A champagne supper party at the-Waldorf-Astoria will follow Cancer Care's film party 'on Oct., i2 of "Finian's Rainbow" at the Penthouse Theater.

Interest rates continued to move up slightly here and there in the credit markets yesterday, but the increases took place in trading activity made light by the Wednesday closing of the New York Stock Exchange, Yom Kippur and the World Series.

THE first thing to be said about Theater 1969's experiment with repertory at the Billy Rose Theater -- Edward Albee's "The Death of Bessie Smith" and "The American Dream" joined the bill yesterday -- is that it deserves the support of everybody who has ever rapped the Broadway theatre for its high prices and stupid plays.

The Bank of America, New York, international subsidiary of the nation's largest bank, announced yesterday that for the first time it had expanded its board to include members from outside the bank.
Prices did little more than hold their own in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Alan Rudkin, the British and Empire bantamweight champion, bounced back tonight and stopped Rudy Corona, a Mexican now living in New York, in the seventh round.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- Argentina has granted President Belaude political asylum, a Foreign Ministry spokesman said tonight.

Relations between the races may be reaching an important turning point in this country. After more than a decade of exciting progress and rapid change, Americans have to decide whether to continue moving toward fulfillment of the promise of equality or lapse into passivity and stasis.

WHITE PLAINS. Oct. 3-Radcliffe-in-Westchester will raise funds for scholarships Oct. 17 by presenting a seminar on "Influences on Politics'' from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. at the Ethical Society Building here.
GENEVA, Oct. 3 -- Negotiators from the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade recessed talks today without resolving the question of subsidies on poultry exports.
AMERICA IS IN DANGER. By Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, with Maj. Gen. Dale O. Smith. 346 pages. Funk Wagnalis. $5.95.

PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The Paris police took about 400 persons into custody tonight for identity checks after several demonstrations and a brief clash with youths proclaiming their solidarity with students in Mexico City.
Henry E. Bowes announced yesterday his resignation as president of the McCall Corporation, a year to the day after assuming the position.
The Federal Home Loan Banks, which provide reserve credit to the savings and loan industry, are reducing their lending rates to 5 3/4 per cent from 6 per cent under pressure from Washington.
BENNINGTON, Vt., Oct. 3 -- Bennington College will go "fully coeducational" in the fall of 1969, the college announced today.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Shapely Louise won the Penny Maid 1 1/4 mile trot today at Freehold Raceway. The winner returned $27.80, $8.80, and $3.40 for $2 across the board.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators were reported today to be considering an offer made by the Cleveland Indians to trade five Indians for Frank Howard, who hit 44 homers this season.
Armand Grover Erpf, the 70year-old investment banker, confirmed yesterday that he and Susan Stuart Mortimer, a New York artist, were married three and a half years ago in Rome.
George C. Wallace has picked a running mate who stands in the military field for the kind of overkill that is embodied -- but never openly stated -- in the Wallace concept of "law and order."
BECAUSE the Green Bay Packers have lost two games in a row there has been talk about how much the team misses Vince Lombardi, with the inference that his successor, Phil Bengtson, is a poor coach.

SAO PAULO, Brazil (AP) -One student was reported killed, dozens were injured and about 40 were arrested in the second straight day of disorders in Sao Paulo. Students of two institutions battled each other and the police with rocks and clubs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Lindsay administration came out today against the Federal Aviation Administration's proposed rules for dealing with air traffic congestion by limiting flights at airports in New York and other large cities.
The New York Telephone Company again will furnish scores of all World Series games. The number is 637-1212, the company's time bureau.
The new management team of Schenley Industries, Inc., officially took over the reins of the big liquor company yesterday and immediately began a study of corporate operations.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- Lou Brock's right shoulder hurts him so badly that he doesn't even give his characteristic smile when he talks about it. He was even drinking a cup of beer after today's game -- spiking it with water -- and muttering, "I've only had three beers in my life, but I figured I'd try it."
UMUAHIA, Biafra (Nigeria), Oct. 3 (AP) -- Biafra has asked the United Nations and member governments to act under the United Nations Charter to stop what it says is genocide in Biafra.

ATLANTA, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Eldridge McMillan, chief of education activities in the Southern regional Office of Civil Rights, resigned today effective Oct. 18. He said he would join the Southern Education Foundation in Atlanta, a century-old private foundation that works for the advancement of Negro education.
Lancastrian will keep on running as "long as we can keep him together," were the words of Sid Watters Jr., who trains the 6-year-old gelding for Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ten House Democrats who backed Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota for their party's Presidential nomination threw their support to Vice President Humphrey today.

VIENNA, Oct. 3 -- The Austrian Communist party declared today that Western Communist parties would probably hold a conference to discuss their disagreements with Moscow over the invasion of Czechoslovakia.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- The virtuoso performance of Bob Gibson in yesterday's World Series opener was magnified to even more grandiose proportions today. MEXICO CITY, Oct. 3 -- Sadly but proudly, riot-plagued Mexico plunged ahead today with preparations for the Olympic Games.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Jack Marin said today he was playing out his option this season with the Baltimore Bullets. This would leave him free to sign either with another National Basketball Association member or with a club in the rival American League.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 3 -- When it's Kentucky Futurity time in this picturesque rolling Blue Grass country, where the horse reigns supreme, nothing else seems to matter to the folks around the area. The World Series? To hear the locals, the Cardinals and the Tigers, as well as Bob Gibson and Denny McLain, might be the title of a television program and its co-stars.

ATHENS -- The present Greek Government is the least appetizing, from an American viewpoint, of any that has ruled Athens since World War II, but this cannot obscure the fact that Greece is strategically more important to the United States today than has ever before been the case.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended Sept. 28 totaled an estimated 15.2 billion ton-miles, an increase of 3.1 per cent over the comparable week of 1967. Carloadings in the same week totaled 593,378, an increase of 7,705 cars or 1.3 per cent above the same period last year.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said yesterday that it would include "only about $100,000" of an $8,797,847 tax refund in reporting its 1968 earnings.

American Standard, Inc., yesterday announced three new executive vice presidents: J. L. Briggs, in charge of plumbing and heating operations; W. A. Marquard Jr., security systems and technical product operations, and L. E. Walkley, industrial product operations. These are new operating groups. A fourth new group, which includes home building, is headed by Paul M. Augenstein, an executive vice president.

All day, Steve Costas, owner of the Headquarters Tavern opposite Police Headquarters in downtown Manhattan, had been serving beer and sandwiches to policemen, who account for more than 60 per cent of his brisk weekday business.

"Ballad for a Firing Squad," a new version of "Mata Hari," the musical that lost at least $500,000 before David Merrick closed it last December during a pre-Broadway tour, will open the week of Nov. 24 at the Theater de Lys.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 3 -- Two Israeli soldiers died today from wounds suffered earlier in border clashes.
The Port of New York, idle for two days in a contract deadlock in the stevedoring industry, started to stir back to action yesterday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 3 (AP) -- France swept into the lead today in the second round of the women's world amateur team golf championship despite a dramatic collapse by the French star, Catherine Lacoste.

CHICAGO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Dr. Christian N. Barnard, the South African surgeon who pioneered heart transplantation, said today that he would eventually have to give Dr. Philip Blaiberg, the world's longest surviving transplant patient, another heart.
PARIS, Oct. 3 -- The French Senate elected a conservative anti-Gaullist early today to preside over what is expected to be its last session under its present form.

The appointment of Robert L. Tinker as general manager of the Empire State Building has been announced by Helmsley - Spear, Inc., the building's renting and managing agents. Mr. Tinker is vice president of Helmsley-Spear, and had been the Empire State's rental manager.

Helynn R. Lewis walked out of her apartment house at 444 Central Park West shortly after noon last Saturday and stood by a stack of a dozen suitcases as her doorman hailed a taxi on West 104th Street. The doorman loaded the luggage into the cab as she slid into the back seat.

SOMETHING nice happened to the musicians of the New York Philharmonic last night. They got speeched at, and that does not often happen. Amyas Ames, president of the Philharmonic, took the microphone after intermission to tell the audience about the recently-concluded Philharmonic tour.
ALBANY, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- State Tax Commissioner Joseph Murphy reported today that the 18-day fall meeting at Aqueduct race track produced $6,280,220 in pari-mutuel revenue.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- A truck careened off an embankment into a river near the town of Pracmuap Khiri Khan, 180 miles south of Bangkok, killing 11 persons, injuring 7 and leaving 32 others missing, it was reported today.

WHITE PLAINS, Oct. 3 -- Two conservation groups and three three Ossining Negroes asked the State Supreme Court today the proposed construction of the Hudson River Expressway along the eastern bank of the river north of the Tappan Zee Bridge.
Top notch opera conductors are relatively rare. It takes a special kind of talent to keep the total sweep of an opera intact and still allow the singers room to flourish.

ONE of the most interesting experiments in New York these days -- and one earnestly hopes it will succeed -- is the continental, high-style breakfast menu recently introduced at The Ground Floor Restaurant, 51 West 52d Street.
MARLENE DIETRICH returned to Broadway last night, and while the legend on the marquee of the Mark Hellinger Theater did seem a little much -- "The Queen of the world" -- it was on the right track.

LIMA, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- A communique issued here tonight by the revolutionary junta appointed an all-military Cabinet in which the three members of the ruling junta hold the army, air force and navy portfolios.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 3 -- George Buck of the Longshore Club of Westport, Conn., took a one-stroke lead today in the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association seniors championship with a 37, 34 -- 71 over the 6,072-yard par-35, 35-70 Innis Arden Golf Club course.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Some key Administration officials believe that the Soviet Union is actively reappraising its defenses in central Europe. Moscow is said to be contemplating cutting its occupation force in Czechoslovakia by more than half in the next seven weeks and increasing forward deployments of Soviet forces elsewhere in Warsaw Pact territory.

The Senate Foreign Relations Committee added an unfortunate qualification to its endorsement of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty when it suggested that the President should delay formal ratification until a majority of the potential nuclear weapons states indicate they intend to accept the treaty.

PRAGUE -- Despite growing Soviet pressures, Czechoslovak publishing houses are pressing ahead with plans to issue almost all the titles that had been scheduled before the invasion of the Warsaw Pact troops on Aug. 21.

The Diamond International Corporation, a diversified paper producer, had a net income of $8,213,000, or 80 cents a share, in the 12 weeks ended Sept. 8 against $8,138,000, or 77 cents a share, in the preceding year's period. Net sales reached a record of $316,779,000, compared with $304,840,000.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Bowie, Pimlico and Laurel race tracks all asked today that they be granted some dates in January.
The election of Yves H. Robert, 41 years old, as president and chief executive officer of the Howmet Corporation, metals maker, was announced yesterday.
CANTON, Ohio, Oct. 2 -- Once again, an organized band of hecklers tried to outshout George C. Wallace and failed.

A United Hospital Fund member voluntary hospital recently invited its neighbors to an open-house "happening." Here they participated in lively discussion groups on such subjects as welfare, open housing, school desegregation, violence and human power that were led by members of the staff of the hospital's community mental health center.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- A fire bomb was thrown in historic Westminster Abbey today and a 23-year-old theology student was charged with arson.

TOKYO, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Takao Sakurai, fifth-ranked world bantamweight contender, scored a unanimous decision over Romy Guelas, the Philippines' No. 3 bantamweight, in a scheduled 10-rounder today. Each weighed 120 pounds.
LONDON, Oct. 3 -- The Labor party conference in Blackpool overrode Government opposition today to pass a resolution opposing further negotiations with the white rebel regime in Rhodesia.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- The House voted today to drop anti-integration provisions that it had written into a major appropriations bill just a few months ago.

ATLANTA, Oct. 3 -- Richard M. Nixon accused George C. Wallace and Mr. Wallace's running mate, Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, of irresponsible and excessively hawkish attitudes on foreign and domestic matters tonight.

The title role of Puccini's "Turandot" is one of the most cruel in the soprano repertory. At the Metropolitan Opera it has been sung mostly by Birgit Nilsson, who has made it one of her great roles. All the alternates have been at best adequate.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- A dispute among Democrats as to whether they dared to work for their national Presidential ticket broke into the open in Missouri a few days ago.
BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 3 -Senator Edmund S. Muskie called today for a lottery draft.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 3 (AP) -- Cleaver delivered a speech to a crowd of 5,000 on the University of California campus today.

Buffalo, Oct. 3 -- Harry D. Holt of Stockton, Calif., was elected president today of the 11-million member American Automobile Association at the final session here of the 66th annual meeting of the organization. Mr. Holt had been appointed to the presidency last April to fill the vacancy created by the death of George M. Frauenheim of Buffalo. William B. Bachman, Jr. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. was elected senior vice president.

The National Catholic Office for Motion Pictures has given condemned ratings to four new films, Paramount's "Barbarella," Regional Film Distributors's "Birds in Peru," Cinerama's "If He Hollers, Let Him Go" and Grove Press's "Weekend."

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- The Swedish Red Cross said today that it had learned it was a drunken Nigerian soldier who killed two British missionaries, a Swedish Red Cross worker, and a Yugoslav doctor in Okigwe yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- A fire, apparently started by a Molotov cocktail, was set off today in the basement of the national headquarters of the Selective Service system, the Fire Department reported. A spokesman said the blaze had caused no injuries and did not damage draft records.

SAVANNAH, Ga., Oct. 3 -- Legislation now pending before Congress and designed to facilitate the movement of freight in international commerce came under sharp attack here today by the nation's largest freight forwarding company.

BIRMINGHAM, England, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- The five surviving Thorns sextuplets were "throwing their arms and legs about quite a lot" at a maternity hospital here today. A spokesman said "every hour increases their chances slightly."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, told the Senate today that General LeMay made Vice President Humphrey and Mr. Nixon look like doves on the Vietnam issue.
QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- At least seven women were killed and three injured when an adobe hut laundry in which they were washing clothes collapsed during torrential rains last night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Defense Department ordered the drafting of 17,500 men today for the Army and Marine Corps in December.

BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- Oscar (Ringo) Bonavena signed today for a 15-round title bout against Joe Frazier, holder of the New York State version of the world heavyweight title, in New York in December.
LONDON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- Gold prices seesawed in world bullion markets today as anxious dealers awaited the outcome of a meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- Consumer installment credit increased by $853-million in August, the largest rise in a single month in the 27 years that the Federal Reserve Board has kept records on consumer credit.
MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Ingo Buding of West Germany will oppose Premjit Lall of India in the opening match tomorrow of the Davis Cup interzone tennis semi-final.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- President Johnson continued to consider in silence today whether to nominate another person for Chief Justice of the United States, but constitutional lawyers on Capitol Hill have already "eliminated" 27 Senators from consideration.
BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 3 -- Members of the faculty at the University fo California, Berkeley, charged the Board of Regents tonight with violating their academic freedom and autonomy.
A 22-year-old man identified by four women as having raped them in the Morningside Heights area was captured yesterday after a woman he allegedly tried to attack managed to escape from him.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- Mickey Lolich tied the World Series with flair today by pitching and batting the Detroit Tigers to an 8-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

STRATFORD, Conn., Oct. 3 -The Fairfield Villages Wellesley Club will open a twoday Bazaar de Noel Oct. 18 with a cocktail party for patrons. The party will be in the Guild Hall of the Stratford Motor Inn's Mermaid Tavern, where Chrismas boutique items will be on sale to the public later that evening and all the next day, Oct. 19.

WOLF PEN, W. Va., Oct. 3 -- Eight years ago, Hubert H. Humphrey stood in a hotel room in Charleston to renounce, for the moment, his hopes for the Presidency. Today he returned to West Virginia, a candidate for the White House once more.
A legislative committee that will decide whether to recommend restoration of the death penalty heard sharply conflicting opinions yesterday.

First reports on September business of the country's large chain-store organizations indicate a continuation of strong volume, and even a few more records. While the figures are incomplete, and in some cases subject to revision, there is enough information to show the trend, pointing to steadily rising dollar volume, with unit volume not gaining quite so much.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- Students leaders who led forces for Robert F. Kennedy, Eugent J. McCarthy and Nelson A. Rockefeller announced plans today to mobilize student support for Vice President Humphrey.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Indiana Pacers withstood a 52-point output by Rick Barry in his first American Basketball Association game and beat the Oakland Oaks, 141-131, in an exhibition before 7,889 persons tonight.
BRUSSELS, Oct. 3 -- Belgium has prepared proposals for revitalizing the virtually dormant Western European Union, which is composed of Britain and the six members of the European Common Market.

West Germany, its prosperity again in high gear, is using an increasing part of its capital resources to help other nations beset by monetary problems, the country's Minister of Economics stressed here yesterday.

PRAGUE, Oct. 3 -- The Czechoslovak television network predicted tonight that there would be hard negotiations with the Soviet Union over proposals taken to Moscow by Alexander Dubcek and his associates.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A United States Army helicopter collided today with a twin-engine cargo plane that had just taken off from the Camp Evans airstrip and all 24 Americans aboard both craft were killed, the United States Command reported.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Baltimore Bullets announced today that Bob Quick, their second-round college draft choice, had been rejected by the Army and has rejoined the National Basketball Association club.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 3 (AP) -- A melee apparently set off by a number of racially tinged incidents broke out today in the cafeteria of Oliver High School just before the noon meal. It was quelled in about an hour by the police, who moved swiftly into the area.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3 -- More important than the external fact that Detroit's 8-1 victory today restored the World Series to even terms was the internal fact that it restored the Tigers' confidence.
A total of $444,200 was realized yesterday in sales of jewelry from the estate of Mrs. Carl J. Schmidlapp of New York and other owners at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Senate sent to the White House tonight a bill abolishing the United States commissioner system and replacing it with a system of salaried Federal magistrates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today it detonated underground a low-yield nuclear device at its Nevada test site. The test, involving the equivalent of less than 20,000 tons of TNT, was the 22d announced this year.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The Senate voted today to give the Pentagon $71.9-billion to run the Vietnam war and provide for the nation's defense over the next year. All efforts to cut the figure were beaten down decisively.

A workman fell to his death yesterday from the ninth floor of a building under construction in the Co-Op City housing project at 2800 Baychester Avenue, in the Northeast Bronx, the police reported. He was Walter Hofving, 25 years old, of 60 Thayer Street.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- Reaction to George C. Wallace's selection of General Curtis E. LeMay as his running mate ranged today from praise by Wallace supporters to expressions of shock by Republicans and Democrats.
Ted Bates Co., one of the big ones, has restructured its creative department and adopted the group system that is now coming into vogue in advertising agencies.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 -- At the suggestion of Richard M. Nixon, Senate Republicans opened a concerted attack today on Vice President Humphrey's Vietnam position.

DETROIT, Mich., Oct. 3 -- After running lap speeds in excess of 182 miles an hour at Michigan International Raceway during tire tests yesterday, STP turbocar No. 20 crashed in the first turn of the new track at Irish Hills and was demolished.

LISBON, Oct. 3 (Reuters) -- Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, the 79-year-old former Premier of Portugal, showed a slight improvement today following a blood transfusion last night, hospital sources said. He has been in a coma since Sept. 16 after a stroke.

One of the few stakes to elude Max Hirsch, the 88-year-old dean of major trainers in the realm of the thoroughbred, will be his objective at Gelmont Park today.
