HOUSTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Paul Gipson sprinted 91 yards with the opening kickoff to a touchdown and added another on a 41-yard run to lead 12th-ranked Houston to a 71-33 rout of Cincinnati tonight in the Astrodome.
CAMDEN, N. J., Oct. 4 -Republicans describe New Jersey's reshaped First Congressional District as a Democratic gerrymander that backfired.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 4 -- The Arkansas River, largely useless for many years, flowed into the 20th century today.
Prices turned slightly downward in active trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- United States officials today privately deplored the military take-over in Peru. They indicated that the Administration would restrict its actions for the time being to consultations with its hemisphere allies.

Prospective investors in fixed-income securities continued to sit on the sidelines yesterday, and Wall Street professionals did what comes naturally in such circumstances -- they marked prices down, raising yields.
Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., announced yesterday the election of three vice presidents: Gerard E. Heffernan, 30 years old; Gerald F. LaKarnafeaux, 32., Donald C. Richards, 35.
An argument over the repair of an automobile transmission led yesterday to the death of one man and the wounding of another on a street in East Elmhurst, Queens.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The Senate leadership has all but abandoned hope of winning Senate approval of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty in this session of Congress. The treaty, once described by President Johnson as the "most important" arms control agreement of the nuclear age, appears to be the victim of two complementary political pressures.

Albert Shanker, president of the teachers' union, rejected a new peace plan yesterday and warned that a strike would be called next week if the Board of Education did not enforce compliance with the agreement that ended the union's recent three-week walkout.

Three Columbia University students yesterday lost their court battle to disqualify Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan from prosecuting them for criminal trespass because he is a trustee of the university.

The election of John C. West as a director of the American Bank Note Company was announced yesterday. Mr. West, a partner of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., succeeds E. R. Harriman, another Brown Brothers partner who has resigned as a board member after serving in that post at American Bank Note since 1937.

ROCHESTER, Oct. 4 Paul H. O'Dwyer, who often remarks that he has "inherited" the leadership of the antiwar forces from Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, told student audiences today to have faith in the Democratic party and fight for change within the political process.

Gov. George Romney described George C. Wallace, the third party Presidential candidate, yesterday as a "frustrated segregationist" and his running mate, Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, former Air Force Chief of Staff, as a "frustrated big bomb general."

TEL AVIV, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- The Jerusalem Post said today that the fate of Czechoslovakia and Biafra strengthened Israel's resolve to have a nuclear deterrent of her own rather than rely on outside help.
HARTFORD, Oct. 4 -- After denouncing George C. Wallace in Atlanta last night as "unfit to be President," Richard M. Nixon reverted to silence today on the third-party threat.

Steve Harris, a junior quarterback, threw four touchdown passes yesterday, three to Charles Liebling, the split end, as Trinity School defeated McBurney School, 33-7, at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

TOKYO, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Hiroshi Kobayashi of Japan, the world junior lightweight champion, ruled a slight favorite today to defeat Jaime Valladares of Ecuador in their scheduled 15-round title bout tomorrow.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Smiling broadly at relatives a few yards away, Sirhan B. Sirhan, who is accused of assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy, made his sixth court appearance today, for a brief five minutes.
A natural substance under intensive study as a potential antiviral agent may also be able to protect against a host of other disease-causing organisms, among them the microbe that causes malaria.

FREMONT, Ohio, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, helped dedicate a library to President Rutherford B. Hayes today and said law and order was an issue when Hayes was in the White House.
PRAGUE, Oct. 4 -- With the flag of the rising sun waving over many sections of Prague, Japan has begun a major drive to sell more industrial products in Czechoslovakia.
SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Scoring the "phony peace talks" in Paris, James L. Buckley called on the United States today to return to a full offensive in North Vietnam.
Denver Oldham is a skilled and sensitive pianist who seems to have a penchant for playing in New York halls that are too big for both his playing style and his public.
DETROIT, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The nation's auto makers, pushing their car production above the 200,000 mark for the first time in the 1969 model run, scheduled an output of 209,457 this week.

CHICAGO, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Internal Inspections Division of the Chicago Police Department recommended today the suspension of two sargeants and eight patrolmen in connection with a disturbance in Lincoln Park on Aug. 25 involving Yippies, hippies and antiwar protesters.

SAIGON, Saturday, Oct. 5 (AP) -- Vietcong rockets struck the vital Benluc bridge 16 miles southwest of Saigon early today. They knocked out an 80-foot center span over the Oriental River, a Government spokesman said.

THE Metropolitan Opera needed a new "Tosca," and last night it unveiled one, its first new production of the season. Traditionalists must have been pleased. It was a good, old-fashioned production, with solid and realistic sets, a general air of gloominess, handsomely costumed.

GROTON, Mass., Oct. 4 -- A 12-yard pass from Alex Richardson to Rico Nappa in the final three minutes of play today enabled Boston English High to outscore Groton, 26-20. It was the season opener for Boston English and Groton's first loss in two games.

THE crowd at the St. Louis airport was typical. There were twice as many girls as boys. Nobody was more than 20 years old. And when their idols arrived, an ebullient blond teen-ager bolted forward, clutched at a brown tweed sleeve and squealed delightedly.

MUNICH, Germany, Oct. 4 (AP) -- India and West Germany divided the opening singles of their three-of-five interzone Davis Cup semi-finals today, with Wilhelm Bungert of Germany and Premjit Lall the victors.
The New York City Central Trades and Labor Council announced its endorsement of Senator Jacob K. Javits, the Republican-Liberal candidate, for reelection yesterday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 -- United States pilots flew 143 missions against enemy targets above the demilitarized zone yesterday in what appeared to be an intensification of the air war in the north.
YOU would have thought they were giving away free samples, there was so much traffic through the ultramodern Italian lighting exhibition at Abraham Straus Thursday night.
The 125th Street Medical-Dental Building, a privately financed office center for physicians and dentists in Harlem, was officially opened yesterday

Victor Solomon, the chairman of the Harlem Congress of Racial Equality, announced yesterday the formation of the Harlem Board of Education Organizing Committee to formulate a plan for a separate school system for Harlem.
BUFFALO, Oct. 4 -- George C. Wallace came to his new running mate's defense on the nuclear weapons issue today and declared there was no difference in their positions.
A Negro psychologist from the Watts section of Los Angeles yesterday called the militancy in many Negro communities "the freshest and most vital model for social change."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- President Johnson formally notified the Senate today of his withdrawal of the nomination of Abe Fortas to be Chief Justice of the United States. He also withdrew his nomination of Judge Homer Thornberry to be an associate justice.

Sydney A. Luria, a senior member of the law concern of Carb, Luria, Glassner, Cook and Kufeld, has been elected a director of Peck Peck, a Fifth Avenue chain of women's stores. He is the first non-family member of the board of Peck Peck, according to A. Wells Peck, chairman.

Shareholders of James Talcott, Inc., approved yesterday a plan to establish the Talcott National Corporation as a parent company to hold James Talcott, Inc., and other subsidiaries to be acquired in the future.
A CRUISING GUIDE TO THE CHESAPEAKE. (Including the Passages from Long Island Sound.) By Fessenden S. Blanchard and William T. Stone. With charts and illustrations. Dodd, Mead. 246 pages. $7.50.

Just because Ted Hendricks is 6 feet 7 inches tall and slim -- at 222 pounds -- and tosses aside the opposition with just a touch of meanness, his adoring fans at the University of Miami have nicknamed him The Mad Stork.

MERIDIAN, Miss., Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Meridian Star, noting that its "heart" was with George C. Wallace, said today it was supporting Richard M. Nixon for President because if the former Alabama Governor was elected he would have difficulty getting support in Congress.

The Students for a Democratic Society chapter at Columbia University has adopted a new organizational structure in an attempt to revitalize the campus movement that it concedes has been lagging this fall.
PEBBLE BEACH, Calif., Oct. 4 (UPI) -- Mrs. Philip Cudone of Myrtle Beach, S.C., won the United States Golf Association's senior women's amateur championship today with a 54-hole total of 236.
The wealthy widow of a skin specialist argued -- and lost -- her case in Civil Court yesterday in a dispute over a $196.13 bill from Saks Fifth Avenue.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 -- The leaders of Czechoslovakia acceded tonight to Soviet demands that they dismantle the remaining results of their liberal policies and agreed to the indefinite stationing of foreign troops in their country.

The office of the superintendant of School District 6 in Upper Manhattan was occupied for more than two hours yesterday by a group of angry residents who "dismissed" the district school board as unresponsive and made plans to elect a new board.

The American Film Institute will provide a $50,000 grant to establish a national organization to facilitate, encourage and coordinate moviemaking by young independent film workers in poor areas. The announcement was made yesterday by George Stevens Jr., director of the institute, and Sidney Poitier, vice chairman of the board of trustees, at the institute's headquarters, 26 West 56th Street.
DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- Frank Crosetti, 37 years a New York Yankee, turned in a handwritten, six-page letter of nostalgia announcing his resignation today, his 58th birthday.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- The Roman Catholic bishops of France appear to be moving toward the granting of a way out to believers who feel they cannot obey the papal ban on the birth-control pill.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 4 -- Julian Beck and his wife, Judith Malina, were cleared today of indecent exposure charges that grew out of a performance last Thursday by their controversial Living Theater Company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- President Johnson visited a "smiling and talking" Dwight D. Eisenhower at Walter Reed Army Medical Center today and said the former President "looks just as good as I ever saw him."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- A cooking utensil invented by a psychiatrist and his twin brother, a lawyer, enables a blind person to find out whether the food is about to burn. By running his fingers down the handle, the cook can judge the temperature inside the pot.
The Peoples Gas Company. Chicago, reported yesterday a decline in net income for 12 months ended Aug. 31 to $48-million, or $3.06 a share, from $50,105,000, or $3.16 a share, a year earlier.
PRAGUE, Saturday, Oct. 5 -- Premier Oldrich Cernik announced early today that a treaty with the Soviet Union for the gradual withdrawal of the occupation troops would be signed within a few days.

WOONSOCKET, R. I., Oct. 4 (UPI) -- Two reporters for The Providence Journal Bulletin were convicted today in district court on charges of obstructing policemen in the performance of their duties. They were fined $100 each.

Robert Bialkin, 33 years old, of 15 Charles Street, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to five years in prison on his plea of guilty to transporting and selling stolen securities. Bialkin admitted that he had transported stolen stock and conspired in selling part of $500,000 worth of securities reportedly stolen from a Los Angeles brokerage concern last November.

The Living Theater will be discussed at Monday's noon meeting of the Drama Desk, a group of reporters and editors, at Sardi's West. The guests of honor will include Julian Beck and Judith Malina, founders of the Living Theater, and two of its players, Jenny Hecht and Rufus Collins.
THE Long Island Regional Championships continue today at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury, L. I., under the auspices of the Nassau-Suffolk Bridge Association.

The appointment of Kirby Peake as general chairman of the 75th anniversary fund-raising campaign of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York was announced yesterday. Mr. Peake is president of Carter-Wallace, Inc., whose products include proprietary drugs and pharmaceuticals.

Pete Myers, a popular disk jockey who for years conducted an afternoon show of recorded music and light commentary on radio station WNEW, died yesterday morning in his East Side apartment of a gunshot wound. He was 40 years old.

The disclosure of systematic fraud in the Neighborhood Youth Corps provides fresh evidence that programs hastily created to relieve social distress provide tempting targets for freebooters. The cruelest aspect of the reported embezzlement is that the perpetrators obviously capitalized on the desire of antipoverty administrators to build up a sense of dignity among ghetto youth by shunning a spy squad to police work sites.
America's Roman Catholic bishops announced plans yesterday to revive the ancient order of permanent deacons for use in this country and to permit married men to enter the diaconate.

SPOKANE, Wash., Oct. 4 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland told an enthusiastic Republican rally here today that Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, retired, picked yesterday as the running mate of George C. Wallace, the third-party candidate, had "made us all very worried" by saying that nuclear bombs were just like any other weapon.

YONKERS, Oct. 4 -- What Joe O'Brien, one of harness racing's outstanding driver-trainers, calls his "bad luck at Yonkers" struck again tonight against Sunnie Tar, his brilliant 3-year-old filly, and turned the favorite into an also-ran in the $35,000 Bronx Filly Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 4 -- New York University's George Wisniewski placed first with a record-breaking time of 25 minutes, 4 seconds in a triangular cross-country meet today, but was unable to prevent Princeton from defeating N. Y. U., 20-35.
Prices on the London stock market closed with a predominance of gains yesterday.
PARIS, Oct. 4 -- Jewish aid sources here asserted today that the Egyptian Government had forbidden Jews to leave the country.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- South Africa declined to accept today a proposal on future gold sales made by a group of 10 leading financial nations, but the rejection was not final.

MITCHELL, Ind. -- If the parade hadn't started an hour late and if that freight train hadn't come along just in time to catch half the marchers on one side of the tracks and half on the other, one might say that there had not been a single hitch in the week-long 22d Annual Persimmon Festival.

GENEVA, Oct. 4 -- The International Committee of the Red Cross announced tonight that the two representatives of the committee and the two British missionaries who were killed in Biafra last Monday had been shot to death by a Nigerian soldier.

HONG KONG, Oct. 4 -- Minor scuffles between the police and Communist demonstrators celebrating China's National Day have put a new strain upon the truce existing between local Communists and the Hong Kong Government since last year's rioting and terrorism.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 4 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie confirmed today that he had urged President Johnson last January to halt unconditionally the bombing of North Vietnam.

IT IS curious how some dance works take a while to settle down to their time and their experience. Anna Sokolow's "Opus '65" has been, as the title suggests, in the repertory of the City Center Joffrey Ballet for some three years.
MELBOURNE, Oct. 4 (AP) -The United States and Australia held a one-stroke lead over France heading into tomorrow's final round of the Women's world amateur team golf championship.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Herve Filion drove Miraculous to victory in the $3,500 1 1/4-mile Realtors Pace at Freehold Raceway today. The winner paid $6, $3.60 and $2.80 for $2 across the board.
Sales of Savings Bonds dropped during September, the Treasury Department announced.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Oct. 4 -- This country's national debt topped the equivalent of $1-billion in July for the first in West Bend, Wis., approved time, it was disclosed today. Foreign debt exceeded $166-million of the total, including loans from the World Bank, the United States, Soviet Union, Canada, China, Britain, West Germany, Yugoslavia, France, Poland and East Germany.

The election of Alan N. Weeden as chairman of the New York Group of the Investment Bankers Association of America was announced yesterday following the 48th annual meeting of the group. Mr. Weeden, president of Weeden Co.,

With only several hundred standing-room tickets remaining, the New York Jets may perform before a record American Football League crowd tonight in their Shea Stadium opener against the San Diego Chargers. The Jets are 6-point favorites.

Two Peruvians who landed at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, allegedly carrying $4-million worth of cocaine, were arrested with four other suspects in an automobile chase that ended in gunfire.
A street sign thrown by vandals across the Long Island Rail Road tracks between Wantagh and Bellmore delayed both eastbound and westbound trains up to 90 minutes last night.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A White House spokesman reacted with remarks about poison pens today to what a newsman called reports that President Johnson is "trying to sit on the Vice President and thwart his efforts to get to the White House."
Another president has resigned from the Chock Full o'Nuts Company, the fourth in seven years.
BUTLER, Pa., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Craig G. Saul, 57 years old, father of Bill Saul, Pittsburgh Steelers' linebacker, was killed today when his automobile struck a tree.
DENVER, Oct. 4 -- A conventioneer from the Society of Exploration Geophysics spotted Jim Ryun standing outside a hotel coffee shop today.

A parent group that has staged a sit-in at Intermediate School 148 in the Bronx since Thursday in an effort to force the appointment of a new principal ended the demonstration yesterday when their candidate declined the job.

VIENNA, Oct. 4 -- In a few weeks it will be 50 years since the end of the imperial court of the Habsburgs in Vienna, but Austria still has hundreds of court counselors and is getting new ones almost daily.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday as the market settled down somewhat in the wake of Thursday's tumultuous session.
OTTAWA, Oct. 4 -- Angry Ontario farmers drove their tractors on Parliament Hill today to protest heavy imports of low-priced corn from the United States.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The problem of dealing with those unable to help themselves is deeply imbedded in the daily welfare operation of this city and reaches out to touch, in one way or another, the lives of everyone here.

Chief Justice Earl Warren said here last night that all local, state and national governmental agencies "must employ their total resources in seeking solutions to the problems of racial hatred and unrest."

My last responsibility, on behalf of our Government before leaving my post as United States representative to the United Nations, was to shepherd the treaty on the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons through the General Assembly.
TRENTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -Phil Jackson scored 32 points to lead the New York Knickerbockers to a 119-106 National Basketball Association exhibition victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it would impose initial 100 per cent margin requirements on 17 issues of 14 companies, effective Monday.
Three major lumber associations reported a decrease of 8.9 per cent in the production for the week ended Sept. 28, compared with the level in the corresponding 1967 week.

ONEONTA, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, professor of psychology at City College of the City University of New York, will receive an honorary doctor of letters degree from Hartwick College Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- United States officials say that Cambodia has conceded indirectly what American military commanders have been saying for years: that North Vietnam and the Vietcong have been using Cambodian territory for attacks against South Vietnam.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 4 -- The Hun School ran its three-season unbeaten streak to 11 games (2 ties) today by defeating Princeton Day School, 27-0.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- An improperly inserted gyroscope in the launching vehicle caused the failure of the Nimbus-B satellite mission last May 18 ,the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- The United States has informed its Allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that it will soon send an Air Force tactical reconnaissance squadron to holster NATO defenses in West Germany.
LIMA, Peru, Oct. 4 -- Peru's new military Government indicated tonight that it might nationalize some American property in this country.
"Candide," whose score is by Leonard Bernstein, will be given a benefit performance Nov. 10 at Philharmonic Hall in honor of its composer.

DETROIT, Oct. 4 -- Some things are working out fine for Orlando Cepeda, like Art Blakey playing in town tonight and Cannonball Adderly playing a concert tomorrow. Other things are not working out so well for the Cardinal slugger -- particularly that wind cutting in from the outfield.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A large Soviet destroyer equipped with missile launchers passed through the Bosporus from the Black Sea to the Mediterranean today. It was the second heavy destroyer to join the Soviet fleet in the Mediterranean.

The American Ballet Theater Company, under the direction of Lucia Chase and Oliver Smith, will fly on Monday to Madrid, for the filming of its new full-length production of "Giselle" by Beta Films, one of Germany's largest film companies.
The Oct. 28 week at the Metropolitan Opera, for which tickets go on sale at the box office tomorrow, will bring the season's first performance of "Die Walkure." Operas and casts for the week follow:
HILLSIDE, N. J., Oct. 4 -- Pingry School defeated Newark Academy, 12-0, today for its second straight victory. The rivalry between the schools started in 1880.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay's name will not be on the ballot as a Vice-Presidential candidate in most states.

THE HAGUE, Oct. 4 -- Twenty members of Socialist student organizations, eighteen boys and two girls, entered the Mexican Consulate in Amsterdam today and occupied it for thirty minutes. They handed out a manifesto that stated their action was a form of protest against the suppression of Mexican students and workers.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- House Republicans today gleefully published excerpts from a Democratic ccampaign kit that they said was a catalogue of the "Nation's ills."

The city Personnel Department established that Mrs. Helynn R. Lewis had no police record before she was hired as a $12,500-a-year administrative consultant in the Head Start program in December, 1966, but it appeared yesterday that no other substantive check was made into her background.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Vietnam:
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 4 (AP) -- United States Lines, Inc., reported today that $380,000 in silver bullion was missing from a shipment to Tilbury, England.
MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the communique on the Soviet-Czechoslovak negotiations as distributed by Tass, the Soviet press agency.

The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced yesterday the appointment of Charles A. Bernard as a vice president. Mr. Bernard, who joined the bank in 1927, is an office head in the metropolitan division.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Oct. 4 (AP) -- A surging mob of 2,000 students hurled stones and broke windows at the United States Consulate today before police stopped the demonstration with tear gas and night-sticks.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 4 -- An Army captain peered out the window of a small plane on a recent trip over enemy infiltration routes between Saigon and Cambodia and said, again and again, "I can't believe it -- I just can't believe it."
New disorders broke out in the city's troubled school system yesterday as students, parents and community organizations continued the decentralization controversy.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Oct. 4 -- The Houston Mavericks, sparked by Willie Somerset and Don Carlos, crushed the New York Nets, 121-104, in their initial American Basketball Association exhibition game tonight.
CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., Oct. 4 (AP) -- Good King collared the pace-setting Roy West at the head of the stretch and continued on to gain a three-length victory at Finger Lakes Race Track today.

A Brooklyn couple whose child was born with physical and mental handicaps after a hospital refused to perform an abortion was awarded $110,000 in damages yesterday by an allmale jury in Kings County Supreme Court.

Hubert H. Humphrey 3d came to New York City yesterday to begin a three-day stumping tour of the city and Rockland County for his father. Mr. Humphrey, 26 years old, is scheduled today to open the Vice President's campaign headquarters in upper Manhattan and the lower Bronx and speak in Rockland County.

WATKINS GLEN, N. Y. Oct. 4 (UPI) -- Bobby Unser, winner of this year's Indianapolis "500," escaped injury today when his British-built BRM car smashed into a dirt bank just beyond the finish line while practicing for Sunday's 248-mile Grand Prix of the United States.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy will begin campaigning for Democratic candidates next Tuesday with a fund-raising dinner in New York for Paul O'Dwyer, who is seeking the Senate seat held by Jacob K. Javits.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -- Vice President Humphrey proposed today that the Federal Government turn back some of its tax revenues to states and cities -- with no strings attached.
The Bermec Corporation, formerly the Berman Leasing Company, reached an agreement in principle yesterday to acquire the Rath Packing Company for stock valued in excess of $15-million.

To repeat is to inure. When President de Gaulle first vetoed the United Kingdom's application for Common Market membership in 1963, a shock reverberated round the world. The slamming of the door surprised a public which had come to believe that the negotiations were going well, and with the shock came the recognition that the Kennedy Administration's "grand design" for a united Europe had been dealt a crushing blow.

TOKYO, Oct. 4 -- Japan's faction-torn Socialist party succeeded today in naming a new chairman after a 20-day impasse. He is Tomomi Narita, aged 55, a former secretary general of the party and a member of its left wing. The party also picked Saburo Eda as secretary general, the second highest post, after a bitterly contested vote.

TRENTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Two girls were suspended at Trenton High School today after admitting that they had cut themselves with broken glass and had then accused unidentified Negro students of attacking them.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- While the majority of speakers at a symposium on business and the arts agreed today that nonprofit foundations and corporations would have to give greater assistance to the arts in the future, others said the need was now and the job might be too big for private enterprise.
Winn-Dixie Stores, Inc., reported yesterday increased sales and earnings for the 12 weeks ended Sept. 21.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- Vaclav Pleskot, the Acting Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, today pledged his country's cooperation with the Communist states that have invaded and occupied her.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Oct. 4 (AP) -- President Rene Barrientos Ortuno swore in a new largely civilian Cabinet today, replacing a military Cabinet formed in July to deal with what was called a Communist -led subversive threat.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- President Johnson accepted today the resignation of Eugene C. Patterson as vice chairman of the Commission on Civil Rights. A member of the commission since October, 1964, Mr. Patterson told the President his new duties as managing editor of The Washington Post precluded further service on the panel.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (Reuters) -- General LeMay was offered a White House briefing on foreign policy today. The White House declined comment on the general's Vietnam statement but said that, like other Presidential candidates, "he will be briefed as he desires."

The introduction of new plans -- imaginative though necessarily still vague -- into the Ocean Hill-Brownsville dispute has substantially increased the options for a satisfactory settlement. The challenge to all the parties now is to demonstrate that they have the flexibility and the sense of civic responsibility to avail themselves of these options in good faith.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- An organizer of the antiwar protests at the Democratic Convention testified today that he met with Vietcong agents two months before the Chicago disorders.
Gilles Villemure, a goalie, was assigned to the Buffalo Bisons of the American Hockey League yesterday by the New York Rangers, the parent club in the National League.

MOSCOW, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union's newest airliner, a three-jet plane resembling the Boeing 727, "behaved beautifully'' during its third test flight, the newspaper Komsomolskaya Pravda reported today. The plane, designated the TU-154, can carry up to 200 passengers.
The battle for control of the First National Bank of Denver, the largest bank in Colorado, was settled yesterday with a compromise.

The Chicago North Western Railway announced yesterday the election of Larry S. Provo as chief executive officer. Mr. Provo, 41, is president of the carrier, which is controlled by Northwestern Industries, Inc., a holding company.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- A preliminary outline for a second United Nations Development Decade was presented today by Philippe de Seynes, Under Secretary General for Economic and Social Affairs.

PARIS, Oct. 4 -- President de Gaulle made it clear today that he was taking a hand in the proposed deal linking Citroen and Fiat. In a cryptic, punning remark, he seemed to imply that he would amend or even veto the deal.

ATLANTA, Oct. 4 -- For the opening of the new Atlanta Memorial Arts Center, the High Museum of Art has secured a remarkable survey of four centuries of French painting. Entitled "The Taste of Paris," the exhibition consists of 49 paintings and 10 drawings, all of which are on loan from museums in the French capital.

Department store business in New York City, reflecting a general letdown in other metropolitan areas of the country, slipped last month and merchants admitted that they could only partly blame it on some warm, unseasonal weather.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- Otto F. Otepka, demoted from his job as State Department security evaluator for allegedly giving unauthorized information to a Senate investigator, said today he had lost his last appeal within the Government for reinstatement.

Remembering those recent days when Richie Havens was laboring valiantly in the coffee-shops of Greenwich Village, as he and many of his fans do, made his appearance at Philharmonic Hall last night a special triumph.

ALSDORF, West Germany, Oct. 4 (Reuters -- The trial of seven men concerned with manufacture and distribution of thalidomide was adjourned today until Oct. 14, when the defense will begin presentation of expert witnesses.
BENTWOOD chairs are getting more careful scrutiny these days as more is learned about them.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 4 -- The long and occasionally violent student protest here appeared today to be smashed as a mass movement following the gun battle in which at least 29 persons lost their lives Wednesday night.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday proclaimed next Friday Pulaski Day in observance of the 189th anniversary of the death of Gen. Casimir Pulaski, the Polish patriot who fought in the American Revolutionary War. A parade will be held on Fifth Avenue beginning at 1 P.M.
ATLANTA, Oct. 4 -- One of the first of the crosscountry wave of cultural centers to house all of a city's arts under one roof will open tomorrow.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The first five miles of Frankfurt's new $225-million subway was opened today, making this metropolis the world's 35th city with an underground railroad. When completed in 1982, the "U-Bahn" will cover 37.5 miles and contain 14 stops.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 5 (UPI) -- Gen. Duong Van Minh, former South Vietnamese Chief of State, returned to Saigon today from three years in exile.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Albert B. Brooke Jr. as a member of the Federal Power Commission. He replaces Charles R. Ross for a term expiring June 22, 1969.

LONDON, Oct. 4 (Reuter) -- The average rate of discount at today's tender of British Treasury 91-day bills fell to 6.539 per cent from 6.595 per cent last week. This week's 150-million offer of 91-day bills met applications of 264,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Senate sent to President Johnson today a bill designed to protect mail patrons from promoters who send them false and misleading advertisements. Sponsors said there had been many instances of such practices, particularly in the fields of real estate and medical science.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 -J.R. Wiggins had planned to retire as editor and executive vice president of The Washington Post next Dec. 4, his 65th birthday. But a phone call from President Johnson changed that plan.

A spot check of the city's Neighborhood Youth Corps records indicated that one of five corps paychecks was embezzled during part of the summer of 1967, according to reports prepared by Federal and city investigators.
Atlantic Container Line, Ltd., has announced the promotion of its general manager for North America, Otto I. M. Porton, to the post of president of Atlantic Container Line, U.S.A.

Cone Mills, Inc., announced yesterday an increase in price on all cotton outing flannel for the 1969 season. Increases range from .01 1/2 cents per yard to 2 1/4 cents per yard. The company said the increases reflect higher costs of raw materials, wages and dyestuffs.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 4 -- Vice President Humphrey was endorsed for President today by Robert McLean, editor in chief of The Santa Barbara News Press, in a signed front-page editorial.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- Two hundred Nicaraguan university students stoned the Mexican Embassy in downtown Managua today and broke several windows. They wrested the Mexican Government seal from the office and ran away with it.

NEWARK, Oct. 4 -- LeRoi Jones, the militant Negro poet-playwright, was arrested in a bank here this afternoon on charges of using loud and offensive language and resisting arrest, as well as on unrelated offenses.

ANYONE fortunate enough to have a ticket for each game can see the Jets and Giants this weekend. The Jets oppose the San Diego Chargers tonight in their Shea Stadium opener. The Giants go against the New Orleans Saints tomorrow at Yankee Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Senate voted today to appropriate $1.93-billion for foreign aid this year, the lowest amount since the program began 22 years ago, and $1-billion below President Johnson's request.

The United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to reduce the one-year bribery sentence of a millionaire certified public accountant who said the sentencing judge had promised him probation if he donated money to charity.
UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 4 -- Alberto Ulloa, head of the Peruvian delegation to the General Assembly, has resigned in protest against the military coup in Lima.
WEST NYACK, N. Y., Oct. 4 -- David Albright, 10-year-old son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Albright of 2 Hemlock Road, was killed by a car tonight as he ran into the road to retrieve a football.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (AP) -- The Senate approved unanimously today a treaty updating a 1951 international agreement that set standards for the protection and rights of refugees.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 4 (UPI) -- The Senate today approved United States participation in an international agreement providing for the enforcement of arbitration awards made in disputes between United States businessmen and their foreign trading partners.
Major airlines serving New York will meet Thursday to decide where they think a new jetport for the region should be built, airline sources said yesterday.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 4 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he would consider an offer of a Cabinet post in a Nixon Administration.
CONCORD, N. H., Oct. 4 -- The politics of "the impossible dream" is being tested in the sprawling Second District of New Hampshire.
SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 5 (AP) -- South Korean Army troops shot and killed a North Korean infiltrator today south of the demilitarized zone, the counter-espionage command reported.

James Earl Jones awoke yesterday, just before noon, to find that he was a Broadway star, something he had in writing not only from critics who saw him open the night before in "The Great White Hope" but also from Herman Levin, the producer, who put it in his contract.

SPARTANBURG, S. C., Oct. 4 -- Richard M. Nixon and Hubert H. Humphrey came into the South this week. Mr. Nixon's journey was undertaken with expectant hope; the Vice President's was an act of desperation.

Prices fell in comparatively slow trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday. Volume was down to 6,344,005 shares, from 7,338,370 on Friday, and the exchange's index was off 5 cents for the day.

BOSTON, Oct. 7 (UPI) -- The Boston Celtics acquired a center, Enoch (Bud) Olsen, on waivers front the Milwaukee Bucks as an understudy for their player-coach, Bill Russell Olsen, a 6-foot-3-inch, 230-pounder, went to Milwaukee from the Seattle Supersonics in the expansion draft.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- The Supreme Court opened its new term today with rebuffs to the efforts of peace groups to put the names of Eldridge Cleaver, the black power advocate, and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy on the Presidential ballot in California.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy made it clear last night that he was not yet ready to endorse Vice President Humphrey's drive for the Presidency.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 7 -- Inflation is a symptom of what ails America and the individual American, organized labor, business and the Administration should get together to stop it, according to George Champion, chairman of the board of the Chase Manhattan Bank.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 7 (Reuters) -- Rear Adm. David H. Bagley, 47 years old, today took command of all 70 United States cruisers and destroyers in the war in Vietnam. Admiral Bagley is the former captain of the cruiser Oklahoma City.

Like Thoreau, who tilled somewhat different soil, Leopold Stokowski enjoys making previously barren ground say "beans." The election of Glenn W. Johnston as a director of Sterling Drug, Inc., was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 -- Richard M. Nixon hinted today that if the military situation in Vietnam improved and if the South Vietnamese shouldered more of the fighting, a Nixon Administration might be able to agree to peace terms that the Johnson Administration could not accept now.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Oct. 7 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland opened his first campaign trip in the South today with an invitation to "protest" voters supporting George C. Wallace to make their protests count by voting Republican.

SAIGON, Oct. I (AP)---The battleship New Jersey continued farther up the coast of North Vietnam yesterday as it shelled an artillery site and supply point near the Ron River about 50 miles north of the demilitarized zone. DETROIT, Oct. 7 -- Few players in baseball history have performed in the World Series as spectacularly as Lou Brock of the St. Louis Cardinals. If the series had ended today, he would have established a flock of records for a five-game series.

Behind the issues of law and compliance, of strike threat and directives are hidden the more elusive social forces of a city buffeted by pressures for a fundamental regrouping of powers. WASHINGTON, Oct. 7 (AP) -- The Senate passed today a compromise bill to close what United States wool producers called a loophole in the tariff laws.

" THE MEGILLA OF ITZIK MANGER," fresh from Israel, light as a quality matzoh ball and as sparkling as seltzer, was served up last night at the John Golden Theater. It should have many golden nights in the near future.
The flow of funds into the nation's mutual savings banks dropped substantially during September, the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks reported yesterday.

Brown Brothers Harriman Co. is a very old and remarkably dignified private bank, and the party its 21 partners gave last night on Pier 13, East River, was not at all in keeping with its very staid image.

OSLO, Norway, Oct. 9 -- Rene Cassin, an 81-year-old French jurist, whose life has been devoted to the protection of human rights, was named today to receive the Nobel Peace Prize for 1968.

Six members of Long Island University's board of trustees, including the chairman and a former chairman, said yesterday that students, faculty and alumni would be given some voice in the naming of a new chancellor.

PRAGUE, Oct. 9 -- Charles University students held their first formal meeting today since the Soviet-led invasion. It was a restrained session against the background of the occupation.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 9 (AP) -- President Johnson appointed today a seven-member National Water Commission that will spend the next five years on a $5-million study of the nation's water needs and problems.
The two top mediators in the critical police, fire and sanitation disputes began a roundthe-clock effort yesterday to achieve a settlement and avert another sanitation strike next week.

Dr. Louis Breglio, acting Dean of Students at Brooklyn College since February, 1967, has been appointed Dean of Students and Dr. George Donald Wiepert has been named Associate Dean of Students. WILTON, Conn. -- When Glenn McCaskey was in art school in Cleveland, Ohio, about 18 years ago, he decided to take up cooking in earnest. He'd read a recipe that called for green spaghetti and, since he couldn't find any in the local supermarkets, he set about making his own.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 9 -- The seventh and deciding game of a World Series, that ultimate in baseball competition, has arrived again for the fourth time in the last five years and for the 10th time in the last 14 years.

The schooner Mystic Whaler, built in Tarpon Springs, Fla., last year with the lines of a 19th-century whaler, is paying her first visit to the Port of New York. She sailed down the East River yesterday to her berth at East 26th Street from City Island.
An eight-man court-martial in the Third Naval District, Brooklyn, yesterday rejected conscientious objection as a permissible defense for an A.W.O.L. Navy man.

A process server who allegedly practiced "sewer service" -- falsely attesting to the service of summonses -- was indicted yesterday on charges of perjury and violating a section of the 1866 Civil Rights Law that prohibits the deprivation of property without due process.

THE mystery over high-flying Metromedia, the broadcasting company, grows deeper. The company has nouncement following the a news conference today at company headquarters, 277 Park Avenue, for an announcement of "major news significance."

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 9 -At midpoint in the Presidential race, Richard M. Nixon continues to hold a substantial lead over Vice President Humphrey and George C. Wallace, according to the Gallup Poll. WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- A policeman whose fatal shooting of a Negro pedestrian caused brief disturbances in Washington Tuesday night was suspended today under a new policy issued by Mayor Walter Washington. Stressing that the policy did not prejudge Patrolman David A. Roberts's conduct, Mayor Washington announced that all policemen involved in fatal shootings in the future "will be automatically relieved of duty" pending the outcome of a preliminary investigation.

WANTAGH, L. I., Oct. 10 (AP) -- A Long Island Parkway policeman was fatally injured today when his police car plowed into the rear of a slowmoving construction vehicle. The victim, Patrolman Jean Bozier, 31 years old, was responding to a report of an accident on the Wantagh Parkway when the accident occurred.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -Patrick Cardinal O'Boyle formally instructed Roman Catholics of the Washington Archdiocese today to submit "mind and will" to the Church's ban on artificial methods of birth control.
TRIER, West Germany, Oct. 10 (Reuters) -- A former staff officer of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was found shot to death near here on Tuesday, it was disclosed today.
The National Hockey League, now actively engaged in extending its image as well as its schedule, will begin another expanded season with three games tonight.

JOHN UNITAS, long acclaimed as pro football's best quarterback, began to throw again this week following five weeks of inactivity to rest the painful tendonitis in his passing arm. Unitas may play when the Baltimore Colts take on the 49ers in San Francisco on Sunday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 10 -- The Apollo 7 countdown began today and was ticking away without interruption toward a scheduled launching tomorrow morning of the first astronauts to fly the nation's mooncraft.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk denied today reports of a "breakthrough" in the stalemated talks in Panmunjom regarding North Korea's release of the Pueblo crewmen.

MELBOURNE, Oct. 10 (AP) -- Marvin Giles, law student from Lynchburg, Va., shot a five-under-par 68 today at the Royal Melbourne golf course and gave the United States the lead in the Eisenhower Cup competition for the world amateur team championship.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -President Johnson announced today that the "emotionalism, partisanship and prejudice" of the times had persuaded him not to nominate another person now for the office of Chief Justice of the United States.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 10 -- Secretary General Thant led the diplomatic community today in congratulating Rene Cassin, the French jurist, on his winning of the Nobel peace prize for his work in promoting human rights.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 10 -Avery Brundage beat back a challenge by Count Jean Beaumont of France today and won re-election as president of the International Olympic Committee.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -Retail sales apparently held about steady during September at the advanced level they reached in August, the Department of Commerce reported today.

ROME -- The trend toward political reaction everywhere now extending from China and Russia to Europe and America is featured by a hankering for what passes as law and order and the old time religion as traditionally applied in these varying regions.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 10 -Taiwan today was an island of flags, bunting, fireworks, parades, ceremonial mass gatherings and general holiday festivity as this Chinese Nationalist haven celebrated the National Day of the Republic of China.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -Following is the text of an address that President Johnson made tonight over the National Broadcasting Company's radio network supporting Vice President Humphrey's candidacy in the Presidential race.

LOUIS, Oct. 10 -- Records aren't much consolation when players lose a championship, as the St. Louis Cardinals did today, but as the years go on the men involved begin to take immense pride in them. Bob Gibson and Lou Brock came out of this World Series with lines added to the record book and so did Dal Maxvill, who can't wait for someone to come along and take him out of it.

HOUSTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -The president of Houston Endowment, Inc., publisher of The Houston Chronicle, said today reports that the newspaper was for sale were erroneous. "The Houston Chronicle is not for sale now nor will it be at any time in the foreseeable future," J. H. Creekmore said.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that members of the Atlantic Passenger Steamship Conference have formally approved the proposed $60-million Hudson River ship terminal, which will serve all passenger liners.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission accused the National Broadcasting Company today of having misled the public by providing the questions -- and in some cases the answers -- to guest celebrities on two television quiz shows prior to the programs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 -Few American painters in the 20th century have produced a body of work as disarming in its esthetic tranquility as Charles Sheeler (1883-1965). His subjects -whether early American rural architecture, modern skyscrapers in Manhattan or a few anonymous objects arranged as a still life -- suggest an atmosphere of painstaking craftsmanship and unwordly innocence.

SPRINAGAR, Kashmir, Oct. 10 -- Sheik Mohammed Abdullah urged Kashmiris today to "take back the initiative" from India and Pakistan and solve the 21-year-old problem of their divided state for themselves.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 10 (AP) -- The Navy moved today to equip United States ships with a new defensive system to deal with the type of missile that sank an Israeli destroyer last year. MIAMI, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The University of Miami football team knocked Louisiana State out of the unbeaten ranks tonight with a 30-0 victory.

The heads of 25 unions that maintain international offices in New York City, representing more than 500,000 workers, announced yesterday that they would mount a sustained effort between now and Election Day to elect the Humphrey-Muskie ticket.
The Federal mediation effort to bring about a contract settlement in the Atlantic and Gulf Coast longshore industry will be resumed next week, an arbitrator in the dispute said yesterday.

More than 100 rebellious students at New York University occupied two Bronx campus buildings from dawn until noon yesterday to protest the dismissal of John F. Hatchett, who had called Vice President Humphrey, Richard M. Nixon and Albert Shanker "racist bastards."
ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- West Virginia's two third-period touchdowns beat Virginia Military Institute, 14-7, tonight in football.

CAPE KENNEDY, Oct. 11 -- Dark clouds and a soft tropical rain had lent a gray gloom yesterday to the sprawling launching site. But early this morning the Florida sun shone brightly and a brisk wind rustled the scrubby palmetto grass and palm trees that cover the flat peninsula.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A watch invented in Switzerland automatically changes dials every evening to show the hours in luminous figures and reverts to black numerals in the morning.
Several thousand passengers were stalled in Pennsylvania Station yesterday afternoon for almost three hours because of a malfunction on the Portal Bridge spanning the Hackensack River in New Jersey.
The national, sectional and conference standings will crystalize even more today in the public's mind as collegiate football, with baseball out of the way, comes up with a bunch of "big" games.
Vice President Humphrey offered yesterday to buy an hour of television time Sunday evening, Oct. 20, for a debate with his rivals for the Presidency, Richard M. Nixon and George C. Wallace.

Bruce Mailman and Dr. John Sugg have taken over the new Fortune Theater at 62 East Fourth Street and the Astor Place Theater at 434 Lafayette Street. Mr. Mailman said that he and his partner plan to acquire other Off Broadway legitimate theaters.
HOUSTON, Oct. 11 -- R. Walter Cunningham may be the only pilot in the world whose wife has told him from the ground what to do while he was flying a plane.
Jules Feiffer's cartoon antiheroes tend to be shaky masochistic types whose only reply, as The System rolls over them, is a tiny, literate squeak of protest. Mr. Feiffer himself is harder to flatten.
"Wild" was the way a broker described world sugar futures trading yesterday. By recent standards the 4,073 contracts traded made a very busy day. Prices advanced quite sharply.
ARMONK, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Mrs. Donna Floyd Fales of New York and Vicky Rogers of Rye, N. Y., who were seeded first, won the women's Eastern invitation doubles tennis tournament today.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The National Catholic Reporter, a nationally circulated independent weekly, was condemned officially today by the Bishop of the Kansas City-St. Joseph diocese, who threatened some members of the newspaper staff with automatic excommunication.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- A group of small securities dealers asked a Federal court today to block the reduction in sales commissions and ban on commission splitting that the New York Stock Exchange plans to put into effect on Dec. 5.
The Beach Boys, a once-influential group in pop that has fallen on hard days, appeared last night at the Fillmore East.
Six subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., yesterday filed applications with the Federal Power Commission to construct a total of $107.5-million of additional pipeline facilities.
What impresses stock-brokers from England when they visit Wall Street for the first time?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- About 35 persons, who said they were refugees of the Poor People's Campaign, returned today to the site of their camp here to talk about plans for the future.
OCTOBER in Central Park means smog-free air, falling leaves and traffic jams on the bicycle paths and roadways.

A ruling by a Family Court judge declaring a 15-year-old boy a juvenile delinquent on the basis of a story by a 10-year-old boy who said the older youth had assaulted and robbed him was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court.
DETROIT, Oct. 11 (AP) -- United States auto makers set schedules calling for the production of 213,415 cars this week, nearly an 8.5 per cent increase over last week, it was reported here today.

WASHINGTON -- When Irvin Williams goes home at night he likes to weed his vegetable garden and think about the flowers he'll grow in the spring and the 150 quarts of applesauce, 200 quarts of tomatoes and 200 quarts of beans his wife Dorothy will put up, mostly for themselves and their five children.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Oct. 12 (AP) -- In a battle that swept through rice paddies and thick hedgerows, United States troops tried to trap 300 enemy soldiers on the northwest invasion corridor to Saigon yesterday, but most of them escaped.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Countries that are owed money by the United Nations for services rendered in peace-keeping operations in the Congo and in the Middle East have been quietly advised that there is practically no possibility they will ever be paid.
Harvard's freshmen football team opened its 1968 season with a 34-6 victory over Columbia yesterday afternoon at Baker Field.

HOF, West Germany, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- A former sergeant in the SS (Nazi elite guard) was charged today with the murder of 217 women prisoners during a forced march from Helmbrechts in Bavaria to Prachatice in Czechoslovakia near the end of World War II.

CAIRO, Oct. 11 -- Highly placed sources sympathetic to the Nasser Government said today that Israel had privately softened her position concerning a Middle East settlement beyond the concessions hinted in the peace plan she made public this week.
Yesterday was one of those days on Wall Street when brokers, traders and almost everyone else in the area would have been happy to see a sweater girl back again.

BONN, Oct. 11 -- Britain was selected today to play a leading role in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's nuclear defense planning for the Continent, a development the British consider a step into Europe that outflanks President de Gaulle's veto of their entry into the Common Market.

PRAGUE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A passenger plane of the Czechoslovak airline C.S.A. crashed shortly after take-off from Prague Airport today, killing eight of the 37 persons aboard. The survivors were hospitalized.
GIBRALTAR, Oct. 11 -- Britain's negotiators were in a mood of discouragement, even gloom, tonight over prospects in the talks with leaders of Rhodesia.

Julian Bream's Carnegie Hall recital was a sellout last season, but this year the English lute and guitar virtuoso decided to give two Town Hall concerts instead. Since his instruments fare better in more intimate surroundings, the move was wholly appropriate, and the only puzzle was why a less-than-capacity audience turned out for the first program.

Those who study health services in the New York Metropolitan area know how complex the urban - suburban problems are. In some areas there is duplication of specific skills and facilities, in others, no such services are available.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 11 -- Robert Hoyt, editor of The National Catholic Reporter, said a complete text of Bishop Helmsing's statement would appear in Monday's issue of the paper.

The question has been raised: Is Russell Wiggins the man for the job? He has been named our Ambassador to the United Nations. The Times, when it learned of the appointment, jumped on Wiggins with both feet.

YONKERS, Oct. 11 -- Three of the nine colts listed to go post-ward in tomorrow night's $150,000 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway will be from Billy Haughton's barn. If the entry of Rum Customer, Bye And Large and Tropic Song finishes 1, 2, 3, the Haughton stable, the perennial first or second highest money-winning outfit in harness racing, will collect a total of $130,500 in purse money.

MOSCOW, Oct. 11 -- Three dissidents, including Pavel M. Litvinov and Larisa Bogoraz-Daniel, were sentenced today to exile in a remote area of the Soviet Union for having staged a demonstration in Red Square against the invasion of Czechoslovakia.
LISBON, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- The condition of former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, in a coma since suffering a brain hemorrhage Sept. 16, continues to improve, a medical bulletin said today.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Jeff Spranger of the Narragansett Bay, R. I., fleet, won the national championship of the Herreshoff-S Class by 8 1/2 points today on Long Island Sound off Larchmont Yacht Club.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Snow Speed and Eric B. both finished ahead of Nevele Pride tonight in the $24,731 Hickory Smoke Trot at Liberty Bell Park.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 11 (AP) -- A man suspected of being a North Korean agent was shot and killed by crewmen of a patrol boat of the United States Second Infantry Division yesterday as he tried to swim across the Imgin River into South Korea on the western front, a United States military spokesman said today.

IN the history of modern art in Germany, the names of Ernst Barlach (1870-1938) and Kathe Kollwitz (1862-1945) do not figure among the great innovators. Barlach, it is true, was an expressionist of a sort, but the expressionist element in both his sculpture and his graphic art was of a deeply conservative cast.
Concert attendance is thought by some in the business to be falling off, but the Master Virtuosi of New York would have to testify otherwise.
Rowe Price New Horizons Fund, Inc., said yesterday it is resuming the sale of its shares, but that purchases are limited to stockholders of record on Oct. 10.
KOTA KINABALU, Sabah -- Until last December, this handsome capital on the western coast of the Malaysian state of Sabah was known by the simpler but decidedly more British name of Jesselton.

"Canterbury Tales," voted by the London drama critics as the best new British musical of last season, will arrive Feb. 3 at the Eugene O'Neill Theater. Music was composed by Richard Hill and John Hawkins. The book is the work of Nevill Coghill, who also wrote the lyrics and Martin Starkie, who will be the director.

THE situation being what it is, nothing is possible but to summarize it in a check list, and nothing could be a greater pleasure. Surely there has never been another time when New York has offered quite such an accumulation of fine exhibitions at one time.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., Oct. 11 -- The Arts Council of Fairfield University has arranged a dinner dance for Nov. 2 in the Campus Center Oak Room here. Mrs. John Davis Lodge is general chairman of the event. Mrs. Wilson Harrell is vice chairman.

A high-speed railroad link between midtown Manhattan and Kennedy International Airport is important for the economy of the city and the entire metropolitan area. Congestion on the highways leading to the airport is monumental even today and rapidly growing worse. Kennedy Airport served twenty million passengers last year; with the advent of jumbo jets this figure is expected to double by 1975.

Two suspected prowlers plunged from a fifth-floor window at 916 Tiffany Street, in the Bronx shortly before 1 P.M. yesterday when a television antenna they had been using to lower themselves from the roof snapped.

Marine Midland Banks, Inc., the statewide bank holding company based in Buffalo, reported yesterday that net operating earnings in the third quarter, after preferred dividend charges, rose to $9.30-million, or 81 cents a share, from $8.29-million, or 73 cents, in the corresponding 1967 period.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Defense Department today identified the following serviceman as having been killed in Vietnam:

President Johnson led from strength when he appealed to the nation to elect Vice President Humphrey and Senator Muskie to carry on the progressive domestic programs of his and preceding Democratic administrations.
Alberto Luzarraga, a vice resident of the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been appointed its zone executive of the Mexico and Central America zone, Latin America area.
QANTARA, Israeli - Occupied United Arab Republic, Oct. 9 -- Israel has dug in at the Suez Canal.

TOKYO, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- Japanese and Peking traders have reinstated sterling as an official currency for dealings between Japan and Communist China. The International Trade Promotion Association of Japan said today a verbal agreement had been reached between its representative in Peking and the Chinese authorities.

THE Giants and the Jets are favored to continue atop their divisions tomorrow. The Giants will play in Atlanta, while the Jets oppose the Denver Broncos at Shea Stadium, with a 1:30 P.M. kickoff, half an hour earlier than last year.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 11 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club's 13th annual Stratford Shoal overnight race, traditionally the last distance event of the Long Island Sound season, began in dismal weather at dusk tonight off Flat Neck Point.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 11 -- A major revision in the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's relationship with private enterprise has apparently paid off with the successful launching of Apollo 7 this morning.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The Syracuse Post-Standard today endorsed Richard M. Nixon, the Republican nominee for President.
PARIS, Oct. 11 -- The French Government's veto of a Citroen-Fiat merger aroused considerable criticism but a great deal more confusion here today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Coal contract talks dragged on today, with little prospect of an agreement that would end a strike by some 80,000 miners before next Tuesday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Oct. 11 -- The Philippines proposed today that a conference be arranged between President Ferdinand E. Marcos and the Malaysian Prime Minister, Prince Abdul Rahman, to discuss the territorial dispute over Sabah.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 11 -- Three American astronauts rocketed into orbit today for the first manned test flight of the Apollo spacecraft, which may some day fly men to the moon.

Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday he feared Congress might attempt to "wipe out" the Neighborhood Youth Corps program because of "sensationalized" charges of fraud in the city's program.

TOWSON, Md., Oct. 11 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew spent as much time answering a small, but spirited, group of hecklers as he did sounding a victory battle cry for about 3,000 enthusiastic supporters during a "homecoming" rally here tonight.
Increased labor and other costs caused net profits of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation to decline in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday.

VIRGINIA WATER, England, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Bob Charles, a left-hander from New Zealand, and 24-year-old Tony Jacklin of England supplied the surprises today at the fifth annual world match play championship.

At 8:30 at night, Tuesdays through Sundays, Max Gordon's Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, is being liberated by a radical task force of four young performers (three men and a girl) and two Columbia professors, armed with a sense of steely outrage sheathed in middle-class guilt.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- The Mount Vernon Board of Education today sought a reversal of a state-ordered school integration plan.
ROME, Oct. 11 -- A Dutch bishop said today he had won reversal of a decision excluding him from the Vatican Commission on the Liturgy.

WITH $140 in the bank and a current budget of $12,500, the Bloomingdale Family Program, an indoor play group for about 100 pre-school children on the Upper West Side, is facing yet another year of scrambling for money.

Dame Judith Anderson will return to the screen after a seven-year absence to co-star with Richard Harris in "A Man Called Horse." The Cinema Center Films Production, a drama of the Sioux Indian Wars, will go before the cameras later this month in Mexico.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- In spare moments during the next several days the three Apollo astronauts may help to settle one of the great debated issues of earth science -- the theory of continental drift.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Oct. 11 -- A journal of poetry featuring unpublished works of Ezra Pound and William Carlos Williams will be issued next month by a group at the State University Center here.

Bill Bergesh, general manager of the New York Generals, announced yesterday that players from the Generals and Inter, the two pro soccer teams of New York, would meet the Israeli team Oct. 27 at Randalls Island.

ALBANY, Oct. 11 (AP) -- New York State's highest court upheld yesterday the constitutionality of the state's so-called "full crew" law prescribing the minimum size of railroad train crews operating in the state.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- A new Supreme Court dispute arose in the Senate today when the Republican Leader, Everett McKinley Dirksen, and the Democratic Leader, Mike Mansfield, put different interpretations on Chief Justice Earl Warren's request for retirement.

The president of the teachers' union called yesterday for a new citywide strike on Monday after the Superintendent of Schools ordered the reopening of Junior High School 271 in Ocean Hill-Brownsville and reinstated seven of the district's principals.

Tickets will go on sale at noon tomorrow for the eighth week of the Metropolitan Opera's season. The week will include the return of "Il Barbiere di Siviglia," Nov. 7, after an absence of three seasons.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Gary Beban, a Heisman Trophy winner, was shunted to the sidelines by the Washington Redskins today for another month. The National Football League team chose to keep Beban, the all-American from University of California, Los Angeles, on the injured list because of a muscle pull suffered before the season began.
If the entire flight of Apollo 7 goes as well as the initial hours yesterday, it is possible that the next shot will carry three astronauts around the moon.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 11 -- Emilio Arenales, President of the 23d General Assembly, is suffering from severe headaches and will have to cut down on his official and social engagements, a United Nations spokesman said today.
Prices advanced but volume eased considerably on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
The annual parade honoring Christopher Columbus will move up on Fifth Avenue today from 44th to 86th Streets starting at noon.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The United States, leading by two strokes after 36 holes, faltered in the third round today as Britain surged into a seven-stroke lead in the world team amateur golf championship for the Eisenhower Cup.

The common stocks of the Ingersoll - Rand Company and the Torrington Company showed little reaction yesterday to the news on Thursday that Ingersoll had agreed in principle to acquire Torrington through an exchange of stock valued at more than $200-million.
HOUSTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- The Apollo 7 spacecraft lifted as gently from the launching pad today as an automobile pulling away from a stop sign.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- A $10-million master plan aimed at attacking the auto safety problem was sent to Congress today by the Department of Transportation. The proposal was supported by Transportation Secretary Alan S. Boyd, who said the lack of adequate Government research facilities was in a large part to blame for the "painfully slow progress in virtually all of the many aspects of the highway safety field."
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has named Lieut. Gen. Leighton I. Davis, Air Force, retired, executive secretary of its corporate safety board.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Under Secretary of the Treasury Joseph W. Barr said today that the heavy inflow of capital that contributed favorably to the United States' balance-of-payments picture in the second quarter is continuing.

Mediators in the police, fire and sanitation contract disputes were aiming yesterday at an over-all settlement this weekend despite continuing threats of a strike by the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association.

The 100-member Rumanian Folk Ballet arrived at Kennedy International Airport yesterday. The company, booked by Sol Hurok, the impresario, for a tour of North and South America, is scheduled to start a one-week engagement at the Felt Forum of Madison Square Garden on Tuesday.
HOUSTON, Oct. 11 -- The astronaut in the middle couch of the Apollo 7 capsule has a personality that fits in somewhere between those of his two fellow crewmen.

Controller Mario A. Procaccino said yesterday that he was investigating a half-dozen confidential memorandums directing antipoverty agencies, in effect, to support the city's school decentralization plan.

George W. Ball, former United States representative to the United Nations, predicted yesterday that there could be a "major breakthrough for substantive negotiations" on Vietnam early in a Humphrey Administration.
The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday it had strengthened its criteria for the delisting of preferred stocks.

NEWARK, Oct. 11 -- Rutgers University dedicated its new concrete-and-glass campus on six former slum blocks in downtown Newark this afternoon to the accompaniment of protests and picketing by student and Puerto Rican groups.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 11 (AP) -- Capt. Walter M. Schirra Jr. lost a $5 bet because the Apollo 7 spaceship blasted off five months later than he once thought it would.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- Plagued by House absenteeism and faced with a boycott by Democratic liberals angered over the scuttling of a television debate bill, Congress abandoned plans to adjourn tonight.
The wholesale commodity price index remained unchanged at 94.5 on Thursday from Wednesday.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Sonny Randle, the San Francisco 49ers' 32-year-old split end, was cut from the team today along with Charlie Johnson, a defensive tackle.

UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 11 -- Secretary General Thant today sent congratulations to the Republic of Equatorial Guinea, which will become independent of Spain tomorrow. Under Secretary General Issoufou S. Djermakoye will represent Mr. Thant at ceremonies in Santa Isabel, the capital.
KIEL, West Germany, Oct. 11 -- Europe's first nuclear-powered freighter, West Germany's Otto Hahn, made her maiden voyage today. It was a smooth six-hour voyage on the Baltic.

MANILA, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- A heavily overloaded ferryboat that sank yesterday in shark-infested waters off Mindanao island carried most of its 300 to 500 passengers to their deaths, authorities said tonight.

PARIS, Oct. 11 -- Two representatives of the National Liberation Front, the political arm of the Vietcong, arrived here today to set up an information bureau. This, for the first time, all four principals in the Vietnam war are represented in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- The State Department said today that the expropriation of American oil property in Peru should have no effect on its consultations with other countries on whether to recognize Peru's military regime, which seized power Oct. 3.

GARDEN CITY, L.I. Oct. 11 -- Nine hundred Episcopalians throughout the Diocese of Long Island, which includes Brooklyn, Queens, Nassau and Suffolk, are expected to attend the Centennial Inaugural Ball of the Long Island Diocese on Wednesday, at the Garden City Hotel.

One rarely attends a concert of recently composed works expecting a consecutive string of masterpieces. The program sponsored by New Music Associates at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, however, hit a surprisingly consistent level of high quality.

An alluring mixture of champagne and money will be served at Belmont Park today. The Champagne Stakes for 2-year-olds will have its 9th running and with seven listed to start the one-mile test will have a gross value of $173,450, a sum that makes the race the richest on the New York calendar.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman said today that he would continue writing letters to Richard M. Nixon until the Republican Presidential nominee told farmers what he planned for them.

The trend to giant mergers continued yesterday with the announcement that the Radio Corporation of America planned to acquire the St. Regis Paper Company through an exchange of stock valued at $700-million.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- William W. Scranton, former Governor of Pennsylvania, the chief foreign policy adviser for the Republican national ticket, dropped into the State Department today to brief Secretary of State Dean Rusk on his recent European tour.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- President Johnson has signed legislation to allow air traffic controllers to collect full overtime pay, the White House said today.

A Brooklyn machinist and a Queens electrician were indicted here yesterday on charges of plotting to murder 158 persons they were said to have labeled "active leftists" in civil rights and left-wing groups.
