One hundred high school students, 40 of them from slum schools, will participate today in the first of a series of nine science lectures to be given during school holidays at City College.
Nino Benvenuti, the world middleweight champion, will defend his title against Don Fullmer of Salt Lake City on Nov. 23 in San Remo, Italy, it was announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Classes at racially mixed Olney High School broke up today when a group of 30 Negroes entered a school assembly and touched off fighting that injured seven students.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- A grenade accidentally dropped by a South Vietnamese soldier wounded 13 Vietnamese civilians and soldiers tonight. The grenade exploded in one of Saigon's busiest traffic circles.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 11 -- Practice sessions began here today for Sunday's running of the 132-mile Monterey Grand Prix, the fourth round of the six-race Canadian-American Challenge Cup for group 7 sports-racing cars.

"This is democracy," said one coed during the long, noisy morning that she and 65 other white students had spent barricaded in the Gould Memorial Library of New York University's uptown campus yesterday.

Paul O'Dwyer of the new politics told some Democratic district captains of the old politics yesterday why it was more important for him "to be right" about the war in Vietnam than be elected to the Senate.

MIAMI, Oct. 11 -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation arrested nine Cuban exiles in Miami today in connection with a wave of threats and terrorist activities against persons and countries doing business with Cuba.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- An intense President Johnson and Foreign Minister Michael Debre of France watched on television today's launching of the Apollo 7 spacecraft and its three astronauts.
DENVER, Oct. 11 -- A tomato and a peace medallion were thrown at George C. Wallace in Denver tonight as he moved his campaign for President westward.

PANAMA, Saturday, Oct. 12 -- A Panamanian military leader declared last night that his forces had seized control of the country in a bloodless coup d'etat. President Arnulfo Arias took refuge in the Canal Zone, which is controlled by the United States.

CHICAGO, Oct. 11 (UPI) -- Kenny Wharram's goal in the second period, on an assist from Stan Mikita, the league's scoring champion last season, was the deciding tally for the Chicago Black Hawks tonight in a 4-3 triumph over the St. Louis Blues.

INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Oct. 11 -- President Johnson paid a visit tonight to the patriarch of the Democratic party, former President Harry S. Truman, and then behaved for a few minutes as if he were running for another term in office himself.
Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., said yesterday that it would reopen a recent Federal court proceeding here that resulted in a ruling that the concern was an investment company.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 11 -- The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the week ended Oct. 5 were an estimated $654-million, an increase of 15 per cent over the $567-million sales for the corresponding week of last year. Total retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $6.82-billion, and increase of 12 per cent over the $6.07-billion sales for the same period last year.

Vice President Humphrey's hopes of carrying New York State suffered a new blow yesterday when the state decided to drop its fight to keep Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's name off the Presidential ballot Nov. 5.
UNION, N. J., Oct. 11 -- A 37-year-old Democrat is challenging one of the state's most formidable Republican vote-getters in New Jersey's 12th Congressional District.

Four teen-agers robbed an A. P. supermarket at 325 Cumberland Street at Greene Avenue in Brooklyn of $4,000 at 9:30 A.M. yesterday. While one youth herded 12 employes and customers to the rear of the store during the 10-minute hold-up, the others emptied the safe and cash registers.

MOMENTUM is to a choreographer what eloquence is to a playwright. The sheer momentum of Balanchine's "Scotch Symphony," given for the first time this season by the City Center Joffrey Ballet at the New York City Center last night, is by itself remarkable.

LONDON, Oct. 11 -- It's supposed to be the same language, but Walter H. Smith isn't so sure, recalling one of his first days in London as managing director (president) of Young Rubicam's British advertising subsidiary.
HOUSTON, Oct. 11 (AP) -- "It's a fantastic world up here," the Apollo 7 astronauts reported today as they hurtled around the world in America's newest space adventure.

Two Pacific Coast League managers moved up to the majors yesterday when Billy Martin of Denver was named manager of the Minnesota Twins and Clyde King of Phoenix took over the direction of the San Francisco Giants.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- The International Swimming Federation decided today that world records would count only in metric events in the future.
LUINO, Italy, Oct. 11 (Reuters) -- International trains were held up for two hours near this northern Italian town today because of a mouse.

DALLAS, Oct. 12 (UPI) -- The Texas Longhorns surged 85 yards against the clock today and scored with 39 seconds left to beat Oklahoma, 26-20.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Oct. 12 -- In a wild scoring contest that had the fans of both colleges biting their finger nails in anxiety, Rutgers held off a determined Lehigh University football team today to score a 29-26 victory.

NEITHER F. Scott Fitzgerald nor Ernest Hemingway lived to see the play about them that opened last night at the Greenwich Mews Theater, and it is a great pity. They would have laughed themselves silly over "Before I Wake," and probably gone out for a drink together afterward.

James M. Hester, president of New York University, yesterday advised students who planned to strike for the reinstatement of John F. Hatchett that they were welcome to picket but must not prevent nonstriking students from entering buildings or classrooms.
Aretha Franklin gave twin concerts last night at Philharmonic Hall that ranged from the earthiness of "Dr. Feelgood" to the loftiness of "We Shall Overcome."

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 13 -- The Westinghouse Electric Corporation has received orders for 18 gas turbine generating units valued at nearly $32-million from four electric utilities in the Southeast: Virginia Electric and Power Company, South Carolina Electric and Gas Company, Carolina Power and Light Company and Duke Power Company. All are members of the CARVA (Carolinas-Virginia Power Pool.

CAIRO, Oct. 13 -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser's political position has improved somewhat in the last several weeks, in the judgment of many wellinformed Egyptian and diplomatic observers here.

Goldberg.

Chet Huntley and David Brinkley, who together have done the National Broadcasting Company television network's evening news since October 29, 1956, will add a half-hour "Huntley-Brinkley Report" Saturdays beginning Jan. 4, thus making the report network TV's first six-day-a-week news program.
DETROIT, Oct. 13 -- The 1969 new model sales are starting out at record levels, General Motors Corporation reported over the weekend.

HOUSTON, Oct. 14 -- Today's television broadcast from the Apollo 7 was admittedly a venture in space agency public relations, but transmission from spacecraft and planes will have far more serious military and economic values in the near future.

A young lawyer was dismissed from his job as associate counsel to the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People yesterday because he wrote an article for The New York Times Magazine critical of the Supreme Court's civil-rights decisions.

If trains of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad are to continue their essential service throughout New England, the Interstate Commerce Commission will have to act swiftly to insure the road's inclusion in the merged Penn-Central system. WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Ralph E. Kent was elected president of the 65,000-member American Institute of Certified Public Accountants here today. Mr. Kent is managing partner of the accounting firm of Arthur Young Co., with headquarters in New York City.

ATHENS, Oct. 14 -- The Greek regime today proclaimed its impartiality with regard to the United States Presidential election and dismissed as "ludicrous" rumors that it was financing Richard M. Nixon's Presidential campaign.
TAMPA, Fla., Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Miami Floridians defeated the New Orleans Buccaneers, 108-85, tonight in an American Basketball Association game.

MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 14 -- A $3-million libel suit was filed in State Supreme Court here today against the American Medical Association by a chiropractor who contends that his reputation had been defamed in an advertisement placed by the Association in Family Circle magazine.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- The British Government announced tonight it would introduce legislation to lower the voting age from 21 to 18, increasing the electorate from 37 million to 40 million.
BALTIMORE, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A suit by 91 Army reservists from Massachusetts, contending they had not received the proper training to be sent to Vietnam, was dismissed today in Federal District Court.

Leonard H. Goldenson, president of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., told a gathering of TV station executives yesterday that television had an obligation to accurately reflect the world's problems and to "tell it like it is."

The Bronxville League for Service will present "Levities '68 -- The Face Is Familiar," a musical production, at 8:30 P.M., Oct. 25 and 26 in the Bronxville School auditorium. Mrs. James Wood is chairman of the event, and Mrs. William Raebeck Jr. is league president.

GARY, Ind., Oct. 14 -- The all-Negro National Committee of inquiry offered today to endorse Vice President Humphrey if he began to speak convincingly to black aspirations and needs. Otherwise leaders of the group said large numbers of black voters will sit put the Presidential election.

NEWARK, Oct. 14 -- The selection of a jury for the trial of Dominick A. Spina, Newark's Police Director, for alleged failure to enforce gambling laws was tentatively completed today in Superior Court. Only two jurors have been permanently accepted, however, and the others face further questioning.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Bok Technical and South Philadelphia High Schools, closed for two days last week when racial violence rocked adjoining residential areas, reopened today under the watchful eyes of hundreds of policemen who moved quickly to avert any stirrings of disturbance.

The Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, Pittsburgh, announced yesterday the naming of James H. Higgins as executive vice president. Mr. Higgins had been senior vice president in charge of the national department.

ITHACA, N.Y., Oct. 14 -- Paul O'Dwyer challenged today a poll that indicated Senator Jacob K. Javits had a substantial lead in his race for re-election. Mr. O'Dwyer predicted his own election on Nov. 5.
SALUDA, Va., Oct. 14 (AP) Lieut. Lewis B. Puller, 23 years old, the only son of Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Puller, Marine hero in World War II, has been critically wounded in Vietnam.

CHICAGO, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Thousands of Negro youngsters joined today a spreading boycott of Chicago high schools, demanding special classes, teachers and administrators for black students. False fire alarms emptied classrooms at some schools.

LONDON (AP) -- Britain drew a record 3.5 million foreign tourists in 1967. The British Travel Association said they had spent a record $556.4 million.

Interest rates on fixed-income securities continued to climb yesterday as the credit markets moved into a second week of heavy new-issue sales. Mrs. Samuel Weinberg, a grand-motherly Queens housewife, had come to buy a handbag and wandered up to the third floor when she heard there was a show.

Dawn Banks, an 11-year-old girl, paralyzed by lead poisoning in an arm and both hands since she ate paint chips that fell into her crib when she was 2, won a 250,000 damage judgment yesterday. If the second session of the Ninetieth Congress had accomplished nothing else, it would still be remembered favorably for its passage of the Civil Rights Act of 1968. This law with its open-housing provision virtually completes the legislative foundation for equal Negro rights so cautiously and laboriously begun eleven years ago when Congress passed the first civil rights law since Reconstruction.
Key developments from Ghent, Belgium, to Accra, Ghana, emphasized yesterday the worldwide scope of the oil industry.
REESE, Md., Oct. 14 -- Mrs. Cheever Porter's Afghan Hound, Ch. Holly Hill Desert Wind, was judged best in an entry of 943 dogs at the Carroll Kennel Club's third show here today.
Senator Eugene J. McCarthy joined the efforts of the state Democratic party yesterday to remove his name from the ballot as a Presidential candidate.

The management of Arrowhead and Puritas Waters, Inc., Los Angeles, sent a telegram last night to all shareholders, asking them to "delay any decision" on a $50-a-share offer for 315,000 common shares from the Allegheny Beverage Corporation, also based in Los Angeles.

GENEVA, Oct. 14 -- France reported today that 269 French manufacturers had applied for a subsidy offered by the Government to help offset the impact of salary increases on their exports, valued at $28.4-million.
VIENNA, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- The Czechoslovak novelist Ladislav Mnacko predicted today that Alexander Dubcek and other leading Czechoslovak liberals would soon be ousted from their posts.
PRAGUE, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Prague radio said today that Premier Cernik would "discuss some of the questions which are the result of the Moscow Protocol" between Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union.
DETROIT, Oct. 14 -- The fast start on new model sales insure that 1968 will be a record car sales year, Detroit auto executives maintain.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- Prime Minister Indiri Gandhi of India told the General Assembly today that aid to needy nations from the affluent countries was a form of enlightened self-interest.

PARIS, Oct. 14 -- Le Duc Tho, a senior member of the leadership in Hanoi and special political counselor to the North Vietnamese negotiators here, left for home unexpectedly today. His departure was kept secret until he was airborne.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The 20-year-old Mexican girl who carried the torch in the official opening ceremonies of the Olympics Saturday made her second Games appearance today -- but it wasn't nearly so successful.
DETROIT, Oct. 14 -- The fast start on new model sales insure that 1968 will be a record car sales year, Detroit auto executives maintain.

BOSTON, Oct. 14 -- A Negro cultural and educational organization began yesterday a drive to raise $1.5-million for the renovation of a former Jewish temple and school for use as a Negro art museum, drama center and an integrated school.
PARIS, Oct. 14 -- The conservative Catholic Center of French Physicians has formally taken issue with the papal encyclical reaffirming the ban on artificial birth control.
HONG KONG, Oct. 14 -- North Vietnam has denounced the Vietnam war policies of both Hubert H. Humphrey and Richard M. Nixon.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- An industrial dye that colors things bright red may be casting a small rosy glow over the future of virus drug research.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Israeli and Jordanian troops briefly exchanged fire across the Jordan River today, an Israeli military spokesman said here tonight. There were no Israeli casualties, he added.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to upset a finding that dealings between Luria Brothers, the steel scrap broker, and 14 steel producers violated anti-trust laws.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider far-reaching constitutional challenges involving the death penalty, "dragnet" arrests by the police and the right of servicemen to be tried in civilian courts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Prices declined and volume increased at this week's "auction" of mortgage purchase commitments by the Federal National Mortgage Association, the agency disclosed today.

McGeorge Bundy's call for a halt to the bombing of North Vietnam, for a negotiated settlement, if possible, and for systematic reduction of the American military effort in South Vietnam, represents a candid recognition by Mr. Bundy, at long last, of the compelling logic of events, and a challenge to those who still cling to the futile policies of the past.
Frederick A. Praeger is retiring from the publishing company bearing his name, which he sold in 1966 to Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc.

About 30 employes of the Columbia University controller's office and three organizers for a drug union staged a sit-in last night in the outer office of the acting president of the university, Andrew W. Cordier, and in a corridor outside the office in a dispute concerning union recognition.

TOKYO, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- The Yomiuri Giants of the Central Baseball League defeated the Hankyu Braves of the Pacific League, 6-1, today in the second game of their series, the Japanese equivalent of the World Series.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Juan Fernandez of Spain kicked the only goal as his nation edged Brazil, 1-0, today in a rugged Olympic soccer match.
NEWPORT, N. H. -- Bark from a fallen white birch kindled the tiny pot-of-tea fire for us at Chapin Pond when we came ashore in mid-afternoon to warm our chilled fingers.
BONN, Oct. 14 -- President Heinrich Lubke marked his 74th birthday today by announcing that he would step down at the end of next June, 11 weeks before his term runs out.
This year's third teachers' strike is causing New York City's high school seniors much apprehension -- some real, some unfounded -- about their futures.

The New York State Banking Department announced yesterday that it had approved the applications of two Brooklyn savings banks to open branch offices in Manhattan -- the Greater New York Savings Bank at the corner of Broadway and 79th Street and the Anchor Savings Bank at 1700 Broadway near 55th Street.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- About 12,000 people in and around Moscow's Central Synagogue cheered tonight, danced the hora and sang Israeli songs in honor of Simhath Torah, the holiday celebrating the giving of the Ten Commandments to Moses.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- General Minh suggested today that the bombing of North Vietnam could end if other ways were found to stem infiltration.

Five closings -- "A Mother's Kisses," the Richard Barr-Edward Albee repertory series, "The Flip Side," "Noel Coward's Sweet Potato" and "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead" -- were announced yesterday.

Romanticism, the steady-going 5-year-old mare owned by William Haggin Perry, contributed a thrilling performance in winning the $27,700 Interborough Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. With Johnny Rotz keeping her close to the rail in the six-furlong sprint, Romanticism succeeded in beating Queen of the Stage by a neck, with Just Kidding trailing the place horse by 2 1/2 lengths.
The city's practice of keeping narcotics addicts in jail after they have served sentences for minor crimes was upheld -- but strongly criticized -- yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice.
ROCHESTER, Oct. 14 (AP) -- A bandit armed with a pistol escaped with about $30,000 today afterthreatening to shoot a teller at the Lincoln Rochester Trust company branch bank in suburban Henrietta.

WOODBRIDGE, N. J., Oct. 14 -- Spiro T. Agnew condemned "phony intellectuals" leading the student rebellion, as well as the war on poverty and crime in the streets, before a wildly cheering group of 3,000 supporters here tonight.
The election of Frank A. Lee as a director of the Foster Wheeler Corporation was announced yesterday.
MONTREAL, Oct 14 -- Maury Wills and Zoilo Versalles -- two of baseball's Most Valuable Players of past years -- were drafted today by the two new teams in the National League
The October platinum futures contract expired with a fizzle yesterday for at least one speculator.
ROME, N. Y., Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Rome Daily Sentinel endorsed Richard M. Nixon today for President as the candidate who presents "the best hope for a change for the better."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court cleared the way today for trial of a libel case involving Melvin M. Belli, San Francisco lawyer, and an item about him in the Orlando, Fla., Evening Star. The Court refused to hold a hearing now, thereby opening the way for a jury trial, as ordered last December by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit.

The University of Southern California's narrow 27-24 victory over previously undefeated Stanford last Saturday may not have been a completely satisfying triumph to rabid alumni and frantic fans, but it was convincing enough to gain the top position for the Trojans in this week's major-college football polls.

Three physicists were honored here last night as recipients of the eighth Atoms for Peace Award for their contributions in promoting international cooperation in the non-military development of nuclear energy.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Oct. 14 -- The Voice of Fatah radio station has warned that the Jordanian army may move to supress the commando organization.

Low pressure at a high altitude is the current design at the Rainbow Grill. The glass-enclosed room on the 65th floor of the R.C.A. Building is the setting for the soft, hushed bossa nova songs of Joao Gilberto, a Brazilian singer and guitarist who carries reserve to an unusual extreme for a performer but, in the process, projects his own special kind of artistry.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 -- Maybe the wind blew the idea into Jay Silvester's head. Whatever the reason, the handsome 250-pounder from Utah saw all his mental barriers whisked away by the gale. He has twice broken the world record in the discus event and will be the favorite to win an Olympic gold medal when the final is held in the stadium tomorrow.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Merv Rettenmund of Rochester, who won the league batting title with a .331 average today was named the International League's most valuable player and rookie of the year. Rettenmund, who also was the only unanimous choice for the circuit's all-star team, is the fourth player in history to win both honors.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Oct. 13 -- At a hall in the village of Castricum northwest of Amsterdam Friday night, a small crowd expressed its preferences among United States political figures.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 14 -- The faculty at the University of California here may decide to confer its own degrees if the Board of Regents remains firm against allowing academic credit for a course on racism taught by Eldridge Cleaver, a leader of the Black Panthers.
Establishment of a high-speed train service between Boston and New York will move a step closer to realization next Monday with the departure of two jet-powered trains from New London, Conn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Vice President Humphrey proposed today a new effort to obtain agreement by management and labor on "a realistic figure for each year's average rate of wage increase that will keep prices stable."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The United Mine Workers signed a new contract today, ending a strike by 130,000 soft coal miners and winning cash gains for them of at least 25 per cent over three years as well as lucrative fringe benefits.
Senator Jacob K. Javits went to Wall Street yesterday to castigate the Conservative party before a lunch-hour crowd of 2,000 people that included some highly vocal Conservatives.

A WIZENED 83-year-old woman who had lived her spring years in Italy and her summer and autumn years in the part of Italy that was transplanted to East Harlem, came to say good-by the other day to Sabato Santarpia.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has invited proposals by Nov. 18 to build two experimental fanjet engines for its "quiet engine" development project.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Members of the Black Students Union seized a classroom building today at the University of California at Santa Barbara, occupying it from dawn to sundown before part of their demands were met.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- The British Foreign Secretary, Michael Stewart, today emphatically endorsed Secretary General Thant's proposal for a meeting of the Foreign Ministers of the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union.
MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- Following are excerpts of the proceedings last Friday in a trial of dissidents, including the final pleas of Mrs. Larisa Bogoraz-Daniel and Pavel M. Litvinov:

Demonstrators marched around City Hall yesterday to shout their support for school decentralization, then moved across Brooklyn Bridge, tangling rush-hour traffic, for a march to the Board of Education headquarters in Brooklyn.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Australian water polo team, which paid its own way to the Olympic Games, was looking forward to meeting Hungary today, but the match was not held and never will be.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson says that Massachusetts officials should seek Congressional action extending the coastel boundaries of all the states to at least nine miles offshore.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Oct. 14 -- Marco Aurelio Robles, former President of Panama, implied his approval for the new military regime today, but said he had no immediate plans to return to Panama.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, Oct. 14 -- Radka Lafchieva, a 21-year-old girl with chestnut colored eyes and a strikingly expressive face, pleaded gently with a Dutch publisher at Sofia's first international book fair:

THE black flag of anarchy fluttered gamely, if symbolically, over the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where last night the Living Theater gave the first New York performance of its collective creation, "Paradise Now."

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 -- A belief is widespread in informed quarters that last week's trial of Pavel M. Litvinov, Mrs. Larisa Bogoraz-Daniel and three others was the most "political," and therefore the most significant, of all the trials of Soviet dissidents.

Carnegie Recital Hall offered a twofold lure last night, when a pianist with the evocative name of Emma Contestabile (meaning contest-worthy in Italian) played a full program of seven Haydn sonatas. The opportunity to hear even one on the commercial recital stage is rare enough these days, for pianists know that if you play these pieces well the public is not impressed.
NEWARK, Oct. 14 -- East Side scored four touchdowns in the last quarter today to defeat West Side, 32-0, in its Newark City League opener at Schools Stadium.

Allegheny Airline will operate two new services from the New York area starting Oct. 27. It will fly two daily flights between Newark Airport and Toronto. One run will land at Philadelphia and Erie and the other only at Erie.

"Four Masters of Impressionism," an exhibition of works by Pissarro, Monet, Renoir and Sisley, will benefit the Lenox Hill Hospital and mark the opening of the new Acquavella Gallery, 18 East 79th Street.
LONDON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Britain will pay the United States about $60-million for canceling an order for 50 F-111 fighter-bombers, the British Government announced tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Army and the Marine Corps are now sending thousands of men back for involuntary second tours of duty in Vietnam. The Army plans to return about 18,000 this year; the Marines plan to return about 6,000.

DUBLIN, N.H. Oct. 14 (UPI) -- A cold, snowy winter is in store for the Western half of the nation, but "Abe Weather-wise" foresees a mild winter from Chicago eastward, marred by "one really big storm" during the last week in April.

The appointment of John C. Senholzi as division executive in charge of the Chase Manhattan Bank's municipal bond division was announced yesterday. He will succeed John W. deMilhau who is retiring after 35 years of service.

Two ad agencies, both of which have in recent years become owners of radio stations, have resigned their memberships in the American Association of Advertising Agencies at the request of the association.
MIAMI, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Two tropical disturbances whipped up squalls in the eastern and western Caribbean Sea today and dumped heavy rains on the Windward Islands and Jamaica.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The National Press Club has invited Vice President Humphrey and Richard M. Nixon to debate under its auspices, the club president, Allen W. Cromley, announced today.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Oct. 14 -- Officials of 19 Alabama school districts were told today by a Federal court that they must adopt programs of zoning, consolidation or pairing of schools to hasten desegregation if they cannot demonstrate that "freedom of choice" is working.

LISBON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- A slight improvement was reported tonight in the condition of former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, in a coma since suffering a severe stroke Sept. 16. However, doctors indicated that his condition was still grave.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 14 -- Richard M. Nixon called today for a "sweeping re-evaluation" of the Alliance for Progress in Latin America, including new efforts to involve European and American capital in an attack on "the real problem of hunger and sagging growth rates."

Mickey Lolich, whose three World Series pitching victories for the Detroit Tigers also brought him a Dodge Charger, given by Sport Magazine to the Series hero, accepted the automobile on behalf of his wife, Joyce, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court rejected today a challenge to the Government's authority to deport aliens who become members of the Communist party.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 14 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, departing tonight on a 74-hour fact-finding tour in Vietnam for George C. Wallace, said that Communist China never would have sent troops into Korea in 1950 had it not been for "traitors" in the United States Government.

STOKE-ON-TRENT, England, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Paul Shardlow, a goalie for the Cleveland Stokers in the North American Soccer League this year, collapsed and died today during training with his English club, Stoke City.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 14 -- Enemy rocket and mortar crews shelled a provincial capital and a South Vietnamese regimental headquarters today in what military officials described as another in a series of sporadic harassment attacks on Government-controlled towns.

WILLIMANTIC, Conn. Oct. 14 -- The pastoral hamlets of eastern Connecticut, even its bustling industrial towns, remain virtually untouched by the crime waves and civil disorders that have swept cities across the country.
Two biochemists who played major roles in cracking the genetic code of life were named yesterday to share the $25,000 Louisa Gross Horwitz Prize for outstanding research in biochemistry.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court let stand today decisions requiring manufacturers to submit for Government approaval certain implements used to tie severed blood vessels during surgery. The action was viewed as highly important to the regulatory powers of the Food and Drug Administration.

AUSTIN, Tex., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Two television executives have resigned from the National Citizen's Committee for Public Broadcasting today in protest against the group's recent attacks on commercial broadcasters.

MOSCOW, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Premier Oldrich Cernik of Czechoslovakia arrived today. He was expected to sign a treaty legalizing the Soviet invasion of his nation and calling for the withdrawal of most of the occupation forces this month.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 14 -- When a noted leader such as Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stands before the audience in the General Assembly Hall, the responsibility for the speaker's life is in the hands of a tall, trim, quiet man the public never notices as he stands in the shadows of the podium.

BANGOR, Maine, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Larry Siegfried and Tom Sanders led the Boston Celtics in a fourth-period surge to a 116-100 National Basketball Association exhibition victory tonight over the Philadelphia 76ers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, advised Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford today that he would call for a broad investigation of Army training methods for reservists bound for Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The police closed off an area in Washington's northeast section tonight when bands of young people went on a window-breaking and looting spree. Headquarters said the trouble apparently was not racial.
BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Two draft protesters, convicted of spilling paint on Selective Service records, were sentenced to prison today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Notes from a traveler's diary: Wednesday, 12:05 P.M. -- Airplane takes off from Washington National Airport, bound for Providence, R. I., via Philadelphia. Climbs through two miles of garbage and surfaces in an oddly illuminated area of brilliant blue.

A Soviet scientist said yesterday that his country was not in a race to the moon with the United States and had no plans to send astronauts to the moon "in the near future." He did not specify what he meant by the "near future."
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Ronnie Shade, Scotland's top golfer, announced today that he was turning professional. Shade will celebrate his 30th birthday tomorrow.
A new strike by teachers, the third in less than six weeks, crippled the city school system yesterday and kept more than a million pupils out of classes.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover opened a new attack on industrial practices today by charging that current industry safety codes provide inadequate protection for the public against the hazards inherent in modern technology.
HARTFORD, Oct. 14 -- Roger B. Ladd has passed out 20,000 green-and-white potholders promising "a new voice" in Washington for the voters of Connecticut's First Congressional District.
GIBRALTAR, Oct. 14 -- Prime Minister Wilson today viewed with equanimity, even serenity, the apparent collapse of the latest British effort to settle with the white rebels of Rhodesia.
With the era of $20-million, 360-passenger jumbo jets a year away, the world's airline industry took a large step yesterday toward setting up its own insurance coverage.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Two leaders of the striking Rhode Island Alliance of Social Workers were found guilty of contempt of court today and were remanded to the adult correctional institutions in Cranston.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Following is a summary of President Johnson's major legislative proposals and of the action taken on them by Congress during its 1968 session:

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Senator George Murphy, Republican of California, predicted today that Republicans would gain 40 seats in the House and 10 in the Senate in the Nov. 5 elections. He is chairman of the Republican Senatorial Campaign Committee.

Assemblyman Joseph Kottler, a Brooklyn Reform Democrat, has been elected chairman of the New York State Americans for Democratic Action. Mr. Kottler succeeds Melvin Dubin, also a Brooklyn Reform Democrat, who resigned.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a ruling that the Texas "disturbing-the-peace" law is an unconstitu tional invasion of peaceful protest. The Court acted on an appeal by State Attorney General Crawford C. Martin.

American Airlines has created a new department for market planning and development and has named Melvin A. Brenner as vice president in charge. Mr. Brenner, who previously was vice president of schedules and market development, joined the company in 1955 as a manager of route development.

Kelso, the world's top money-winning thoroughbred who has been taking a few tentative steps toward a new career, will give a jumping exhibition at the National Horse Show this year, Walter Devereux, the show's president, announced yesterday.

J. Wilson Newman, 60-year-old chairman of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., will retire in November after 16 years as chief executive. He has been with the company for 36 years. "It is time for a change," he said.

ABOARD U. S. S. BENNINGTON in the Gulf of Tonkin, Oct. 14 -- This huge aircraft carrier, her flight deck bristling with airplanes, prowls restlessly through the sea in search of an enemy that has yet to be found, but whose presence might one day be a reality.

Rod Laver of Australia is still the leader for the tennis player-of-the-year award after balloting by an 11-member international panel. Despite having been upset by Cliff Drysdale of South Africa in the United States open, Laver was the unanimous first choice with 110 points in the vote made public yesterday.

TRENTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Spokesmen at Newcomb Hospital here said today a 6-year-old boy had died of Eastern encephalitis, bringing to eight the number who have succombed to the disease this year in New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Warren Spahn and Orlando Cepeda came out on the losing side today in separate decisions by the Supreme Court.
Spiro T. Agnew, the Republican candidate for Vice President, told a Conservative party audience last night that a debate among all the Presidential candidates would be a "three-way circus."

BOSTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Seattle Pilots won the coin toss tonight and elected to give the Kansas City Royals first choice tomorrow in the American League expansion draft. Seattle's president, Dewey Soriano, gave away the No. 1 selection in order to get the second and third choices in the draft.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court denied today a hearing to Robert Bolivar DePugh, a founder of the secret Minutemen organization, who had challenged a Federal law restricting the transportation of firearms.

During a recent Richard Nixon rally at the Pacific Auditorium in Santa Monica, local policemen began ungently pushing along a group of long-haired picketers gathered outside. Whereupon these members of the witty and sassy younger generation dumfounded them by setting up the chant:

Production in the nation's steel mills jumped 5.6 percent in the week ended Saturday, compared with that of the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was the highest week-to-week percentage increase registered by the industry in 1968.
Vandalism broke out at New York University's Bronx campus yesterday as student protests continued over the dismissal of John F. Hatchett as director of the university's Afro-American Student Center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower flashed his familiar grin and gave the two-fingered victory salute today as he was serenaded by the United States Army Band and Chorus and cheered by 200 spectators on his 78th birthday.

MONTREAL, Oct. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The exhibition on the site of Expo 67, Man and His World, closed its gates to the public today after a five-month run and began immediately to prepare for the opening of its second season next spring.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- The first National Hockey League scout to watch the St. Louis Blues this season was not interested in the players -- but the organist. Norm Kramer, playing stirring songs at the St. Louis home games, is credited with promoting interest in the expansion team, which went to the Stanley Cup finals last season.

During his twelve years in the United States Senate Jacob K. Javits has served the state and the nation energetically and responsibly. He has worked hard on legislation to meet critical urban needs and to overcome poverty. He has made himself an expert on such important issues as economic development, international trade and foreign aid. Invariably speaking up on behalf of civil liberties and civil rights, he has reaffirmed this state's great liberal tradition.

Sgt. Robert Schatz, second of the three policemen wounded by a sniper outside Public School 155 in the troubled Ocean-Hill-Brownsville school district late Sunday night, was released from Brookdale Hospital Center in Brooklyn yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 -- The United States picked up its second straight easy Olympic basketball victory today, using the shooting and rebounding of Spencer Haywood to drub Senegal, 93-36.
A new effort to wrest control of Defiance Industries, Inc., from Victor Muscat, the financier, was disclosed yesterday.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday but above the day's lows.

C. (for Cyril) Northcote Parkinson, the British lawgiver ("Work expands so as to fill the time available for its completion") came to town yesterday for his annual visit and to take part in the debut of his latest book, "Mrs. Parkinson's Law."

Legitimately hopeful, but clearly in danger, of being over rated before they begin to play, the New York Knickerbockers open the National Basketball Association's 23d season when they face the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden tonight at 8:30 P.M.
The October platinum futures contract expired with a fizzle yesterday for at least one speculator.

AMERICAN MOTORS was a standout in an otherwise lackluster market yesterday as it barreled to a 1 1/8-point gain at 14 1/4. The stock has been higher this year -- 15 1/8 -- but its partisans have seldom been more hopeful that the nation's No. 4 auto maker was finally ready to turn the profit corner.

YONKERS, Oct. 14 -- No one at Yonkers Raceway was the least surprised tonight when Billy Haughton drove Laverne Hanover to the easiest triumph in the second of two mile trials for Friday night's rich Roosevelt Futurity.

VADUZ, Liechtenstein, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Swiss soldiers accidentally fired five mortar shells today into Liechtenstein, the 62-square-mile principality wedged between Switzerland and Austria. The authorities here said that nobody had been hurt and that they would protest, "but only mildly."

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- An earthquake rocked the southwest part of Western Australia State today, reducing almost all of a small town to rubble and injuring about 30 persons in the state.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, is supporting Richard M. Nixon for President, Scripps Howard Newspapers reported today.

FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 14 -- George C. Wallace said today he would accept Vice President Humphrey's offer to debate on television if Richard M. Nixon, the Republican nominee, also accepted. He added he doubted that Mr. Nixon would agree.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- With Democrats and Republicans quarreling right up to the end, the second session of the 90th Congress adjourned today.

BOULDER, Colo., Oct. 14 -- Students for a Democratic Society emerged from a longwinded and sometimes chaotic national conference today with a convictoin that its strength was growing on campuses and a determination to sek ways of moving into other areas of society.
A TASTEFUL sampling of classical Spanish drama began a five - show run yesterday afternoon at the Hunter College Playhouse under the title, "Esta Noche . . . Teatro," or theater tonight.
PARIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Frankie Narvaez of Puerto Rico won a 10-round decision over Rene Roque of France tonight in the Paris Sports Palace. Narvaez weighed 138 pounds, Roque 137.
An increase of 2.3 per cent in traffic over the Delaware Memorial Bridge last month has been reported by the Delaware River and Bay Authority.
The Board of Education has decided to elect John M. Doar, a recent appointee of Mayor Lindsay and a strong proponent of school decentralization, as its new president.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League today assigned Terry Crisp, a wing and center, and Bill Plager, a defenseman, to the Blues' Kansas City farm of the Central League.

CHERRY HILLS, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Pappa Steve overtook Angelico, the favorite, near the half-mile pole today and went on to win the six-furlong Quaker City Handicap before an opening-day crowd of 15,978 at Garden State Park.
An increase of 2.3 per cent in traffic over the Delaware Memorial Bridge last month has been reported by the Delaware River and Bay Authority.
The Board of Education has decided to elect John M. Doar, a recent appointee of Mayor Lindsay and a strong proponent of school decentralization, as its new president.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The St. Louis Blues of the National Hockey League today assigned Terry Crisp, a wing and center, and Bill Plager, a defenseman, to the Blues' Kansas City farm of the Central League.

CHERRY HILLS, N. J., Oct. 14 (AP) -- Pappa Steve overtook Angelico, the favorite, near the half-mile pole today and went on to win the six-furlong Quaker City Handicap before an opening-day crowd of 15,978 at Garden State Park.

LISBON, Oct. 14 -- The Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization urged the alliance today not to abandon the road to detente in the wake of the Czechoslovak crisis, but he acknowledged that there would be greater emphasis on defense.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Kentucky Colonels, led by Louie Dampier's 27 points, crushed the Dallas Chaparrals, 143-115, in an American Basketball Association exhibition game tonight.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Lowell North of San Diego skippered his yacht North Star to victory today in the first of seven races to determine the Olympic Star Class gold-medal winner.
Higher prices for lead became the general trend yesterday.

The difficulties of bidding when the opponents have opened with one no-trump have given rise to a variety of conventional devices. Many experts use Astro, in which an overcall of two diamonds shows a two-suiter that includes spades, while two clubs shows hearts and a minor suit.
A court action in favor of the newly formed American Professional Golfers association yesterday opened the way for two national pro golf circuits in 1969.
Gov. Spiro T. Agnew declared his net financial worth yesterday at $111,084.44.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 "En sus Marcos!" the starter commanded, and eight 100-meter finalists took their marks today at Olympic Stadium. "Listos?" he asked, meaning "Are you ready?" Then the gun went off and the sprinters catapulted themselves along the reddish Tartan track like jet fighters going off the deck of an aircraft carrier.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Earl G. Graves, a former aide to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has been named coordinator for minority groups in the Presidential campaign of Hubert H. Humphrey and Edmund S. Muskie.

ISMAILIA, United Arab Republic, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Seamen from the ships of eight nations bottled up in the Suez Canal since the war last year ran their own mini-Olympics recently with Egyptian and Israeli guns at the ready on either side of them.
The New York Stock Exchange expects to utilize a mammoth trading floor of 90,000 square feet, or three times the size of its existing floor, when it moves into its new home in the 1970's.
Mayor Lindsay's plans to campaign for fellow Republicans were ruined once again yesterday by the city's persistent school problems.
PARIS, Oct. 13 -- French geneticists, doctors and psychiatrists failed today to persuade a nine-man jury to free a self-confessed murderer on the ground that he had an inherited chromosome imbalance.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 (AP) -- The Supreme Court dismissed today the appeal of a group of retail liquor dealers against a California law setting a minimum figure for liquor prices. The Court said no "substantial Federal question" was involved.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The United States rebuked today the deposed President of Panama, Dr. Arnulfo Arias, for a "call to arms" yesterday while in the United States-controlled Canal Zone.
MALSTETTEN, West Germany, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- A small plane flying just above ground level killed an 11-year-old girl yesterday as she walked in a Sunday-school outing, the police reported.
Prices managed to achieve a modest advance in yesterday's trading on the American Stock Exchange although volume was down and declines outnumbered advances.
The stock market scored another small gain in relatively quiet and dull trading yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The Treasury bill rate rose at today's auction from last week's levels, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
NEW DELHI, Oct. 14 (AP) -- India today requested a one-week postponement of the interzone Davis Cup Final against the United States, scheduled for San Juan, Puerto Rico, Nov. 9-11.

"WE'RE back in the race," said Wally Lemm, coach of the Houston Oilers, and no one was more surprised than he. The Oilers, prior to Sunday's action, had lost three straight games plus their quarterback, Pete Beathard, who underwent an appendectomy.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 14 -- At 8:25 P.M. today, in a dramatic ceremony that will be repeated many more times during the next two weeks, the Star Spangled Banner echoed throughout Olympic Stadium.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie told 1,200 applauding partisans last night that Richard M. Nixon had avoided George C. Wallace's "direct appeal to man's worst instincts" but was "playing the same tune in a different key."

The first performance of Milton Babbitt's "Relata II," scheduled by the New York Philharmonic for Oct. 17 with repeat performances on Oct. 18, 19 and 21, has been postponed. It will be replaced by Randall Thompson's Symphony No. 3. Haydn's Symphony No. 87 and Richard Strauss's "Don Quixote" will complete the program.
BONN, Oct. 14 -- The United States, Britain and France rejected today a Soviet charge that a rally by refugees in West Berlin on Sept. 1 violated the divided city's occupation status.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 14 -- The United States share of the recent $2-billion standby credit to Britain to guarantee the value of holdings of pounds by sterling-area countries was $650-million, it was disclosed today.

LONDON, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Sterling area countries withdrew 230-million from their holdings in the months following the currency's devaluation last Nov. 18 last year, the British Government disclosed today.

PORTON DOWN, England, Oct. 14 (UPI) -- British military officials said today that they had been giving doses of LSD to selected soldiers to determine how effective the hallucinatory drug would be in chemical warfare. "Officially LSD comes under our research into incapacitating agents," a Government official said.

"Rockefeller and the Red Indians," formerly called "The Wind in the Sassafras Trees," will open Oct. 24 at the Ethel Barrymore Theater. Frankie Howerd, British comedian, will be starred in the comedy by Ray Galton and Alan Simpson, adapted from a French play by Rene de Obaldia.

Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis announced yesterday the appointments of Henry Arbeeny, John O. Florence, Vincent Gentile, Edward W. Niemiec and William T. Sullivan as general partners. They are based in New York City.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- President Johnson yesterday signed into law a bill continuing Government subsidies toward the cost of merchant vessels constructed in United States shipyards. However, he complained it was a "piecemeal" measure without long-term benefits, and regretted that Congress had not approved recommendations to change the merchant marine policy.

TIFFANY'S is feeling bullish about silver and thus is ready to offer what it thinks is a neat solution to a fiscal and merchandising problem. For the last several years, the price of silver has been going up. In the light of this, those making and selling silver hollow ware, as Tiffany's does, would appear to be faced with two possibilities: Make the sterling objects thinner (Tiffany's sells only sterling; plate went out when Walter
MINEOLA, L. I., Oct. 14 -- Nassau County's method of selecting the members of its Board of Supervisors was declared invalid in State Supreme Court here today.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 14 (AP) -- Two representatives of the National Liberation Front, the political arm of the Vietcong, arriced today to prepare to open an information office. The two, Tran Van An and Tran Van Hue, arrived via Moscow, from South Vietnam and said at a news conference that the guerrillas would win the war in Vietnam.

BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 14 (Reuters) -- Police attacks on newsmen during the Democratic National Convention in Chicago last August were cited today by an official of the Inter-American Press Association as an example of the use of hasty methods in emergency situations.
PANAMA, Oct. 14 -- Panama's three-day-old military government appears to retain tight control of the country despite appeals for street warfare voiced by the man it ousted.

COLOR television coverage of the XIX Olympic Games in Mexico City, which will continue until Oct. 27, could prove to be one of the sustained highlights of this fall's far from distinguished TV season. In the initial events, reported in the American Broadcasting Company's exclusive coverage, the athletes fared better than the actors.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Peter Curraz, Puerto Rico's boxing delegate, said today he still hoped that a 16-year-old flyweight, Heriberto Cintron, would be able to fight in the Olympic boxing tournament.

NEW HAVEN, Oct. 15 -- Television has its reruns, and so does Connecticut's Third Congressional District, which includes the city of New Haven and 12 suburban towns. The three candidates who ran for the House of Representatives in 1966 are back running again.

STRATFORD - ON - AVON, England, Oct. 15 -- "Much Ado About Nothing," the final production in this year's Stratford - on - Avon season, has a fair claim to the title of Shakespeare's most operatic play. Certainly its confusions of character and plot are best tackled by pushing every change from high comedy to romantic melodrama to the stylistic limit.

The Appellate Division of state Supreme Court refused yesterday to review its decision to place Senator Eugene J. McCarthy of Minnesota on the state ballot, against his will, as a candidate for President.

One of New York's venerable grocery store chains, which gained prominence partly by catering to the gourmet trade, is merging with one of the country's most successful convenience store chains, it was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- An investigating Senator said today that the automobile insurance system apparently needs a "rather basic overhaul."
A booing, jeering crowd, massed in and outside a Brooklyn Jewish center, goaded Mayor Lindsay to evident anger last night when he appeared to plead for understanding of school decentralization.

HOUSTON, Oct. 15 -- While the Apollo 7 "television roadshow" sped through its fifth smooth day in orbit, expectations mounted here today that the next flight would take three men around the moon in December.
A Federal review of New York City's skyrocketing relief rolls, to be made by the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, was announced yesterday by the State Department of Social Services.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange made a modest advance yesterday after some days of desultory backing and filling.

The general counsel of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday he would "fight within the organizational structure" for the reinstatement of a young lawyer dismissed for writing an article critical of the Supreme Court's civil rights rulings.

The Madison Square Garden Corporation is negotiating a plan to acquire from the Penn Central Company the railroad's 25 per cent interest in Madison Square Garden Center, Inc., and its 55 per cent interest in No. 2 Pennsylvania Plaza Office Building, it was disclosed yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Avery Brundage, head of the International Olympic Committee, was caught today in a controversy involving black American athletes at the Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A Maine member of the House of Representatives charged today that his Democratic colleague, Representative Hale Boggs of Louisiana, had "tainted and tarnished" Maine's bid for a big oil project.

BELGRADE -- This being an essentially cynical world, I very much fear that Russia's rape of Czechoslovakia will in the long run prove useful to the Soviet cause and detrimental to America's -- for the wrong reasons and in unexpected places.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -The athletes competing in Olympic Stadium have been sharing the spectators' attention with a tiny figure hovering 246 feet above.

Metromedia, Inc., has asked Senator Eugene J. McCarthy to keynote the election night coverage on its five television stations, but a Metromedia official described the Senator's reaction to the proposal as "distant and aloof -- but he didn't spit on us."
Gas leaking from a pipe beneath bustling 42d Street just east of Eighth Avenue exploded at midday yesterday, injuring eight firemen and utility workers and forcing 1,000 people to flee to safety.

SEATTLE, Oct. 15 -- Washington's contest for Governor has been blown wide open by a public disclosure that Attorney General John J. O'Connell, the Democratic challenger of Gov. Daniel J. Evans, has been a patron of Las Vegas gambling casinos for years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Secretary General Thant has proposed that the Foreign Ministers of the four major powers meet to stiffen their support and guidance for Ambassador Gunnar V. Jarring's peace mission in the Middle East.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 15 -- Outside the Civic Center Auditorium last night were pickets with signs and leaflets urging Senator Eugene J. McCarthy to endorse Hubert H. Humphrey for President.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Robin Douglas-Home, nephew of a former Prime Minister, Sir Alec Douglas-Home, was found dead in his Sussex house today.

Disgusted with themselves after a sloppy, back-pedaling effort against the Black Hawks in Chicago Sunday night, the Rangers yesterday promised their new coach a victory tonight when they open their home season by taking on the Philadelphia Flyers at Madison Square Garden.

THE happiest folk at last night's opening appearance of the Rumanian Folk Ballet at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum were those with a special taste for chain dances and violins. But even those who prefer their national dance troupes with a bit more variety and a little less music would have to agree that this Bucharest company is a first-class folk group with outstanding dancers.
BOSTON, Oct. 15 -- The American League worked only an eight-hour day today, and when it was finished it had passed around $10.5-million and formed two new baseball teams.

A new president and chief executive officer will be named by the directors of Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc., following the company's annual meeting in December, thus ending the five-year tenure of Robert H. O'Brien.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- The dean of Harvard College couldn't restrain himself today after a remarkable comeback that put his school's eight-oared crew into the Olympic rowing final.

CIVILIZED violence is at the heart of Harold Pinter. The violence of a businessman playing a strange game of football, which might develop -- or might not develop -- into rape, with his unnaturally sexual secretary: a man throwing, with deadly aim, huge marbles at another man: two rivals for a girl edging around each other, dueling with broken milk bottles -- all this is a part of Pinter's inconsequentially deadly world.
An order that may change the ground rules of a forthcoming court-ordered election in the National Maritime Union was signed yesterday by Judge Constance Baker Motley in Federal Court here.
TOKYO, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Japan Air Lines announced today that it would build a jet pilot training center at Grant County Airport in Moses Lake, Wash., to prepare for bigger planes.
THE lips curve into a wry smile, and the words are forceful. They come from a small woman balanced on toothpick heels of green silk, but they do not sound incongruous.
A head-to-head confrontation between the two rival professional tennis groups will take place at Madison Square Garden with an eight-man, $20,000 indoor tournament Nov. 28 to 30.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie went into Harlem and the BedfordStuyvesant area of Brooklyn yesterday and told rallies of Negroes that he wanted to help them help themselves.
Parents and teachers in many parts of the city formed special action groups yesterday in an attempt to continue instruction in spite of the strike.
HONG KONG, Oct. 15 -- Communist China indicated this morning that it had taken some action formally depriving the chief of state, Liu Shao-chi, of his Government and party functions.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The fast-moving United States economy -- and its inflation -- slowed scarcely at all in the third quarter, the Department of Commerce reported today.
Toots Thielemans has brought an unusual mixture of jazz virtuosities to Plaza 9, the Plaza Hotel's new subterranean jazz room.
The Allied Chemical Corporation reported yesterday a net loss of $15,482,000 for the third quarter of this year on sales of $303,150,000.

Why anyone should have been optimistic about the British-Rhodesian negotiations at Gibraltar is a mystery. It seemed obvious that neither of the Prime Ministers could make the concessions necessary to reach agreement on a legal status of independence for Rhodesia.
IN the credo of Liu Shao-chi, unconditional sacrifice has always loomed large. The ideal Communist, he has said, recognizes "that he bears the sorrows of the world now for later happiness."
MIAMI, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Tropical storm Gladys lashed Cuba's Isle of Pines with winds up to 55 miles an hour tonight and forecasters said that it would probably hit Florida.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Oct. 15 -- Three weeks to go and Hubert H. Humphrey, bouncing around mid-America, seems finally to have settled on his last objective: victory by a whisker. The opinion polls were supposed to have shown him galloping by now.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (AP) -- Ted J. Davis, an Oklahoma City lawyer and rancher, was sworn in today as an Assistant Secretary of Agriculture, Mr. Davis, 38 years old, will be in charge of the department's marketing and consumer services.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- Responsible West European sources said here today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union assured Secretary of State Dean Rusk last week that there would be no East European threat to West Berlin in the foreseeable future.

The University Council of Columbia University voted yesterday to establish a faculty committee that would set policy on research contracts with outside institutions, including Government agencies, and apply it in important individual cases.
An inquiry announced last June by Mayor Lindsay into alleged ties between Manhattan Republican Chairman Vincent F. Albano Jr. and figures in the Marcus kickback conspiracy has never begun.
Richard M. Nixon said yesterday he would take steps if elected to end the treatment of the American poultry industry "as a step-child" of the Department of Agriculture.

About 400 movie theaters here are urging their patrons to protest a pending Board of Estimate resolution that, they said, would permit three private cable-television companies "to originate and charge for the same kind of programs you now get free."
The proposal to fight air-traffic congestion crises by introducing fare differentials between peak and low-volume periods has apparently become snagged by disagreements in the airline industry.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Bill Hosket and Ken Spain paced a United States surge late in the first period tonight that sent the Americans to their third straight Olympic basketball victory, a 96-75 decision over the Philippines.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Oct. 15 -- Apartment owners and managers from across the country turned their attention here today to what was described as a spreading uneasiness among tenants about the security of their persons and property -- a topic viewed as closely related to the national political issue of law and order.
One of the factors behind the Federal review of the city's welfare program is its explosive growth.
Edward E. Booher, president of McGraw-Hill Book Company since 1960, became chairman of the concern yesterday and Harold W. McGraw Jr., executive vice president, succeeded him as president.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 15 -- George C. Wallace's third-party Presidential campaign has slowed noticeably during the last week as he has ventured into strange and hostile territory.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- At four-year intervals, the world is treated to 29 days in February, a United States Presidential election and A1 Oerter winning an Olympic gold medal.
Maurice Girodias, the supreme pornographic publisher of Paris, has come to New York, where he sees signs of a changing market.

OSCAR STRAUS, not to be confused with any of the various members of the Strauss family, composed "A Waltz Dream" in 1907 and it almost immediately made the international rounds. It is one of the last of the great Viennese operettas and, as such, something special.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 -- Some high-ranking Israeli officials are speaking more optimistically than at any time since the 1967 Arab-Israeli war of the chances of peace talks with Jordan.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association announced yesterday that 23,000 policemen would begin a curtailment of service "within 48 hours" because the city had refused to reopen negotiations on a proposed contract that the union's delegates rejected Monday night.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- Tear gas was used again tonight to disperse small groups of militant Negro youths in a slum section of northeast Washington.
DOES General Host Corporation have designs on Armour Co? That question arose following the purchase of 600,000 shares of Armour Co. from Gulf Western yesterday.

Theodora A. Randolph's Bon Nouvel started in yesterday's 60th running of the Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park like an old-fashioned firehorse responding to the clanging call of a three-alarm blaze.

INDIANAPOLIS, Oct. 15 -"Yes, we will listen to your complaints," Gov. Spiro T. Agnew said today of the poor and of dissident youths. "You may give us your symptoms [but] we will make the diagnosis and we, the Establishment, for which I make no apologies for being a part of, will implement the cure."

The New York Knickerbockers opened a new basketball season at Madison Square Garden last night in much the same fashion that they had spoiled previous seasons. They waged an uphill struggle on a mountain they had helped to create, then fell short of the summit and took a 100-96 defeat at the hands of the Chicago Bulls.
Continuing their low-key recovery from last week's set-back, stock prices registered another modest advance yesterday in more active trading.
A group of students, teachers and parents opened the Bronx High School of Science yesterday in support of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district.

One of the nation's leading labor experts said yesterday that the emphasis of public employe unions in New York City on the right to strike was deterring many other cities from overdue changes in their relations with their employes.

LISBON, Oct. 15 -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, the commander of allied forces in Europe, castigated the French today for their "ambiguous" military position. He warned that in the event of aggression the Atlantic allies could be forced to resort to nuclear arms sooner than they otherwise would.

MONTEREY, Calif., Oct. 15 -- Somewhere in Tokyo today there is a freshly written contract bearing the customary hancos -- stamped symbols that stand for the signature of a Japanese. Amid those hancos is a ball-point signature scrawled in the American manner -- not very decipherable even to another American, certainly bewildering to the Japanese eye.

THERE were two startling developments in the Ivy League last Saturday. Penn pulled a major upset by beating defense-minded Cornell, and Princeton ended its three-year domination by Dartmouth by romping over the Hanover Indians, 34-7.
Frank Pace Jr., chairman of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, said yesterday that he would start operations of the publicly financed corporation next week.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Southern Regional Council reported today that there had been a "deplorable degree of failure" in desegregating Southern schools.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- A drive to bring consumer issues into political campaigns throughout the country was started today by the Consumer Federation of America.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 5 -- The enemy's main - force units have pulled back or been driven back from all of South Vietnam's major cities for the first time since the Tet offensive in late January, high-ranking military, and civilian officials said today.

The Brooklyn District Attorney began an investigation yesterday into alleged acts of terrorism, including death threats, at Junior High School 271 in Ocean Hill-Brownsville as more than a million city pupils remained without classes because of the new teachers' strike.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 15 -- The battleship New Jersey, steaming along the panhandle of North Vietnam, has fired on a target almost as far above the demilitarized zone as United States planes are authorized to strike.
New York City, feeling the impact of the steep rise in interest rates since early August, sold a bond issue yesterday at a cost just below 5 per cent, its most expensive borrowing since 1932.

Kremlinologists like to remind us that the Russian heritage includes a strong strain of the Oriental, so one should not have been surprised to hear the Chinese bass-baritone Yi-Kwei Sze do well last night at Carnegie Hall with the songs of composers named Mussorgsky and Tcherepnin.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- On his third throw, Al Oerter uncoiled his 32-year-old frame and spun the discus into the cloudy Mexican sky. It went 212 feet 6 1/2 inches, farther than he had ever thrown it before.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 15 -- Because she is generally expected to win three Olympic swimming championships, Debbie Meyer was a rather disconcerting sight when she arrived at Olympic Village a week ago. The pert 16-year-old was hobbling with a crutch under her right arm. But after her first workout the next day, she was carrying the crutch like a musket over her shoulder.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 15 (UPI) -- A team of foreign observers reported today that there was no evidence supporting the allegations of genocide in the region of eastern Nigeria where secessionist Biafrans are making a last stand against federal troops.

Your Oct. 10 editorial regarding John F. Hatchett raises some important issues concerning the proper purpose of a modern university. Is the university to function solely as a custodian of genteel learning and celebrator of the conventional wisdom?
Sullivan, Stauffer, Colwell Bayles anounced yesterday that it had resigned the $5-million Ballantine beer account.
Paul O'Dwyer declared yesterday that if George C. Wallace received a big vote for President in November, he would be "off and running with a party completely opposed to the American system."
There was plenty yesterday at the Commodore Hotel for the stockbroker who has everything.

Should the nations of the world work together to present a united front to those allegedly piloting unidentified flying objects? Or is the evidence for such visitations so flimsy that the subject of U.F.O.'s does not merit serious inquiry?
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -President Johnson signed today a new interna-i tional treaty representing a bill of rights for refugees fleeing to the United States.

LONDON, Oct. 15 -- Britain made concessions to the rebel white Government of Rhodesia in the just-concluded talks at Gibraltar -- but not on the key issue of guarantees of the rights of black Africans.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 15 -- Representative Donald J. Irwin is campaigning like an underdog in Fairfield County because, as he admits with good-natured candor, "if the election were held today, I'd lose."

An attempt to cure the electrical difficulties that have been stalling the operation of part of the Government-sponsored program for high-speed train service between New York and Washington will be made today by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.

KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., Oct. 15 -- With evident confidence, Richard M. Nixon predicted this morning that he would lead his party back into power with sweeping triumphs at every level of government three weeks from today.

A promising approach to the prevention of illness is aimed at detecting and treat ing disease in its earliest stages. A new project of one of the 78 member voluntary hospitals of the United Hospital fund, it is the first Multiphasic Health Screening Program in New York City, one of only four in the United States, and uses the latest in medical test equipment linked with a computer.

MOSCOW, Oct. 15 -- The Soviet Union and Czechoslovakia were reported to have completed today the drafting of a treaty that will permit Moscow to station troops on Czechoslovak soil for an indefinite period.

The Republic Steel Corporation, the first major steel producer to issue third-quarter results, reported a sharp drop in its income yesterday, reflecting declining sales and shipments in the wake of the steel-labor settlement.
CLEVELAND, Oct. 15 (AP) -A marijuana planter called Johnny Pot, a sort of modernday Johnny Appleseed, is being sought by agents of the Federal Bureau of Drug Abuse Control.
James L. Buckley suggested a shift in business taxes yesterday as part of his plan for a step-by-step dismantling of the Federal bureaucracy.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 15 -- Mixing jest with political invective, Vice President Humphrey stumped through Missouri today, taunting "Richard the Chicken Hearted" to speak out on the issues and christening the Wallace-LeMay ticket "The Bombsy Twins."

Moore-McCormack Company, which is in the process of merging into the City Investing Company, has begun the corporate reorganization of its subsidiaries, according to William T. Moore, chairman and president of the parent company.
LONDON, Oct. 15 (UPI) -An Indian scientist said this week that the Olympics are unfairly weighted in favor of the taller and heavier races of the world -- specifically the nations of the West.
PARIS, Oct. 15 -- Editors and reporters of Le Figaro, France's leading morning newspaper, announced today that it would not appear on Thursday.

IN Jerry Smith's family, it's the children who delight in giving toys to their father. Some of those toys are among the 1,001 trains, tractors, carrousels, circuses, horses and soldiers that make up an exhibition called The Toy Collector that opens today at the Hallmark Gallery, 720 Fifth Avenue (at 56th Street). The exhibition, which is likely to inspire at least as much adult nostalgia as childish excitement, will continue through Dec. 31.
The growing use of air-cushioned vehicles -- craft capable of riding across water and land on a cushion of air -- is demonstrated by three British-made craft.
KNOXVILLE, Oct. 15 -- Mr. Nixon opened heavy fire today on both his rivals for the Presi dency. He asserted that Mr. Wallace was a delusion and suggested that Mr. Humphrey was a demagogue.

SOME of the most exciting bridge games regularly last less than an hour, and the commuters who play them are less indignant than their fellow-passengers when the occasional vagaries of the Penn Central and the New Haven lead to a late arrival at Grand Central Terminal.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- President Johnson is sending Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach to meet President Tito in Belgrade as a demonstration of United States concern over implied Soviet threats to Yugoslavia.
Uday Shankar, who has never met a Beatle, looked back over his 44-year career as a lending interpreter of India's dance and culture, and commented quietly upon the current scene.
Like falling dominoes, silver futures prices had a tumbling effect yesterday.
FRESNO, Calif., Oct. 14 -There is a giant boot made of raisins with a sole fashioned from prunes at the Fresno District Fair, and it might well symbolize the attitude of Fresno's women voters.
The reaction of some New York furriers to current efforts by conservationists to stop the sale of leopard, cheetah and other spotted cat skins is both deplorable and ridiculous.

The biennial appraisal by this newspaper of candidates for the House of Representatives from the metropolitan area begins today. Our recommendations are based on our judgment of each candidate's merit as a legislator without regard to party.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Supreme Court ruled, 6 to 3, today that the State of Ohio must list the name of George C. Wallace and his American Independent party on the ballot for the Presidential election on Nov. 5.

Senator Jacob K. Javits warned yesterday that the country would "explode with insurrection" unless moderates of all races intensified their efforts to win social justice and racial equality for all Americans.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -United States officials say the fighting in South Vietnam has dropped off again in recent weeks, with American casualties approaching the low point of the summer lull.

John Hatchett's statement upon his dismissal from N.Y.U. complains about the "hostile atmosphere" and asserts that "no statement of charges was given me, which is the minimum requirement for any proceeding from which dismissal may result."
Two massive paintings by Larry Rivers went on display yesterday afternoon in the lobby of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts.

Comcet, Inc., a newly formed company that expects to produce a family of communications computers, made its first public offering of common stock yesterday and investors quickly bid up the shares to nearly three times the initial price.

Membership in Harness Racing's Hall of Fame has been voted to four men. The latest to be honored by the United States Harness Writers' Association are Walter J. Michael of Bucyrus, Ohio; Delvin Miller of Meadow Lands, Pa.; Frank Ervin of Lexington, Ky., and William R. (Billy) Haughton of Oyster Bay Cove, L. I.
Twenty-one women, including Mrs. Dean Rusk, wife of the Secretary of State, received awards yesterday for service to the cause of human rights.
Net income of the Sinclair Oil Corporation for the third quarter and the first nine months of 1968 fell sharply, but there were extenuating circumstances.

ROME, Oct. 15 -- A priest who, against his personal conviction, presented and defended the Papal encyclical renewing the Roman Catholic ban on artificial contraception, has been named Archbishop of Perugia.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The John Birch Society's executive committee has unanimously endorsed the theory that proCommunists could operate more successfully with Richard M. Nixon as President than under Hubert H. Humphrey.
