IF television is normally hung up on trivia, it wasn't last night. The Columbia Broadcasting System's "Playhouse" socked the facts of life to its audience with a bluntness of language and a vividness of depiction that mark a definite turning point in the evolution of the medium.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, Oct. 16 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay flew the Pacific last night for Saigon to begin his three-day "fact-finding" tour of Vietnam for George C. Wallace.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 15 -- Secretary General Thant today made public an exchange of letters in which Israel refused to receive his special representative to study the condition of Arabs in the territory occupied by Israel, unless the condition of Jews in Arab countries was also studied.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -- The Federal Trade Commission, on the basis of new laboratory tests, has rated king size Carlton filter cigarettes and regular Marvel filter cigarettes as lowest in tar content among 122 varieties.

As the number of student pickets at New York University's Washington Square dwindled yesterday, leaders of the demonstration against the university administration tried a new tactic -- the "mill-in." It succeeded in jamming the lobby and elevators of the main building.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 -The political pollsters agree that there is a greater chance their polls may be wrong this year than at any time since 1948, when the major polls predicted the wrong winner in the Presidential race.

Mayor John V. Lindsay began his administration by promising greater centralization in municipal affairs through the establishment of new "super agencies" whose powers were very carefully defined. Now he has come full cycle as an advocate of decentralization, but without the same attention being given to the exact division of powers between the central agencies of city government and local elected boards.
Charges of criminal trespass against 346 more Columbia University students arrested during last spring's campus disorders were dismissed yesterday.
Mayor Lindsay will meet with officers of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association today to try to avert a threatened work-curtailment by 23,000 policemen.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- An American spokesman asserted today that there had been "movement" in the Vietnam talks but that it was too soon to say if it amounted to real progress.
Columbia University said yesterday that criticism of its expansion policies had caused it to cancel plans to cosponsor a major redevelopment project on the west fringe of Harlem.
Mayor Lindsay last night appointed a three-member panel headed by Theodore W. Kheel, the labor mediator, to try to settle the teachers' strike arising from the Ocean Hill-Brownsville dispute.

NEWARK, Oct. 10 (UPI) -- A state of emergency in this city's 1,400-man police force was declared today, with all patrolmen put on mandatory overtime because of manpower shortages and a rising crime rate.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- Pat Stapleton scored a goal and had four assists and Jim Pappin collected three goals and an assist as the Chicago Black Hawks routed the Minnesota North Stars, 10-4, for their third straight triumph tonight.

CHICAGO, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Marcor, Inc., proposed parent of Montgomery Ward Co. and Container Corporation of America, has extended its offer to exchange 6 1/2 per cent subordinated installment debentures for outstanding common shares of Container Corporation.

HRADEC-KRALOVE, Czechoslavakia, Oct. 14 -- Polish troops, flying their red and white flags over Quonset huts and tents, have taken over occupation duties in this area of northeastern Bohemia near the Polish frontier.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- The Los Angeles Times and Washington Post news service was awarded a bronze plaque today for the "excellence of its Latin-American news coverage."

Wilhelm V. von Moltke, professor of urban design at Harvard University, has joined the Perkins Will Partnership as staff consultant. He will assist in master planning and urban design projects being conducted by the architectural firm's offices in White Plains, Chicago and Washington, and will continue to head the urban design program in Harvard's Graduate School of Design.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Selective Service System says that the number of Negroes and other minority members on local draft boards has tripled in the last 18 months. The System's October newsletter said that since the start of 1967 the number of Negroes on boards rose from 278 to 822 as of last August.

The meeting today between Mayor Lindsay and leaders of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association provides an opportunity for reconsideration of the mistaken course that threatens to plunge the city's law-enforcers into a law-breaking program of "job action."

LONDON, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- The House of Lords passed a Government bill today to protect the million Asians and Negroes here against discrimination in jobs, housing, insurance and borrowing. The third reading in the Lords left only the formal royal assent needed to make the controversial race-relations bill law.
Sales and earnings of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation climbed to record levels in the quarter and nine-month periods ended Sept. 30, the company announced yesterday.
SEATTLE, Wash., Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister Keith J. Holyoake of New Zealand left today for Tokyo, ending his visit to the United States.

The Interstate Commerce Commission, which in the last several months has been challenging the nation's railroads on how much money they would save if they didn't operate passenger trains, announced yesterday it would make a study of what it costs the carriers to provide passenger-train service.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, opening its New York season last night at Philharmonic Hall, offered a not too traditional program in -- for the orchestra -- traditional performances, superbly suave and polished.

The Wall Street Journal announced yesterday plans for building its ninth printing plant at South Brunswick, N. J., next year. That plant and one at Riverside, Calif., will print regional editions on offset presses direct from wire facsimile transmission.

The 10th annual dinner dance for the benefit of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York will be held at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof next Tuesday. Two hundred and fifty are expected to attend the invitational event, which will also celebrate the 75th anniversary of the agency.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- With the talks on Vietnam reported to be in a sensitive phase, the French Government has quietly ordered the dissolution of an antiwar organization of Americans residing here.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- President Johnson is expected to sign shortly a bill that would produce a painless "cut" of $771-million in his budget while simultaneously increasing Government spending.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday the suspension, effective today, of dealings in American Depository Receipts (A.D.R.'s) of the Singer Manufacturing Company, Ltd., a British concern.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- A young man who was reported to have displayed a loaded gun was arrested by the police today shortly before Vice President Humphrey appeared at a downtown street rally. The police said that Peter Zimmerman, 22 years old, a margin clerk at A. G. Edwards Stock Brokers in St. Louis, was charged in a warrant with carrying a concealed weapon.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 16 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said tonight the Arab air forces were now 50 per cent stronger than on the eve of the Arab-Israeli war in June, 1967.

The engineering firm of Farkas, Barron Partners has accepted Samuel Alden, a professional engineer, as a partner. Mr. Alden has been with the firm for more than 20 years, most recently as a senior associate.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 16 (AP) -- A contempt of court citation against Mickey Rooney, the actor, was dismissed today. The judge said that Mr. Rooney had paid $1,072 in delinquent alimony to his sixth wife.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Vaccines against rubella have been found highly effective in their first trial against a natural epidemic of the disease.
PARIS, Oct. 16 -- Under Secretary of State Nicholas deB. Katzenbach urged Western European nations today to move toward unity and assume a greater share of "the burden of common defense."

SOME of the most interesting deals relate to problems of controlling the trump suit. A declarer who thinks he has an easy task may find himself in danger of running out of trumps if his trump suit breaks badly.

PITTSBURGH, Oct. 16 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew said today that he did not feel the Republicans were running a "white oriented" campaign, although he indicated that he would probably not make any appearances in Negro communities.

MOSCOW, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The newspaper Literaturnaya Gazeta said today that Jean-Paul Sartre and Bertrand Russell had joined forces with anti-Communist propagandists by opposing the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia.

Strikes in several plants of the Reynolds Metals Company caused a net loss of $2,892,000 in the third quarter, the company reported yesterday. In the three months last year, Reynolds earned $8,509,000.

A QUIET, modest man, with sandy hair and blue eyes, who devotes most of his time to his work . . . In spare time, tinkers with photography, and likes to take long walks on the beach to look at tide pools and the ocean . . .

MILWAUKEE, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Chicago Bulls, behind a 23-point performance by Flynn Robinson, pulled away from the Milwaukee Bucks in the third period, then hung on for an 89-84 victory tonight. It was the National Basketball Association debut at home for the Bucks.
John M. Doar and the Rev. Milton A. Galamison, two strong advocates of school decentralization, were elected last night as president and vice president, respectively, of the Board of Education.
Three of the nation's largest airlines -- T.W.A. American and National -- reported yesterday sharply lower profits for the third quarter and first nine months of this year despite increased revenues.

A controversial soul-rock performance of the National Anthem, sung by the blind pop singer Jose Feliciano before the fifth game of the World Series in Detroit last week, has been rushed into release by RCA Records, on a single disk.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- Two journalists were given suspended six-month sentences today for publishing a letter from President Johnson to Premier Ismet Inonu during the 1964 Cyprus crisis. The journalists, Ferhan Develusoglu and Cuneyt Arcayurek, disclosed that Mr. Johnson had warned Mr. Inonu, then Premier, that Turkey could not expect support from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization if a Soviet attack followed Turkish around intervention in Cyprus.

BERNE, Oct. 16 -- The Swiss Government has offered to let Dr. Ota Sik, former Deputy Premier of Czechoslovakia, remain indefinitely in Switzerland.
The process by which you acquire blue or brown eyes, black or white skin and countless other inherited characteristics depends upon a complex chemical code.
ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- A new heart operation, so delicate that it is performed under a microscope, promises prolonged life for persons whose only other hope would be a transplanted heart.
BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 16 -- A fundamental disagreement on birth control, with potential implications for all of Latin America, has emerged here this week.

President Johnson unsheathed a rapier wit last night in a brief speech in which he chided the Presidential candidates, some noncandidates and the press. Looking fit and relaxed, the President told 2,500 persons gathered for the 23d annual dinner of the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel: "Pretty soon you won't have Lyndon Johnson to kick around any more."
"If you don't dig the blues you got a hole in your soul," says Albert King, a guitarist who digs the blues. "This is what they call blues power."
The Humphrey-Muskie ticket, behind in the polls and needing money, has received a conditional offer of aid from a group that heavily backed Senator Eugene J. McCarthy.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- The United States' hopes for its first Olympic volleyball medal suffered a setback today when Bohumil Golian led Czechoslovakia, the 1964 silver medalist team, to a 15-0, 10-15, 15-7, 15-7 victory.

ATLANTA, Oct. 16 -- A midnight ball and a champagne buffet will be held in the Galleria Promenade of the Atlanta Memorial Arts Center on Oct. 29 after a gala preview benefit of what is believed to be the North American premiere of "King Arthur," the Purcell-Dryden masque.

The Museum of Modern Art has opened an unscheduled display of the latest and probably final design for a New York memorial to the six million Jews killed in concentration camps in World War II. A 6-foot scale model will be on exhibition in the main lobby through Nov. 15.
IN an age of scatter-shot merger activities, Monogram Industries seems almost prosaic with its three basic lines and going on four.
BERLIN, Oct. 16 -- What began during the summer as a spontaneous occupation of women's living quarters by young men at a student village here has won the reluctant approval of the administration.
London stocks moved higher in light trading yesterday. The advance was over a broad front.

Moe Finkelstein, the head of the city high school Football Coaches Association, said last night that the 23 public high schools would continue the football season despite the teachers' strike. "We completely support the United Federation of Teachers in their present efforts to make the schools safe for all teachers and children," he said.

The Justice Department's antitrust division moved yesterday in Federal Court here to force Combustion Engineering, Inc., to divest itself of the 21 per cent of the outstanding stock of the United Nuclear Corporation it acquired last June.
"Adriana Lecouvreur" was given such a satisfying performance last night at the Metropolitan Opera House that it was almost possible to forget that Cilea's music for it is less than first-rate.

A student-faculty committee at Columbia College has recommended means of involving students in decision-making on curriculum, admissions and other college policies. It has also proposed giving them greater control over strictly student matters, such as extracurricular activities and dormitory life.

HONG KONG, Oct. 16 -- A new policy pronouncement from Peking indicates that Mao Tse-tung, the Chinese Communist party chairman, hopes to scrap the party constitution and "party legality" to hand-pick a new hierarchy of loyal lieutenants, some Western political analysts said today.
Zev Bufman, Broadway producer, will meet Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior, in Washington today to discuss the possibility of the producer's taking over operation of Ford's Theater there.

Ford Foundation funds continue to be channeled to the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district, but the foundation is keeping hands off the district's current battles with the teachers' union and the Board of Education.

The all-Czech program by Erich Leinsdorf and the Boston Symphony will be given at the Brooklyn Academy tonight as originally announced.
The Nixon-Agnew campaign organization is putting out 13 million labels, each resembling a postage stamp, bearing the picture of a smiling Richard M. Nixon and the words "Nixon Now."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to block the shipment to Vietnam of 91 Army reservists who contended they had not been properly trained.

HOUSTON, Oct. 16 -- Apollo 7 cruised into the last half of its planned 11-day flight tonight with the three astronauts relaxing after another television appearance and a successful test of the spacecraft's rocket.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 16 (Reuters) -- Indonesia today signed major oil exploration contracts with two American companies that agreed to supply a total of $7.5-million in immediate cash bonuses.

Harry Kaufman, who usually waits five hours each Sunday morning to tee off for a round at Brooklyn's Dyker Beach Municipal Course, won the metropolitan public links championship yesterday after waiting four months.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 16 -- American Jews are to be called upon to help Israel cover the United States bill for an expected sale of Phantom jets by financing a greater part of her nonmilitary needs. NEW HAVEN, Oct. 16 (UPI) -- A Federal court judge in New Haven approved today a petition for the trustees of the financially troubled New Haven Railroad to borrow $4-million from the Penn-Central system on Nov. 1.

The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the shareholdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
NEWARK, Oct. 16 (AP) -- The Newark Star-Ledger today endorsed Hubert H. Humphrey for the Presidency.

The Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday that record highs in sales of electricity for the third quarter had helped raise operating revenues to $574,335,708 for the first nine months.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 16 -- One of the most traditional and recurring 19th-century boyhood dreams involved a dashing young officer entrusted with a crucial message. He rides breakneck over rough terrain until his horse is shot out from under him. He leaps free and dispatches the ambushers with his rapier. He draws his pistol and blasts his way to the edge of a cliff. He hurls himself into the boiling river and swims to safety.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 (AP) -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie carries his soft-sell campaign of mutual trust and common effort back to the middle west tomorrow for a weekend of campaigning. The Vice-Presidential candidate rested at home today after a nine-day swing through East Coast states, ending with visits yesterday in the slums of upper Manhattan and Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 -- Pearl Presnell makes hand-tied lace on a frame that her husband, Mack, now 72, made last year from two boards left over when he built the new outhouse a few years back, two sticks that he used to hang tobacco on, and one broom handle.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 -Brooklyn political and civic figures suggested today that the proposed sale of the Brooklyn Navy Yard to New York City had been snagged by the White House.

Silver futures prices turned upward yesterday. Brokers said the "technical reaction" might, or might not, be a key reversal.

The United States Merchant Marine Academy and State University Maritime College will honor Cornelius Shields, one of America's eminent yachtsman, in a regatta today off Kings Point, L. I. The Corny Shields Regatta will feature the 30-foot, one-design racing and sailing yachts designed by Shields.

THE Metropolitan Knockout Team Championship begins at 1:3.0 P.M. today at the New York Hilton Hotel and continues through Monday evening.

AURORA, N. Y., Oct. 18 (AP) -- John D. Wilson, assisant provost and director of undergraduate education at Michigan State University, was elected today as the 12th president of Wells College. The 37-year-old educator, a defensive halfback on Michigan State's 1952 national championship football team, succeeds Louis J. Long, who is retiring.

The Man o' War stakes, a relatively late arrival on the major thoroughbred scene, continues as an attractive competition for fans and hrosemen alike. Today's renewal of the race, at Belmont Park, has attracted a feild of 13, making for a gross purse of $117,200 and a winner's share of $76,180.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday adjustments in maintenance service charges on some data processing equipment. The adjustments cover both monthly maintenance agreements and maintenance performed on an hourly call basis.

If this were a normal political year, Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff would encounter little difficulty in winning re-election over his inexperienced, lackluster Republican opponent, former Congressman Edwin May. During the past twenty years Mr. Ribicoff has had a distinguished career as a Congressman, as Governor, as a member of the Kennedy Cabinet, and as a United States Senator. He is an able, energetic and creative legislator who has earned re-election.

BERLIN, Oct. 21 -- The East Germans opened a series of political trials today involving students and intellectuals who staged protests in August against the Soviet bloc's invasion of Czechoslovakia.

Prices edged up in modest trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

Stockholders of Gamble-Skogmo, Inc., diversified retail chain, voted yesterday at a special meeting in Minneapolis to change the company's name to Gambles, Inc. The stockholders also approved an increase in the number of directors to 17 from 14.

TRENTON, Oct. 21 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that the state did not have the power to order psychiatric examinations of defendants in first-degree murder trials unless the accused planned to plead insanity.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 2I -- The United States is resuming the delivery of major military equipment to Greece, ending a 17-month selective embargo imposed after a military junta overthrew the parliamentary regime.
Eighty-six used cars brought a total of $197,140 at a Parke-Bernet auction of antique automobiles yesterday, held at Arthur G. Rippey's Veteran Car Museum in Denver.

SYDNEY, Australia, Oct. 21 -- An antivenom serum that will treat the bites of all venomous snakes in Australia and New Guinea has been produced by the Commonwealth Government's serum laboratories. The serum will neutralize the venom of the Taipan death adder, and brown, tiger and black snakes.
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 21 -- Princeton University's dean of students has ordered an investigation of a racial incident on the school campus over the weekend.
BOSTON, Oct. 21 (UPI) -Elston Howard, the Boston Red Sox catcher, announced his retirement as a player today. He said he hoped to land another major league job soon.

The 20th anniversary of the late Dr. Martin Luther King's graduation from Morehouse College, one of the member schools of the United Negro College Fund, will be commemorated Friday night at the third annual ball sponsored by the group's New York Council.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Oct. 21 -- A plan that may eventually unite the Episcopal Church in the United States, the Anglican Church of Canada and the Anglican Church of the West Indies received enthusiastic approval today from two of the top-ranking church leaders of North America.

The National Securities and Research Corporation, a mutual fund concern, announced yesterday that three senior members of its investment staff have been named vice presidents. They are George S. Tamlyn, Victor F. Morris and Richard N. Westbrook.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 21 -- A two-engine, C-47 transport en route from the Tansonnhut airfield at Saigon to Danang crashed in the Central Highlands, about 175 miles northeast of Saigon, today. The 24 passengers and crewmen, all Americans, were killed.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 21 -- Colgate University, Joining Williams and Trinity Colleges, announced plans today for an exchange of students with Vassar College.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 (AP) -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the merger of the Continental Oil Company with Malco Refineries,Inc., violated Federal antitrust laws. This means Continental must give up the assets it acquired from Malco 10 years ago, including Malco's petroleum refinery in Artesia, N.M.

Cassese, then a vice president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, was assigned the job by the P.B.A., which was cooperating in the production of the show.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 21 (AP) -- Loretta Young, the actress, agreed in a compromise settlement today to divide more than $1-million in assets with her estranged husband, Thomas H. A. Lewis, a producer. The Sheik beat Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, before a crowd of 10,443 in the feature heavyweight wrestling exhibition last night at Madison Square Garden. The Sheik, from Syria, was billed as the Arabian champion.

The election of John T. De Palma as a trustee of the Bushwick Savings Bank, Brooklyn, was announced yesterday. He is executive vice president of the Kings County Lafayette Trust Company.

A seat in the United States Senate is a coveted position because with only a hundred members the Senate is a small enough institution for a man of energy and conviction to make his views known and make them count. Five major merger proposals were broken off yesterday as the recent hectic merger movement slowed down somewhat.

A number of experts on public opinion polls agreed yesterday that the 7-point discrepancy between the current Harris and Gallup Polls on the Presidential race is too large to be caused by the normal imprecision of statistical surveys.

FORT WORTH, Tex., Oct. 22 -- Leaving the soot and uncertainty of New York, Vice President Humphrey flew to Texas today and found what he wanted: a state party apparently united behind his banner and new hope of winning the nation's sixth largest electoral prize.
A panel of people who are rarities in the advertising industry addressed themselves yesterday to the topic, "How it is now?"

The Ocean Hill-Brownsville school conflict, with its tragic consequences for all the children of New York City, has yet to be understood in terms which lend themselves to a solution.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 22 -Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower labeled as "nonsense" today a widely held contemporary view "that I conducted the Presidency largely through staff decisions."

I., Oct. 22 -- Billy Haughton, who had hoped to send a three-colt entry of Rum Customer, Bye and Large and Tropic Song against Fulla Napoleon -- and others -- in next Saturday's Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway, learned this morning that he would have to go with only two representatives in the world's richest harness race.

A FORMIDABLE collection of experts assembled at the Harmonic Club here Monday night for a special annual event organized by Bill Root, a member of the 1968 international team. At the end of this week he will begin a 10-day struggle in Atlantic City to qualify for the 1969 team, which will be captained by Oswald Jacoby of Dallas.
NEW HYDE PARK, L. I., Oct. 22 -- Rod Seiling limped off the Skateland rink today, holding his left leg. His only comment muttered softly, was "Ah, nuts."

The return of Apollo 7 after eleven days of nearperfect cruising through outer space is a remarkable tribute to man's capacity to manage almost anything outside his own disordered world. The precision that characterized every phase of the long voyage brings much closer the possibility that men will be able to fly to the moon almost as readily as they now orbit the earth.

The school crisis has occasioned much discussion about decentralization and community control. It begins to appear that this city has grown too large to be governed by the kind of men we now have in public office, and it would be a practical step to divide the five boroughs, each of which is a large city unto itself.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 22 -Aldie Belle, owned by Bittersweet Farm of Norwalk, Conn., took a commanding lead tonight in the regular working hunter division of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Oct. 22 -A Brazilian newsman who visited a prison for American fliers in Hanoi earlier this month said the airmen were well-treated but appeared confused about their participation in the Vietnam war.

About 175 supporters and committee members of the Society for the Rehabilitation of the Facially Disfigured are expected at a dinner dance on Sunday at Raffles, a new private club in the SherryNetherland.

The Neiman-Marcus Company of Texas -- famous for the prestige appeal of its merchandise -- was reported last night to be merging with Broadway-Hale Stores, Inc., operator of the largest chain of department stores on the West Coast. Broadway-Hale is expected to be the parent company.
Wall Street's back-office paperwork problem has moved into the international area.

LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 22 -- The United States chess team scored its third straight victory today by defeating Australia 2 1/2-1/2, with one game adjourned, in the fourth session of the preliminary rounds of the 53-team competition in the 18th Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.
Interest rates on key new issues of corporate and taxexempt bonds were lowered slightly yesterday, and investors balked at accepting them quickly.
For the second day in a row, speculative interest in commodity futures centered on fast-moving silver and sugar. In one case, the reason was technical, and in the other, fundamentals were involved.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Lester B. Pearson, former Prime Minister, announced today the names of a group of seven men, each from a different country, who will be members of his World Bank commission looking into international development policy.

MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Premier Mauno Koivisto of Finland arrived in Moscow today for a holiday. He was met at the railroad station by Premier Aleksel N. Kosygin and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Piere Franco Vianelli of Italy won the Olympic 196-kilometer (122.5-mile) bicycle race today. Denmark's Leif Mortensen won the silver medal.

These are tense days again in Yugoslavia, full of anxieties such as that small country has not experienced since shortly after the death of Stalin a decade and a half ago. Once again both the rulers and the ruled in Yugoslavia are united in dread of foreign invasion -- and in resolve to fight, if necessary, in defense of their homeland.

The women's division of Maimonides Institute will hold its annual luncheon and fashion show at the Americana next Wednesday. Proceeds will enable mentally handicapped children to attend the institute in Far Rockaway, Queens.
A seat on the American Stock Exchange was sold yesterday for $277,000, a historic high and $2,000 higher than the preceding sale on Oct. 14. Seats now are quoted at $180,000 bid, $295,000 asked.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art is offering a series of study programs for New York City elementary and high school students affected by the citywide teachers' strike.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Joseph Palmer, United States Assistant Secretary of State, met with Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster today as part of a five-day visit to South Africa.

A former stockholder of the Delhi-Taylor Oil Corporation has filed a lawsuit against the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company and Joseph E. Seagram Sons, Inc., alleging that the two companies have failed to provide proper accounting of income from former properties of Delhi-Taylor.

The evening at the Fillmore East began as an avant-garde theatrical audience-participation event to aid the legal defense fund for Columbia University students facing prison sentences in connection with the student strike there last spring.

SINGAPORE -- In a small, temporary building in the middle of the vast British naval base here, a freshly painted sign reads: "Swan Hunter Group Limited, Managing Agents."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Americans for Constitutional Action endorsed 148 House and Senate candidates today, declaring that they should be elected to "bring about the change the forgotten Americans now demand."
MOSCOW, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The Soviet press made its first mention of the Kennedy-Onassis marriage today by questioning the bride's taste and deriding the publicity in America's news media.

The Kennecott Copper Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter, before extraordinary items, rose to $41,745,434, or $1.26 a share, from $9,665,927, or 29 cents a share, a year earlier.
An angry Westchester commuter called on the Penn Central yesterday to be as energetic about improving commuter service as it is about painting its new corporate symbol on its rolling stock.

When the Federal Government first started to subsidize high-speed rail experiments along the Washington New York Boston corridor, John Connor, then Secretary of Commerce, predicted that by 1966 trains would be speeding along those routes at 150 miles an hour. Another company joined the ranks of those seeking control of the United Fruit Company -- the International Harwood Company. The company describes itself as a diversified investing and economic consulting concern in New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent and her con, Lyn, arrived at the White House today to be close to her sister, Mrs. Charles S. Robb, who is expecting a baby. Mrs. Robb says the baby could come at hany time now.

The New York City Opera's production of Handel's "Julius Caesar" is as handsome a show as one can find anywhere in New York. For Government securities dealers in Wall Street, the chief surprise in the Treasury's $11.9-billion refinancing plans outlined yesterday was the unexpected decision to included a six-year note in addition to the expected 18-month note.

Directors of the Cessna Aircraft Company proposed yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock and announced their intention to raise the dividend to 20 cents a share on the new shares. The split is not expected to be completed before next March.

Traders jumped into the world sugar futures market yesterday for a quick fling after getting the news that a partial world price agreement had been reached. In record trading, prices moved up sharply.
The American Electric Power Company earned an indicated $22.73-million, or 39 cents a share, in the third quarter of 1968, compared with $21,686,000, or 38 cents a share, in the quarter last year.

The city teachers' union yesterday rejected an offer from the Ocean Hill-Brownsville governing board to permit a controversial group of union teachers to return to classroom duties in the district.

The election of Joe E. Hutton of Equitable Securities, Morton Co., Nashville, Tenn., as president of the National Security Traders Association was announced yesterday at its 35th annual convention in Palm Springs, Calif. Morton N. Weiss, executive vice president of Singer Mackie, Inc., New York, was elected second vice president.

Maids at many major hotels in the city refused to work overtime yesterday, causing some inconvenience to guests. The maids, members of the New York City Hotel and Motel Trades Council, have been seeking, with other hotel employes, to have their contracts reopened to gain higher wages.

Milton S. Eisenhower, brother of former President Eisenhower, yesterday endorsed the candidacy of Richard M. Nixon and Gov. Spiro T. Agnew, saying that "the nation needs new leader ship, new ideas, new directions."

Leaders of the major Conservative and Reform rabbinic groups in this country met for the first time yesterday and agreed to cooperate in developing a "liberal religious alternative" to Orthodox Judaism within the state of Israel.

Dr. Benjamin Spock, one of the sponsors of New York State's Freedom and Peace party, will speak on behalf of the comedian Dick Gregory, the party's candidate for President, tonight on radio station WQXR.

WESTPORT, Conn., Oct. 23 -- The Western Connecticut Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society will give its annual Fan Ball on Saturday at the Rolling Hills Country Club in Wilton. Norton Simon, Inc., announced yesterday that it is holding discussion on the possible acquisition of Renfield Importers, Ltd., an importer, distiller and distributor of wine and liquors.

James L. Buckley and three "Buckley Belles" in red, white and blue costumes had just stationed themselves at the exit to the Chevrolet plant in Tarrytown yesterday when, on the other side of the parking lot, lights flashing, came a motorcade.

John D. Rockefeller 3d described student activists last night as "in many ways the elite of our young people" and said that "instead of worrying about how to suppress the youth revolution we of the older generation should be worrying about how to sustain it."

HOUSTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The space agency said today that it had asked the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to design a "super Gemini" space bus capable of ferrying up to nine astronauts into orbit and back.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 -- Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign army moved across Texas and on to California today, intent on recovering ground that it lost last summer and heartened by evidence that there was ample fight left in elements of the old Democratic coalition.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The 83,000-ton Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth left Southamption today on her last trans-Atlantic voyage to New York.
PITTSBURGH, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Jim Pappin, Bobby Hull and Doug Mohn scored two goals each tonight to lead the Chicago Black Hawks to an 8-5 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Planned Parenthood - World Population announced today the establishment of a national center to help community agencies develop family-planning services available to "all 5.3 million medically indigent U.S. women who need and want them."
PARIS, Oct. 23 -- Babar, the lovable elephant of the picture books who has delighted children for almost four decades, is moving into the electronic age.
Plans for the construction and expansion of major facilities in Europe that will cost more than $200-million were announced yesterday by the Dow Chemical Company.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Two boxers from the United States gained the Olympic semi-finals today. They were a light heavyweight, John Baldwin of Detroit, and Ronnie Harris of Canton, Ohio, a lightweight.

More than 1,100 patrons of America's ski racing development program attended New York's second annual ski ball in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night. Thirty members of the United States Ski Team were present.
The Nelman-Marcus Company, Dallas, and Broadway-Hale Stores, Los Angeles, conrfimed reports yesterday that they have agreed in principle to a merger.
Rodney C. Gott, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Machine Foundry Company, has been elected to the board of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, a leading department-store chain.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- During the Watts riots in 1965, the Defense Department requested White House clearance for 30 Air Force planes to fly California National Guard troops to Los Angeles.

CAPETOWN, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Dr. Christian N. Barnard, the first human heart transplant surgeon, was admitted to Groote Schuur Hospital today suffering from "a mild gastro-duodenal hemorrhage." The hospital's acting medical superintendent, Dr. C. W. Vivier, said Dr. Barnard's condition possibly was due to "stress."

United Air Lines, Inc., yesterday reported a drop in third-quarter earnings to $20.5-million, or $1.11 a share, from $30.9-million, or $1.80 a share, a year earlier. In the nine months ended Sept. 30, earnings fell to $36.9-million, or $1.98 a share, from $63.1-million, or $3.71 a share.
More than a dozen local, national and international organizations will benefit from the annual antiques fair and sale to be held from Nov. 5 through 8 at the Congregational Church of Manhasset.
New York Airways, the airline that has familiarized the city with helicopters, will soon switch to cheaper fixed-wing STOL (short take-off and landing) planes for the bulk of its runs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The nation's gold stock rose by $74-million in September, the second consecutive monthly increase, the Treasury disclosed today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The San Francisco Examiner, which endorsed Richard M. Nixon in his 1960 Presidential campaign against John F. Kennedy, today endorsed Vice President Humphrey over Mr. Nixon.
A 20-inch water main ruptured early yesterday at Grand Concourse and East Tremont Avenue in the Bronx, sending water gushing into a subway station and snarling service on the IND line.
ROME, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Vatican officials reacted with disbelief today to Cardinal Cushing's statement that the former Mrs. Kennedy could marry "whomever she wants."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- Two of the most articulate leaders of the youth movement -- one who urges revolutionary action to overthrow the political system and another who tried to work through it -- agreed today on why the youth of the nation is frustrated.
CANBERRA, Australia, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- Prime Minister John Gorton was presented with a partly-eaten cake by William H. Crook, the United States Ambassador, today.

THE affinity between bridge and chess, the two great intellectual games, is an obvious one; so one might expect to find one or two persons equally expert at both games. Many chess experts are good bridge players and vice versa, but to scale both peaks seems to be impossible, since the mental effort and time required are too great.
ST. LOUIS, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a labor representation election at the aerospace plant of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation this month was a tie.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 23 -- Barbara Simpson of Canada enjoys wearing the leading rider's sash at the Pennsylvania National Horse Show. She came out tonight and won the international fault-and-out class on Australis.

Arthur J. Goldberg announced yesterday that former supporters of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for President had formed the New Coalition for Humphrey-Muskie to win support for the Democratic ticket.
SINGAPORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- About 70 Maoist youths set fire to a bus in a fashionable area of Singapore today and then went on to wreck a local headquarters of the governing People's Action party.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted Guido Iozzi Jr., president of the Baltimore Building and Construction Trades Council, today on charges of extorting $28,000 from contractors and the owner of a building.

Peter Glenville, stage and film director, is restaging the $720,000 musical. "Dear World," starring Angela Lansbury. He succeeded Lucia Victor after the show, written by Jerry Herman, Robert E. Lee and Jerome Lawrence, had been in rehearsal for two and a half weeks.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Olympic championship basketball game between the United States and Yugoslavia on Friday night will be telecast live to the United States by the American Broadcasting Company starting at 11 P.M., New York time, officials said today.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Peter Macdonal, general manager of the Harris Newspapers, based in Hutchinson, Kan., is the new president of the Inland Daily Press Association. Gordon Craig, chairman and president of the Booth Newspapers, Detroit, was named vice president at the election yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The State Department said that the United States and North Korea met for more than three hours today at Panmunjom on the subject of release of the United States intelligence ship Pueblo and its 82-man crew.

Almost a third of the residents of a new Barnard College dormitory today defied university regulations that men be out of the dorms by midnight -- though not all had men in their rooms after that hour.

PERTH, Scotland, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Pamela Teeguarden, a 17-year-old tennis player from Los Angeles, defeated Diane Bridger, of Britain, 6-4, 6-2, today to reach the quarter-finals in an indoor tournament.

IN the dog-show world, Jim and Helen Warwick are a noted judging team. They have ruled in rings from coast to coast, in England and Scotland. They are also known for Labrador retrievers, and their Lockerbie Kennels at Little Silver, N. J., has sent out some top ones. But to an earlier generation, the Warwicks were much better known in the entertainment world.
THE HEART-KEEPER. By Francoise Sagan. Translated by Robert Westhoff. 128 pages. Dutton. $3.95.
The elections of William H. Palm as a director and executive vice president and of Jack T. Walker as senior vice president of the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company were announced yesterday.

IF James M. Caine had ever written teen-age romance, it might have been something like Stephen Geller's short novel. "She Let Him Continue," the screen version of which opened as "Pretty Poison" yesterday at the Harris Theater on 42d Street and in neighborhood houses.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 23 (AP) -- Israeli and Egyptian jet fighters clashed today for the first time since the Arab-Israeli war of June, 1967, in a brief action above the Suez Canal.

BOSTON, Oct. 23 -- Richard Cardinal Cushing, rebuking critics of Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, has termed "a lot of nonsense" suggestions that she is "excommunicated" from the Roman Catholic Church and is a "public sinner" because of her marriage to Aristotle Socrates Onassis.

LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 23 -- The United States chess team was upset by Denmark, 2 1/2-1 1/2, today in its fourth round of the preliminaries of the 53-team 18th Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.

Like the American involvement in Vietnam, the teachers' strike in New York City has escalated beyond all reason, threatens to engulf in disaster the parties involved if it is not brought to a conclusion and yet cannot possibly end in complete victory for either side.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- The Canadian kayak four-man crew lost a chance to qualify for the Olympic canoeing semi-finals today because they were not fast enough on land.

AT the close of Martha Graham's last performance in London in 1967, yards of black-and-green-checked material were suddenly unfurled from the balcony and loges. According to a young woman enthusiastically heaving her end of the cloth from the heights, the checked pattern -- a reference to the American artist's forebears -- represented the Graham pattern.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, Oct. 23 -- Governor Rockefeller suggested today that one of the first things Richard M. Nixon should do if he is elected President is to appoint a high-level committee to study possible changes in the nominating convention and Electoral College systems.
Robert T. Connor, the Republican Borough President of Richmond, demanded yesterday that Mayor Lindsay be removed from office for failing to settle the teachers' strike.
The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday consolidated net income of $72.1-million in the third quarter, equal to 66 cents a share, on record sales of $2,619,100,000.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 23 -- A new franchise in a familiar setting was the order of business for the New York Knickerbockers tonight, as they faced the Milwaukee Bucks for the first time.

ROANOKE, Va., Oct. 23 -- George C. Wallace was met here today by the Louisiana segregationist, Leander H. Perez, one day after Mr. Wallace's Vice Presidential running mate, Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, indicated he did not oppose the integration of public schools.

HONG KONG, Oct. 23 (Reuters) -- The Chinese Communist Foreign Ministry issued its 464th "serious warning" to the United States today over violations of Chinese territorial waters and airspace, Hsinhua, the official press service, reported.

Two of the five counties making up New York City are electing District Attorneys to complete the terms of incumbents who have resigned to run for the Supreme Court. In both cases the voters have a splendid opportunity to improve the administration of justice.
MIKE TALIAFERRO, the quarterback of the Boston Patriots, will have a $210 bounty on his head when he is attacked by the New York Jets' pass-rushers Sunday at Shea Stadium.
The New York and the American Stock Exchanges reported yesterday changes in the share holding of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.
This is Wallace or anti-Wallace Day in New York, depending on the viewpoint.

LIMA, Peru, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The new military Government suspended constitutional guarantees today for an additional 30 days "to maintain internal order." The emergency measure was announced by the President of the revolutionary government, Gen. Juan Velasco Alvarado.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that outstanding commercial paper rose to a record seasonally adjusted level of $21,003,000,000 in September, 5 per cent higher than the previous high of $20.4-billion in August.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- Dick Gregory, the Negro comedian running for President, ran afoul of the Treasury Department today because his campaign handbills look too much like dollar bills.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 23 -- Ground action has increased sharply in the last 36 hours, with almost 225 enemy soldiers reported killed in engagements in the Danang area.
The Union Carbide Corporation, reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter was up a little, but down for the first nine months.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Oct. 23 -- Ron Stonitsch set a course record today in leading the undefeated C. W. Post College cross-country team to a 15-49 victory over the New York State Maritime Academy. Stonitsch was timed in 25 minutes 25.1 seconds for the five miles.

"BEYOND THE LAW," which was shown at the New York Film Festival and which opened yesterday at the Art Theater, is so much better than Norman Mailer's last movie, "Wild 90," that it is possible to like it a lot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- New orders to manufacturers of durable goods rose sharply in September, in a further indication of delay in the widely expected slowdown in the economy, the Commerce Department reported today.
KEY WEST, Fla., Oct. 23 (UPI) -- A bearded freelance photographer hijacked a small plane and forced it to fly to Cuba today. He left his wife and three children in Key West.
PRAGUE, Oct. 23 (UPI) -- The Czechoslovak press published admiring accounts of the Apollo 7 space flight today and disdainfully noted that a Soviet radar ship watched the recovery operation.
BRIGHT sunlight poured into Anne Weiskopf's kitchen, and she was indulging herself in what she considers the finest breakfast of all.

GENEVA, Oct. 23 -- A United Nations conference agreed here tonight on the terms of a five-year pact for regulating world trade in sugar -- without, however, the participation of either the United States or the Common Market.

JACKSONVILLE, N. C., Oct. 23 (AP) -- A Marine helicopter crashed today at a Jacksonville shopping center killing its marine pilot and crew chief, according to a spokesman at the New River Marine Air Station. The main portion of the helicopter fell through the roof of a supermarket. No civilian casualties were reported.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- In Boston a few days ago, "Teddy in '72" bumper stickers were selling briskly at $1 apiece. In New York, green-and-white buttons marked "EMK 1972" were mailed under a signature of HOPE (Help Organize People Early), along with this message:

Another tired, overplayed West Division club was methodically chopped down by the Rangers last night as the New Yorkers trounced the revamped Oakland Seals, 6-1.

A supper dance for the 500 people who purchase $100 tickets to the Nov. 10 concert of "Candide" will be held at the Plaza after the operetta's performance at Philharmonic Hall. The evening will benefit the Foundation for International Child Health.
NAGS HEAD, N. C., Oct. 23 -- The surf was a welter of white and tumbling water laced with foam and bits of Sargasso weed, and the fish were eager to bite.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Federal Power Commission released details today of a new technique for designing natural-gas pipelines, using computers to determine the most efficient and economical methods among a number of variables. LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 (AP) -- A surgical technique said to be a potential substitute for transplants in many serious heart disease cases was described here today.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 23 -- Nearly a hundred riot policemen armed with tear - gas equipment and wielding billy clubs clashed with University of Ghana students who demonstrated at the Legon campus for the second day.

LAST night's televised profile of Sophia Loren, the film star, reminded the viewer that the movie fan magazine never dies but was only wired, for sound and movement. The idolatrous hour over the network of the American Broadcasting Company detailed the actress's rise from an unmarried mother's gawky waif on the streets of Naples to mistress of the sumptuous Villa Ponti, where she and her husband, Carlo Ponti, the producer, live in monarchial splendor.

FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 23 (AP) -- Vortex, with Sal Guglielmini driving, won the New Irvington Hotel Pace at Freehold Raceway today. The winner returned $4.40, $2.80 and $2.60. Lift Off was second, paying $3 and $2.80 and Blaze Oregon third at $3.40.

BERLIN, Oct. 23 -- Student activity in East Germany in protest of the invasion of Czechoslovakia led to the arrest of more than 100 youths, many of them children of prominent political figures, according to reports reaching West Berlin.

Nine Cuban exiles, described as members of a military organization plotting the overthrow of Premier Fidel Castro through assassination and terror, were seized by the police yesterday in pre-dawn raids and charged with a series of bombings here of offices of nations that trade with Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 -- The Treasury, its cash needs met for the rest of the year, offered today to holders of $5.6-billion of securities maturing in November and December the choice of an 18-month note yielding 5.73 per cent or a six-year note yielding 5 3/4 per cent.

CHICAGO, Oct. 23 -- A life-insurance executive told a group of mortgage bankers here today that a 10 per cent interest rate on mortgages would be as common in 10 years as an 8 per cent rate is at present.
BATON ROUGE, La., Oct. 23 (AP) -- The Baton Rouge Morning Advocate endorsed Mr. Nixon today.

The first annual ASCAP-Deems Taylor awards, given for outstanding books, newspaper and magazine articles published on music, were presented yesterday at the Library and Museum of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center.

OTTAWA, Oct. 23 -- Canadian taxpayers have learned that they will pay substantially more taxes next year to help the Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau balance its books while paying for the country's increasingly expensive new welfare and educational programs.
TOKYO, Oct. 23 (AP) -- The National League champion St. Louis Cardinals arrived in Tokyo today, to play 18 games against Japanese baseball teams. The Cardinals open Friday against the Yomiuri Giants.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 23 -- Like every small town, Olympic Village has its unofficial center for meeting, trading gossip and hanging around. It is the Adidas shoe store, a square, one-story structure off the main plaza directly in front of the building that houses the American men athletes. It is not a large store and it is made smaller by the hulking Iranian wrestlers, the Yugoslav basketball players, the Mongols who travel in packs.

The Council for Parks and Playgrounds at 120 East 86th Street will conduct a bus tour to Staten Island on Saturday. The State Insurance Department announced yesterday approval of a plan of operation for the New York Property Insurance Underwriting Association, a new assigned-risk insurance pool for fire and extended coverage. Charles A. Schoerech, the state Republican chairman, has asked county chairmen to meet on Monday with Governor Rockefeller and Richard M. Nixon, the Republican Presidential candidate.
HAZLETON, Pa., Oct. 24 -- Richard M. Nixon pledged tonight that if elected President he would restore "clear-cut" American military superiority over the Soviet Union.
The city hopes to recover about $2-million from persons who cheat on their city income taxes by claiming residence in a suburb while also maintaining apartments in the city.
ATHENS, Oct. 24 -- Aristotle Socrates Onassis flew to Athens today to talk business while his wife, the former Mrs. John F. Kennedy, went swimming off the Onassis-owned island of Skorpios.
EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Oct. 24 (AP) -- General LeMay denied today charges by Senator Kennedy that the American Independent party was directed by extremist groups.
PARIS, Oct. 24 -- Jacques Soustelle returned to France today after seven years of exile but was ostentatiously ignored by the French police in perhaps the ultimate insult to a pardoned subversive.

GREAT NECK, L. I., Oct. 24 -- Jay Kramer, chairman of the State Labor Relations Board, disclosed tonight a program designed to end the teachers' strike. He said it had the support of some leaders in the Legislature.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 -- At 7 o'clock this morning, Mrs. Victoria de Miguel de Torres lined up outside the Olympic Pool to buy tickets for tonight's four-final swimming program.
ROME, Oct. 24 -- The Vatican expressed concern today over indiscipline amounting to open rebellion by an entire Parish in Florence.

BONN, Oct. 24 -- The Defense Committee of the West German Bundestag voted authorization today for the Federal Government's purchase of 88 Phantom aircraft from the United States for close to $500-million.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -Foreign purchases of United States stocks fell in August, but this appeared to follow a pattern of relatively low purchases in the "middle month" of each quarter -- February, May, August and November.
NEWARK, Oct. 24 -- Dominick A. Spina, Newark's Police Director, was accused in Superior Court today of having deliberately overlooked "a vast network of crime at his very feet."
Jacques Barzun, a leading scholar and critic of higher education, charged yesterday that American universities had destroyed themselves by turning into "a public utility."

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 24 -Skillful Danny Lopez, aged 19, rode Cappella fast and exactly right to become the winner tonight of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show's "big jump," a highlight of the open jumper competition.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- If Hubert H. Humphrey is successful in his Presidential bid, certain of his financial backers can count on a White House invitation and other flattery. But if he loses, they may have to settle for cuff links all around.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 -- Standing barefoot, her frosted blond hair still stringy wet, Debbie Meyer reached the golden step on the Olympic victory platform for a record third time tonight.
" DARK MEADOW," revived last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music by Martha Graham and her dance company, was once considered one of Miss Graham's most difficult, if rewarding, works.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 -- Rumors that some American athletes were accepting payola from equipment manufacturers were whispered even before the final Olympic tryouts. The whispers became a guarded shout the day after the conclusion of the track and field program until this Olympic capital was abuzz with wild speculation.
In one of the most active trading sessions in recent weeks, grain and soybeans futures prices dipped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 24 -- The New York Knicker-bockers explored a brand new link of the National Basketball Association treadmill today as they visited Arizona for the first time in their much-traveled existence for a game with the Phoenix Suns tonight.
CHRISTMAS trees of Plexiglas? Why not, in the space age?

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -Top officials of two of the nation's largest corporations and one of its biggest banks have been raising thousands of dollars to give to political candidates through committees whose names do not reveal the actual source of the campaign funds.
PRINEVILLE, Ore., Oct. 23 -- Reluctantly, but as surely as snow has already mantled central Oregon's mountain peaks, Crook County appears to favor Richard M. Nixon for President.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 24 -- Israeli occupation authorities warned today that they would fire on west-bank Arabs violating curfews if that became necessary to maintain public order.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- Lyndon B. Johnson will present the next President with the results of a comprehensive study of alternative world strategies, the foreign bases that each would require and the cost of each package.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 24 -- The South Vietnamese Government and the Vietcong announced today that they were freeeing some prisoners.

With reference to your editorial "Besieged City" (Oct. 19). New York City might consider defending itself against civic extortion, as practiced by public employes calling in "sick," by establishing the daily average of sick employes during normal times, then increase that amount by. say, 65 per cent.

Le Cerisier, owned and trained by Frank H. Merrill, won the 30th running of the New York Turf Writers Cup at Belmont Park yesterday. The outcome was a surprise to most of the crowd of 21,030, inasmuch as the field for the 2 1/2-

The Transportation Administration called on the city yesterday to initiate studies for a major STOL strip on the Hudson River. The agency also asked for funds to seek sites for hydrofoil and air-cushion craft and to develop airports in Queens and on Staten Island.
FROM its new highly functional offices at 410 Park Avenue, the National Football League is working hard this week at promoting the Green Bay-Dallas game to be played on Monday night in Dallas.
ANYONE who likes good design and toys -- and the two don't go together nearly as often as they should -- will want to take a look at Georg Jensen's new toy section on the store's third floor.

Policemen in overpowering numbers made a fortress last night out of Madison Square Garden and adjacent streets, enabling George Corley Wallace of Alabama to hold a Southern-style Presidential rally replete with dime-store Confederate flags, "Dixie" and the kind of oratory that sent part of his 16,000 listeners home shouting "White power."
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- President Johnson said today that he had not yet received a reply from Hanoi to his latest proposals for a complete halt in the bombing of North Vietnam.
Tenneco, Inc., reported yesterday record earnings for the third quarter and the first nine months of the year and predicted that year-end results would exceed earlier estimates.

The continued intransigence of the United Federation of Teachers in prolonging the strike that has shut down more than half of New York City's schools is as saddening as it is destructive of the rights of the children, of the teachers, and of the communities that make up this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The chairman of the Penn Central Company said today that he did not think it would make too much difference to his business whether Richard M. Nixon or Hubert H. Humphrey was elected President of the United States.
The formation of a faculty committee to seek a new president for Columbia University was announced yesterday by the Executive Committee of the Faculty.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- A University of California criminologist said today that the New York City police force was the most effective in the country in controlling group violence.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- Sweden's Olympic modern pentathlon team, which won the team bronze medals last week, was disqualified today and ordered to return the medals because of violating Olympic rules against the use of stimulants.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- If a campaign issue is to be defined as something that really agitates the ordinary voter on a nationwide scale, then the domestic issues of this campaign can generally be grouped under the heading "the cities."
Cluett, Peabody Co., Inc., announced yesterday record sales and net income for the third quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 and also two new acquisitions in the apparel-manufacturing field.

CHICAGO, Oct. 24 -- Information supplied for a magazine article by James Earl Ray, who is accused of murdering the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., has apparently helped the Federal Bureau of Investigation to trace Ray's whereabouts during two months of last year.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Charges that free-style wrestling matches at the Olympic Games were thrown were made today by Tom Evans, head coach of the United States free-style wrestling squad.

The Cunard Line is having second thoughts about selling its 83,000-ton liner Queen Elizabeth outright to a group of American entrepreneurs for a second career as a resort-museum-hotel attraction at Port Everglades, Fla.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 24 -- Although Richard M. Nixon holds only a slight lead over Vice President Humphrey in the East, he has a solid lead in the Middle West and Far West, according to the Gallup Poll.

EAST NORWICH, L. I., Oct. 24 -- Mike Krak, who was born in Czechoslovakia and learned to play golf in West Virginia, won the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association championship today by four strokes.
T. S. Eliot's original manuscript of "The Waste Land," bearing extensive editing changes by Ezra Pound, has been held secretly in the New York Public Library for 10 years.
LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 24 -- The United States chess team defeated Venezuela 3 1/2-1/2 today in the sixth round of the preliminaries of the 53-team 18th Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.

More than 5,000 people roared their opposition yesterday to George C. Wallace's bid for the Presidency at a noontime garment center rally set up by labor, political, civil rights and civil liberties supporters of Paul O'Dwyer for the United States Senate.

IF you are beginning to think that the large number of suspense and spy novels of intrigue are exhausting the genre, then the books by a couple of veteran craftsmen listed at the head of this column will restore your interest. They'll do more than restore it; they'll keep it sharply alive. If you enjoy this kind of skulking and mayhem, no more need be said.
ADEN, Southern Yemen, Oct. 24 -- Republican and royalist forces in neighboring Yemen are reported to be engaged in a serious clash, with several thousand men on either side involved.

PERTH, Australia, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Gary Player of South Africa lipped the cup with a 66-foot putt on the 18th hole and missed equalling the course record on his first round of the Australian open golf championship at Lake Karrinyup Club near here today.
A 16-story commercial building at 251-255 West 30th Street has been purchased for $925,000 by an investing group headed by Harry B. Helmsley.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., who bad previously supported the Presidential aspirations of Eugene J. McCarthy, Robert F. Kennedy and George S. McGovern, and then had praised Governor Rockefeller's Presidential campaign, yesterday endorsed Vice President Humphrey.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The National Labor Relations Board upheld today the relatively new practice of labor unions banding together to coordinate their bargaining with a big corporation.
The money market eased substantially during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures released yesterday indicated.
A multimillion-dollar prescription for the service and equipment ills of the Penn Central commuter service was offered yesterday by the state's riding railroad expert.
Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday it intended to seek control of the Sinclair Oil Corporation through a tender offer valued at about $1.42-billion.
Major executive changes were announced yesterday by the Grace Line.
BETHESDA, Md., Friday, Oct. 25 -- Mrs. Charles S. Robb, the older daughter of President and Mrs. Johnson, gave birth to a 7-pound, 8-ounce girl early today.
Members of the New York Stock Exchange have approved by a vote of 925 to 266 the first major reduction in commission charges in Big Board history.
Five' Jewish organizations that participated in a meeting with Mayor Lindsay on the New York school crisis have denied the Mayor urged them to "control Albert Shanker and his U.F.T."
MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- The first report of the withdrawal of a Soviet military unit from Czechoslovakia appeared in the Soviet press today.
Fading hopes for a quick breakthrough in the Vietnamese peace overtures kept the stock market in a downward trend yesterday.
MEXICO CITY, Oct. 24 (AP) -- The United States basketball team will battle tall Yugoslavia tomorrow night, heavily favored to notch its seventh straight Olympic gold medal.
Prices turned downward as trading volume rose on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.
The New York Telephone Company reported yesterday declines in net income for three and 12 months ended Sept. 30, despite higher operating revenues in both periods.
Directors of the GAC Corporation and the Gulf American Corporation yesterday authorized a merger which had been announced last July 17.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (AP) -- Warrie Lynn Smith, a close friend of President Johnson's oldest daughter, is being sent to Chile as an officer of the United States Information Agency, despite the cutback of foreign service officers overseas.

The Board of Estimate heard testimony yesterday from 58 witnesses for and against the origination of programs by three cable television companies in the city and postponed a decision on the expansion of franchises until Nov. 7, the board's next meeting date.

Members of the Detroit Tigers earned $10,936.66 each for winning the World Series and members of the losing St. Louis Cardinals received a share of $7,078.71 each from the player pool, Charles Segar, secretary-treasurer of the baseball commissioner's office, announced yesterday.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Oct. 24 (AP) -- The Apollo 7 astronauts discussed today their 11-day space mission with the next two Apollo crews, including the three men who may circle the moon on Christmas Day.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 -- The steep climb in mortgage interest rates that began late last year came to an end in September, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The "effective interest rate" on mortgages for purchase of new homes in September was 7.23 per cent, almost unchanged from the 7.24 per cent figure of August.
The city faced labor trouble in a new sector yesterday as large numbers of policemen continued to call in "sick" and firemen refused to perform nonemergency duties.

The argument within the Johnson Administration that the Soviet occupation of Czechoslovakia requires further delay in opening missile-curb talks with Moscow has now been challenged publicly by the director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, William Foster.

Thousands of parents of public -school children have been calling the headmasters and admissions officers of the city's private schools, wheedling, cajoling and imploring that they take their children -- victims of the teachers' strike -- into classes.

BUFFALO, Oct. 24 -- Four men and a woman were arrested by Buffalo police and Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today on charges of conspiracy in connection with the theft and attempted interstate transportation of art treasures whose value is estimated at more than $1.5million.

DICKSON CITY, Pa., Oct 24 -- Standing on a red, white and blue platform, across the street from "Lenn's Home Cooked Meals" and "Monaghan's Barber Shop," Senator Edmund S. Muskie told 600 supporters this morning that he was happy to be in the town where his Polish immigrant father first lived and worked in the United States in the early 1900's.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Hundreds of policemen battered their way into a campus building at the University of California early today and recaptured it from student insurgents who had held it all night.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass. Oct. 24 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy made a passionate appeal today to the supporters of his two slain brothers to reject the "dark" and "extremist" movement led by George C. Wallace.

WALL STREET oil analysts were wondering yesterday whether Gulf Western Industries' interest in Sinclair Oil would draw bids from companies rich in crude oil that could use Sinclair's refining and marketing network.

Richard M. Nixon, Republican nominee for President, who for two years has not appeared on any major television network interview program, agreed yesterday to meet a panel of reporters on "Face the Nation" from 6:30 to 7 P.M. on Sunday over the facilities of the Columbia Broadcasting System.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Oct. 24 -- Disciplinary action was taken today by the California Board of Medical Examiners against seven physicians for performing therapeutic abortions on women threatened with giving birth to deformed children.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 24 -- The Harvard Crimson, Harvard University's undergraduate newspaper, urged its readers in an editorial today not to vote for any of the three major Presidential candidates.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The United States Supreme Court was told today that if it struck down state laws imposing residency requirements on welfare recipients, it would, in effect, outlaw all state-imposed waiting periods, including those for voting, divorce actions and licensing.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 (UPI) -- The Government conceded today that draft regulations concerning delinquents "are not as clear as they might be" but urged the Supreme Court to wait a while before examining them.

The General Motors Corporation, the nation's largest automobile maker, reported an increased third-quarter net income of $182-million yesterday on record sales for the quarter.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

Manhattan's West Side sprawls unspectacularly northward from 59th to 125th Street, an immense checkerboard of wealth and poverty, of black, white, yellow and brown, a three-mile-long tract that is simultaneously running up and running down.

THE eighth International Team Trials begin tonight in Atlantic City, N.J., and will be the last in the series. There was a long day of words and music by Donovan here yesterday. He starred at an afternoon "tea party" for the press at the Plaza Hotel and went on to give a pair of evening concerts at Carnegie Hall.

ROME, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Sandro Mazzinghi of Italy retained his world junior middleweight boxing title tonight in a no contest decision against the United States challenger, Freddie Little, that left Little's manager charging an "international scandal."

The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that it had arrested 11 men and broken up a large loan-shark network in Brooklyn that had financed its operations by masterminding truck hijacks throughout the city.
Paul O'Dwyer, who has steadfastly refused to support Hubert H. Humphrey for the Presidency, said yesterday that he thought the Vice-President would carry the state on Election Day.

HERSHEY, Pa., Oct. 25 -- Through the Amish countryside and into the reputed chocolate capital of the country, George C. Wallace led his campaign caravan today to an ice hockey arena where 3,000 partisans gave him an exuberant reception.

LONDON, Oct. 25 -- Students at the London School of Economics occupied its two main buildings today. This evening, more than 1,000 young men and women milled around the corridors, exchanging revolutionary slogans and arranging blankets and sleeping bags.

EVERYONE, both live and on film, wore clothes last night at Dance Theater Workshop's third program at Riverside Church. Another factor that distinguished it from the troupe's two earlier evenings was the generally higher quality of the four works on the program.
The problems of international diplomacy were shrugged off briefly last night while delegates to the United Nations dined and danced at the 11th annual ball given in their honor.

SEOUL, South Korea, Oct. 25 -- The ministerial conference of Colombo Plan Consultative Committee closed its four-day session here today with a call for greater flow of aid into Asia. It called also for measures to promote exports by developing countries in the region.

Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., announced yesterday the "complete liquidation" of GreatAmerica Corporation in accordance with terms approved by both concerns earlier this year. L-T-V held a majority of GreatAmerica stock.

Your editorial (Oct. 12) questioning Consolidated Edison's move to locate a nuclear power plant on Welfare Island is a most welcome call to reason. Of late it seems that the decision as to whether or not to add another atomic power-generating facility to our ever-growing inventory is being decided purely on economic grounds.
The High School Principals' Association reaffirmed yesterday an order prohibiting athletic contests from being held during the teachers' strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Proposed rules that would tighten the tax treatment of restricted stock plans were announced by the Treasury Department today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- In a Baltimore showroom decorated like an 1890 saloon, Stephen R. Krause displays his latest invention -- a computerized automatic bartender. The dispenser is described as capable of mixing any one of 1,000 drinks in four seconds, at the push of a button.
Two more tankers of 228,000 deadweight tons have been ordered from the Gotaverken yard in Sweden by the fast-growing World-Wide Shipping Group, the Hong Kong-based company headed by Y. K. Pao.

BERLIN, Oct. 25 -- In a series of political trials this week East Germany cracked down on opposition youths, sentencing a son and daughters of prominent Communist party figures to prison terms ranging from 22 to 27 months.

BERKELEY, Cal., Oct. 25 -- An attempt by student activists to promote a third sit-in within a week at the University of California fell flat today following a noon rally.

WENDSSEI, Vt., Oct. 25 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie urged the creation today of new kinds of governmental institutions in blighted and poor neighborhoods so that all people could help to "develop policies which direct the shape of their lives."
SAN JOSE, Calif., Oct. 25 -- Vice President Humphrey campaigned hard for Kennedy and McCarthy support in California today and picked up help from a number of sources.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Los Angeles district attorney prosecuting Sirhan Bishara Sirhan for the alleged assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy has asked the Supreme Court to ease restrictions on newsmen covering the case.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Oct. 25 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today he would not commit himself to voting for the Republican Vice Presidential candidate, Spiro T. Agnew, if the election was thrown into Congress to decide and the Senate had to pick a Vice President.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Oct. 25 -- The international jumping of the Pennsylvania National Horse Show involved a game of cards played on horseback tonight and John Kidd held the winning hand. Three airlines reported results of operations for the September quarter yesterday, only one of which managed to lift profits over the corresponding period last year.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The Olympic Organizing Committee's unexplained decision to curb the number of participants in closing ceremoies Sunday has revived complaints from athletes and former champions that they have no voice in the operation of the Olympic Games.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Secretary of Defense Clark M. Clifford conceded today that the Soviet Union had markedly narrowed the nuclear missile gap but insisted that the United States still maintained "substantial military superiority."

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (AP) -- The nation's automakers increased their production again this week, scheduling an output of 205,645 cars, the trade magazine, Automotive News, reported today.
