The 10th week of the Metropolitan Opera's season will include, on Nov. 22, the premiere of a production of Wagner's "Das Rheingold" staged and conducted by Herbert von Karajan.

DETROIT, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Dave Bing scored 37 points and made 11 assists tonight in leading the Detroit Pistons to a 132-122 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers in a National Basketball Association game.
BONN, Oct. 25 (Reuters) -- The West German Government said today that six Communist spies recently escaped to East Germany but denied that the flights had been the result of a security failure.

ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 25 -- Buyuk Adam -- The Big Man -- as headlines here call President de Gaulle, received a friendly though not demonstrative welcome on his arrival for a six-day state visit today. MEXICO CITY, Oct. 25 (UPI) -- Vera Caslavska of Czechoslovakia and Larrisa Petrik of the Soviet Union tied for the gold medal in the women's floor exercise event of the Olympic gymnastics finals tonight. Natalia Kuchinskaya of the Soviet Union was third.

WRIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Oct. 25 -- A delegation led by Rennie Davis, national coordinator of the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam, formally asked permission of Fort Dix authorities today to hold a picnic and musical entertainment for soldiers on Nov. 3 at the huge military reservation here.

The Two Bridges school district, originally set up as an experimental decentralized district on the Lower East Side, is sponsoring a recorded telephone message in Chinese, English and Spanish inviting licensed city teachers to apply for substitute jobs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- Two men from different worlds -- Eric Hoffer, the white longshoreman and philosopher, and Herman Blake, a Negro sociologist whose life and works is the ghetto -- collided today over white racism and black militancy.

COSTA MESA, Calif., Oct. 25 (AP) -- Bob Dickson, an amateur champion in 1967, carded a six-under-par 65 today to take a two-stroke lead at the midway point of the $110,000 Haig national open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 -- President Johnson showed his grandson Lyn today the daughter born this morning to the former Lynda Bird Johnson.

The directors of the Columbus Line have chosen Walter A. Nielsen to be president. He succeeds John Henry de La Trobe, who becomes chairman.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Two lame duck members of Congress, both defeated for renomination, are taking a last junket abroad, one around the world and the other to Africa.

AFTER an unusually bad week in the New York theater, a return to Martha Graham is like a return to the source, a reaffirmation of theatrical values and dramatic verities. This really is -- call it dance if you like or drama if you wish -- a theater of compulsive power.

IN generally avoiding the inscrutability common to many Japanese period pieces, "Rebellion," which opened at the 55th Street Playhouse yesterday, is a clear departure from the norm. Despite a creakingly slow pace and a format that is often close to soap opera, it evolves as a compelling legend by stressing one man's opposition to tyranny in an age when such opposition was unthinkable.

The three national television networks plan a conservative approach in making any early projections of the winner in the Presidential race on election night.

The city's museums, libraries, zoos and other cultural institutions were urged yesterday to waive admission fees and otherwise help children affected ty the teachers' strike.

DENVER, Oct. 25 (AP) -- Schenley Industries, Inc., and five affiliated concerns were accused of scheming to monopolize the distilled spirits business -- especially Scotch whisky -- in a $5-million lawsuit filed yesterday in United States District Court here.

PARIS, Oct. 25 -- Informed sources said today that the critical unresolved question in the talks here on the Vietnam war was the conditions under which the South Vietnamese Government and the National Liberation Front could enter the next phase of negotiations.

PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 25 -- Three men went on trial here today for the murder of Gabriel DeFranco, a convicted gambler who was found with his throat slashed in front of his Paterson home on the morning of Oct. 6, 1966.

Grain and soybean prices rebounded yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade following rumors that the Administration may make some new overtures in the Vietnam war over the weekend. The prices had dropped the day before.

VIENNA, Oct. 25 -- Soviet officers who were posted at several crossing points on Czechoslovakia's border with Austria have been withdrawn within the last two days, the Austrian Interior Ministry announced today.

The New York Giants, who so far have played only one team with a winning record (San Francisco) and lost, meet the Baltimore Colts on Sunday after the Colts have just achieved one of the best victories in the club's history.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Neal Shapiro of the United States Equestrian Team and Trick Track alone were able to complete the course faultlessly in the jumping competition of the Washington International horse show tonight for a rarity in big-time competition.
Automation Industries, Inc., reached an agreement yesterday to acquire the Vitro Corporation of America in exchange for stock valued at $50-million.

The premieres of "Triple Play" and "Huui, Huui" have been postponed. The former, a collection of one-act plays by Randolph Carter, has been set back from tonight to Sunday night at the Cherry Lane Theater. Anne Burr's "Hui, Hui," will open Nov. 16, instead of Sunday night, at the Public Theater.
SHREVEPORT, La., Oct, 29 (UPI) -- A disappointing crowd and a band of antiwar protesters met the third party, Vice-Presidential candidate, Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, when he arrived here today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, United States commander in South Vietnam, flew secretly to Washington and conferred with President Johnson today, apparently about the possible effect of the military situation on the Paris negotiations.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 29 (AP) -- A man who identified himself as Eric Galt underwent plastic surgery in Hollywood "sometime before the assassination" of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., an attorney for the physician said today.

Supporters of Vice President Humphrey and Senator Edmund S. Muskie announced yesterday that they would conduct a nationwide "phone-a-thon" drive for the Democratic ticket in the campaign's final week. Joseph H. Kanter of Cincinnati, chairman of the drive, said that 50,000 personal letters would be sent out asking persons to phone five additional friends in a pyramid phone-calling drive for votes.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 -- Cool crowds, hot crowds, big breaks and bad breaks -- that was Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign today as it moved from the Dickensian factory alleys of Pittsburgh, through the hills of Bethlehem and to the chilly ghetto asphalt of West Philadelphia.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Richard M. Nixon would be the next President of the United States if the Swedes had the choice, according to a poll published here today. And Swedish Socialist voters like him best, the figures indicated.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- A Senate subcommittee called today for a $2 minimum hourly wage and a "massive employment program" to eliminate poverty. It said that the present welfare system was failing.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Syracuse Herald-Journal became today the first daily newspaper in the state to endorse the United States Senate candidacy of James L. Buckley of the Conservative party.
NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Norfolk Ledger-Star announced today its support of Richard M. Nixon for President.

The campaign manager of Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland, the Republican Vice-Presidential candidate, charged yesterday that The New York Times had shown a "wanton, reckless disregard" of Mr. Agnew's reputation by reprinting yesterday an editorial critical of the candidate.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 29 (UPI) -- A 19-year-old soldier, absent without leave, received sanctuary from an antiwar group today at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology student center.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Some Pentagon officials tended to play down the importance to Soviet intelligence of the Sidewinder missile and two aircraft navigation instruments stolen in West Germany over the last year and a half.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Vice President Humphrey was endorsed today by The Charleston Gazette. The Gazette, traditionally a Democratic newspaper and the largest in the state, conceded, however, that it "doesn't perceive a world of difference" between the Democratic nominee and Mr. Nixon.
It was early afternoon and Henry Hall sat alone in his campaign headquarters above a cluttered grocery in a noisy block of Seventh Avenue in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- One of President Johnson's advisers leaned forward in his chair here the other day and remarked: "The President simply said to me, 'I want to have the best Presidential library in the world.'"

AS if to clinch without question the record of the new art season as the best New York has ever seen, two more first-rate exhibitions are opening to the public today -- "Gods and Heroes: Baroque Images of Antiquity" at Wildenstein Co., 19 East 64th Street, and "Medieval Art from Private Collections" at the Metropolitan Museum's medieval branch, The Cloisters, in Fort Tryon Park.

In the center for mental retardation at a United Hospital Fund member hospital, a "buddy" program between 12-year-olds flourished throughout the year and established bonds of common interest between youngsters of widely different attainments.
TOKYO, Oct. 29 -- Foreign Minister Takeo Miki resigned today to challenge Premier Eisaku Sato for leadership of Japan's ruling Liberal-Democratic party.
FLINT, Mich., Oct. 29 (AP) -- A 12-day strike by 17,000 United Automobile Workers at the Buick plant in Flint was settled today.

PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. George Trainor of Rochester took the first-round lead today in the women's North and South senior golf championship with a par 73 over the Pinehurst Country Club's No. 1 course.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 (AP) -- Following is the text of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's statement saying he would vote for Hubert H. Humphrey for President:

CINCINNATI, Oct. 29 -- Max Rudolf announced his resignation today as the music director of the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra to join the faculty of the Curtis Institute of Music in Philadelphia, effective in September, 1970.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Oct. 29 -- The Northeast Airlines plane that crashed into a fog-shrouded mountain Friday night, killing 32 of the 42 persons aboard, was apparently making a normal approach to the Lebanon, N.H., airport when it crashed, the investigator said today.

BERLIN, Oct. 29 -- The East German Communist regime has disclosed that an East Berlin court sentenced seven youths who demonstrated against the Aug. 20-21 invasion of Czechoslovakia to prison terms up to 27 months.
The American Heart Association reaffirmed yesterday its advice that the risk of having a heart attack could be lowered by reducing the amount of animal fats in the diet.

LUBBOCK, Tex., Oct. 29 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie barnstormed through conservative strongholds today from the Panhandle to east Texas in an effort to keep the state's 25 electoral votes in the Democratic column.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Oct. 29 (AP)--A sharp 20-second earthquake jolted the Fairbanks area this afternoon, sending frightened people running into the streets and spilling stocks from the shelves of stores.

Richard M. Nixon said yesterday that he could not sympathize with the "illegal strike" by New York City teachers but that he believed they have "a right to require Ironclad assurances" against threats of violence before they return to work.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- Indonesia executed three Communists for treason today, ignoring a request by President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union to spare their lives.

MINNEAPOLIS, Wednesday, Oct. 30 -- The Chicago Tribune's report that Mr. Humphrey had been given his lake property at Waverly, Minn., was denied late yesterday by the wife and a brother of the Minneapolis businessman who was the alleged donor.

The Fire Department disclosed last night that fire marshals were investigating the mysterious turning on of gas jets on two floors at Eleanor Roosevelt Junior High School in Washington Heights yesterday.
TORONTO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The heart and both kidneys of a 20-year-old accident victim were transplanted today into three separate recipients. His eyes were donated to an eye bank.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 29--Princeton University announced today the publication of "The Otomi Catechism," a facsimile of a manuscript in native picture writing, prepared by Spanish friars to educate Mexican Indians in Christianity.

The city's Environmental Protection Administration -charged with cleaning up refuse, providing clean water and air and controlling noise -- asked yesterday for about one-fourth of the city's total capital budget.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Eight days after the 1960 Presidential election California counted its absentee ballots, and the state was shifted from the Democratic to the Republican victory column.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -Gen. William C. Westmoreland said today that "our infantry has beaten the guerrilla at his own game" in South Vietnam.
The election of Howard B. Johnson as chairman of the board of the Howard Johnson Company was announced yesterday. He continues as president and chief executive officer.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- George C. Wallace has collected more than $4.7-million in campaign contributions of less than $100 each, his official campaign financial statement disclosed today.
DETROIT, Oct. 29 -- More than 10,000 Wallace partisans and hecklers waged a war of shouts, screams, boos and occasional blows tonight in a tumultuous rally in Detroit's Cobo Arena.

Liggett Myers, Inc., yesterday became the third major cigarette manufacturer to raise its regular brand prices. The company announced it had increased the price of its regular Chesterfield. Home Run, Piedmont and Picayune brands to wholesalers from $9.25 to $9.45 a thousand cigarettes.

As Senator Eugene J. McCarthy has consistently recognized throughout this political year, he has the kind of following which cannot be "delivered" to any other candidate. When he began campaigning last winter against the Johnson Administration and the Vietnam war, Mr. McCarthy discovered that his constituency already existed and was simply waiting for a leader with the courage to take the field.
HONG KONG, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Hong Kong Star said today that an accident on an intermediate range test missile on the launching pad had delayed Communist China's long-range missile program.
IF playing football is supposed to be fun, the members of Penn's undefeated squad must be in a hilarious mood.
The election of R. D. Ziegler to the board of directors and as a vice president of the Rexall Drug and Chemical Company was announced yesterday.
The election of Benjamin Blackford to the board of directors of the Sperry Hutchinson Company was announced yesterday. He is president of the State National Bank of Connecticut.
Paul O'Dwyer refused yesterday to follow Senator Eugene J. McCarthy in supporting Vice President Humphrey and reacted cooly to backing any new political party.
Like the Supreme Court, the Federal Reserve Board may be watching the election returns next Tuesday with more than usual interest.

MEXICO CITY, Oct. 28 -- When Manhattan was a virtually uninhabited island in the middle of the 14th century, Munich was a sleepy river town of 10,000 people. But Mexico City already had become the center of the Aztec culture and civilization with 60,000 homes. Even today this lovely city is almost six times larger than the German metropolis with a rapidly expanding population of 7 million.
WHAT'S good for one investor may not be the best course of action for another. Take Harry Hasim and Melvin Monroe, for example.
LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 29 -- The United States team drew with the Philippines today, 2-2, in the fourth round of the finals of the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.

SYRACUSE, Oct. 29 -- There were policemen in the corridors and tense undertones of unrest were apparent when William Nottingham High School reopened today, but there was no repetition of the racial disorders that caused the school to be closed yesterday afternoon.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's 18-member council placed La Salle College of Philadelphia, St. Bonaventure University of Olean, N. Y., and Florida State University on probation today for basketball violations.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The White House said today that Mrs. Charles S. Robb and her five-day-old daughter, Lucinda Desha, are being deluged with mail, including a letter containing $1,000 for a shade tree to be planted in honor of President Johnson's granddaughter.

The Nixon-Agnew organization said yesterday that a spot commercial depicting Vice President Humphrey grinning between scenes of war, poverty and rioting had been withdrawn from the Nixon television campaign.

PARIS, Oct. 29 -- Usually informed diplomats said today that North Vietnam had been seeking an advantage by pressing President Johnson as close as possible to the Presidential elections before giving a final answer to American proposals for a bombing halt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The American Federation of Teachers, parent organization of the striking New York City teachers' union, plans to-call a national conference of teachers and citizens soon to try to develop guidelines for school decentralization.

PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 29 -- As the Presidential campaign enters its final stage, the nation's voters are showing growing confidence in the ability of the Democratic party to deal with the nation's top problems, according to the Gallup Poll.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 29 -- Losses incurred by the General Electric Company in such new ventures as computers, nuclear power and commercial jet engines were reported here today to have reached their maximum and total sales of all products are expected to top $8-billion for file first time.

The United Federation of Teachers argued before the state's highest court here yesterday that its president, Albert Shanker, had a constitutional right to a jury trial on charges of criminal contempt of court.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Oct. 29 -- With Election Day exactly a week away, Hubert H. Humphrey is finally beginning to act like the Happy Warrior of campaigns long past. To a reporter rejoining the Humphrey caravan after an absence of two weeks, the changes in mood, style and substance are unmistakable.

ON the Lower East Side, where poverty stalks the streets, so do young men in $60 sweaters propelled by $70 shoes. One can hear 14-year-olds and 15-year-olds, still puffing from a basketball game, discussing the relative merits of their tailors.
The scramble for sales of tomorrow's superjet airliners intensified yesterday with an announcement by Northwest Airlines that it was buying 14 long-range DC-10's with Pratt Whitney engines.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Total Government spending in the first quarter of the current fiscal year ran well within the ceilings that Congress set for the whole year in its tax-expenditure bill, high officials disclosed today.

Negotiators for steamship operators and longshore labor said yesterday that they were resuming contract talks today with a feeling of "cautious optimism" that a new agreement could be reached long before a court-ordered 80-day cooling off period expires on Dec. 20.

CARTHAGE, Tex., Oct. 29 (UPI) -- A tank truck exploded in this small east Texas town today, washing the downtown business section with 20,000 gallons of flaming butane. The Panola County sheriff's office said three buildings had been destroyed.

CHICAGO, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Jerry Rubin, leader of the Youth International Party (Yippies), reportedly was named in a true charging him with soliciation to commit mob action for inciting crowds in downtown Grant Park Aug. 28 during the Democratic National Convention.

Philip Capice has been appointed director of special programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System Television Network. He succeeds Michael Campus, who resigned recently to join Universal Pictures. Mr. Caprice had been with the Benton Bowles advertising agency, serving in a number of executive positions.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 29 (AP)--Johns Hopkins University announced today the establishment of the first graduate center of Canadian studies in the United States. It will be conducted at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies and will be financed by a $1-million grant over a five-year period from the William H. Donner Foundation and the Donner Canadian Foundation.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Senator J. W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, in a report filed in the Senate, lists no contributions and no expenditures in his re-election bid.

Spartans Industries, Inc., and the Mangel Stores Corporation said yesterday they had terminated negotiations involving Mangel's purchase of the Spartan Atlantic discount store chain. TUCSON, Ariz., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Russian and American scientists have reached agreement on 500 place names for the far side of the moon.

SAPPORO, Japan, Oct. 29 (AP) -- Joe Hague's three-run homer in the sixth inning today enabled the St. Louis Cardinals to turn back the Yomiuri Giants, 6-3, in the fourth game of their Japanese baseball tour.
LONDON, Oct. 29 (Reuters) -- A leading bookmaker today reported heavy betting on Vice President Humphrey to win the Presidential election.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The Labor Department moved today to invalidate last February's election of officers by the International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union of North America.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, Oct. 30 -- The Soviet Union ended its first manned space flight in 18 months today and returned the Soyuz 3 vehicle and its pilot safely to earth on the fifth day of its flight, informed sources said.

The New York Rangers, who haven't lost a game in four tries against expansion teams this season, will play the Pittsburgh Penguins tonight in Madison Square Garden. The Penguins, an expansion team, lost seven of a possible eight points to the Rangers last season.

The stock market reverberated with uncertainties yesterday as it declined for the second successive trading period and for the fourth time in the last five days.

John Huston, the director-writer-actor, will play a featured role in "de Sade," a film dramatization of the career of the Marquis de Sade, which is being shot in Berlin by American International Pictures. Keir Dullea is portraying the 18th-century French writer and sex criminal.

ARMONK, N. Y., Oct. 29 (AP) -- Nine miles of Interstate 87 between White Plains and Armonk will open to traffic at noon tomorrow without ceremony. WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The Post Office Department said today that two Republican Senators would meet soon with Postmaster General W. Marvin Watson to discuss allegations that they had abused their franking, or free mail, privileges.

"Mark Twain Tonight," Hal Holbrook's critically acclaimed dramatic readings, will be re-broadcast on the Columbia Broadcasting System television network Thursday, Jan. 2, from 7:30 to 9 P.M. The Xerox Corporation will again sponsor the 90-minute special, which was first televised on the network in March, 1967.

Future political historians digging deep into the records of 1968 might well conclude that the major error made by the current crop of candidates was their failure to seek closer identification with our furry friends.
Interest rates rose yesterday throughout the money and capital markets as bond men awaited news on the Vietnam peace talks, the election campaign and the economy.

ATLANTA, Oct. 29 (UPI) -Brendan McCarthy, a rookie running back, expressed dismay today about being one of six Atlanta Falcon regulars placed on waivers last night by the new coach, Norm Van Brocklin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- This year's climb in the Consumer Price Index -- the steepest since the Korean war -- tapered off slightly to a more modest monthly rise of two-tenths of 1 per cent in September, the Labor Department reported today.

The candidates and the press are fussing at each other again and this is the way it should be. They have different jobs and in many ways they are natural enemies, like cats and dogs. The first job of the candidate is to win, and he usually says what he thinks will help him win.

Borden, Inc., the second largest in the dairy products industry, after National Dairy Products, set records in sales and operating income in the third quarter, but the tax surcharge reduced net income below the record levels of a year ago, the company reported yesterday.

AKRON, Ohio, Oct. 25 -- In this election year, Akron stands as an example of the middle-sized American industrial city, watched paternally by four giant corporations, a bit uncertain about its usual Democratic politics and busy at work.

A take-over by the state of the controversial Ocean Hill-Brownsville school district was proposed yesterday by Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, in a move to end the citywide teachers' strike.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- The Medal of Honor was awarded posthumously today to Capt. James A. Graham of the Marine Corps, who was killed in Vietnam after refusing to leave a wounded man in a battle in which the captain was credited with killing 15 enemy soldiers.
CEDARHURST, L. I., Oct. 29 -- "Senator Javits," cried the woman standing near the canned grapefruit juice at the Waldbaums supermarket here, "when are we going to solve the city's school strike?"

ATHENS, Oct. 29 (AP) -- The army-backed Greek regime has released 85 political prisoners from the Aegean prison islands of Leros and Gyaros. The Ministry of Public Order said today that those set free included aged and sick persons and several others who had signed a statement pledging "lawful behavior."
ANKARA, Turkey, Oct. 29 -President Cevdet Sunay told the Turkish people today that their country would continue to strengthen its defensive alliances.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Oct. 29 (AP) -- An explosive charge thrown by a Vietcong guerrilla exploded in a marketplace in the Mekong Delta town of Kienlong early today, killing six civilians and wounding 17, the United States mission reported.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- An Australian Air Force Mirage jet fighter crashed near a gunnery range 100 miles north of here today. The pilot landed unhurt after using his ejector seat. It was the eighth Mirage crash since the French-designed aircraft went into service with the Australian Air Force.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 29 (UPI) -- General Manager Larry Regan of the Los Angeles Kings hockey team was fined $1,000 today for having punched referee Bruce Hood in the face after a game at Oakland Oct. 13.
PARIS -- In dingy offices over an ancient book store near the Sorbonne, a group of Russian emigres is quietly compiling and reprinting books that have carved a niche in publishing history.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Oct. 29 -- Two years ago Army upset Penn State, 11-0, in the fifth straight football battle of defenses between the Black Knights and the Nittany Lions. Ken Johnson, captain and middle linebacker of the present Army team, said "that was the best defensive game Army played from 1965 through 1967."

BERLIN, Oct. 29--East German Communist border guards have barred access to West Berlin to a West German Deputy en route to the city to attend committee sessions of the Bundestag, the lower house of Bonn's Parliament.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Stanley (Kitten) Hayward of Philadelphia, fighting for the first time as a middleweight, scored an upset split decision over Emile Griffith, the former middleweight champion, in a 10-round bout at the Spectrum tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy will be the key speaker here Nov. 10 at a gathering of United States Catholics aimed at healing a split in the church that developed after Pope Paul VI issued his ban on birth control.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy announced today that he would vote for Hubert H. Humphrey for President but said that he would not seek the Democratic nomination for the Senate in 1970 or for the Presidency in 1972.
BOSTON, Oct. 29 (UPI) -- Peter Fuller, the car dealer who owns Dancer's Image, said today that the retired race horse would stand in stud in Maryland.
One of these days when the superliner Queen Elizabeth steams out of Southampton bound for her appointed landlocked career, she will carry away the career of Geoffrey Thrippleton Marr.

Robert Kuehn, a baritone who has appeared with the New York Pro Musica and on Broadway in Douglas Campbell's "The Golden Age," sang a recital at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. He performed songs and arias by Purcell, Handel, Schubert Wolf, Carl Loewe and Priaulx Rainier, whose "Cycle for Declamation" was given its United States premiere.

PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 29 -- The Passaic County grand jury has charged individual members of the Paterson Police Department with vandalism, brutality and intimidation in quelling a week of racial disorders here last July.

ATHENS, Oct. 29 -- Former Premier George Papandreou was in critical condition in an Athens hospital tonight after a second attack of intestinal bleeding in three days. The 80-year-old politician was hospitalized Saturday because of a gastric hemorrhage caused by an ulcer.

TORRANCE, Calif., Oct. 29 -- Has success spoiled Parnelli Jones? Depends on your viewpoint. If you're going to be a race driver the rest of your life, you may miss that familiar sight of Jones's tailpipes, along with his practical jokes.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 29 -- The profit return on manufacturing investments abroad by United States companies declined last year for the third year in a row, the Commerce Department reported today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 29 -- White men have offered "big money" to Negroes to burn white-owned buildings in Negro sections here, Eldridge Cleaver, the Black Panther leader said today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Boston edged the Minnesota North Stars, 4-2, in a National Hockey League game tonight, marking the first time the Bruins had defeated the West Division team on their home ice.
PASADENA, Calif., Oct. 30 -- It was proposed here today that on the basis of a new study of the astronomical objects known as quasars, the quasars are not so extremely distant as generally believed.

Dr. Clark Kerr, a leading authority on higher education, made a sharp counterattack yesterday against Jacques Barzun's charge that the universities are destroying themselves by turning from scholarship to public service.

The election of Thomas Dimond as a director of Scudder Duo-Vest, Inc., was announced yesterday by George S. Johnston, president. Mr. Dimond, who is president of Humes-Schmidlapp Associates, a private investment firm in New York, fills a vacancy caused by the resignation of George P. Baker on Oct. 2.

NEWARK, Oct. 30 -- A Newark police car was spotted three years ago at the scene of a lottery bank under surveillance by county detectives and the state police, and a patrolman in the car was seen handing "a volume of slips" to a lookout for the gambling operation, a prosecution witness testified today during the trial of Dominick A. Spina, Newark's Police Director.

Brown Williamson Tobacco Corporation yesterday became the fourth major cigarette producer to raise its regular brand prices. The company announced it had inceased the price of its regular Kool cigarettes to jobbers to $9.45 from $9.25 a thousand cigarettes.

Supporters of Childville, a residential treatment center for emotionally disturbed boys and girls, will hear about the institution's development plans on Saturday at a luncheon in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

The Socialist Workers party said yesterday it had formally protested the exclusion from the Tennessee ballot of an independent elector pledged to the party's Presidential and Vice-Presidential candidates, Fred Halstead and Paul Boutelle.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Herve Filion set a single-year world record for harness-racing drivers tonight at Liberty Bell Park with his 314th victory.
Children from the East Side, West Side and all around the world will benefit from a Halloween costume party to be held tonight in the Plaza's Baroque Suite.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Heartened by political gains and more generous contributions, the Democrats have in-ceased their Presidential campaign budget from $10-million to $12-million.
Everyone did his thing last night at the Fillmore East Theater and 500 hippies thereby lost a chance to have free use of the theater one night a week.

The Boston Maine Corporation, which operates the Boston Maine Railroad, announced yesterday it had filed a prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering its plans for exchanging the corporation's stock for stock of a new company, Boston Maine Industries, Inc.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Defense ministers of the Warsaw Pact nations today completed a two-day discussion of methods of strengthening the defenses of Eastern Europe.
The election of H. Russell Morrison Jr., president of Standard Poor's Corporation, as a director of McGraw-Hill, Inc., was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Prof. Paul A. Samuelson said today that the New York Stock Exchange's planned reduction in sales commissions on large transactions "is a mere token reduction, designed to take off the heat of criticism."

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 30 -- Two United States scientists were awarded the 1968 Nobel Prizes in physics and chemistry today, thereby giving America a sweep this year in all three Nobel science categories. This last happened in 1946.

TORONTO, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens, leaders of the East Division, got three goals during the first 35 minutes and went on to a 5-0 National Hockey League victory tonight over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The collapse of an Ohio River bridge last December, which killed 46 persons, started when a chain snapped, Government investigators reported today.
White, Weld Co. priced yesterday for offering today 409,900 common shares of Wells, Rich, Greene, Inc., at $17.50. This is the advertising agency's first public offering.

BERKELEY, Calif., Oct. 30 -- For the first time in 10 years the University of California appears to be a bona fide contender for the Rose Bowl, helping square-jawed Ray Willsey to enjoy his fifth and most promising season as head coach.
The Daily News straw poll today shows Richard M. Nixon cutting Vice President Humphrey's lead in New York State to 2 percentage points.

DENVER, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit today ordered Capt. Dale Noyd of the Air Force released from confinement at Cannon Air Force Base, N. M., and taken to the Federal prison at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.
WARSAW -- "You've been occupied for five days," a Polish scientist told a bitter Czech colleague soon after the invasion of Czechoslovakia, "but we have been occupied for 150 years."
The London Stock Exchange closed firm yesterday as advances outnumbered declines.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Oct. 30 -- A group of more than 100 academic and professional men in the Boston area was formed today as the Massachusetts Committee of Scientists, Engineers and other professionals for Humphrey-Muskie.
John G. Proudfit, the Republican candidate to represent the 20th Congressional District on Manhattan's West Side, calls the area "a microcosm of all the urban problems in the country."

A choral and orchestral ensemble from Germany, with the lengthy title of Bach Collegium Stuttgart and Gaechinger Kantorei, made its New York debut last night in Philharmonic Hall as part of its first American tour.
LONDON, Oct. 30 -- The Government moved today toward what could be a historic change in the political structure of the United Kingdom.

Crowell Collier and Macmillan, Inc., said yesterday that more than the 345,000 shares of C. G. Conn, Ltd., common shares, which it offered to buy, had been tendered. All tendered through Oct. 28 are being purchased.
SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Bedecked with scores of banners and pennants, the first ship passed through the huge new $40.3-million Poe Lock at Sault Ste. Marie today.
WARSAW, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Poland defeated Ireland, 1-0, in a soccer match tonight.

FALMOUTH, England, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Derek Heath, a 43-year-old truck driver, a sailor at heart, set out again today in a 12-foot rubber dinghy to cross the Atlantic. It was his third departure since Saturday.

Bill Hosket, a two-time all-American at Ohio State, player of the year in the Big Ten Conference and a member of the victorious United States Olympic team, signed a contract yesterday with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association.
BONNEVILLE SALT FLATS, Utah, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Mickey Thompson's planned assault on the world speed record for piston cars was put off today because of a rainstorm.

PRAGUE, Oct. 30 -- Pro-Dubcek Communist forces, including workers organizations in industrial plants, are rallying against the formation of Soviet-backed conservative factions within the Communist party.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Professional Golfers' Association sought an injunction today in United States Appeals Court to prevent operation of the breakaway American Professional Golfers.
Staff musicians at the three major television networks went on strike yesterday, but members of other broadcast unions crossed their picket lines.

ENTHUSIASM, competitive drive, plus talent for objective analysis advanced Jude Acers of San Francisco into a three-way first-place tie with F. Thornally and David Blohm in the recent Northern California Open at Sunnyvale.

MONTGOMERY, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A Negro farmers' co-operative, founded by members of the Selma civil rights marchers led by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., filed suit in Federal court to end "harassment and intimidation" by Gov. Albert Brewer and other officials.

The General Dynamics Corporation and its subsidiaries incurred a loss of $15,805,000 in the third quarter, after deducting a write-off of $30,074,000 of excess costs on certain long-term surface ships and submarine construction contracts, it was reported last night.
"Harry, if the weather's nice this weekend, what would you like to do -- visit my mother, help me clean out the hall closet or go look at some more houses?" she asked.

A Bronx Criminal Court judge dealt leniently yesterday with a black militant coed at Queens College who had been arrested at the Tremont Welfare Center while pleading for emergency grants for an ailing, destitute Jewish man and a Negro mother of three sick children.
PINEHURST, N. C., Oct. 30 (AP) -- Mrs. John Haskell of Titusville, Pa., took a stroke lead today after 36 holes of the 54-hole North and South senior women's golf chamiponship with a 78 for 155.

JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Israeli military government arrested the Mayor of Ramallah and deported nine other Arab leaders to Jordan today amid continuing tension in the occupied west bank area of the Jordan River.

Dr. Arnulfo Arias, the deposed President of Panama, said yesterday that he would have no objection to the formation of an inter-American military force to overthrow Panama's military junta and restore him to power.
CINCINNATI, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Cincinnati Royals took a 17-point haft-time lead, then staved off a New York Knicks' rally to score a 118-114 National Basketball Association victory tonight.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Oct. 30 (AP) -- John Suminski, Kevin Foley and Larry Rovelstad, the only seniors on Seton Hall University's basketball team, were elected tri-captains today of the team for the 1968-69 season.

MONTREAL, Oct. 30 (Canadian Press) -- The British Newfoundland Corporation, Ltd., today increased its authorized share capital to 25-million common shares from 19,999,988 at a special meeting of shareholders.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- President Johnson used the pocket veto today to kill a bill that would have created an independent Maritime Administration.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Kathy Kusner, shy, almost frail Olympic equestrienne who was granted a thoroughbred racing jockey's license yesterday in Maryland, insisted today she was no crusader.

Three prisoners who broke out of Rikers Island Penitentiary were back in jail yesterday after an unsuccessful attempt to swim the East River to Manhattan. They are Angelo Garcia, 20 years old, of Brooklyn, Michael Padilla, 19, of Irvington-on-Hudson, and Louis Galarza, 19, of the Bronx.
A revival of "Harvey" will be presented tonight through Saturday night at The Lambs, 130 West 44th Street. Freeman Parks, who directed, will play the leading role.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Mrs. Charles S. Robb and her new daughter, Lucinda Deshe, are expected to leave Bethesda Naval Medical Center tomorrow or Friday, the White House said today.

The resumption of Atlantic and Gulf longshore negotiations has brought a glimmer of hope that union and employer representatives have not resigned themselves to repeating the dreary ritual under which every Taft-Hartley national emergency injunction is merely the forerunner of another crippling strike.

A 14 per cent increase in earnings was announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company of California for the third quarter. The West Coast oil giant's profits rose 11 per cent in the first nine months of 1968.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Qualified sources said here today that the American people felt a deep sense or obligation to see Israel survive as a nation. However, they noted that United States policy in the event of a joint Arab-Soviet Union attack on Israel would be determined at the time by the President in the light of events.

A bitter eight-year-old dispute over whether a plot of land in the Melrose section of the Bronx should be used for housing or a playing field was settled yesterday by a plan to split the plot and use it for both purposes.

New York City public-school seniors who have used their free time during the last two months to read books and study rather than go to the movies may find their chances of getting into college have been increased, rather than handicapped, by the teachers' strike.
A three-hour meeting on a contract between steamship operators and longshoremen working in North Atlantic coast ports ended fruitlessly yesterday.
CAIRO, Oct. 30 -- Defying Israel's military power, the United Arab Republic insisted today that it had the right to make "protective" attacks on Israeli emplacements along the Suez Canal.

Emile Griffith, the former world middleweight and welterweight champion, and his co-managers, Gil Clancy and Howard Albert, have been granted a hearing on Monday by the Pennsylvania State Athletic Commission to appeal Griffith's defeat by Stanley (Kitten) Hayward Tuesday night in Philadelphia.
The Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association announced yesterday that the formal signing of its new two-year contract with the city would take place at 9 A. M. tomorrow at City Hall.

A free performance of "By George," Max Adrian's one-man program about George Bernard Shaw, author, will be given tomorrow night at Columbia University's McMillan Theater. Tickets may be obtained by calling 280-4477.

Earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation declined only slightly in the third quarter, the nation's second largest steel producer reported yesterday. Bethlehem cleared 49 cents a share, compared with 50 cents in the 1967 period.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Oct. 30--Ed Gaffney, a center forward, scored three goals in the third period to lead the Hofstra University soccer team to a 3-1 victory over Rutgers today.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation filed suit yesterday in Federal Court here against four members of the Presidential Cabinet seeking an injunction to halt proceedings on an application for the creation of a foreign trade zone, including an oil refinery, in Maine.

Republican campaign officials resumed their attacks yesterday on The New York Times by adding a grievance of Richard M. Nixon, their Presidential candidate, to those of his running mate, Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland, against editorial page commentaries on the ticket.

The New York Symphony, a permanent orchestra of about 100 members, will make its debut Dec. 19 at Carnegie Hall. With Joseph Eger as conductor, the new orchestra will play a season of five concerts at Carnegie Hall and appear in other communities.

The Court of Appeals held, 4 to 3, yesterday that one judge rather than a 12-man jury should decide whether Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, was in defiance of court orders to end the teachers' strike.
Thirty countries, including the United States, have entered teams in the 1968 Paralympics, which open Monday in Israel.

TOKYO, Thursday, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Kyodo news service reported today that Japanese "Government sources" expected a suspension of United States bombing of North Vietnam to be announced "within several hours."

CAPETOWN, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Dr. Christiaan N. Barnard, the heart transplant surgeon, was discharged from Groote Schuur Hospital today after undergoing treatment for a stomach hemorrhage. He was admitted to the hospital at week ago
The Army announced yesterday it had awarded ammunition contracts totaling more than $500-million.

MRS. CURTIS E. LeMAY, a candidate's wife for the first time, is going at the job with the relish of an old pro. And, in a sense, the traveling and the meeting people are nothing new to the wife of General LeMay, who became the Vice Presidential candidate on George C. Wallace's ticket less than a month ago.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- Time appears to be running out for the deadlocked negotiations between Israel and the United Arab Republic and Jordan, in the view of many well-informed diplomats here.

Chester M. Ross has been named president and chief executive officer of the Novo Industrial Corporation effective Jan. 1. William A. Romain, now chief operating officer of Novo, has been named president and chief executive officer of a newly-created autonomous subsidiary to be known as the United Filtration Corporation.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 -- An appeals court today acquitted three Athens journalists who were brought to trial because of a magazine article last July that said that some of the most famous writers, artists and philosophers of ancient Greece were homosexuals.
TEL AVIV, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- Israeli troops killed three Arab guerrillas in a gun battle last night on the slopes of Mount Hermon near the Lebanese border, officials announced here today.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The Philadelphia Flyers of the National Hockey League recalled two players from farm clubs today to replace Doug Favell, a sidelined goalie, and John Miszuk, a defenseman. The Flyers brough up Bob Taylor, goalie from the Jersey Devils of the Eastern Hockey League and Ralph MacSweyn, a defenseman from the Quebec Aces of the American Hockey League.

BRATISLAVA, Czechoslovakia, Oct. 30 -- With the cheers of Slovak youths reverberating outside the Bratislava castle, the leaders of Czechoslovakia today signed a constitutional law long sought by the Slovak people, providing for Slovak and Czech local autonomy within a federal state.

A flag-bedecked Nixon bus, blaring gay music, led the James L. Buckley campaign caravan to Hempstead, L.I., and Hofstra College yestereday to enable Mr. Buckley to attack his Republican opponent, Senator Jacob K. Javits.

The Fairleigh Dickinson soccer team snapped Long Island University's 36-game winning streak in Metropolitan Conference play yesterday by defeating the Blackbirds, 3--1, at the losers field in downtown Brooklyn.

A hostile, sneering crowd at Madison Square Garden changed loyalty in mid-game last night as the Rangers, behind by 3-0, suddenly started popping in goals against the Pittsburgh Penguins and went on to a 7-3 rout.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Utah State University was reprimanded, censured and placed on probation for an indefinite period today by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for violations of financial aid and eligibility rules.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- A situation of complete famine is likely next year in the area of Nigeria under Biafran control, Dr. William Clyne Shepherd, a physician from that area, said here today.

ALBANY, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- In new program to increase the sales of lottery tickets, State Tax Commissioner Joseph H. Murphy announced today that cash incentive awards would be given to sales agents who sell tickets that win the first four monthly prizes.
LUSAKA, Zambia, Oct. 30 -- The Zambian Government will take control of all pricing and marketing policy affecting this country's mineral products, it was announced here today.

ROME, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Pope Paul VI accepted today the resignation of Msgr. Stephen S. Woznicki as Bishop of Saginaw, Mich. The Vatican said the 74-year-old bishop has asked to be relieved of his duties because of his advanced age.

THIS was to be the year of Columbia's athletic revolution. The fencers were champions, the basketball players were champions, and a new, aggressive athletic director told the football team at fall practice that "nothing can do more to unify the student body than a good winning team." There were new facilities, a public show of interest by the new president, fresh alumni support and more money.
The Greater Harlem Real Estate Board has elected Edward A. Ellerbe to serve as president for the coming year. He is president of the Ellerbe Organization.

Two Olympians and a Bronx high school athlete will be honored at 7 o'clock tonight, by the Metropolitan Track and Field Association at its annual awards dinner at Rose's Restaurant, 41 West 52d Street.
LISBON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Dr. Bissaia Barreto said today that former Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar was making "very satisfactory progress" in his recovery from a stroke.

Dr. Donald B. Duncan has been named group vice president of a new defense and space systems group at the Singer Company. The new group consists of the HRB-Sinder Division and the Metrics Division of Singer, and two groups of the General Precision Equipment Corporation, acquired by Singer in July. These are Librascope and Kearfott.
Miss Mildred Custin, president of the Bonwit Teller chain of women's specialty stores, will receive the 1968 Tobe Award for distinguished retailing.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Christian Science Monitor said today that its final pre-election survey sees Richard M. Nixon as the Presidential winner. But there is a chance, the paper added, that Hubert H. Humphrey will capture enough electoral votes to throw the contest into the House of Representatives.

Don V. Ruck, the public relations director of the National Hockey League, was named vice president yesterday of the 12-team circuit. Ruck is the first person to hold the title of vice president in the league's 52-year history.

LONDON, Oct. 30 (Reuters) -- The Sir Ivor, English Derby winner, has hardened in the betting for the Washington International at Laurel Nov. 11 following the news there would be no replacement for the injured United States champion, Damascus.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- The United States today sharply criticized Canada for raising import fees on potentially cheap American corn. The United States threatened to retaliate by raising duties on some Canadian products unless the United States-Canadian trade balance is maintained.

THOSE musicians from Marlboro! Each year they turn up in Town Hall, and each year the new crop seems to top the old. All have a family relationship. They are young, they are talented, they are superbly trained, they are perfect ensemble players.
The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange reported yesterday changes in the share holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of listed companies.

Revere Copper Brass, Inc., and the Cerro Copper Brass Company, a division of the Cerro Corporation, announced yesterday they would increase prices by about 5 per cent on all copper water tube and pipe, including drain, waste and vent tube.

Brother Barnabas Paul has been named director of the national office of the Christian Brothers at Lockport, Ill. The Lockport headquarters houses the order's educational, financial, fund-raising and research agencies.

George T. Scharffenberger, president of the City Investing Company, said yesterday that on the basis of preliminary estimates "the quarter ending Oct. 31 will show up most favorably with last year and we think the outlook for the year is good."
Hubert H. Humphrey campaigned yesterday on the sidewalks of New York, a city that has fueled the Presidential drives of Democratic nominees since the 1930's.
The election of William K. Barry, vice president and general merchandise manager of soft lines at the J. C. Penney Company, Inc., as a director was announced yesterday by the department-store chain.
JERUSALEM, Oct. 30 -- Deputy Premier Yigal Allon said in Parliament today that Israel could count on United States support if the Soviet Union intervened militarily in any Middle East conflict.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 30 -- In more direct and precise language than he has used before, Richard M. Nixon renewed today his challenge to Vice President Humphrey to join him in pledging support for the candidate who wins the most popular votes in the Presidential election next Tuesday.
SENDAI, Japan, Oct. 30 (AP) Bob Gibson, the winner of the Cy Young Award, showed the Japanese his pitching and hitting ability today as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Yo miuri Giants, 8-1.
ATLANTA, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Atlanta Falcons recalled Jim Norton, a defensive tackle, at the last minute today, but it was not clear if Norton would actually rejoin the team.

BOSTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- Jimmy Walker's jump shot from the corner with 9 seconds left gave the Detroit Pistons an uphill 119-117 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.

YONKERS, Oct. 30 -- Stanley Dancer, the squire of New Egypt, N. J., whose fame as a harness horseman spreads over the world, usually is too busy to afford the luxury of a smile. In fact, some people refer to him as the "stone-faced one."

Two supporters of Dick Gregory filed a Federal court suit yesterday seeking $5-million in damages and a court order for the three major TV networks to give "equal time" to Mr. Gregory as a candidate for President.

The award of the Nobel Prize to two American scientists yesterday raises to 79 the total number of scientists working in this country who have been given the Nobel prize since its establishment in 1901.
W. R. GRACE a name linked with shipping for 114 years -- ever since the founder fled an Irish potato famine to sell ship supplies in Callao, Peru -- is ready to sell its fleet.

The New York City Opera's new production of Gounod's "Faust" had major cast changes in the performance given last night at the New York State Theater. Patricia Brooks appeared as Marguerite for the first time, and Joseph Rouleau made his debut with the company in the part of Mephistopheles.

Union rejection of the peace proposals by State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. dashes what had seemed the most promising of all initiatives to rescue New York from its disastrous school strike -- one that included every conceivable ingredient for a workable settlement.

Tuesday night, in one citadel of the workingman -- Detroit -- George Wallace received a deafening and blood-tingling welcome, even if it was marred by heckling and fist fights. But Mr. Wallace's campaign is supposed to be going down.

BERLIN, Oct. 30 -- The outlines of a new Soviet strategy to straighten out the wrangling world Communist movement and reimpose tighter controls over most parties have emerged in the last week in speeches by Walter Ulbricht, the East German Communist leader, and others in his Central Committee.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 30 -- Sitting in a hotel room here recently with a group of people interested in conservation, Charles A. Lindbergh Jr. recalled stories his father told of a boyhood in Minnesota when it was still Indian territory.

The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis, which often plays the role of gadfly in the Federal Reserve System, came to New York yesterday to take his colleagues in the central bank to task.

BUDAPEST, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A 21-year-old American Indian was sentenced to six months at hard labor by a Hungarian court today for having helped to smuggle an East German youth out of Hungary while she was on a vacation tour of Europe.

Passengers broke into applause yesterday morning when Penn Central officials announced that the inaugural run of the Jersey Arrow had just reached 100 miles an hour on the outskirts of New Brunswick, N. J.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Several thousand Federal agents will be on duty Election Day to deal swiftly with any attempt to interfere with an American citizen's right to vote.

WASHINGTON, Oct 30 -- Authoritative sources said today that Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, the United States commander in South Vietnam, told President Johnson yesterday that he could accept the military consequences of a complete halt in the bombing of North Vietnam under present battlefield conditions.
Medical World News, a weekly magazine for doctors, said yesterday that it had polled more than 6,000 doctors and 62.2 per cent of them favored Richard M. Nixon for President.
WASHINGTON -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay blames a small, Communist-inspired minority for much of the opposition to the Vietnam war in this country.

The Mutual Broadcasting System radio network has petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to order the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., to discontinue the operation of its four radio networks.

Dillon, Read Co., Inc., announced yesterday that Frederick H. Cook, former president and chief executive officer of Congoleum-Nairn, Inc., will become a consultant to the investment banking concern tomorrow.
College men, who have long been a bastion of traditional apparel, have moved strongly into fashion merchandise and retailers who sell to this market are clamoring for more of the same.

The women hunched their shoulders under their cloth shawls and shabby winter coats as they hurried along Myrtle Avenue, bent slightly against the harsh bite of impending winter. Many looked up warily when asked about the Presidential election and brushed past in silence.
The Columbia Broadcasting System reported last night that posters of the Soviet leaders, put up as usual for the annual celebration of the Bolshevik Revolution Nov. 7, were taken down Tuesday.

Litton Industries, Inc., a leading conglomerate concern that until now has made most of its acquisitions in this country, yesterday further broadened its horizons by completing negotiations to acquire Triumph Werke Nuremberg A. G. in West Germany and the related worldwide typewriter operations of the Grunding organization.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 96.8 on Tuesday from a revised level of 96.4 on Monday.
MOSCOW, Oct. 30 -- Georgi T. Beregovoi brought the Soyuz 3 to a soft landing in the snow-covered steppes of Kazakhstan today, four days after he had been lofted into orbit.

HARRY GAMBLE, Lafayette's football coach, is surprised but certainly happy over the unexpected success of his team this fall. Before a 13-10 loss to Bucknell last Saturday, Lafayette ran up its longest winning streak since 1960 (four games) and has its first chance for a winning season since that year.

"SIX DAYS TO ETERNITY," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, is a documentary, produced by an Israeli company, about the Arab-Israeli war that runs about an hour and a half -- that is, about one per cent of the length of the war itself.

Federal-state agreement on an $11-million work incentive program for 8,400 New York City welfare recipients was announced by Governor Rockefeller yesterday. The new program complies with a 1967 Federal law requiring certain employables to take jobs or training.
The map of the 21st Congressional District in the Bronx looks "something like an upside-down toadstool," according to some of the politicains working there.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Every Thursday for months past, the Ambassador at one European embassy and his most knowledgeable diplomats have drafted a dispatch to their foreign ministry telling how they think the American election campaign is going.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Oct. 31 -- Enemy guns, probably firing from positions in North Vietnam, shelled two United States bases just south of the demilitarized zone yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- An Army sergeant killed while singlehandedly destroying an enemy machine gun position has been posthumously awarded the 56th Medal of Honor of the Vietnam war. The widow of First Sgt. Maximo Yabes of Lafayette, Colo., will receive the nation's highest decoration in his behalf tomorrow.
DETROIT, Oct. 30 (AP -- The Ford Motor Company hired its 5,000th employe from the ranks of Detroit's hard-core unemployed today in a program that has become a model for businesses across the nation.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Biafra radio announced today that the secessionist regime had terminated relations with Henry Wharton, a naturalized American who had been flying arms into the former Eastern Region of Nigeria for at least two years.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A disturbance broke out tonight during a slum rally for Richard M Nixon at a dance hall, packed three times its capacity, to hear Lionel Hampton and his band. The police called the civil disturbance unit to break up looting and end rockthrowing.

Fordham University has disclosed plans to expand its board of trustees, elect a majority of laymen, and thus become the first Jesuit institution of higher learning in the country in which laymen would have numerical control of policy.
The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday a reorganization of its senior management, providing a line of succession that should stretch through the nineteen-eighties.

LONDON, Thursday, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union has carried out at least a dozen test launchings of rockets carrying its space bomb, the authoritative Jane's All The World's Aircraft reported today.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Farm prices fell 2 per cent during the month ended Oct. 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

EACH year a new crop of games emerges to educate, stimulate and, occasionally, baffle those who would pit their wits against them. A group of action or "body contact" games, relative newcomers to the scene, have caught on particularly well with teen-agers.

LANSING, Mich., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Former Gov. William W. Scranton of Pennsylvania said today he was not interested in a Cabinet post under a Republican administration but that it was "quite logical" that Gov. George Romney of Michigan would be asked to serve.

ATLANTIC CITY, Oct. 30 -- Robert Hamman and Edwin Kantar of Los Angeles this afternoon held on to the lead they established in the qualifying stage of the International Team Trials here, but several New York stars improved their positions.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Minnesota North Stars announced tonight that John Muckler had been named coach of the National Hockey League team.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Three defensemen, Doug Harvey, Noel Picard and Barclay Plager, scored goals tonight and led the St. Louis Blues to a 4-1 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers and sole possession of first place in the West Division of the National Hockey League.
LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 30 -- The United States team drew with Bulgaria, 2-2, today in the fifth round of the finals of the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell trophy.
ROCHESTER, Minn., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Richard M. Nixon will break an Election Day tradition and vote by absentee ballot, an aide said today.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Oct. 30 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie continued today his assault on strongholds of George C. Wallace, the third-party candidate.
SYRACUSE, Oct. 30 -- On this last upstate swing before the election there is little of the old-fashioned "hurrah" about Paul O'Dwyer's campaign for the United States Senate.
MACON, Ga. -- The old names and the new money in this central Georgia city of 140,000 are strongly behind Richard M. Nixon.

THERE are 70 artists represented in a new exhibition called "In Honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.," and just about the only thing they have in common is the space they share at the Museum of Modern Art.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A television engineer alone in the studio after the station shut down has acknowledged that he televised a stag movie thinking he had cut off any possible transmission, the police reported today.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The United States and North Vietnam have entered the "final stages" of bargaining on a halt to United States bombing of North Vietnam and the start of full-scale peace talks, Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman said today on his return from the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- Governor Rockefeller of New York disputed tonight the reliability of opinion polls. He told 4,200 persons at a Republican fund-raising dinner here, "There is no reason whatsoever to despair about the outcome in New York State next Tuesday for the Nixon-Agnew ticket."
BONN, Oct. 30 -- The chief Bonn correspondent of C.T.K., the official Czechoslovak press agency, was interrogated last night and today by West German security policemen as a spy suspect.

The Treasury's $11.93-billion refinancing operation, a three-day offer that came to a close yesterday, caused less stir than any refunding in recent years, Government securities dealers reported as the offer ended.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Gangster-type weapons such as machine guns and sawed-off shotguns and destructive devices such as bombs and mines must be registered with the Federal Government between Nov. 2 and Dec. 1., Sheldon S. Cohen, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, announced today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 30 -- Examination of courthouse records revealed today that Ray C. Ewald, Minneapolis businessman, was credited with paying property taxes on six lakeside lots in suburban Waverly for more than a year after he deeded the land to Hubert H. Humphrey in 1956.
A working relationship may be established by the National Council on the Arts and the American National Theater and Academy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower said today that the former President "is too thin, but his color is good" as he continues to recover from the most recent of seven heart attacks.

The Abe Schrader Corporation, a leading producer of quality apparel for women, will be aaquired by The Villager, Inc., under an agreement in principle announced yesterday. The Villager is one of the largest diversified producers in the apparel industry.

ATHENS, Oct. 30 -- Former Premier George Papandreou, who is 80 years old, was still in critical condition tonight in an Athens hospital after recurring internal bleeding. The leader of the Center Union was taken to the hospital Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- In deciding which candidate for President to vote for, the important thing is system. The wisest approach is to set aside a period time for deciding upon a candidate and to agree with yourself that once the choice is made, you will stick with it.

NEWARK, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- United Press International reported inadvertently yesterday that The Newark Star-Ledger had endorsed Richard M. Nixon for President. The Star-Ledger in its editions Oct. 16 came out for Hubert H. Humphrey.

SAIGON, Thursday, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Amid worldwide speculation that their missions over North Vietnam soon would end, United States jets struck again today at the enemy's supply lines in the southern panhandle, informed sources said, and more bombing strikes were planned for tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Total monetary reserves of the industrial countries were more than $1-billion lower at the end of the third quarter than they were a year earlier, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

WNBC-TV began a five-minute daily program yesterday offering information on events and activities of interest to schoolchildren on Channel 4. The feature, titled "Show and Tell," with Aline Saarinen, the news correspondent, as hostess, will be seen weekdays at 5:55 P.M. to 6 P.M.

Wendell A. Milliman of the actuarial consulting firm of Milliman Roberston, Seattle, Wash., has been elected president of the Society of Actuaries. He succeeds Morton D. Miller, vice president and actuary of the Equitable Life Assurance Society, New York.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Candles borne silently by about 200 marchers near the Lincoln Memorial last Friday night in a nationwide series of vigils reflected the rising concern of the American people, especially students, over the plight of Nigeria's starving war victims.

CAST changes are a welcome occurrence in the lyric theater. Both opera and ballet derive an appreciable part of their appeal from the presentation of varying casts, enabling aficionados to -- as the old examination papers used to put it -- compare and contrast.

The Ocean Hill-Brownsville district of Brooklyn is a small piece of New York City filled with people searching for something that the outside world has assumed they already had -- a thing called community.

The resignation of D. Mead Johnson as chairman of the board of Mead Johnson Co., a division of the Bristol-Myers Company, was announced yesterday. He also stepped down as senior vice president, director and member of the executive committee of Bristol-Myers.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- Neal Shapiro made the chestnut gelding Trick Track leap high and wide and handsomely enough for victory in the jumping competition of the Washington International horse show tonight. They had to go high.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 30 -- That's Great wasn't tonight in the $59,000 New York Sire Stakes for 2-year-old trotting colts and geldings at Roosevelt Raceway. On the strength of a record of 10 triumphs in 13 outings, Lloyd Lloyds's That's Great was barred from the betting in the field of nine.
NEW HAVEN, Oct. 30 -- The Yale Daily News, the undergraduate paper of Yale University, endorsed today, "with considerable reluctance," the candidacy of Vice President Humphrey.

Archimandrite Antony, head of the Russian Orthodox Church in Israel, has denied a report that his church is seeking control of "White" Russian Orthodox properties in the lands occupied by Israel during the war last year. The report was published in The New York Times Oct. 6.

The breakthrough toward peace in Vietnam that the world long has awaited now seems imminent. Hanoi's favorable reaction to an American-proposed formula for seating the Saigon Government and the National Liberation Front in the Paris negotiations, assuring an early start for substantive discussions, evidently is enabling the two sides to compromise their long-standing difference over a bombing halt.
PARIS, Oct. 30 -- The South Vietnamese Government and the National Liberation Front dueled tonight with cocktails and canapes at 3,000 yards.

I Philip Morris, Inc., reported yesterday record net income and revenues for the third quarter and for the first nine months of this year. The company sald that its worldwide cigarette unit sales rose about 12 per cent from the year earlier period.

Abie J. Nathan, the Israeli restaurateur and art gallery owner who twice piloted personal peace missions to the United Arab Republic, said yesterday he planned to leave for Biafra Sunday with a planeload of medical supplies.
Although the United States merchandise trade took a turn for the better in September, there is little reason for unrestrained optimism.

Governor Rockefeller said last night he was considering calling a special session of the State Legislature to deal with the city school crisis. He spoke after leaders of the teachers' union had rejected a state plan to end the teachers' strike.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- San Francisco's Police Chief, Thomas J. Cahill, called on Americans today to "rise up and support law enforcement."

ELIZABETH, N. J. Oct. 30 (AP) -- A grand jury said today that noise from low-flying Secret Service and news-media helicopters had partly drowned out warning horns on a train that killed two persons the day that Sen. Robert F. Kennedy's funeral train passed through this city.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- "Law and order" in a free society is not achievable by massive applications of police power alone, two witnesses testified today before the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence.
WARSAW, Oct. 28 -- The political decline of Adam Rapacki, the Polish Foreign Minister, has been confirmed.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today that First Lieut. Donald T. Penney of Willseyville, N.Y., had been killed in action in Vietnam.

More than 900 men in black tie and women in glittering dresses or silken pajamas attended a preview at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday evening to honor the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and to buy some of the paintings and sculptures that were exhibited.

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 30 -- In the last lap of California's Senate race, Dr. Max Rafferty is drawing ovations from audiences but he is not convincing some of his strongest supporters.

The election of Thor W. Kolle Jr., a partner in the investment banking firm of Hornblower Weeks-Hemphill, Noyes, as a director of the Federal Pacific Electric Company was announced yesterday.

The City Planning Commission was asked yesterday to prevent further real estate development near the confluence of the Hudson and Harlem Rivers in the Bronx.

Millen Brand's new novel, "Savage Sleep," had an advance printing of 46,000 copies, will be a Literary Guild alternative selection and has been sold for $205,000 to Bantam Books for paperback reprinting.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Mr. Humphrey told Maryland Democrats tonight he was "absolutely sure" he would win if the party faithful kept fighting for the next six days. He spoke at a $300,000 fund-raising inner at the Pikesville National Guard Armory.
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 30 -- George C. Wallace, after receiving an unresponsive daytime reception in Wheeling, W. Va., drew a wildly shouting crowd of partisans at an evening rally here.
ALBANY, Oct. 30 (AP) -- New York State has asked the Federal Government for $2.175-billion to help build 20 superhighways.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- A 20-room office suite in the Executive Office Building next door to the White House has been reserved for the President-elect, the White House announced today.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 30 -- A study at the National Institutes of Health has shown that half of a group of surgery patients who received blood that came from commercially paid donors developed hepatitis, probably as a result of the transfusions.

The Menorah Home and Hospital for the Aged and Infirm in Brooklyn will receive the proceeds of a luncheon to be given by its 20 auxiliaries on Monday at the New York Hilton. The theme, "The Art of Life," will be carried out in the ballroom decor with a display of embroidery, paintings, tapestries, ceramics and sculpture made by residents of the home.

QUITO, Ecuador, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- About 40 persons were burned to death or drowned when the coastal motorship Rio Esmeraldas caught fire and sank earlier this week, Ecuadorian authorities reported today.

Four store managers of Macy's New York have been named vice presidents. They are Myron Hirsch of the New Rochelle, N. Y., store; Aldo Papone, of the New Haven store; Edmund Rubin, of the Parkchester, N. Y., store; and Frederick Wilkinson, of the Jamaica, Queens, store.

ACCRA, Ghana, Oct. 30 -- The executive committee of the University of Ghana closed its campus today and ordered students to leave the university premises until further notice.

At a time of life when others of her stature would be looking backward and writing their memoirs, Martha Graham is looking to the future. SHORTLY before World War II started, leading American scientists met in Washington to ponder recent discoveries in atomic physics and discuss the possibilities of building a super weapon. All were aware of the theory that enormous amounts of energy could be released through a chain reaction started by the bombardment with neutrons of a rare isotope of uranium, number 235.

BALTIMORE, Oct. 30 (UPI) -- Earl Monroe's 25-foot jump shot with two seconds remaining in the overtime period capped a rally by Baltimore tonight and gave the Bullets a 112-110 National Basketball Association victory over the San Francisco Warriors.

ABERAVON, Wales, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Virginia Wade of England, the United States womens' open tennis champion, gained the semi-finals of the Welsh covered courts championships today with a 6-3, 6-0 victory over 17-year-old Pamela Teeguarden of Los Angeles. Winnie Shaw of Scotland rallied to beat Mary Ann Eisel of St. Louis, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5.

A state corporation created by the 1968 Legislature will build and outfit four new hospitals, eight neighborhood health-care centers and two housing projects for hospital staffs in this city at a cost of $276.4-million dollars, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

BUFFALO, Oct. 31 -- Governor Rockefeller broke ground for the State University's Amherst campus today and told of its ''breath-taking" dimensions that would make it one of the largest college complexes in the nation.

Kinney National Service, Inc., announced yesterday plans to acquire the $150-million Hackensack Trust Company through an exchange of its stock valued at somewhat over $23-million. Kinney would offer, 11-3 of its shares for each of the 231,800 shares of the New Jersey bank.

The Friends of Animals, Inc., will benefit from a soiree Wednesday at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel. The evening will include two films, the world premiere of "The Alps by Helicopter" and "Village Under the Sea in the Bahamas," followed by supper and dancing. The Duke and Duchess of Windsor are honorary chairmen of the event.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $641-million, up 12 per cent from the year-earlier $572-million. Total retail store sales last week were about $6,654,000,000, up 10 per cent from $6,056,000,000.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A proposal that would have merged two northern California thoroughbred racing groups with Hollywood Park in southern California has been called off.

The Pakistani field hockey team, which won the gold medal at the Olympic Games in Mexico City, was honored last night at Pakistan House here. Agha Shahi, Pakistan's permanent representative to the United Nations, and Agha Hilaly, the Pakistani Ambassador to the United States, and his wife tendered the reception.

Businessmen responded last night to President Johnson's order to halt the bombing of North Vietnam with personal delight and professional bullishness. LONDON, Oct. 31 -- John Osborne's "Look Back in Anger," which shook up British stage traditions in 1956, had a triumphant revival Tuesday night at the Royal Court Theater.
