A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group of companies reported yesterday sharply higher profits for the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30 over a year earlier.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Oct. 31 (AP) -- Skee Foremsky of El Paso, Tex., rolled 1,365 in a six-game block today and increased his lead after the third round of the $30,000 Professional Bowlers Association Green Bay open.

Seven months to the day from his announcement of a partial cessation of the bombing of North Vietnam and his withdrawal from the Presidential race Lyndon Johnson has ordered the rest of the bombing halted. With the ground rules for substantive peace negotiations fixed meanwhile in secret talks, the search for a political settlement of the long Southeast Asian conflict can now begin.
CAIRO, Oct. 31 -- The Grand Rabbi of Cairo said last week that as far as is known only one child was born into Egypt's dwindling Jewish community this year.

IF all the old bellhops from the Catskills are true friends of Dave Newmark, they have put away their pens and their stationery and resisted the urge to write Big Wilt Chamberlain one more letter. Their buddy Dave has to look Big Wilt in the eye tonight.
DANBURY, Conn., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Danbury News-Times endorsed Vice President Humphrey for the Presidency today.
MILWAUKEE, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Bucks gained their first National Basketball Association victory tonight, 134-118, over the Detroit Pistons as Wayne Embry scored 30 points.

Elizabeth Harwood, a pretty, gracious and very accomplished soprano from England, made her New York debut with a recital in Town Hall last night. Her varied program ranged from arias by Handel, Mozart and Donizetti to songs by Mozart, Richard Strauss, Schoenberg, Britten and Hageman. John Streets, an equally accomplished artist, was at the piano.
LET us pause this morning and bid Wahoo McDaniel a fond farewell. The Miami Dolphins have dropped Wahoo, the middle linebacker from Oklahoma with the Indian ancestors who was the Jets' first hero.
O. Wayne Carrico, general manager of the industrial division of Aerojet-General Corporation, has been elected a vice-president of the company. It is controlled by the General Tire and Rubber Company.
The Federal Reserve is continuing to press the restrictive monetary policy that it began in September, banking data published yesterday indicated.

The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation and the Williams Brothers Company reached an agreement in principle yesterday to merge in an exchange of stock with an estimated market value of $187-Million.

"CHERS amis. bonjour." With those words, press conferences are habitually opened by a short. wiry. bespectacled man with a quick smile, a zest for repartee and an evident affection for proverbs and folk tales.
DETROIT, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Frank Mahovlich's last of three goals enabled the Detroit Red Wings to register a 7-5 National Hockey League victory over the Boston Bruins tonight.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- A Congressional committee said today that employment in Federal executive agencies decreased by 90,624 in September, partly because of the mandatory rollback in Government manpower levels ordered this year by Congress. The Congressional Joint Committee on Reduction of Federal Expenditures said that the September employment level was 2,928,438.

The mothers of the 14 young women who will be presented Nov. 30 at the 26th annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball were honored yesterday at a tea given by Mrs. David Granger at her home at 940 Park Avenue. She is serving on the committee for the event, which benefits the Grosvenor Neighborhood House, 176 West 105th Street. Mrs. Charles I. Pierce Jr. is ball chairman.

The little-known game or Australian football will be exhibited here Sunday at 3 P.M., when a group of Australian all-stars plays a team of Irish-Americans at Gaelic Park, 240th Street and Broadway, in the Bronx.
Record earnings for the third quarter and the nine months ended Sept. 30 were reported yesterday by Schlumberger, Ltd., an international oil field services and electronic instrument company.
KANSAS CITY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Kansas City Chiefs placed Wendell Hayes, a fullback, on the injured waiver list today.

Mayor Lindsay told the City Planning Commission yesterday that nearly half of all capital funds available for the 1969-70 fiscal year would probably be required for two major programs -- schools and rapid transit.
The annual Greenwich House antiques show opened yesterday with a blend of antiques of traditional character and "pop" antiques, the latest designation for the "wild" and "camp" with slim tradition.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Oct. 31 -- Nigeria has apologized for a field commander's insulting remarks to a group of international observers invited to watch the conduct of the civil war, a Government spokesman said here today.
ATLANTA, Oct. 30 -- The third-party Presidential campaign mounted by former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama has lost momentum in the South, the region on which he is most heavily dependent.
A new trade group, the Brotherhood of Towmen Association, Inc., was formed yesterday. It said its first item of business would be to ask the city for an increase in rates.
The discovery of a protein that appears to facilitate the transfer of calcium in food from the intestines to the blood was announced yesterday by two Cornell University scientists.

Spartans Industries, Inc., which operates the E. J. Korvette discount-store chain, reported yesterday a small gain in sales in its fiscal year ended July 29, while the nation's three largest general merchandise-catalog chains announced substantial increases in volume in October.
Cocoa trading was hectic yesterday, with three sharp rallies and declines and heavy volume of 4,973 contracts.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Defense Department identified the following men from the New York area today as having been killed in Vietnam:
EDGARTOWN, Mass. -- Not long after World War II, I was taught to cat squid by Capt. John Aiello of Gloucester, Mass.

Eighty-four 19th-century European paintings and drawings, including examples of the Barbizon School, were auctioned yesterday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries for a total of $301,045, reflecting, according to a gallery spokesman, a 30 per cent rise over prices last Spring.
WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- President Johnson has received at least one, and possibly more. conditional offers of an advance in excess of $1-million for his memoirs.

CLOVIS, N. M., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Capt. Dale Noyd of the Air-Force said today he would appeal the latest ruling in his refusal to train pilots for Vietnam, possibly to the United States Supreme Court. An appellate court ruled yesterday that he should be taken to the Federal penitentiary at Fort Leavenworth, Kan.
The Federal Trade Commission has asked the St. Regis Paper Company and the Radio Corporation of America for information concerning their proposed merger, officials of the companies said yesterday.
Remember Jason Robards in "The Petrified Forest"? Anne Jackson and Eli Wallach in "This Property ls Condemned"? Charlton Heston in "The Millionairess"? Rod Steiger in "A Sound of Hunting"?

MOSCOW, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Lenin's granite mausoleum on Red Square will be closed for repairs from Nov. 12 to Jan. 12 and barred to the public, it was announced today. The airconditioned tomb containing the embalmed body of the founding father of Soviet Communism is regularly closed once or twice a year.

The appointment of Charles W. Carson Jr. as a senior vice president of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company was announced yesterday. He is in charge of most of the European area for the bank's international division.

MANDALAY, Burma. Oct. 22 -- Communist insurgents operating in the densely forested hills of central Burma are reeling from a disastrous series of setbacks a year after Communist China declared its open support for their rebellion.

CLEVELAND, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Luis Tiant was named the Cleveland Indians' man of the year for 1968 today by the Cleveland chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America. Tiant's 21 victories were the most by a Cleveland pitcher since Early Wynn and Bob Lemon won 23 games each in 1954.

BONN, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A senior Defense Ministry clerk, missing since Oct. 21, was found dead today, a Ministry spokesman announced. He said the clerk, Gerhard Boehm, 61 years old, had committed suicide. Officials said an investigation had turned up no evidence of breaches of security by him.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Time has passed for the Negro to be patient about the denial of his legal rights, a leading Negro lawyer told the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence today.

BALCHIK, Bulgaria -- In late 1940 I accompanied the Bulgarian Army that occupied this pleasant seaside capital of the wheat-growing South Dobrudja Province, then held by Rumania. It was an operetta performance with gypsy children mingling in the triumphal parade, seeking to beg from troops, while a mixed population of Bulgars, Rumanians, Turks, Ukrainians and Tartar remnants of the Golden Horde regarded the splendid sight.

ATHENS, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- After ending another day of business talks with Greek Government officials, Mr. Onassis told newsmen today in Athens that he would shortly take his wife to the island of Skorpios.

DAYTONA Beach, Fla., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Pete Hamilton, a 25-year-old Massachusetts native who swapped mechanical engineering studies for racing, was named Nascar's Grand National rookie of the year today. Hamilton competed in 15 races, finishing in the top five three times and the top 10 on six occasions. He won $7,920.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- Unless the fans at the Spectrum for tonight's contest between the New York Rangers and the Philadelphia Flyers looked closely, they might never have noticed a shadowy figure in a white-and-red-trimmed Ranger uniform named Bob Nevin.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Association of American Railroads reported freight traffic in the week ended Oct. 26 totaled an estimated 15.6 billion ton-miles, 3.9 per cent above the like period of last year.

As many political observers had long expected, President Johnson moved last night -- less than a week before what already appeared to be a close Presidential election -- to end the bombing of North Vietnam and get down to serious peace negotiations.
TOKYO, Friday, Nov. 1 -- The Japanese financial community welcomed the American bombing halt today as a step toward peace but warned that it might have a dampening effect on the Japanese economy.

TOWSON, Md., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The general counsel for the Chesapeake National Bank has written James Reston, executive editor of The New York Times, asking for a retraction of an editorial criticizing Gov. Spiro T. Agnew.
The American Stock Exchange ended lower yesterday after selling pressure in the afternoon erased most of the earlier gains.

Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, demanded yesterday that Democratic national campaign chairman, Lawrence J. O'Brien, explain a reported $100,000 contribution to his party by the Seafarer's International Union after the State Department refused to extradite Harold C. Banks, union executive.

IN England, Colin Davis and Berlioz have become all but synonymous. Thus it was no surprise, when on Mr. Davis's first appearance with the New York Philharmonic, he devoted his entire program to music by the French romanticist. Berlioz plays a prominent part in this year's Philharmonic programing.

The Girl Scout Council of Greater New York will benefit from the opening-night champagne gala art show Wednesday at the Hammer Galleries. The show, marking the 40th anniversary of the galleries, will include paintings lent from private collections throughout the world.
A work stoppage by members of the American Radio Association yesterday immobilized more than 20 freighters and tankers in East and Gulf Coast ports.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- President Chiang Kai-shek quietly observed his 81st birthday today.
Pvt. William Steven Brake-field, RA 16941810, stood in a ballroom at City College yesterday and talked about the spirit of the bayonet.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 -- The usual reckless final minutes staged by the team that is trailing by one goal was not enough tonight for the Flyers, who gave the Rangers their toughest game against a West Division club but wound up losing, 2-1.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Oct. 31 (AP) -- A Lovely Latin posted her third straight victory today in winning the St. Helena Purse by a neck at Bay Meadows and returned $53.20, $11.20 and $8 for $2 across the board.
Something of the political virulence of the 1950's has reappeared in the 23d Congressional District race in the Bronx.

Anne Kaye, the tenth actress to play the girl, the only feminine role in "The Fanasticks," since the play opened in 1960, will receive the Beaux Arts Club's award for Off Broadway acting. The presentation will be made Nov. 15 at the group's ball in the Gotham Hotel.

MIAMI, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Miami Hurricanes, dumped out of the nation's top 10 by last week's 31-6 rout by Auburn, hopes to get their bandwagon back on the track tonight as host to Pittsburgh in the Orange Bowl.
MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's endorsement Tuesday of Vice President Humphrey could provide Mr. Humphrey with the margin of victory in his home state.
A rally in support of the Humphrey - Muskie ticket at Manhattan Center was disrupted last night by chanting demonstrators led by a naked man and woman.

WHEN a play is about David and Goliath and you find yourself rooting for Goliath, you might well conjecture on what the author did wrong. "The David Show," which opened at the Players Theater last night, is monstrous, pretentious and, perhaps most of all, vain.

HOT SPRINGS, Va., Oct. 31 -- At the Homestead -- huge, elegant, well appointed and rising in quiet grandeur from well-tended lawns, it is hard to think of the nation's teeming ghettos, angry campuses and soaring crime rate.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Nov. 1 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that the United States had acted unilaterally in its decision to halt the bombing of North Vietnam.
LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 -- Former Governor Edmund G. Browns of California, co-chairman of the California-Humphrey Campaign, said:
ALBANY, Oct. 31 (AP) -- A relatively low total of 8,113,216 persons registered to vote in the Presidential election in New York Tuesday, the Department of State reported today.

NORFOLK, Va., Oct. 31 -- George C. Wallace refused tonight to speculate on possible motives behind President Johnson's announcement of a bombing halt in North Vietnam. He said his only hope was that the war comes to an "honorable end."

SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 31 (AP) -- George Archer and Miller Barber led a par-breaking barrage in the first round of the $100,000 Lucky International open golf tournament today, tying for the lead with five under-par-66's.
Channel 13 broke an embargo and televised the President's speech 20 minutes before it was officially released last night.

Concerts as a form of abstract theater, in which sights, lights and movement mean as much as notes, are no longer novelties on the contemporary scene. And so it was not surprising that the first event on this year's New Image of Sound series at Hunter College Assembly Hall was devoted almost entirely to theaterlike pieces.

A Negro insurance man and a Puerto Rican physician, two of the candidates for Congress in the southeast Bronx, are using their racial and ethnic identities in an attempt to crack the solid dominance of the Democratic party in the predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican area that forms the 22d Congressional District.

A new post office that will handle packages faster and in greater volume than any other in the country opened here yesterday morning across the street from the old Sutton Station, which it has replaced.
LISBON, Oct. 31 -- A crowd of several hundred Portuguese students protesting the death of a political prisoner was dispersed by security police today.
MOSCOW, Oct. 31 -- The Central Committee of the Communist party, the Soviet Union's highest policy making body, unanimously endorsed today Soviet foreign policy.

LAUREL, Md., Oct. 31 -- George Cusimano, an apprentice jockey and the nation's third leading rider this year, rode winners with his first four mounts today at Laurel Park. The 19-year-old Cusimano also was aboard the victor in the final event yesterday, giving him a five-race streak.

A church service written and performed "in the rock idiom" might, it could he presumed, be somewhat startling. But R. Clayton Pitts Jr., who conducted selections from his rock service, "Praise the Lord," in the auditorium of the Library of the Performing Arts at Lincoln Center late yesterday afternoon, assured his audience before the performance that "it was no gimmick."

The State Conservation Department announced yesterday a four-month deadline for installing either incinerators or holding tanks for human wastes on inland water craft. Owners of coastal vessels, tugs, barges and pleasure craft have until March 1 to comply.
Mrs. Rhena Eckert-Schweitzer, daughter of the late Dr. Albert Schweitzer, said yesterday that her father's hospital at Lambarene, Gabon, was ing opened to starving children from Biafra.
"Lenny," based on the nightclub material used by the late Lenny Bruce, comedian, is being prepared for a late spring opening on Broadway. The show was adapted and directed by Fred Baker.

ROME, Oct. 31 -- The Vatican's Cabinet of Ministers met today to discuss such issues as taxes, the institution of a top-level theological commission and the world-wide reaction to the recent birth control encyclical of Pope Paul VI, informed Vatican sources said.

Walter Brewus, the violinist who played at Carnegie Hall last night, is clearly not afraid of challenging music. His boldest choice was Bach's unaccompanied Partita in D minor (which includes the great Chaconne), but his program also held Faure's Sonata in A (Op. 13), Bloch's Sonata, the Saint Saens-Ysaye Etude in Form of a Waltz, and a new piece--Nicholas Flagello's "Declamation."

"A Way of Life," Murray Schisgal's second new play of the season, will open Jan. 27 at a theater to be named. His first, "Jimmy Shine," starring Dustin Hoffman, has been postponed from Nov. 21 to Nov. 27 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater.
Senator Edmund S. Muskie warned leading Democrats here last night that the road to peace in Vietnam could still be long and arduous.

STOCKHOLM, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Swedish Aliens Commission granted asylum to 11 more United States military fugitives today, raising the total here to 126. The commission said some of the American servicemen had entered Sweden by way of the Soviet Union while others fled from units in West Germany and elsewhere.
Yesterday was a big day for Chester Williams, Annie Dunn and Louis L. Allen. Each was busy at the opening of the Afro-Spanish Co-op Restaurant in Brooklyn -- and each in a different way.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- In the summer of 1964, unknown to the American public, President Johnson was told by his top military, diplomatic and intelligence advisers that unless the United States took decisive military action to bolster South Vietnam, the Saigon Government probably would collapse, permitting the Communists to take over.

"First Aid for Broadway?" will be discussed at next Monday's luncheon meeting of the Drama Desk at Sardi's West. The organization of drama reporters and editors will hear the views of James Earl Jones, Jane Alexander, Edwin Sherin, Jason Robards, Diana Sands, Morton Gottlieb, Joseph Heller and Robert Anderson.

MINNEAPOLIS, Oct. 31 -- Warren Spannaus, chairman of the Democratic - Farmer Labor party Vice President Humphrey was instrumental in forming in Minnesota 24 years ago, said he was "exhilarated" by the President's announcement tonight of a bombing halt.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The Johnson Adminsitration's decision to stop the bombing of North Vietnam was greeted enthusiastically tonight by Congressional doves and somewhat skeptically by leading hawks.

Stock prices raced upward early yesterday in anticipation of a breakthrough in the Vietnamese peace negotiations, but the advance foundered in the absence of definite developments to confirm the earlier optimism.
Several major figures in Senator Eugene J. McCarthy's campaign for the Presidency disagreed sharply yesterday with his endorsement of Vice President Humphrey.

HOLLYWOOD, Oct. 31 -- In their ample offices here above a Rexall drug store, Geoffrey M. Shurlock, director of the Motion Picture Association of America's Code Administration, and his five-man staff have been quietly classifying movies that go into general release beginning tomorrow.
Missing custodians, padlocked schools and teacher picket lines are complicating the job of getting voting machines into the schools for Tuesday's national elections.
JERUSALEM, Friday, Nov. 1 -- Israeli commandos struck deep into the United Arab Republic early today in retaliation for Egyptian incursions Saturday on the eastern bank of the Suez Canal.
Two American scientists have reported evidence that at least two mountains deep within Marie Byrd Land periodically spout steam into the frigid Antarctic sky.
Welfare has supplanted education as the city's biggest expense item.
PARIS, Oct. 31 -- The Government today ordered the dissolution of the extreme-right Occident organization of students under a 1936 law against "private militias."

John C. Bogle, president of the Wellington Management Company, forecast yesterday that "institutionalization" of the nation's security markets will continue into the 1970's and exert a positive effect on stock-price stability.

ROME, Oct. 31 -- The Most Rev. Frantisek Towasek, apostolic administrator of Prague, has arrived in Rome to take part in meetings of the Secretariat for Christian Unity, a Vatican body concerned with the union of Christendom.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Lucinda Desha Robb, just six days old and wearing a yellow hair ribbon for "her daddy who is far, far away," came home to the White House today for a sentimental welcome from her grandparents.
Following is a transcript of President Johnson's address to the nation last night as recorded by The New York Times:

The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that the issue in the musicians' strike against the three major television networks was "the insistence by the union membership that the networks continue to retain the quota system of paying a large number of musicians for whom there is no work."
A Tel Aviv newspaper has made it clear that you don't have to be Gentile to like Paul O'Dwyer.

YONKERS, Oct. 31 -- Brad Hanover, a full brother to Bullet Hanover, brought $100,000 when he was purchased as a yearling at Harrisburg in 1966. Today, as the ninth revival of the Old Glory Horse Sale ended at Yonkers Raceway, Brad Hanover, now a 3-year-old pacer with a mile mark of 2:00 1-5 over the half-mile oval at Saratoga Raceway, was auctioned for $28,000.

The Union Pacific Railroad, the most profitable railroad in the nation, reported yesterday equal to $1.13 a share, for the three months to Sept. 30. This compared with $25.3-million, or $1.09 a share, in the same quarter last year.
Richard M. Nixon expressed last night his hope that the halt in the bombing of North Vietnam would "bring some progress" in the Paris talks on the war.

PRAGUE, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Vera Caslavska, married to Josef Odlozil in Mexico last Saturday, received the Czechoslovak Order of The Republic today from President Ludvik Svoboda. She won four gold and one silver medal in gymnastics at the Olympic Games in Mexico City.

The city's firefighters decided yesterday at a raucous meeting in Manhattan Center to conduct a mail referendum on whether to accept a proposed contract that would give them a raise of $1,367 over two years.

Transamerican Trailer Transport has moved its Manhattan office to 76 Beaver Street, effective today. The steamship line operates a weekly roll-on, roll-off service on the trailership Ponce de Leon from its Staten Island dock to San Juan, P. R.
A one-day wildcat strike by longshoremen yesterday halted work on 25 of the 76 drycargo ships in port.
The Allied Chemical Corporation, which registered a loss of $15.4-million in the third quarter, announced yesterday it was cutting its quarterly dividend from 47 1/2 cents a share to 30 cents.

ROXBURY, Conn. -- William Styron, who won this year's Pulitzer Prize for the novel "The Confessions of Nat Turner," earlier this month protested in Moscow the jailing of writers in the Soviet Union. He disclosed his action in an interview at his home here this week.

Two sopranos and a contralto won the Marian Anderson Scholarship auditions held in Philadelphia last week. Linda Matousek, a contralto from Muncie, Ind., and Nelda Ormond, a soprano from Ayden, N. C., are co-winners of the $800 first prize.
THE JOURNEY TO THE EAST. By Hermann Hesse. Translated from the German by Hilda Rosner. 118 pages. Farrar, Straus Giroux. $4.50.

James Farmer, Republican candidate for the House of Representatives from Brooklyn's 12th Congressional District, announced yesterday his support of Hubert H. Humphrey for President. Mr. Farmer is former director of the Congress of Racial Equality.
BOSTON, Oct. 31 -- The Boston Globe will break a silence of 76 years on Presidential endorsements when it comes out tomorrow for Vice President Humphrey.

A nationwide effort was announced here yesterday to get the eight million enrolled Negro voters in the 50 states to the polls on Tuesday. Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People; said the campaign would be directed by John M. Brooks of Richmond.

PARIS, Friday, Nov. 1 -- North Vietnam's negotiators responded with official silence early today to the announcement that American bombardment of their country would cease. They said that there might be an official statement later in the day.

A dozen youths hurled rocks, eggs and firebombs in a 10 minute attack on a Jewish school in Brooklyn last night, shattering windows, setting several small interior fires and disrupting classes for several hundred junior high and high school students.

MAIDENHEAD, England, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Princess Stanislas Radziwill, sister of Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis, was fined the equivalent of $36 today for careless driving. Princess Radziwill, who is married to a London businessman, did not appear in court and a guilty plea was entered by a lawyer.
Stock exchanges and the over-the-counter market, still hampered by a logjam of paper work, will continue to operate on four-day weeks during November.

"The Playwright and the Technician: A Dialogue?" will be discussed at 8 P.M. next Wednesday at the Co-Op Theater Club, 106 East 14th Street, under the auspices of the Insti tute for Theater Technology. Off Off Broadway will be represented by Herbert Dana Greggs and Ron Olson; Off Broadway, Kert Lundell and Ronald Ribman, and Broadway, Jo Mielziner.
The credit markets, responding to reports that full-scale Vietnam talks were closer at hand, advanced in price yesterday morning. Trading activity also picked up.

The exchange offer of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., designed to reduce the company's longterm debt and the number of outstanding common shares, became effective yesterday and will remain open until Nov. 15, unless extended.

CHICAGO, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Jerry Rubin, a leader of the Youth International party (Yippies), and three other men were indicted today on charges stemming from the battles between policemen and demonstrators during the Democratic National Convention.

Mrs. Billie Jean King received a trophy yesterday honoring her as the world's No. 1 woman tennis player. Fourteen of 15 sports writers on a selection committee actting for World Tennis magazine accorded Mrs. King the top ranking. Rod Laver of Australia was the unanimous choice for No. 1 among the men.

Pat Pomfrey, a hurdler and sprinter in the Air Force at Sacramento, Calif., was named yesterday to replace Tom White of Los Angeles on the six-man track and field team that leaves Monday for a six-week tour of Africa. Pomfrey was named as a replacement because White is due to assume military duty in a few days.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- An organization of Roman Catholic laymen joined today a revolt by liberal priests against Archbishop Robert E. Lucey.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- On Oct. 9, 1968, North Vietnam began asking the United States some serious questions. These questions and the American replies dominated 22 days of tense and tangled diplomacy, involving a dozen capitals, and led today to an order to cease all bombing of North Vietnam.
ELIZABETH, N. J., Oct. 31 -- Hubert Humphrey's last hurrah in this campaign is a loud but surprisingly serene message that says, in effect, "Come home, for heaven's sake, come home."

The chairman of the state's Joint Legislative Committee on Consumer Protection questioned yesterday whether the five-member Public Service Commission represented "the broad philosophical spectrum of the people of New York."

Last season during a Baltimore-New York National Basketball Association game, Earl Monroe of the Bullets faked around Butch Komives. Walt Bellamy, the Knick center, picked him up on the drive. Monroe faked again on his shot, Bellamy went for the shot, but Earl waited for him to come down. He then jumped and sank the shot.

WESTBURY, L. I., Oct. 31 -- Dayan, described by John (Tic) Wilcutts, who catch-drove him to a one-length victory in the $96,865.38 Westbury Futurity for 2-year-old trotters tonight at Roosevelt Raceway, as "tall, leggy, green, awkward, but potentially great," won a lot of money for a young horse who did so many things wrong.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed lower across the board yesterday. Dealers attributed the decline to large-scale profit taking following rumors of a further credit squeeze.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The 56th Medal of Honor of the Vietnam war was presented today to an Army the widow of sergeant who died in a single-handed attack on an enemy machine gun nest. Mrs. Janis A. Yabes of Lafayette, Colo., accepted the medal on behalf of her husband, First Sgt. Maximo Yabes, who was killed in South Vietnam's Binhduong Province, ten not knowing who there Feb. 26, 1967.
A letter sent by an aide of Richard M. Nixon to rabbis in this country proposing that they support Mr. Nixon in their sermons has drawn the ire of Jewish leaders.

SINCE its inception in 1947, the Brooklyn Museum's National Print Exhibition has become the most important show in the field, with the best of traditional printmaking serving as a sounding board for the most promising experiments.

SAIGON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- United States planes carried out daylight missions against North Vietnam today but orders went out to stop the bombing by 9 P.M. Saigon time in line with President Johnson's orders.

Mayor Lindsay and the president of the teachers' union both reacted coolly yesterday to a suggestion that Governor Rockefeller convene a special session of the State Legislature to deal with the city school crisis.
COLUMBIA, S. C., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Columbia Record endorsed Richard M. Nixon today as "the one best qualified to administer a stable, harmonious and progressive government.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Oct. 31 -- The 34th American Assembly began today an investigation of how the world can feed population that is racing toward six billion people er more by the end of this century.
John W. deMilhau, who retired last month from the Chase Manhattan Bank, where he headed the municipal bond department, today will become an executive vice president and director of Altgelt Co., Inc.
NEW PALTZ, N. Y., Oct. 30 -- A psychologist who has studied the visual acuity of both monkeys and men has concluded that nearsightedness in most people results from reading a lot.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Oct. 31 (UPI) -- The Pompano Beach Sun-Sentinel endorsed Mr. Nixon today, saying that he was "by experience, ability and temperament" the man needed in the White House for the next four years to lead our country to a return to stabiliyt, sound economics, law and order, sensible foreign policy and confidence in our national Government."
PRINCETON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- On the basis of Gallup Poll evidence, a record total of 75 million persons will vote for President in Tuesday's election.
The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation announced yesterday that Charles M. Beeghly, 60, had elected to retire as chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Administration officials cautioned tonight against expecting an early end of the war in Vietnam as a result of the agreement to stop the bombing of North Vietnam announced by President Johnson.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Oct. 31 -- Senator W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said he was hopeful that President Johnson's announcement of a bombing halt would soon lead to a general ceasefire in Vietnam.

BANGKOK, Thailand; Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- A general election bill for the return of parliamentary government to Thailand after 10 years of army-backed rule was approved today by the Senate. After the king signs it, a decree will be issued setting Feb. 15 as the date for general elections.

BOB CREWE, 35-year-old record producer, song writer and, on ooccasion, singer, was living in an apartment on the West Side when he "decided it was time to look for something more permanent." So in 1966 he bought a three-story penthouse on Fifth Avenue for $275,000.

"When she's good, I think she's very good. But the trouble is, I don't know when she's going to be good," was the comment made by Jimmy Conway after the main race at Aqueduct yesterday. He was referring to the 4-year-old filly Shore, whom he trains for Charles H. Wacker 3d.

DAYTON, Ohio, Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Dayton Area Chamber of Commerce threatened today to cancel its contract to be host to the P.G.A. championship tournament here next August unless it can be assured that top golfers will participate.
BONN, Oct. 31 -- The West German Government, buffeted in a storm over a series of spy scandals, opened a full-scale investigation into the work of its three espionage services today.

A major reorganization of the bank credit card business is under way. It will greatly broaden the utility of existing credit cards and will hasten the development of two highly competitive: national credit card systems.
PADUCAH, Ky., Oct. 31 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay asserted today that any bombing halt that would be announced could be a political move to influence the election rather than a "real move toward peace."

PATERSON, N. J., Oct. 31 -- A defense lawyer, his voice high-pitched and scornful, thumped his fist on the rim of the witness box today and shouted a challenge at a convict who had testified he helped murder Gabriel (Johnny the Walk) DeFranco.

Mayor Lindsay cut a bright red ribbon yesterday to open the city's new computerized air-pollution monitoring system, which he said would give "for the first time anywhere in the nation, a scientific profile of the quality of air in virtually every neighborhood."
PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Stewart Hanover, with Ronnie Dancer driving, captured the feature race, a $45,000 pace, at Liberty Bell Park tonight.

The Hambro American Bank and Trust Company, a new state bank formed by Hambros Bank, Ltd., the London merchant bank, and the commercial banking business of the New York private banking concern of Laidlaw Co., will begin operations this morning at 25 Broad Street.

COLLEGE football coaches usually do all the talking, and their young charges listen, trying to absorb the many intricacies of offensive and defensive formations, both of their own team and the next opponent.

Six men, including a law professor and four Southern businessmen, were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury in connection with an international fencing operation to dispose of $350,000 in stolen blue chip securities.
Dr. George H. Gallup said yesterday he was scrapping a poll of Harlem Negro attitudes on public and personal problems because two specially employed interviewers "had falsified part of their data."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The first full committee meeting of the 1968 Washington National Symphony Ball was held today, but that wasn't what held the interest of the 100 people from Virginia, Maryland and capital society.
Mayor Lindsay was invited to attend the Nixon rally in Madison Square Garden last night but said he was unable to do so.

Jules Munshin will be co-starred with Barry Nelson and Dorothy Loudon in the musical, "The Fig Leaves Are Falling." Miss Loudon's role in "Noel Coward's Sweet Potato" has been assumed by Monique Van Vooren.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Oct. 31 (AP) -- The Phoenix Suns, led by Gail Goodrich's 30 points, moved into a tie for the Western Division lead in the National Basketball Association tonight with a 112-103 triumph over the Chicago Bulls.
DENVER, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Dr. Charles H. Brimfield of York, Pa., was elected today president of the American College of Osteopathic Surgeons.

Dr. Harold M. Proshansky, an environmental psychologist, has been named dean of the graduate division of the City University. The appointment was announced yesterday by the division's provost, Dr. Mina Rees. He will head the development of the division's doctoral programs, which currently enroll 1,400 students in 23 fields.
Five New York newspaperwomen were named yesterday as winners of the 31st annual Front Page Awards for distinguished journalism.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Oct. 31 .(AP) -- Daniel Cohn-Bendit, hero of the French student rebellion last May, was sentenced to three days in jail today for disrupting the arson trial of four opponents of the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- The assumption of the New York Stock Exchange that dire consequences would follow abolition of uniform, fixed commission charges on stock transactions was challenged today by two economists.

LUGANO, Switzerland, Oct. 31 -- The United States team lost to the Soviet Union today, 2 1/2-1/2, with one game adjourned, in the sixth round of the finals of the 18th Chess Olympiad for the Hamilton Russell Trophy.

NEWARK, Oct. 31 -- The chief of the Essex County prosecuor's gambling squad testified today that he "often lied" to the Newark policemen participating in gambling raids with him so that "the job would not be blown."

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 -- Gay Wiles, young, pretty, brunette and new to international circles, gave the United States a fourth straight victory at the Washington International Horse Show tonight. The event was for the Ringmaster Challenge Trophy and Miss Wiles rode The Senator to first place in it with a flashing round that also was flawless in a 13-horse jumpoff.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Oct. 31 -- Vice President Humphrey reacted cautiously but with scarcely concealed exuberance tonight to the news that President Johnson had ordered a halt in the bombing of North Vietnam.

The promotion of Dr. Thomas D. Nicholson, assistant director of the American Museum of Natural History, to the new position of deputy director, was announced yesterday.

WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Prince Philip arrived here by plane today on his way to Recife, where he will join his wife, Queen Elizabeth II, tomorrow for her state visits to Brazil and Chile.

The return of Herbert von Karajan's "Die Walkure" to the Metropolitan Opera stage last night offers one another chance to learn to live with this highly individualistic conception. The elements familiar from the production's first season were again evident, perhaps the most characteristic one being the conductor's emphasis on suavity and grace in an opera more usually marked by crunching power, massive sonorities and vocal outbursts bordering on dementia.

WALTHAM, Mass., Oct. 31 -- The sculpture of David von Schlegell has a short history. The earliest work, in wood and metal combinations, dates from 1962. The constructions in polished aluminum, which have brought the artist his current reputation, date from 1964-65.

Mrs. Andrew Goodman, who took up painting seriously only four year ago, has scheduled the second benefit exhibition and sale of her works at her penthouse apartment, 2 West 58th Street, for Wednesday. She works in oils and specializes in flowers.

The big merger trend among the nation's major corporations accelerated yesterday with the proposed acquisition of the Sinclair Oil Corporation by the Atlantic Richfield Company for stock valued in excess of $1.6-billion. The merger, if completed, would be one of the largest in history.

ALBANY, Oct. 31 (UPI) -- Governor Rockefeller today appointed Supreme Court Justice J. Irwin Shapiro of Far Rockaway to the temporary state commission to study transplantation of vital organs of human beings.

LOS ANGELES, Oct. 31 (AP) -- Lamar Lundy must undergo knee surgery tomorrow and will be lost to the Los Angeles Rams for the remainder of the National Football League season.

LONDON, Oct. 31 -- Aristotle S. Onassis and Maria Callas won a long legal struggle today against a former friend over the opera singer's control of a $3 million freighter.

The American Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was informing members that its new commission rate structure would be become effective Dec. 5.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Twenty members of Women Strike for Peace held an antiwar demonstration in front of the White House today, but the Park Police dispersed the group because it did not have a permit. The Baltimore Bullets, unexpectedly leading the National Basketball Association, showed the New York Knickerbockers and a crowd of 11,542 at Madison Square Garden last night why they are. ABIQUIU, N. M. -- Georgia O'Keeffe, who decided when she was young to paint, dress and live as she chose, is still living happily ever after in that manner, as she approaches her 81st birthday on Nov. 15.

Agnew of Maryland, the Republican nominee for Vice President, who criticized The New York Times in a statement this week for printing "distorted," "inaccurate" and allegedly "libelous" editorial comments about his fitness as a candidate, raised three substantial objections to the editorials.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Nov. 1 -- Richard M. Nixon chose the home state of Lyndon B. Johnson to restate tonight in harsher language his charge of a week ago that the President had permitted "a security gap" to develop in the nation's military strength relative to that of the Soviet Union.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 -- Gen. Curtis E. LeMay has been dropped as board chairman of an electronics company because of his Vice-Presidential candidacy with the American Independent party, the company's president said today. The job paid $50,000 a year.

Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania, demanded yesterday that Democratic national campaign chairman, Lawrence J. O'Brien, explain a reported $100,000 contribution to his party by the Seafarer's International Union after the State Department refused to extradite Harold C. Banks, union executive.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- Crash programs to help Jews fleeing from Czechoslovakia and Poland are seriously depleting the funds of the American Joint Distribution Committee, an official of the Jewish welfare agency said today.

COMMACK, L. I., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Les Hunter dropped in a free throw with 13 seconds to play, sending the Miami Floridians to a 111-110 American Basketball Association victory over the New York Nets tonight.
Red Foley of the Daily News was elected chairman of the New York chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday.
"The David Show" closed Thursday night after its premiere at the Players Theater. A. R. Gurney Jr. wrote the comedy, which was produced by Donald H. Goldman at an estimated cost of $15,000.

HAGIOLOGY, love and sacrifice provided the subject matter for Martha Graham's triple bill at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last night, where the Graham Company offered "Seraphic Dialogue," "Diversion of Angels" and "Alcestis."
Liquor distributors in the metropolitan area were struck yesterday by their unionized salesmen, cutting off liquor deliveries to retail outlets and bars.
The promotion of Dr. Thomas D. Nicholson, assistant director of the American Museum of Natural History, to the new position of deputy director was announced yesterday.

The only United States Embassy in the United States is 42 stories up, in the Waldorf Towers, far from paint throwers and pickets. It is the official residence of the United States representative at the United Nations, Suite 42-A of the Towers.

The concert by the baritone Geraint Evans and the Chamber Symphony of Philadelphia, the third in the series of "Three in November" at Hunter College Assembly Hall, has been canceled. The concert was originally scheduled for Nov. 29 put erroneously announced for Nov. 8.

The Fordham cross-country team defeated Brown, 15-47, yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park. Terry McKoy of the Rams led five teammates across the finish line with a winning time of 26 minutes 39 seconds for the five-mile course.
Rabbi Henry Enoch Kagan is concerned about what he calls the drift of Jews away from the synagogue, the breakdown in Jewish family life and the high incidence of Jewish neurotics in mental hospitals.

New York University's center for black students, which has been involved in controversy since the hiring and subsequent dismissal of its director, is to be operated next year by an independent board of black students and faculty members.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 1 -- Mrs. Justus Laube of Knickerbocker was elected president of the Women's New Jersey Golf Association at its annual meeting today at the Montclair Golf Club.

HONG KONG, Nov. 1 -- At an unheralded plenary session in Peking, the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party formally expelled Liu Shao-chi, the country's disgraced head of state, from the party and from all party and other posts, Communist China announced today.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 1 (Reuters)) -- Judy Heldman of the United States beat Maria Christina Fernandez of Argentina, 6-1, 8-6, today in the first round of the South American open tennis championship.
Dr. Fager, the redoubtable 4-year-old colt owned by the Tartan Stable, will seek to cross the million-dollar threshold today when he makes the final competitive appearance of his career.
AS the number of inexperienced art collectors rises in this country, we are told, so does the percentage of art fakes. How can the former avoid getting lumbered with the latter?
The Uniformed Sanitation-men's Association and the city signed a new two-year contract yesterday that provides across-the-board pay increases of $800.

Mrs. Grace Mora Newman, 41 years old, Puerto Rican and mother of four children, is the Peace and Freedom Party candidate in the 22d Congressional District in the Bronx. Through an inadvertance, her candidacy was not included in Thursday's story dealing with the race in the district.

CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- At first, great excitement and hope. Then, a studied show of prudence. Finally, a calm assessment that no one really knows what the break in the Vietnam talks may mean to Hubert H. Humphrey's candidacy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Nov. 1 -- American warplanes bombed targets in North Vietnam today and then, in mid-evening, returned to their bases and carriers as President Johnson's order to halt the bombing went into effect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- Total construction expenditures edged up further in September to a record annual rate of $85.5-billion, the Commerce Department reported today.

THE Jets are favored to maintain their momentum toward their first divisional title tomorrow, but the Giants are underdogs. The Jets oppose the Buffalo Bills at Shea Stadium, while the Giants go against the Baltimore Colts at Yankee Stadium.
Kenny Burrell, the jazz guitarist, headed a lively variety program at Town Hall last night, presented by College Careers Program, an adjunct of the city's Human Resources Administration.

Scores of leading football games will be given at the end of the WQXR 6 P.M. news broadcast and in other news reports. Please do not telephone The New York Times or WQXR for scores: the calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and the radio station.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent, daughter of President Johnson. will fly to Hawaii in three weeks for a vacation and reunion with her husband, who is an airman first class on duty in Vietnam.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Nov. 1 -- Penn State's football team will put its two-season undefeated string of 13 games and its No. 4 national ranking on the line against Army tomorrow in what appears to be the Nittany Lions' stiffest test so far.

SANTA ANA, Calif., Nov. 1 -- One of the absolute certainties of next Tuesday's election is that Orange County, Calif. -- Richard M. Nixon's birthplace -- will vote for him and most of the rest of the Republican ticket.
MILWAUKEE, Nov. 1 (AP) -The Milwaukee Bucks of the National Basketball Association placed Bob Warlick and Jay Miller on waivers today, reducing the team's roster to 12.
Nine parents occupied a Greenwich Village school yesterday in an attempt to force the reopening of classes over the opposition of the school's regular teachers.
UNIONVILLE, Pa., Nov. 1 -With Haffaday on the sidelines with an injured leg, Dr. John Fisher's Landing Party ruled the favorite to win the Pennsylvania Hunt Cup here tomorrow.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 1 -- A student disciplinary committee at Princeton University, after 12 days of study, yesterday censured both black and white students involved in a racial incident last month.
Western Union announced yesterday a new rate structure for both interstate and intrastate telegram services.

NEW CASTLE, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Senator Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois, campaigning in Western Pennsylvania for Representative Richard S. Schweiker, said today if there had been a halt in the Vietnam bombing a year ago "we could have saved thousands of lives and billions of dollars."
LONDON, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -The average rate of discount at today's tender of British Treasury bills rose to 6.552 per cent from 6.492 per cent last week.
As the stubby, four-engined transport plane flew over the Hudson River yesterday, its passengers looked up at the city's buildings.

ISTANBUL, Turkey, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Fifteen persons were reported injured today in a brawl between some 500 left-wing and right-wing students in the garden of Istanbul University. The police said the fight had started when students gathered to sing the national anthem before classes.
BERLIN, Nov. 1 -- Dr. Gustav Heinemann, West Germany's Minister of Justice, was nominated today as the Social Democratic party's candidate for the office of President in the election next year.

WESTBURY, L. I., Nov. 1 -The second of two New York Sire Stakes events at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, this one a $50,000 one-mile test for 2-year-old pacing colts and geldings, was marred by a pile-up of three horses.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 1 -- A judge prohibited today lawyers and all public officials -- including Gov. Ronald Reagan of California and Mayor John Reading of Oakland -- from making any statements or comment about the case of Eldridge Cleaver and five other members of the Black Panther party accused of attempted murder and assault stemming from a shootout with the police.

TIMBUKTU, Mali -- Tourist brochures in West Africa gush about "mysterious Timbuktu." Worldly Africans in Bamako, the capital of Mali, are as eager to see Timbuktu as many New Yorkers are to see Niagara Falls.
MEMPHIS, Nov. 1 -- "We expected some sacrifice," General E. LeMay said to newsmen here this evening in discussing his loss of his job.
Richard Lewisohn, the city's Administrator of Economic Development asked yesterday for $58,161,367 in capital funds "so that we can identify and apply cures for the ills that plague the city."

The head of an organization representing major Jewish groups in the United States said yesterday that its members were "heartened" by Vice President Humphrey's "assurances of concern and pledges of action" on the issues of peace in the Middle East, the security of Israel and other questions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- The General Assembly today elected five countries to serve on the Security Council for two-year terms, starting in January, to replace five members whose terms expire then.

The "spiritual patronage" of General George Washington, the Count de Rochambeau and the Marquis de Lafayette was invoked last night as inspiration for the Bal de l'Amitie at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
Directors of Twentieth Century - Fox Corporation have elected William Self as vice president in charge of television for the company, it was announced yesterday.

A spokesman for the Reynolds Metals Company in New York said that officials of the Reynolds International subsidiary were continuing discussions with Mr. Onassis about a possible alumina-aluminum facility but had "nothing further to report."
Tickets will go on sale at noon tomorrow for the 11th week of the Metropolitan Opera season. The schedule for the week follows:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- About 10 persons suffered minor tear gas effects this afternoon when two Negro teen-agers discharged a tear gas device at Wallace for President headquarters in the downtown area.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Nov. 1 (Agence France-Presse) -North Vietnamese sources who knew of the move tonight welcomed the bombing halt and said that the participation of the National Liberation Front in the Paris talks was a "smarting defeat for the U. S. and a victory of the Vietnamese people in their struggle against aggression."
The New England Refining Company, Inc., announced yes-barrel-a-day refinery at a cost of $97-million in the proposed foreign trade sub-zone at Machiasport, Me.
"Beclch," previously announced to open Oct. 15, will open Dec. 16 at Tambellini's Gate Theater, 162 Second Avenue.

With the season just beyond the halfway mark bowl talk and conference championships loom larger in the total picture of college football. Southern California, ranked No. 1, returns after a week off to lead the top ten teams in action against squads rated lower or not at all.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 1 -- Israelis reflected pride and uneasiness today as they awaited Cairo's reaction to the Israeli commando raid last night in the heart of the United Arab Republic.
LAGOS, Nigeria, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Nigerian Army headquarters today reported heavy fighting on all fronts against rebel Biafran troops in the 16-month-old civil war.
Tickets for the musical "Dear World" will be on sale from 8 A.M. to midnight on Monday and Tuesday at the Mark Hellinger Theater.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- Elmo Roper, public opinion analyst, said here today that the halt of American bombing of North Vietnam had come too late t have an appreciable effect on the Presidential election.
PARIS, Nov. 1 -- The North Vietnamese issued a statement here this afternoon indicating their agreement to broadened Vietnam talks including the South Vietnamese Government as a participant.

The Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company announced yesterday that it had adopted the straight-line method of accounting depreciation, and revised its third-quarter earnings figures. The change, which has been made by most major steel producers, restates third-quarter profits at $4,451,000, or 42 cents a share, against the originally reported $2,581,000, or 24 cents a share.
CHICAGO, Nov. 1 -- A crowd of 10,000 waved hats, signs and arms and roared for 20 minutes without stopping tonight when George C. Wallace walked into the International Ampitheatre.
LISBON, Nov. 1 -- The Portuguese are taking to the current liberalization of the press eagerly but warily as to a heady new wine.
The nation's four leading auto makers announced yesterday a rise in car production levels in October.

Peace talk may be wonderful but yesterday it had little influence on commodity futures trading. In commodities like silver, the bombing halt had already been discounted, while in the cases of other commodities such as world sugar the contracts moved at their own paces for other reasons.

BOSTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Boston Celtics, with John Havlicek and Sam Jones showing the way, outscored the Philadelphia 76ers at a two-to-one clip in the second period tonight and went on to a 118-99 National Basketball Association victory.

Fifty Columbia University employes and several union organizers staged a sit-in at Low Memorial Library last night to demand an election to choose a bargaining agent for clerical workers in five university orfices.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Lamar Lundy, a defensive end and one of the Los Angeles Rams' Fearsome Foursome, underwent knee surgery today and the doctor said Lundy should be able to walk in a day in a cast.

Sales of the S. S. Kresge Company rose 23 8/10 per cent during the four weeks ended Oct. 26 to $125,619,722 from $101,503,141 in the year-ago month. The Detroit-based retail chain had a sales gain of 25 8/10 per cent in the 34 weeks ended Oct. 26, with volume totaling $1,127,356,282, compared with $895,963,551 in the preceding year.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Hartford Knights, led by Mel Meeks's three touchdowns, all but nailed down the Atlantic Coast Football League's Northern Division title tonight with a 37-7 triumph over the Bridgeport Jets.

GENEVA, Nov. 1 -- An official of the World Health Organization said here today that the new wave of Asian influenza has spread rapidly but had caused very few deaths since the virus that causes it was first identified in Hong Kong last July.

The Liberty Corporation, the holding company that controls the $238-million Liberty Life Insurance Company, has agreed in principle to merge with the South Carolina National Bank, the largest bank in that state, with assets of more than $500-million.
HANOVER, Pa., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Hanover Sun advised its 28,500 readers in tonight's editions that Mr. Nixon "is the soundest choice for President" among those seeking the office.

A group of Jewish teachers have formed an organization to combat what they say is apparently a general belief that all Jewish teachers oppose community control of school and consider Negro parents who favor it "gangsters."

THE accessories that designers show with their clothes can be more revealing than the clothes themselves. Last year it was fancy stockings, matched to shoes or dresses. Now that short skirts are no longer news, the designers who are showing their spring collections on Seventh Avenue have clad their models' legs in nude, sheer nylons, and embellished their costumes with scarves, chains, gardenias and platform shoes.

MOSCOW, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- Red Star, the Soviet Defense Ministry newspaper, today accused the Czechoslovak press of having lied about the actions of Soviet troops and what it termed anti-Socialist forces in the occupied country.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 1 -- The undefeated United States Merchant Marine Academy steps up the caliber of its opposition tomorrow night when it meets Hofstra University on the Hempstead school's AstroTurf gridiron before a sellout crowd of 7,000.

Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., decided yesterday to make a fight of it for control of the Sinclair Oil Corporation by formally approving a previously proposed tender offer for the petroleum company.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced yesterday that his staff would be alert for voting irregularities next Tuesday from 6 A.M. until all the votes are counted. A special telephone number -- RE 2-7311 -- has been set up to receive calls from voters who observe irregularities at the polling places, Mr. Hogan said.
Richard S. Salant, president of the Columbia Broadcasting System news department, yesterday strongly defended the integrity and ethics of Channel 13, the noncommercial station.

BUCKINGHAM PALACE. And Its Treasures. By John Harris, Geoffrey de Bellaigue and Oliver Millar. Photography by Lionel Pell, Kerry Dundas and Sidney Newbury. Introduction by John Russell. 320 pages. StudioViking. $25.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary prices for the dates shown:

Six descendants of William Brewster, the ruling elder of Plymouth Colony and one of the 25 signers of the Mayflower Compact, were among the 12 young women who bowed to society last night at the annual dinner dance and ball of the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York.
A plastic structure was inflated at the Metropolitan Museum of Art yesterday to provide a temporary shelter for 660 stones from the ancient Egyptian Temple of Dendur.

LONDON, Nov. 1 -- The Haymarket Theater production of Jean Anouilh's "Ring Round the Moon" follows "Look Back in Anger" as the second historic revival of the week. Just as John Osborne's play set the style for the last decade, so Peter Brook's postwar production of Anouilh's rococo fantasy burst on theatrical London like and expensive present marking the end of the age of austerity.

The spending in this year's political campaign is likely to set a record. But that is no surprise. Each Presidential campaign is the costliest ever. There is no ceiling in sight as political expenses continue to climb toward the stratosphere.

Unkempt youths, some who were long-haired and tieless, others who merely wore O'Dwyer or peace buttons -and even some neatly dressed ones -- were turned away from Thursday night's Nixon-Agnew rally at Madison Square Garden even though they had admission tickets.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Nov. 1 -The Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma, voiced satisfaction today over the United States decision to end the bombing of North Vietnam.
A Federal Court ruled unconstitutional yesterday a section of state law that requires voters on village propositions to be property owners.
TOKYO, Nov. 1 -- The Japanese Government announced today that it would buy the F-4E American Phantom jet fighter as the chief weapon for its air self-defense force.
MIAMI, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Miami Hurricanes, moving easily on the passes of David Olivo and the running of Vince Opalsky and Bobby Best, routed Pittsburgh, 48-0, tonight.

BOSTON -- Next to the el tracks high above Dudley Square in Boston's Roxbury ghetto, a billboard shows two clenched black fists defiantly snapping a chain that has bound them. In giant black letters the billboard proclaims, "UHURU!"
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Chief Justice Warren, at the dedication ceremony, praised Ramsey Clark as "a great Attorney General."
Mayor Lindsay called on the city's striking teachers yesterday to return to work and to submit the issues in the school dispute to binding arbitration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Navy said today it was questionable whether an effort would be made to retrieve pieces of the nuclear submarine Scorpion located yesterday two miles beneath the Atlantic about 400 miles south of the Azores.

Senator Jacob K. Javits yesterday applauded President Johnson's order halting the bombardment of North Vietnam and called on the Administration to step up its efforts toward international arms control.

In the spring of 1965, when the Republican leaders were looking for a candidate for Mayor, Representative Paul A. Fino, the Bronx leader, put up the name of Mario Biaggi, a much-decorated retired police lieutenant, as his choice.
Paul O'Dwyer, the Democratic candidate for the United States Senate, ended a long political holdout yesterday and endorsed Vice President Humphrey for President.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 1 (AP) -Roy Emerson defeated Rod Laver, 8-6, 6-4, last night as the Lima tournament of world tennis champions opened. Fred Stolle defeated Andres Gimeno of Spain, 2-6, 6-2, 6-3. Mrs. Ann Haydon Jones and Gimeno
PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Donna Capone and Mrs. Kathy Cornelius shot firstround 72's today to share the lead in the $22,000 Canyon women's golf classic at the Canyon Country Club.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 1 (AP) -- About 4,800 production and maintenance workers returned to their jobs today, after a week's strike at four local plants of the Libbey-OwensFord Company. They are members of the United Glass and Ceramic Workers of America.
BHUBANESWAR, India, Nov. 1 (Reuters) -- At least 35 persons were killed by a cyclone in coastal districts in Orissa State, official reports said today.

BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Nov. 1 (AP) -- A 20-year-old Mexican, accused of forcing an airline pilot to fly from Tampico, Mexico, to Brownsville, was handed over to the Mexican authorities yesterday. Juan Zurita of Vera Cruz was released from jail here after withdrawing an application to enter the United States.
The majority leader of the State Senate predicted yesterday that no strong school decentralization plan could get through the 1969 Legislature.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Nov. 1 (Reuters)Pakistan said today that her representatives had reached agreement with India on a procedure to draw the 300-mile border between the two countries in the disputed Rann of Kutch.

THE biggest news at City Center last night was the D'Oyly Carte Opera Company's announcement that instead of doing "Pirates of Penzance" on Nov. 17, it will offer, for the first time in America, a program called "???."
LONDON, Nov. 1 -- Hereditary peers, who for six centuries have shared the legislative power in Britain, would lose that role under a reform proposed today.
PRAGUE, Nov. 1 -- "Not true," said the young editor. "Not true," said the Prague factory worker. "Not true," said the economist. "Not true," said the army lieutenant colonel.
DALLAS -- Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Dallas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Association released Jim Ware, a 5-foot-7inch forward, on waivers today.
The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said yesterday that it had increased prices of aircraft tires 4 1/2 per cent and aircraft tubes 7 per cent, effective February, 1969.
Everyone agrees that the country is swinging right: that the American people are more conservative in 1968 than they were in 1964 and that they will probably be more conservative still in 1972.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 1 (AP) -- Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said today that a political movement outside the two-party system might be necessary to accomplish reforms in the United States political structure.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 1 (AP) -Max Conrad took off in a private airplane today to fly around the world by way of the North and South Poles.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 (AP) -- Officials at Walter Reed Army Hospital said today that no date had been set for former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's departure.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 -- The United States intends to triple the level of bombing along the Ho Chi Minh Trail in Laos in an effort to compensate for the effects of the cessa tion of air strikes against North Vietnam, high Administration officials disclosed today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 1 -- Eddie Kantar and Robert Hamman of Los Angeles regained their lead in the International Team Trials here this afternoon by beating Gerald Caravelli and Milton Rosenberg of Chicago, 52-32.

Mayor Lindsay paid an unscheduled visit yesterday to a Jewish religious school in Brooklyn that had been firebombed Thursday night and ordered the police to give top priority to the investigation of the incident.
ATHENS, Nov. 1 -- A long, silent line of Greeks today filed past the body of former Premier George Papandreou, kissed the icon resting on his flowered, open coffin, and made the sign of the cross.

KEY WEST, Fla., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Don Pruett of Miami, recovered from a boat explosion and serious burns three weeks ago, blasted over the finish line first today to win the Miami-Key West powerboat race.

Henning A. Blomen, the Socialist Labor party candidate for President, said yesterday that his campaign had drawn "much greater sympathy" than four years ago because of "the recognition that the major parties don't have the answers."

COPENHAGEN, Denmark -Taxidrivers and tourist guides in Copenhagen like to say, "When people drink Carlsberg, they are helping arts and science. When they drink Tuborg, they are helping industry and commerce.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 31 (Reuters) -- Indonesia has completed negotiations with the Aluminum Company of America over a bauxite mining project, which has been under discussion for the last year.
ROCHESTER, Nov. 1 -- James L. Buckley, the Conservative candidate for the United States Senate, made some converts among a raisin-cookie-eating group of young women in a suburban home today.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., NOV. 1 -- Gov. Spiro T. Agnew of Maryland set a leisurely pace and adopted a cautious style today as he began his final campaign swing across the country.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 1 -Harvard turned back Princeton and Yale in a triangular crosscountry meet today, taking five of the first 10 places. The Crimson defeated Princeton, 22 to 37, and Yale, 21 to 40. Princeton beat Yale, 28-29, for second place.
A membership on the New York Stock Exchange was sold yesterday at $485,000, down $15,000 from the previous transaction. Memberships currently are quoted at $350,000 bid, $500,000 asked.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 1 -- The United States called upon the Security Council tonight to strengthen United Nations machinery for maintaining the cease-fire in the Middle East and thus prevent further fighting between Israel and the Arab nations.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 97.2 on Thursday from 97.1 on Wednesday.

MIAMI, Nov. 1 (AP) -- The era of wooden-deck ocean liners in America steams away today on the last voyage of the Bahama Star -- a delayed victim of the blaze that sank the Yarmouth Castle, killing 90 passengers, on Nov. 13, 1965.

It is not often that a comprimario singer gets propelled into a title role, but that's what happened last night at the State Theater when Norman Treigle fell ill and Michael Devlin found himself singing the central part in Handel's "Julius Caesar."
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Nov. 1 -- Prime Minister Keith J. Holyoake today described the bombing halt as "a generous and far-sighted initiative which opens the way to a speedy end to the war."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Nov. 1 (AP) -- The Arizona Republic quoted former Senator Barry Goldwater tonight as having said he had been amused to see newsmen kicked and beaten at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., Nov. 1 (UPI) -- Suffolk County Attorney George Perry, a Democrat, today announced "with some sadness" that he intended to enroll as a Republican and vote a straight Republican ticket Tuesday.

LONDON, Nov. 1 (UPI) -- The Rev. Paul Weir, a priest suspended from his duties for having refused to accept Pope Paul's encyclical reaffirming the ban against artificial means of birth control, has been given the position of non-preaching curate, the Most Rev. Cyril Conrad Cowderoy, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Southwark, announced today.
PORTLAND, Me., Nov. 2 -- Senator Edmund S. Muskie returned to home soil today almost optimistic about the elections.
CLARK, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Seeking its best won-lost record in football. Clark defeated North Plainfield, 14-7, today. Clark, which has a 5-1 record, never has won more than seven games in a season.
HAUPAUGE, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Brad Rock passed for one touchdown and scored another as Hauppauge defeated Copiague, 20-6, today.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 2 -- Dickinson scored three times in the first seven minutes of the second quarter and went on to defeat Marist, 34-0 today. The triumph earned Dickinson's record at 3-3 and the loss was the fourth straight for Marist.
The 75 Columbia University employes who had staged a sit-in at the university president's office left during the night, a Columbia spokesman said yesterday.
TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Alabama combined the running of Pete Moore and Pete Jilleba with a tough defense to defeat Mississippi State, 20-13, before a crowd of 58,084 today.
SUMMIT, N. J., Nov. 2 -- Turning a recovered fumble into a touchdown drive. Summit beat Millburn, 7-0, today to remain the only unbeaten team in the Suburban Conference.

HOMEOWNERS and apartment dwellers who have always desired the warm look, textured feeling and maintenance-free durability of real brick can now create the same effect on almost any wall without having to put in a special supporting foundation and without need of special skills or tools.

LISBON, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- A team of 14 leading Portuguese doctors was engaged today in a desperate battle to save the life of former Premier Antonio De Oliveira Salazar. Forty-eight hours after he suffered a major relapse, the condition of D. Salazar, who is 79, was described as "grave." His breathing is being assisted by a respirator.
THE veteran Argentine grandmaster, Oscar Panno, won first prize in the recent Buenos Aires Master Tournament when he scored nine points out of a possible 11 in this strong 12-man round robin.
IRVINGTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 2 -- Once-beaten Byram Hills won its fifth game of the season today, a 19-0 triumph over Irvington.
Joe Stanton has been named Herbert H. Lehman College's freshman and assistant varsity basketball coach.

WAYNE, N. J., Nov. 2 -- An alert defense, which intercepted two passes and recovered three fumbles, helped Wayne Valley to its 22d straight victory today, 28-7, over Paramus in a televised football game. Wayne has won six games this season.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Mineola posted its 15th straight victory today, 35-13, over Great Neck North, and moved a step closer to its Nov. 16 meeting with Port Washington, its undefeated North Shore Division 2 rival.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 2 (AP) -- Bruce Lee passed for 201 yards, scored one touchdown and set up two others today as Arizona defeated Washington State, 28-14.

CHICAGO, Nov. 2 -- There were din and ballyhoo aplenty in the cheers and band and balloons and floats of the traditional, campaign-ending parade and rally staged last night by the Cook County Democratic organization.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Nov. 2 (UPI) -- Bobby Douglass threw two touchdown passes to Junior Riggins to lead third-ranked Kansas to a 27-14 victory over Colorado today in a steady, fumble-forcing rain. Scouts from four major post season bowls watched the game.
NORTH MERRICK, L. I., Nov. 2 -- Kennedy Bellmore, after running up an 18-0 lead, defeated Calhoun, 24-13, for its fifth straight victory today.

CAPE KENNEDY, Nov. 2 (UPI) -- The United States plans to put a spacecraft into orbit around the sun on Wednesday to help scientists devise an interplanetary weather map charting radiation from solar storms.

FORT HOOD, Tex., Nov. 2 (AP) -- An Army court-martial gave today harsh sentences to three soldiers convicted of charges of refusal to obey an order shortly before the Democratic National Convention in Chicago.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, was engaged in secret conversations yesterday in an effort to close the gap between the disputants in the citywide teachers' strike.
Prof. Allan Nevins, the historian, will receive the 1968 Alexander Hamilton Medal from the Association of the Alumni of Columbia College.
